translation: For those who are underweight and weak, aging, as well as those seeking prosperity, complexion, and strength, and for women whose menstrual cycles are impaired by some disorder, [he] knows the causes and remedies. (76)

sloka: garbhārthinīnāṃ garbhaśca sravedyāsāṃ mriyeta vā| dhanyā balyā hitāstābhyaḥ śukraśoṇitavardhanāḥ||77|| iti pañcamasarpirmodakāḥ|
translation: For the pregnant women and the embryo, one should listen to the teachings that foster growth. Let them thrive and be nourished. These are indeed beneficial to them. This is the fifth set of instructions, pertaining to the churning of the ocean.

sloka: bastideśe vikurvāṇe strīprasaktasya mārute| vātaghnān bṛṃhaṇān vṛṣyān yogāṃstasya prayojayet||78||
translation: In a location where the wind is stirring, for a man who is attached to women, he should cause the application of remedies to increase his strength and virility.

sloka: śarkarāpippalīcūrṇaiḥ sarpiṣā mākṣikeṇa ca| saṃyuktaṃ vā śṛtaṃ kṣīraṃ pibet kāsajvarāpaham||79||
translation: One should drink milk, mixed with sugar, powdered long pepper, and ghee, optionally boiled together, as a remedy for Kasa-jvara.

sloka: phalāmlaṃ sarpiṣā bhṛṣṭaṃ vidārīkṣurase śṛtam| strīṣu kṣīṇaḥ pibedyūṣaṃ jīvanaṃ bṛṃhaṇaṃ param||80||
translation: Consumed by ghee, the bitter tamarind is made suitable to be mixed into the sugarcane juice. Deprived of strength, it is drunk by women for life-sustenance and growth enhancement.

sloka: saktūnāṃ vastrapūtānāṃ manthaṃ kṣaudraghṛtānvitam| yavānnasātmyo dīptāgniḥ kṣatakṣīṇaḥ pibennaraḥ||81||
translation: The rice cooker's Agni, named Ksata-ksiina, consumes the churning of saktu grains, previously mixed with ghee and water, now reduced to small portions. It burns brightly, being well-established in the rice-cooking vessel.

sloka: jīvanīyopasiddhaṃ vā jāṅgalaṃ ghṛtabharjitam| rasaṃ prayojayet kṣīṇe vyañjanārthaṃ saśarkaram||82||
translation: Upon exhaustion of the essence, you all should cause the untreated fuel in the form of dry leaves, etc., to be applied with ghee, either refined or not, for the purpose of producing smoky signals.

sloka: gomahiṣyaśvanāgājaiḥ kṣīrairmāṃsarasaistathā| yavānnaṃ bhojayedyūṣaiḥ phalāmlairghṛtasaṃskṛtaiḥ||83||
translation: Using cow's milk, mixed with the ghee from mares and elephants, as well as meat soups and rice cooked with yava, one should offer sustenance to worthy guests, dishes that are completed with fruits and ghee that has been clarified.

sloka: dīpte'gnau vidhireṣaḥ syānmande dīpanapācanaḥ| yakṣmiṇāṃ vihito grāhī bhinne śakṛti ceṣyate||84||
translation: When a fire is burning, this is the prescribed rule: the one who initiates kindling (the fire) is referred to as an eliminator of darkness, and they will assume a distinctive form/role (while performing this action).

sloka: palikaṃ saindhavaṃ śuṇṭhī dve ca sauvarcalāt pale| kuḍavāṃśāni vṛkṣāmlaṃ dāḍimaṃ patramarjakāt||85|| ekaikaṃ maricājājyordhānyakāddve caturthike| śarkarāyāḥ palānyatra daśa dve ca pradāpayet||86||
translation: Prepare in a dish one quantity each of salt, black pepper, dried ginger, two measures of turmeric powder, and pieces of belva, amla, belleric, and haritaki; add to this the juice of one freshly grated ginger, one measure of juice from crushed garlic, and one quarter the amount of sugar; add ten measures of water elsewhere.

sloka: kṛtvā cūrṇamato mātrāmannapāne prayojayet| rocanaṃ dīpanaṃ balyaṃ pārśvārtiśvāsakāsanut||87|| iti saindhavādicūrṇam|
translation: After preparing the powdered form of Saindhava and other ingredients , one should administer the measured quantity of it in drinking water . This enhances color , illumination , and strength , as well as alleviates side pains, coughs, and other bodily ailments . This is known as the use of Saindhava salt powder .

sloka: ekā ṣoḍaśikā dhānyāddve dve'jājyajamodayoḥ| tābhyāṃ dāḍimavṛkṣāmlaṃ dvirdviḥ sauvarcalātpalam||88|| śuṇṭhyāḥ karṣaṃ dadhitthasya madhyāt pañca palāni ca| taccūrṇaṃ ṣoḍaśapale śarkarāyā vimiśrayet||89||
translation: Among the sixteen types of grains, take one; from sesame and sugarcane, take two each; from ajaji and modaka, take one each; along with dāḍima from the vṛkṣa āmla tree, and twice the sauvarcalātpala. In the middle of these and five more from shuṇṭhi, after grinding all this into sixteen parts, it should be mixed with unrefined sugar.

sloka: ṣāḍavo'yaṃ pradeyaḥ syādannapāneṣu pūrvavat| mandānale śakṛdbhede yakṣmiṇāmagnivardhanaḥ||90|| iti ṣāḍavaḥ|
translation: This Ṣāḍava should be offered as a sacrificial gift, not in food or drinks as before. Its presence in a small fire enhances the heat, affecting Yakṣmiṇām (disease-causing demons).

sloka: pibennāgabalāmūlamardhakarṣavivardhitam[ | palaṃ kṣīrayutaṃ māsaṃ kṣīravṛttiranannabhuk||91||
translation: Drink deeply from the base of the fully grown and abundantly nourished banyan tree, which has been fed by a thousand palas, for a month of sustenance on milk alone. (Verse 91, Shloka 85, Shukla Yajurveda)

sloka: eṣa prayogaḥ puṣṭyāyurbalārogyakaraḥ paraḥ| maṇḍūkaparṇyāḥ kalpo'yaṃ śuṇṭhīmadhukayostathā||92||
translation: This practice, referred to as "Mandooka Parneya's doctrine," is supremely effective in promoting strength, longevity, and health. It is also known as "Shunthi" and "Madhuka."

sloka: yadyat santarpaṇaṃ śītamavidāhi hitaṃ laghu| annapānaṃ niṣevyaṃ tatkṣatakṣīṇaiḥ sukhārthibhiḥ||93|| yaccoktaṃ yakṣmiṇāṃ pathyaṃ kāsināṃ raktapittinām| tacca kuryādavekṣyāgniṃ vyādhiṃ sātmyaṃ balaṃ tathā||94||
translation: Whatever is found to be coolingly soothing and beneficial, easily ingested and promoting well-being, should be consumed as food and drink by those seeking their own welfare. Furthermore, one should perform (kuryāt) what is prescribed as a remedy for those suffering from consumption disorders by the red-hued Kāsin ascetics, after carefully examining oneself, the fire (digestive power), disease, and strength.

sloka: upekṣite bhavettasminnanubandho hi yakṣmaṇaḥ| prāgevāgamanāttasya tasmāttaṃ tvarayā jayet||95||
translation: Neglect of the early onset of consumption in this [ particular case] should be avoided, for its bond becomes firmly established then. Therefore, it should be overcome without delay.

sloka: tatra ślokau kṣatakṣayasamutthānaṃ sāmānyapṛthagākṛtim| asādhyayāpyasādhyatvaṃ sādhyānāṃ siddhimeva ca||96|| uktavāñjyeṣṭhaśiṣyāya kṣatakṣīṇacikitsite| tattvārthavidvītarajastamodoṣaḥ[1] punarvasuḥ||97||
translation: In that , two verses describe the emergence of a weakness and the difference between the general and specific ; as well as the irreproachability and accomplishment of teachings for the supreme disciple who is skilled in eliminating debilitating afflictions .

sloka: ityagniveśakṛte tantre'prāpte dṛḍhabalapūrite cikitsitasthāne kṣatakṣīṇacikitsitaṃ nāmaikādaśo'dhyāyaḥ||11||
translation: "This is the eleventh chapter, titled 'Kshatakshina Cikitsita,' found in the dual-accusative scripture 'Agniveśa,' describing robustly effective cures that have been powerfully established."

sloka: athāto gulmacikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: Now, we shall explain the method for treating gulma (a type of digestive ailment). Thus declared Bhagavan Atreya.

sloka: sarvaprajānāṃ pitṛvaccharaṇyaḥ punarvasurbhūtabhaviṣyadīśaḥ|  cikitsitaṃ gulmanibarhaṇārthaṃ provāca siddhaṃ vadatāṃ variṣṭhaḥ||3||
translation: The eternal lord and eternal resort for all beings, having considered the desired remedy for the growth/tumor, the most excellent among those who have accomplished success, spoke what was to be done/established as the remedy for the affliction.

sloka: viṭśleṣmapittātiparisravādvā taireva vṛddhaiḥ paripīḍanādvā|  vegairudīrṇairvihatairadho vā bāhyabhighātairatipīḍanairvā||4||  rūkṣānnapānairatisevitairvā śokena mithyāpratikarmaṇā vā|  viceṣṭitairvā viṣamātimātraiḥ koṣṭhe prakopaṃ samupaiti vāyuḥ||5||
translation: The wind arises in the body due to violent expulsion of phlegm and bile by the elderly, or due to blows from external causes, consumption of rough food in excess, unwholesome eating, or wrong actions, irregular exertion, or even due to grief.

sloka: kaphaṃ ca pittaṃ ca sa duṣṭavāyuruddhūya  mārgān vinibaddhya tābhyām|  hṛnnābhipārśvodarabastiśūlaṃ karotyatho yāti na baddhamārgaḥ||6||
translation: Even though one, identified as the doer, binds and eliminates, in a proper manner, the corrupting influences of both phlegm (kapha) and bile (pitta), while being impelled by a disturbed wind, if they still deviate from the correct path through that very elimination process, they are not on the right path.

sloka: pakvāśaye pittakaphāśaye vā sthitaḥ svatantraḥ parasaṃśrayo vā|  sparśopalabhyaḥ paripiṇḍitatvādgulmo yathādoṣamupaiti nāma||7||
translation: Residing in a place that is either fully digested food or phlegm, being self-reliant or seeking support from others, similar to how a lump forms due to tangible perception and becomes known by that name.

sloka: bastau ca nā bhyāṃ hṛdi pārśvayorvā sthānāni gulmasya bhavanti pañca| pañcātmakasya prabhavaṃ tu tasya vakṣyāmi liṅgāni cikitsitaṃ ca||8||
translation: In the stomach, but not in the exterior regions, the five sites of the rice indeed exist; I will describe the symptoms and treatment of its fivefold manifestation.

sloka: rūkṣānnapānaṃ viṣamātimātraṃ viceṣṭitaṃ vegavinigrahaśca|  śoko'bhighāto'timalakṣayaśca nirannatā cānilagulmahetuḥ||9||
translation: Consuming rough food, excessive eating, and acting in haste, as well as enduring the harmful consequences of wind and indigestion, are all indeed detrimental; the latter is characterized by the complete elimination of waste matter.

sloka: yaḥ sthānasaṃsthānarujāṃ vikalpaṃ viḍvātasaṅgaṃ galavaktraśoṣam|  śyāvāruṇatvaṃ śiśirajvaraṃ ca hṛtkukṣipārśvāṃsaśirorujaṃ ca||10||  karoti jīrṇe'bhyadhikaṃ prakopaṃ bhukte mṛdutvaṃ samupaiti yaśca|  vātāt sa gulmo na ca tatra rūkṣaṃ kaṣāyatiktaṃ kaṭu copaśete||11||
translation: The one who, comprehending the distinction between firmness and instability, overcomes phlegm-induced afflictions, possesses a dark, yet shimmering complexion like a rain-cloud, and a coolness akin to winter; whose body parts remain unfatigued even in old age, becoming even more tranquil upon consuming food; who tames excess wind, bile, and their accompanying roughness, discoloration, and bitterness – such an individual is indeed hard to come by.

sloka: kaṭvamlatīkṣṇoṣṇavidāhirūkṣakrodhātimadyārkahutāśasevā|  āmābhighāto  rudhiraṃ ca duṣṭaṃ paittasya gulmasya nimittamuktam||12||
translation: The missile, made sour, pungent, and scorching due to excessive exposure to the sun, has caused the release of bloody discharge and impurities from the ulcerated body as a result of imbibing too much alcohol.

sloka: jvaraḥ pipāsā vadanāṅgarāgaḥ śūlaṃ mahajjīryati bhojane ca|  svedo vidāho vraṇavacca gulmaḥ sparśāsahaḥ paittikagulmarūpam||13||
translation: Fever, thirst, and bodily inflammation; a pointed stake that greatly corrodes during mealtime; sweating, burning, abscesses, intestinal tumors, unbearable touch - all taking on the form of bile.

sloka: śītaṃ guru snigdhamaceṣṭanaṃ ca sampūraṇaṃ prasvapanaṃ divā ca|  gulmasya hetuḥ kaphasambhavasya sarvastu diṣṭo nicayātmakasya||14||
translation: The cooled (past passive participle), heavy, and unctuous entity is identified as the cause of digestion and daytime sleep as well. The collection of all things is favorably disposed towards the formation of phlegm, which arises from it.

sloka: staimityaśītajvaragātrasādahṛllāsakāsārucigauravāṇi|  śaityaṃ rugalpā kaṭhinonnatatvaṃ gulmasya rūpāṇi kaphātmakasya||15||
translation: The consistent coldness, mild fever sweats, and handsome appearance are symptoms of a person whose phlegm-predominant constitution has hard, elevated forms (in their body).

sloka: nimittaliṅgānyupalabhya gulme dvidoṣaje doṣabalābalaṃ ca|  vyāmiśraliṅgānaparāṃstu gulmāṃstrīnādiśedauṣadhakalpanārtham||16||
translation: Upon recognizing the distinguishing symptoms in a bloated condition caused by an imbalance of dual doshas, one should also take into account those atypical signs for planning remedies, especially for women and similar cases.

sloka: mahārujaṃ dāhaparītamaśmavadghanonnataṃ śīghravidāhi dāruṇam|  manaḥśarīrāgnibalāpahāriṇaṃ tridoṣajaṃ gulmamasādhyamādiśet||17||
translation: Prescribe the great Rujaman, an inflammable and extremely scorching entity like a heated stone, which swiftly consumes, has a harsh nature, and has the power to destroy both mental and physical strength. It can alleviate the three imbalances (Tridosha) and is hard to cure, such as gulma.

sloka: ṛtāvanāhāratayā bhayena virūkṣaṇairvegavinigrahaiśca|  saṃstambhanollekhanayonidoṣairgulmaḥ striyaṃ raktabhavo'bhyupaiti||18||
translation: Through the suppression of fear by a controlled and steady man, as well as the elimination of faults in standing, moving, and sitting, a tumor characterized by the expulsion of bloody fluid arises in women during menstruation.

sloka: yaḥ spandate piṇḍita eva nāṅgaiścirāt saśūlaḥ samagarbhaliṅgaḥ|  sa raudhiraḥ strībhava eva gulmo māse vyatīte daśame cikitsyaḥ||19||
translation: The one who constantly tremors, contained within a distinct physical form, lacking limbs for an extended period, having an underdeveloped embryonic state, and resembling a red tumor, will need to be medically treated in the final month of pregnancy.

sloka: kriyākramamataḥ siddhaṃ gulmināṃ gulmanāśanam|  pravakṣyāmyata ūrdhvaṃ ca yogān gulmanibarhaṇān||20||
translation: I will explain the sequential method that has been accomplished for destroying tumors within the body, as well as the higher yoga practices that help eradicate them.

sloka: rūkṣavyāyāmajaṃ gulmaṃ vātikaṃ tīvravedanam|  baddhaviṇmārutaṃ snehairāditaḥ samupācaret||21||
translation: Should one carefully tend to, using gentle means, a growth that is harsh, arising from exertion, akin to a wind-knob, and extremely painful, having bound it through affection? (21)

sloka: bhojanābhyañjanaiḥ pānairnirūhaiḥ sānuvāsanaiḥ|  snigdhasya bhiṣajā svedaḥ kartavyo gulmaśāntaye||22||
translation: The sweating induced by medicinal food, drinks, and other remedies should be performed for alleviating the abdominal lump; this is the duty of a skilled healer.

sloka: srotasāṃ mārdavaṃ kṛtvā jitvā mārutamulbaṇam|  bhittvā vibandhaṃ snigdhasya svedo gulmamapohati||23||
translation: By making the fluidity of the body's channels smooth and having conquered the wind-like movement, after breaking open the binding tension of what is lubricated, sweat, as the third-person singular present indicative active of apohati, removes dampness from the body.

sloka: snehapānaṃ hitaṃ gulme viśeṣeṇordhvanābhije|  pakvāśayagate bastirubhayaṃ jaṭharāśraye||24||
translation: The nourishment resulting from the gradual feeding of affection is highly beneficial for the gulma, both in the area of the upper navel and in the lower abdomen, which is situated in the region known as jarā (jaṭharāśraye). This is particularly true when it has become fully mature and settled (pakvāśaya-gata).

sloka: dīpte'gnau vātike gulme vibandhe'nilavarcasoḥ|  bṛṃhaṇānyannapānāni snigdhoṣṇāni prayojayet||25||
translation: In the fire blazing, in the air, in the cloud, and in the sun’s radiance, one should cause to apply warm, oily substances.

sloka: punaḥ punaḥ snehapānaṃ nirūhāḥ sānuvāsanāḥ|  prayojyā vātagulmeṣu kaphapittānurakṣiṇā||26||
translation: Again and again, apply unctuous substances, remove waste matter, apply ointments, and use fomentations as treatments on the southern side to protect against an excess of phlegm and bile.

sloka: kapho vāte jitaprāye pittaṃ śoṇitameva vā|  yadi kupyati vā tasya kriyamāṇe cikitsite||27||   yatholbaṇasya doṣasya tatra kāryaṃ bhiṣagjitam|  ādāvante ca madhye ca mārutaṃ parirakṣatā||28||
translation: If in most cases the air has been tamed, should one treat the disorder of wind and bile with that air, or should one treat it otherwise if it becomes aggravated during treatment? Similarly, for an excessively severe dosha, what should the disease conqueror do at the beginning, in the middle, and while protecting the wind?

sloka: vātagulme kapho vṛddho hatvā'gnimaruciṃ yadi|  hṛllāsaṃ gauravaṃ tandrāṃ janayedullikhettu tam||29||
translation: Upon cutting down in this location the ripe dust particles and the small particles, if one were to cause fear, shame, and drowsiness in oneself, then they would be the cause of such disturbances.

sloka: śūlānāhavibandheṣu gulme vātakapholbaṇe|  vartayo guṭikāścūrṇaṃ kaphavātaharaṃ hitam||30||
translation: In furrowed fields located in such a place, where there is a severe wind disorder accompanied by phlegm, it is beneficial to apply, in the form of a pill, the finely ground powder of śūlā herbs as a remedy.

sloka: pittaṃ vā yadi saṃvṛddhaṃ santāpaṃ vātagulminaḥ|  kuryādvirecyaḥ sa bhavet sasnehairānulomikaiḥ||31||
translation: If bile becomes excessively robust, causing discomfort in the stomach, then it should be treated by using substances that are both warm and unctuous.

sloka: gulmo yadyanilādīnāṃ kṛte samyagbhiṣagjite|  na praśāmyati raktasya so'vasekāt praśāmyati||32||
translation: If a tumor, among those associated with winds, is properly treated, it subsides from the blood without subsiding, should the healer treat it completely; such is the case.

sloka: snigdhoṣṇenodite gulme paittike sraṃsanaṃ hitam|  rūkṣoṣṇena tu sambhūte sarpiḥ praśamanaṃ param||33||
translation: Applying oil with warmth in summer and consuming ghee with warmth in winter is extremely beneficial, while employing rough techniques in a dry/cold state is the ultimate pacification.

sloka: pittaṃ vā pittagulmaṃ vā jñātvā pakvāśayasthitam|  kālavinnirharet sadyaḥ satiktaiḥ kṣīrabastibhiḥ||34||  payasā vā sukhoṣṇena satiktena virecayet|  bhiṣagagnibalāpekṣī sarpiṣā tailvakena vā||35||
translation: Having ascertained whether it is pitta or pittagulma, one should promptly eliminate it using ripe kshira and bastibhi when it has fully matured in the body. Alternatively, one can alleviate its effects by using warm and agreeable liquids such as sukhoṣṇena, or through medical treatment, bhiṣakagni-balāpekṣī, or by using clarified butter, sarpiṣā, and oil, tailvakena.

sloka: tṛṣṇājvaraparīdāhaśūlasvedāgnimārdave|  gulmināmarucau cāpi raktamevāvasecayet||36||
translation: You should cause rice and barley to be cooked in, or pour only reddish substances in cases of extreme thirst , fever , inflammation , colic , and sweating . This is referring to the digestive fire that cooks/affects the rice and barley .

sloka: chinnamūlā vidahyante na gulmā yānti ca kṣayam|  raktaṃ hi vyamlatāṃ yāti tacca nāsti na cāsti ruk||37||
translation: When roots are extracted, they do not regrow, nor do they decay; just as redness flows away and does not stay, so exists the arising and ceasing of existence.

sloka: hṛtadoṣaṃ parimlānaṃ jāṅgalaistarpitaṃ rasaiḥ|  samāśvastaṃ saśeṣārtiṃ sarpirabhyāsayet punaḥ||38||
translation: The serpent should once again cause to soothe the heart, tainted by a fault, completely pacified and rid of all concerns, having been nourished by the juices of jāṅgala plants, and now passively endured. (38)

sloka: raktapittātivṛddhatvāt kriyāmanupalabhya ca|  yadi gulmo vidahyeta śastraṃ tatra bhiṣagjitam||39||
translation: If an excessively aggravated inflammation and swelling in the spleen region are observed, once they have become markedly conspicuous, then medical treatment should be applied there.

sloka: guruḥ kaṭhinasaṃsthāno gūḍhamāṃsāntarāśrayaḥ|  avivarṇaḥ sthiraścaiva hyapakvo gulma ucyate||40||
translation: The strict and steadfast teacher, serving as the shelter for hidden knowledge, undeceptive, stable, and unripe is referred to as a gulma (young shoot).

sloka: dāhaśūlārtisaṅkṣobhasvapnanāśāratijvaraiḥ|  vidahyamānaṃ jānīyādgulmaṃ tamupanāhayet||41||
translation: One should recognize and actively seek to alleviate an internal inflammation, similar to a feverish affliction, caused by piercing pains, agitation, fainting, insomnia, and other distressing symptoms. (41)

sloka: vidāhalakṣaṇe gulme bahistuṅge samunnate|  śyāve saraktaparyante saṃsparśe bastisannibhe||42||    nipīḍitonnate stabdhe supte [4] tatpārśvapīḍanāt|  tatraiva piṇḍite śūle sampakvaṃ gulmamādiśet||43||
translation: In the case of a bloated abdomen, when there is distension in the outer region, and it resembles a ripe fruit; when, due to being touched, it becomes unsteady, immobile, and dormant, or when it causes discomfort to the adjacent areas – it is in such cases that an enema should be administered into that very location, starting with the intestines.

sloka: tatra dhānvantarīyāṇāmadhikāraḥ kriyāvidhau|  vaidyānāṃ kṛtayogyānāṃ vyadhaśodhanaropaṇe||44||
translation: In that context, authority in performing therapeutic actions, such as cleansing and purgation, belongs to those doctors who have been properly trained and are capable in such procedures.

sloka: antarbhāgasya cāpyetat pacyamānasya lakṣaṇam|  hṛtkroḍaśūnatā'ntaḥsthe [5] bahiḥsthe pārśvanirgatiḥ||45||
translation: Of the dispersed portion being cooked, this is the defining feature: an internal bubbling/foaming and rising of the heartwood's sap, and its emergence on the exterior.

sloka: pakvaḥ srotāṃsi saṅkledya vrajatyūrdhvamadho'pi vā|  svayampravṛttaṃ taṃ doṣamupekṣeta hitāśanaiḥ [6] ||46||   daśāhaṃ dvādaśāhaṃ vā rakṣan bhiṣagupadravān|
translation: As a doctor, either for ten or twelve days, I should attend to patients, whether they are getting better or worse, and disregard my own faults, being focused on what is conducive to their health.

sloka: ata ūrdhvaṃ hitaṃ pānaṃ sarpiṣaḥ saviśodhanam||47||  śuddhasya tiktaṃ sakṣaudraṃ prayoge sarpiriṣyate|48|
translation: Hence, by elevating themselves with the wholesome consumption of purified ghee, it becomes beneficial and mildly astringent in use for what has been purified.

sloka: śītalairgurubhiḥ snigdhairgulme jāte kaphātmake||48||  avamyasyālpakāyāgneḥ kuryāllaṅghanamāditaḥ|
translation: With cool and soothing breezes being its birthplace, one should carefully perform the expulsion of the phlegm-dominated dosha from this weakened body, using oleated agents.

sloka: mando'gnirvedanā mandā gurustimitakoṣṭhatā||49||   sotkleśā cāruciryasya sa gulmī vamanopagaḥ|
translation: The one who is lazy, has a weak digestive fire, and weak intellect, such a person is the companion of phlegm-related afflictions, for the fair-complexioned one who possesses grace.

sloka: uṣṇairevopacaryaśca kṛte vamanalaṅghane||50||  yojyaścāhārasaṃsargo bheṣajaiḥ kaṭutiktakaiḥ|
translation: In preparing food and drink, one should respectively use coolant medicines with uṣṇaiḥ (mild fever) and digestive medicines with kaṭu-tiktakaiḥ (pungent and astringent properties) after having undergone emesis, as prescribed.

sloka: sānāhaṃ savibandhaṃ ca gulmaṃ kaṭhinamunnatam||51||  dṛṣṭvā''dau svedayedyuktyā svinnaṃ ca vilayedbhiṣak|
translation: Upon seeing a thick and firmly swollen growth, the physician should promptly incise it, inducing sweating through appropriate words and methods.

sloka: laṅghanollekhane svede kṛte'gnau sampradhukṣite||52||   kaphagulmī pibet kāle sakṣārakaṭukaṃ ghṛtam|
translation: Upon performing the acts of licking and recording, when (it) is produced in sweat and offered in the sacred fire, one should, at the appropriate time, drink ghee mixed with a small amount of water and chebulic myrobalan.

sloka: sthānādapasṛtaṃ jñātvā kaphagulmaṃ virecanaiḥ||53||   sasnehairbastibhirvā'pi śodhayeddāśamūlikaiḥ|
translation: Having understood something dislodged from its proper position, one should cleanse it using expectorants and other liquids, as well as through the application of oils and various medicinal plants, such as those that help treat phlegm-related ailments.

sloka: mande'gnāvanile mūḍhe jñātvā sasnehamāśayam||54||    guṭikācūrṇaniryūhāḥ prayojyāḥ kaphagulminām|
translation: Even for someone who is foolish and in a state of weakness, it is appropriate to administer medicinal tablets, when one becomes aware of emotional vulnerability, to alleviate ailments caused by an excess of phlegm.

sloka: kṛtamūlaṃ mahāvāstuṃ kaṭhinaṃ stimitaṃ gurum||55|| jayetkaphakṛtaṃ gulmaṃ kṣārāriṣṭāgnikarmabhiḥ||
translation: A foundation that is firmly established through one's own efforts, formidable, made steady and heavy, can be conquered by someone who can neutralize phlegm-related ailments using fire-like actions.

sloka: doṣaprakṛtigulmartuyogaṃ buddhvā kapholbaṇe||56||   baladoṣapramāṇajñaḥ kṣāraṃ gulme prayojayet|    ekāntaraṃ dvyantaraṃ vā tryahaṃ viśramya vā punaḥ||57||    śarīrabaladoṣāṇāṃ vṛddhikṣapaṇakovidaḥ|
translation: Having comprehended the unfavorable combination of dosa, prakriti, and gulma in a specific season, a knowing person who is aware of the measure of their strength should apply kṣāra to it. After resting for a while, either once, twice, or thrice, one may repeat the treatment as needed. A specialist in balancing bodily humors should administer this treatment.

sloka: śleṣmāṇaṃ madhuraṃ snigdhaṃ māṃsakṣīraghṛtāśinaḥ||58||  chittvā chittvā''śayāt kṣāraḥ kṣaratvāta kṣārayatyadhaḥ|
translation: Having discarded, and then discarded again, the phlegm which is sweet, oily, found in meat-eaters and those consuming milk and ghee, this digestive agent (kshara) becomes thinner and causes thinning from below.

sloka: mande'gnāvarucau sātmye madye sasnehamaśnatām||59|| prayojyā mārgaśuddhyarthamariṣṭāḥ kaphagulminām||
translation: For those accustomed to moderately consuming food and drinks mixed with alcohol, pure digestive herbs should be consumed after meals to facilitate the purification of bodily humor pathways, as prescribed.

sloka: laṅghanollekhanaiḥ svedaiḥ sarpiḥpānairvirecanaiḥ||60||  bastibhirguṭikācūrṇakṣārāriṣṭagaṇairapi|       ślaiṣmikaḥ kṛtamūlatvādyasya gulmo na śāmyati||61||    tasya dāho hṛte rakte śaralohādibhirhitaḥ|
translation: The churned rice gruel and liquid preparations, administered along with sneezes and excretions, cannot alleviate the internal cold's clump in one whose cold has been previously treated by therapeutic interventions. For such an individual, their fever, kindled by components like blood and flesh, continues to rage, even when drained of these elements.

sloka: auṣṇyāttaikṣṇyācca śamayedagnirgulme kaphānilau||62||   tayoḥ śamācca saṅghāto gulmasya vinivartate|
translation: By mitigating excessive heat and cold, Agni (the digestive fire) within the body, composed of phlegm and wind, subsides; their equilibrium brings about this cessation.

sloka: dāhe dhānvantarīyāṇāmatrāpi bhiṣajāṃ balam||63||    kṣāraprayoge bhiṣajāṃ kṣāratantravidāṃ balam||
translation: Even in treating burns, a healer's strength resides not only in their medical knowledge but also in their mastery of applying therapeutic methods.

sloka: vyāmiśradoṣe vyāmiśra eṣa eva kriyākramaḥ||64||
translation: This very sequence of actions is tainted by a mixture of faults in itself.

sloka: siddhānataḥ pravakṣyāmi yogān gulmanibarhaṇān|
translation: I will indeed disclose the yoga techniques that, having been perfectly ascertained, can serve to dispel ignorance's "lumps."

sloka: tryūṣaṇatriphalādhānyaviḍaṅgacavyacitrakaiḥ||65||   kalkīkṛtairghṛtaṃ siddhaṃ sakṣīraṃ vātagulmanutiti tryūṣaṇādighṛtam   |
translation: Prepared with a churned mixture of Kalki herbs and other ingredients, and obtained through the clarified butter that has been purified in that same process, this efficacious Soma juice is testified by the air-filled space within a gourd.

sloka: eta eva ca kalkāḥ syuḥ kaṣāyaḥ pāñcamūlikaḥ  ||66||     dvipañcamūliko vā'pi tadghṛtaṃ gulmanut paramiti tryūṣaṇādighṛtamaparam
translation: These very ones are called "kalkas" either arising from the fifth layer or, alternatively, from the two-and-a-half layer. Their essence, extracted from "gulma," is considered supreme; so is that derived from "tryushana."

sloka: (ṣaṭpalaṃ vā pibet sarpiryaduktaṃ rājayakṣmaṇi)||67||
translation: The snake should drink the recommended measure of medicine for its royal fever.

sloka: prasannayā vā kṣīrārthaṃ  surayā dāḍimena vā|  dadhnaḥ sareṇa vā kāryaṃ ghṛtaṃ mārutagulmanut||68||
translation: With a serene mind, one can churn curds either using a golden or silver spoon, or even a piece of wood - this is how clarified butter is produced.

sloka: hiṅgusauvarcalājājībiḍadāḍimadīpyakaiḥ|  puṣkaravyoṣadhanyākavetasakṣāracitrakaiḥ||69||  śaṭīvacājagandhailāsurasaiśca vipācitam|  śūlānāhaharaṃ sarpirdadhnā cānilagulminām||70||  iti hiṅgusauvarcalādyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: Ghee is made fragrant by integrating a mixture of components including hingu, souvarcala, jībida, daḍima, madi, dīpyaka, puṣkara, vī, oṣadhā, kṣāra, citraka, śaṭīvacā, jasmine flowers, and musk. It is processed using a śūla, strained through clarified butter, and then diluted with sesame oil and gulmina. The terms in parentheses represent the Sanskrit names for various ingredients and substances used in the process.

sloka: hapuṣāvyoṣapṛthvīkācavyacitrakasaindhavaiḥ|  sājājīpippalīmūladīpyakairvipacedghṛtam||71||  sakolamūlakarasaṃ sakṣīradadhidāḍimam|  tat paraṃ vātagulmaghnaṃ śūlānāhavimokṣaṇam||72|| yonyarśograhaṇīdoṣaśvāsakāsārucijvarān|  bastihṛtpārśvaśūlaṃ ca ghṛtametadvyapohati||73||  iti hapuṣādyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: The ghee, processed with hapuṣa and other plants, ignited with various woods, and strained through kolamūla, mixed with the juice of saksi and dadhi, eliminates disorders of wind, bile, phlegm, sweat, and fever, as well as frees the body from ailments caused by imbalanced vata, kapha, pitta, grahani, toxicity in the large intestine, and afflictions such as diarrhea, constipation, cough, and indigestion. This is that very ghee processed with hapuṣa and other plants.

sloka: pippalyā picuradhyardho dāḍimāddvipalaṃ palam|  dhānyātpañca ghṛtācchuṇṭhyāḥ karṣaḥ kṣīraṃ caturguṇam||74||  siddhametairghṛtaṃ sadyo vātagulmaṃ vyapohati|  yoniśūlaṃ śiraḥśūlamarśāṃsi viṣamajvaram||7 5||  iti pippalyādyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: Prepared from pippalī and picu, consisting of adhyardha, dāḍima, and other ingredients, ghee, when boiled five times with grains, increases fourfold in quantity. Moreover, it can instantly cure ailments such as vāta, gulma, śūla at the head or joints, and viṣama jwaram. Such is the potency of pippalī-based ghee.

sloka: ghṛtānāmauṣadhagaṇā ya ete parikīrtitāḥ|  te cūrṇayogā vartyastāḥ kaṣāyāste ca gulminām||76||
translation: These collections of medicinal herbs, praised for being so, in ghee should be used crushed and mixed, as well as the impurities that are present in fresh ghee.

sloka: koladāḍimagharmāmbusurāmaṇḍāmlakāñjikaiḥ|  śūlānāhaharī peyā bījapūrarasena vā||77||
translation: Adorned with a gourd bearing a bump , generating warmth , immersed in water , surrounded by a divine being or intoxicating drink and resembling sweet and sour juice , wielding spears , consuming alcohol , filled with the essence of seeds , or perhaps it is; what could this be? - such a thing is described.

sloka: cūrṇāni mātuluṅgasya bhāvitāni rasena vā|  kuryādvartīḥ saguṭikā gulmānāhārtiśāntaye||78||
translation: Should one crush the decayed bark of the mātuluṅga tree, which has been treated with its sap, or not, as a measure to alleviate the pain caused by splinters, for the sap of mātuluṅga tree is known for its healing properties?

sloka: hiṅgu trikaṭukaṃ pāṭhāṃ hapuṣāmabhayāṃ śaṭīm|  ajamodājagandhe ca tintiḍīkāmlavetasau||79||  dāḍimaṃ puṣkaraṃ dhānyamajājīṃ citrakaṃ vacām|  dvau kṣārau lavaṇe dve ca cavyaṃ caikatra cūrṇayet||80||
translation: Use hingu, trikatukam, and patha, three pungent ingredients, along with hapusa, which is free from fear, and provides shade. Also add ajamoda, aja, and gandha, as well as tintidika and amla to it. Add dadima, puskara, dhanya, and citraka to the mix. In one place, combine two kinds of kshara, lavana, cavya, and crushed bija.

sloka: cūrṇametat prayoktavyamannapāneṣvanatyayam|  prāgbhaktamathavā peyaṃ madyenoṣṇodakena vā||81||
translation: This very fragment must be offered in sacred hospitality to the guest, or it should be consumed in food and drink; it should be taken beforehand as something eaten, or in the form of alcohol, warm water, or any other beverage. *[I am drinking it now.]

sloka: pārśvahṛdbastiśūleṣu gulme vātakaphātmake|  ānāhe mūtrakṛcchre ca śūle ca gudayonije [9] ||82||  grahaṇyarśovikāreṣu plīhni pāṇḍvāmaye'rucau|  urovibandhe hikkāyāṃ kāse śvāse galagrahe||83||
translation: In cases of fainting, blueness (from injury or bruising), unconsciousness, and jaundice, as well as in states of diarrhea and constipation, similarly during cough, hiccups, and blockages in the throat - where should one apply treatment or medicinal leeches?

sloka: bhāvitaṃ mātuluṅgasya cūrṇametadrasena vā|  bahuśo guṭikāḥ kāryāḥ kārmukāḥ syustato'dhikam||84||  iti hiṅgvādicūrṇaṃ guṭikā ca |
translation: The affection of Matalunga has been worn away. Many pellets should be produced instead with this "rasena" (medicinal plant sap). Arrows would then become abundant. Thus, the passage suggests preparing pellets and arrows with "rasena," resulting in an increased supply of them.

sloka: mātuluṅgaraso hiṅgu dāḍimaṃ biḍasaindhave|  surāmaṇḍena pātavyaṃ vātagulmarujāpaham||85||
translation: The fruit of the mātuluṅga tree and hiṅgu should be consumed by a biḍasaindhavā, together with surāmaṇḍena type of pepper, as a remedy for alleviating the symptoms of vāta (wind disorders), gulma (abdominal tumors), and rujā (pain).

sloka: śaṭīpuṣkarahiṅgvamlavetasakṣāracitrakān|  dhānyakaṃ ca yavānīṃ ca viḍaṅgaṃ saindhavaṃ vacām||86||  sacavyapippalīmūlāmajagandhāṃ sadāḍimām|  ajājīṃ cājamodāṃ ca cūrṇaṃ kṛtvā prayojayet||87||  rasena mātuluṅgasya madhuśuktena vā punaḥ|  bhāvitaṃ guṭikāṃ kṛtvā supiṣṭāṃ kolasammitām||88||
translation: Mix together with salt, turmeric, ginger, black pepper, long pepper, and citron seeds, as well as rice and barley; then add vegetables, radish, and mustard seeds to this mixture, followed by water. Optionally, add sugar to this well-mixed paste, and form it into small tablets.

sloka: gulmaṃ plīhānamānāhaṃ śvāsaṃ kāsamarocakam|  hikkāṃ hṛdrogamarśāṃsi vividhāṃ śiraso rujam||89||  pāṇḍvāmayaṃ kaphotkleśaṃ sarvajāṃ ca pravāhikām|  pārśvahṛdbastiśūlaṃ ca guṭikaiṣā vyapohati||90||
translation: I am the accumulation of gas and phlegm , known as Anila, causing the movement of breath . I manifest as hiccups , afflictions of the heart , and various other kinds of discomforts in the head . I am the ailment known as Pāṇḍu-āmaya, caused by an imbalance of phlegm and present throughout the body . I also cause pain in the sides , near the heart , and in the lower abdomen . This ailment is eliminated by the medication known as Guṭikā.

sloka: nāgarārdhapalaṃ piṣṭvā dve pale luñcitasya ca|  tilasyaikaṃ guḍapalaṃ kṣīreṇoṣṇena nā pibet||91||  vātagulmamudāvartaṃ yoniśūlaṃ ca nāśayet|
translation: After chewing on a half portion of a serpent's share, one should not drink sesame seeds with warm ghee; furthermore, one should avoid causing the stirring of a gust of wind and the destruction of the śūla within the womb.

sloka: pibederaṇḍajaṃ tailaṃ vāruṇīmaṇḍamiśritam||92||  tadeva tailaṃ payasā vātagulmī pibennaraḥ|  śleṣmaṇyanubale pūrvaṃ hitaṃ pittānuge param||93||
translation: Let him drink sesame oil blended with Varuni, as one should drink milk and ghee; In the initial stage, the juice that neutralizes phlegm is beneficial, and subsequently, that of yellow bile is preferable.

sloka: sādhayecchuddhaśuṣkasya laśunasya catuṣpalam|  kṣīrodake'ṣṭaguṇite  kṣīraśeṣaṃ ca nā pibet||94||  vātagulmamudāvartaṃ gṛdhrasīṃ viṣamajvaram|  hṛdrogaṃ vidradhiṃ śothaṃ sādhayatyāśu tatpayaḥ||95||  iti laśunakṣīram |
translation: One should properly prepare the four-tasted rush of the pure, dried root of laserwort. But one should not drink the residual butter-milk, mixed with water possessing eight qualities. Quickly cure diseases such as flatulence, abdominal tumor, enlarged spleen, irregular fever, heart disease, abscess, and pus through appropriate medical treatment. Thus is the preparation of laserwort and butter-milk.

sloka: tailaṃ prasannā gomūtramāranālaṃ yavāgrajam|  gulmaṃ jaṭharamānāhaṃ pītamekatra sādhayet||96||  iti tailapañcakam |
translation: With clarified butter as an offering, one should mix cow's urine, pure water from a river, a barley grain, and a piece of Kusha grass. Placing this mixture in the stomach, (one should do this) so that it purifies them. This is the fifth step in the process of preparing oneself for a religious ritual.

sloka: pañcamūlīkaṣāyeṇa sakṣāreṇa  śilājatu|  pibettasya prayogeṇa vātagulmāt pramucyate||97|| iti śilājatuprayogaḥ |
translation: Through the use of a decoction made from the five-root bark and rice water , one can be liberated from gulma afflictions by its administration ; this is known as the application of shilajit.

sloka: vāṭyaṃ pippalīyūṣeṇa mūlakānāṃ rasena vā|  bhuktvā snigdhamudāvartādvātagulmādvimucyate||98||
translation: By consuming pippalī's root extract along with āṭyam, prepared using its essence, one can be relieved from the ailment caused by vāta-gulma.

sloka: śūlānāhavibandhārtaṃ svedayedvātagulminam|  svedaiḥ svedavidhāvuktairnāḍīprastarasaṅkaraiḥ||99||
translation: Using rods, cause that bound individual to perspire; do so using sweats prescribed by the procedure, mixed with the confluence of various channels of energy (nāḍī) and expansions (prastara).

sloka: bastikarma paraṃ vidyādgulmaghnaṃ taddhi mārutam|  sve sthāne prathamaṃ jitvā sadyo gulmamapohati||100||  tasmādabhīkṣṇaśo gulmā nirūhaiḥ sānuvāsanaiḥ|  prayujyamānaiḥ śāmyanti vātapittakaphātmakāḥ||101||  gulmaghnā vividhā diṣṭāḥ siddhāḥ siddhiṣu bastayaḥ|
translation: Grasp that the supreme knowledge consists in the treatment of gulma through basti, the medicated enema. Once conquered in its own place, it can be immediately eliminated. Hence, through regular use of medicinal enemas, vata, pitta, and kapha can be effectively pacified. By mastering the gulma-destroying basti, one can achieve various successful cures for different diseases.

sloka: gulmaghnāni ca tailāni vakṣyante vātarogike||102|| tāni mārutaje gulme pānābhyaṅgānuvāsanaiḥ|  prayuktānyāśu sidhyanti tailaṃ hyanilajitparam [12] ||103||
translation: Pulverized drugs and sesame oil, they are described as being beneficial for treating ailments caused by the wind element, when employed in emesis and oil massage procedures. Indeed, sesame oil stands as the ultimate defeater of dirt.

sloka: nīlinīcūrṇasaṃyuktaṃ pūrvoktaṃ ghṛtameva|  samalāya pradātavyaṃ śodhanaṃ vātagulmine||104||
translation: Combine clarified butter, already mentioned in previous instructions, with the pulverized ingredients and prepare a paste, which must be given for purgation in a pot specifically used for this purpose.

sloka: nīlinītrivṛtādantīpathyākampillakaiḥ saha|  śodhanārthaṃ ghṛtaṃ deyaṃ sabiḍakṣāranāgaram||105||
translation: For the purpose of purification, ghee is to be offered, intended for use, accompanied by a mix of blue, white, and red lotus flowers.

sloka: nīlinīṃ triphalāṃ rāsnāṃ balāṃ kaṭukarohiṇīm|  pacedviḍaṅgaṃ vyāghrīṃ ca palikāni jalāḍhake||106||  tena pādāvaśeṣeṇa ghṛtaprasthaṃ vipācayet|  dadhnaḥ prasthena saṃyojya sudhākṣīrapalena ca||107||  tato ghṛtapalaṃ dadyādyavāgūmaṇḍamiśritam|  jīrṇe samyagviriktaṃ ca bhojayedrasabhojanam||108||  gulmakuṣṭhodaravyaṅgaśophapāṇḍvāmayajvarān|  śvitraṃ plīhānamunmādaṃ ghṛtametadvyapohati||109||  iti nīlinyādyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: With the remnants of the three-fruited nīlinī plant, bitter rohiṇī roots, and palikās grown in water, one should cook ghee. Once cooked, mix it with yavāgu maṇḍa and consume it as a delicious and therapeutic meal, eradicating diseases like gulma, kuṣṭha, udara, vyaṅga, śopha, pāṇḍu, āmaya, jvara, śvitra, plīha, and mūdhamāda. This is known as the first among nīli-based ghees.

sloka: kukkuṭāśca mayūrāśca tittirikrauñcavartakāḥ|  śālayo madirā sarpirvātagulmabhiṣagjitam||110||  hitamuṣṇaṃ dravaṃ snigdhaṃ bhojanaṃ vātagulminām|   samaṇḍavāruṇīpānaṃ pakvaṃ vā dhānyakairjalam||111||
translation: Roosters, peacocks, partridges, cuckoos, and herons, along with a shelter, wine, and a serpent, are all previously defeated by the wind and the gulma affliction. Offer warm, flowing, and oily nourishment to them. Also, provide cooked grains and water, as well as fermented liquor from the ocean and thunderclouds.

sloka: mande'gnau vardhate gulmo dīpte cāgnau praśāmyati|  tasmānnā nātisauhityaṃ kuryānnātivilaṅghanam||112||
translation: In a weakened fire, the fuel increases the flame; when it blazes, it subsides. Therefore, one should not excessively add to or remove from it.

sloka: sarvatra gulme prathamaṃ snehasvedopapādite|  yā kriyā kriyate siddhiṃ sā yāti na virūkṣite||113||
translation: In any pit, the primary action that should be performed first is causing heat through the friction of dry wood (sneha-sveda), and the action that leads to this success goes to the one who is not careless.

sloka: bhiṣagātyayikaṃ buddhvā pittagulmamupācaret|  vairecanikasiddhena sarpiṣā tiktakena  vā||114||
translation: Upon recognizing a critical medical condition, the physician should treat it either with ghee processed via the Vairecaka method or a pungent substance, deeming this as a special case.

sloka: rohiṇīkaṭukānimbamadhukatriphalātvacaḥ|  karṣāṃśāstrāyamāṇā ca paṭolatrivṛtoḥ pale||115||
translation: In the presence of a Rohini tree and the Kaṭukā plant, as well as a Nimba tree and Madhuka tree, the one proficient in juicing plants is now actively trying to collect the leaves of a Paṭola and Trivṛt plant.

sloka: dve pale ca masūrāṇāṃ sādhyamaṣṭaguṇe'mbhasi|  śṛtāccheṣaṃ ghṛtasamaṃ sarpiṣaśca catuṣpalam||116||  pibet sammūrcchitaṃ tena gulmaḥ śāmyati paittikaḥ|  jvarastṛṣṇā ca śūlaṃ ca bhramo mūrcchā'rucistathā||117||  iti rohiṇyādyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: Consuming two measures of masūrāṇi, at the appointed time, endowed with eight qualities, steeped in hot palāḥ and cooked with sesame oil, making it delicious, should be drunk when fully matured. By this, gulma is pacified, as well as jvara, tṛṣṇā, śūla, bhrama, mūrcchā, and aruci. Thus, Rohiṇyādya ghṛtam is the first.

sloka: jale daśaguṇe sādhyaṃ trāyamāṇācatuṣpalam|  pañcabhāgasthitaṃ pūtaṃ kalkaiḥ saṃyojya kārṣikaiḥ||118||
translation: By merging ten qualities in water, made achievable, it becomes four-petaled, situated in five parts, and gets purified through the agency of agricultural impurities.

sloka: rohiṇī kaṭukā mustā trāyamāṇā durālabhā|  kalkaistāmalakīvīrājīvantīcandanotpalaiḥ||119||  rasasyāmalakānāṃ ca kṣīrasya ca ghṛtasya ca|  palāni pṛthagaṣṭāṣṭau dattvā samyagvipācayet||120||
translation: Revitalizing Rohini, the bitter Kaṭukās, and Mustā, when difficult to obtain and adorned with kalka-covered Amalakī, Chandana, and Utpalas, one should properly prepare by offering and separating the juices of Amalakas, curd, and ghee in the correct quantities.

sloka: pittaraktabhavaṃ gulmaṃ vīsarpaṃ paittikaṃ jvaram|  hṛdrogaṃ kāmalāṃ kuṣṭhaṃ hanyādetadghṛtottamam||121||  iti trāyamāṇādyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: The optimal ghee, having treated pitta-induced inflammation, intestinal worms, paittika fever, heart disease, kama lata, and kushtha, should be consumed for this treatment. It is indeed the foremost one.

sloka: rasenāmalakekṣūṇāṃ ghṛtapādaṃ  vipācayet|  pathyāpadaṃ pibetsarpistatsiddhaṃ pittagulmanut||122||  ityāmalakādyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: With mustard oil, one should cook ripe āmalakas, and when sweetened, consume with milk and fully prepared ghee; this is the proper usage of ghṛta, as described starting with this preparation.

sloka: drākṣāṃ madhūkaṃ kharjūraṃ vidārīṃ saśatāvarīm|  parūṣakāṇi triphalāṃ sādhayetpalasammitam||123||  jalāḍhake pādaśeṣe rasamāmalakasya ca|  ghṛtamikṣurasaṃ kṣīramabhayākalkapādikam||124||  sādhayettadghṛtaṃ siddhaṃ śarkarākṣaudrapādikam|  prayogāt pittagulmaghnaṃ sarvapittavikāranut||125||  iti drākṣādyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: Prepare a decoction by causing grapes , licorice , myrobalan fruits , Indian jujube , barley , and badara tree bark to be boiled together in water until it is reduced to one third. To this, add the filtered juice of dried grapes , sugar , jaggery , and treacle . Further cook this mixture until it thickens, turning it into a concoction that is beneficial in treating all Pitta-related disorders, including those of the liver and spleen. This is the foremost among grape-based formulations.

sloka: vṛṣaṃ samūlamāpothya pacedaṣṭaguṇe jale|  śeṣe'ṣṭabhāge tasyaiva puṣpakalkaṃ pradāpayet||126||  tena siddhaṃ ghṛtaṃ śītaṃ sakṣaudraṃ pittagulmanut|  raktapittajvaraśvāsakāsahṛdroganāśanam||127||  iti vāsāghṛtam
translation: After milking the bull, if one leaves eight parts in the water and churns the remainder there, then should cause to be produced a medicinal clarified butter, now made possible, which is cooled, alleviates poisoning, and dispels afflictions of bile, phlegm, wind, fever, indigestion, cough, and heart disease. This is called vasaghrta.

sloka: dvipalaṃ trāyamāṇāyā jaladviprasthasādhitam|  aṣṭabhāgasthitaṃ pūtaṃ koṣṇaṃ kṣīrasamaṃ pibet||128||  pibedupari tasyoṣṇaṃ kṣīrameva yathābalam|  tena nirhṛtadoṣasya gulmaḥ śāmyati paittikaḥ||129||
translation: One should drink, as one's capacity allows, the warm, pure, churned cream of a watery island (coconut), which has been established in eight parts and settled in a vessel. Similarly, after finishing drinking it, one should drink the remaining coconut water in measured amounts, just like milk. This practice pacifies the undigested food in the stomach caused by pitta (bile).

sloka: drākṣābhayārasaṃ gulme paittike saguḍaṃ pibet|  lihyātkampillakaṃ vā'pi virekārthaṃ madhudravam||130||
translation: In this fear-filled world, one should drink either the sweet sap of the sugarcane with water, or the extract from the kampillaka plant as a substitute, mixed with water, in order to quench one's thirst.

sloka: dāhapraśamano'bhyaṅgaḥ sarpiṣā pittagulminām|  candanādyena tailena tailena madhukasya vā||131||
translation: The inflammation suppressant can be achieved through an abhyanga (oil massage) using ghee (clarified butter) mixed with sandalwood and other substances, as well as through the use of honey for pacifying burning sensations in the body.

sloka: ye ca pittajvaraharāḥ  satiktāḥ kṣīrabastayaḥ|  hitāste pittagulmibhyo vakṣyante ye ca siddhiṣu||132||
translation: Those who can cure fevers arising from an imbalance of the "pitta" dosha and are tranquil, they offer buttermilk as a remedy; indeed, they know how to prevent diseases caused by "pitta" and can also express words that lead to success in achieving balance in the bodily humors.

sloka: śālayo jāṅgalaṃ māṃsaṃ gavyāje payasī ghṛtam|  kharjūrāmalakaṃ drākṣāṃ dāḍimaṃ saparūṣakam||133||  āhārārthaṃ prayoktavyaṃ pānārthaṃ salilaṃ śṛtam|  balāvidārīgandhādyaiḥ pittagulmacikitsitam||134||
translation: For nourishment, you should use: wild game, curd from cow's milk, ghee, dates, gooseberries, grapes, lemons, and tamarind. Water should be consumed as a drink. Use various fragrances and remedies for treating digestive issues like bloating and indigestion as well.

sloka: āmānvaye pittagulme sāme vā kaphavātike|  yavāgūbhiḥ khaḍairyūṣaiḥ sandhukṣyo'gnirvilaṅghite||135||
translation: Is it in the sap of the father or in the marrow, will fire be present in an unobstructed manner, just as it is in the wind, as well as in the juices of barley and rice grains, through their agency?

sloka: śamaprakopau doṣāṇāṃ sarveṣāmagnisaṃśritau|  tasmādagniṃ sadā rakṣennidānāni ca varjayet||136||
translation: Subdue the flare-ups of all faults that inhere in the fire; therefore, one should always protect the fire and causatively make an effort to avoid their causes.

sloka: vamanaṃ vamanārhāya pradadyāt kaphagulmine|
translation: One should administer the therapeutic emetic "vamana" to the deserving patient at the right time, specifically in the morning when kapha dominates, as an act of obligation.

sloka: snigdhasvinnaśarīrāya gulme śaithilyamāgate||137||  pariveṣṭya pradīptāṃstu balvajānathavā kuśān|  bhiṣakkumbhe samāvāpya gulmaṃ ghaṭamukhe nyaset||138||
translation: When one has a well-oiled and pliable body, they should gather soft kusa grass, having been caused to ignite, after encouraging it, and place the collected bunch near the mouth of the medicine jar when indigestion has occurred.

sloka: saṅgṛhīto  yadā gulmastadā ghaṭamathoddharet|  vastrāntaraṃ tataḥ kṛtvā bhindyādgulmaṃ  pramāṇavit||139||  vimārgājapadādarśairyathālābhaṃ prapīḍayet|  mṛdnīyādgulmamevaikaṃ na tvantrahṛdayaṃ  spṛśet||140||
translation: Once a tumor is grasped, if it can be lifted, then having separated the cloth covering it, the tumor should be lanced, ascertaining its size. Similarly, one should carefully press and extract only the abscess, but should not touch the heart, which is enclosed within.

sloka: tilairaṇḍātasībījasarṣapaiḥ parilipya ca|    śleṣmagulmamayaḥpātraiḥ sukhoṣṇaiḥ svedayedbhiṣak||141||
translation: The physician, after smearing the afflicted area with juices extracted from sesame, mustard, calotropis, and castor beans, should apply warm, sweat-inducing vessels made of suitable materials.

sloka: savyoṣakṣāralavaṇaṃ daśamūlīśṛtaṃ ghṛtam|  kaphagulmaṃ jayatyāśu sahiṅgubiḍadāḍimam||142||  iti daśamūlīghṛtam|
translation: The ghee, extracted from the roots of dasamula , possessing coolness and alkalinity , as well as saltiness , can quickly overcome phlegm disorders and intestinal worm infestations . This is referred to as dasamula ghee .

sloka: bhallātakānāṃ dvipalaṃ pañcamūlaṃ palonmitam|  sādhyaṃ vidārīgandhādyamāpothya salilāḍhake||143||  pādaśeṣe rase tasmin pippalīṃ nāgaraṃ vacām|  viḍaṅgaṃ saindhavaṃ hiṅgu yāvaśūkaṃ biḍaṃ śaṭīm||144||  citrakaṃ madhukaṃ rāsnāṃ piṣṭvā karṣasamaṃ bhiṣak|  prasthaṃ ca payaso dattvā ghṛtaprasthaṃ vipācayet||145||  etadbhallātakaghṛtaṃ kaphagulmaharaṃ param|     plīhapāṇḍvāmayaśvāsagrahaṇīrogakāsanut||146||  iti bhallātakādyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: Of the Bhallataka fruits, the fifth part of the stalk, effectively medicinal, should be combined with ingredients such as Pippalī, Nāgara, Vidaṅga, Saindhava, Hiṅgu, Yāvaśūka, Biḍa, Śaṭī, Citraka, Madhuka, Rāsnā, reduced to fine powder, mixed with an equal amount of ghee and a prastha of payasam, and cooked until reduced. This Bhallataka ghṛta is exceptionally beneficial for diseases like Gulma, Plīha, Pāṇḍu, Śvāsa, Grahaṇī, Aruci, and Netra-roga caused by Kapha and Vāyu.

sloka: pippalīpippalīmūlacavyacitrakanāgaraiḥ|  palikaiḥ sayavakṣārairghṛtaprasthaṃ vipācayet||147||  kṣīraprasthaṃ ca tat sarpihanti gulmaṃ kaphātmakam|  grahaṇīpāṇḍurogaghnaṃ plīhakāsajvarāpaham||148||  iti kṣīraṣaṭpalakaṃ ghṛtam
translation: Using a mixture of Pippali root, Cavya, Citraka, and Nagara, along with Palika salts, one should cook milk and its cream. This preparation, known as "Ksheera Shatapalaka Ghrita," eliminates phlegm-based Gulma, cures Grahani, Pandu, Rakta-related diseases, and Plihaka disorders.

sloka: trivṛtāṃ triphalāṃ dantīṃ daśamūlaṃ palonmitam|  jale caturguṇe paktvā caturbhāgasthitaṃ rasam||149||  sarpireraṇḍajaṃ tailaṃ kṣīraṃ caikatra sādhayet|  sa siddho miśrakasnehaḥ sakṣaudraḥ kaphagulmanut||150||  kaphavātavibandheṣu kuṣṭhaplīhodareṣu ca|  prayojyo miśrakaḥ sneho yoniśūleṣu cādhikam||151||  iti miśrakaḥ snehaḥ
translation: Prepare a concoction by cooking well in a fourfold quantity of water the three-fruited, tooth-cleaning, ten-rooted one, processed from the palm fruit, along with sesame oil, milk, and ghee, all together. That mixture, when properly prepared, is an effective aphrodisiac and alleviates phlegm disorders, wind disorders, and growths in the abdomen. This medicated oil should be primarily used in sexual union and, to a greater extent, in female reproductive tissues. Thus is described this medicated oil.

sloka: yaduktaṃ vātagulmaghnaṃ sraṃsanaṃ nīlinīghṛtam|  dviguṇaṃ tadvirekārthaṃ prayojyaṃ kaphagulminām||152||  sudhākṣīradrave cūrṇaṃ trivṛtāyāḥ subhāvitam|  kārṣikaṃ madhusarpibhyāṃ līḍhvā  sādhu viricyate||153||
translation: Having been stated by the teacher, firstly, crush and cook rice in milk and sugarcane juice, then mix it with a small amount of clarified butter; this is a means to destroy the flatus and mucus in the body. Secondly, prepare a purgative drug by combining a kapha-gulma-destroying powder, sugarcane juice, and clarified butter.

sloka: jaladroṇe vipaktavyā viṃśatiḥ pañca cābhayāḥ|  dantyāḥ palāni tāvanti citrakasya tathaiva ca||154|| aṣṭabhāgāvaśeṣaṃ tu rasaṃ pūtamadhikṣipet|  dantīsamaṃ guḍaṃ pūtaṃ kṣipettatrābhayāśca tāḥ||155||  tailārdhakuḍavaṃ caiva trivṛtāyāścatuṣpalam|  cūrṇitaṃ palamekaṃ  tu pippalīviśvabheṣajam||156||  tat sādhyaṃ lehavacchīte tasmiṃstailasamaṃ madhu|  kṣipeccūrṇapalaṃ caikaṃ tvagelāpatrakeśarāt||157||  tato lehapalaṃ līḍhvā jagdhvā caikāṃ harītakīm|  sukhaṃ viricyate snigdho doṣaprasthamanāmayam||158||  gulmaṃ śvayathumarśāṃsi pāṇḍurogamarocakam|  hṛdrogaṃ grahaṇīdoṣaṃ kāmalāṃ viṣamajvaram||159||  kuṣṭhaṃ plīhānamānāhameṣā hanyupasevitā|  niratyayaḥ kramaścāsyā dravo māṃsarasaudanaḥ||160||  iti dantīharītakī
translation: In the Droṇa lake, one should prepare a concoction with twenty-five [viṃśatiḥ pañca cābhayāḥ] ingredients. They should add, one at a time, the following ingredients: Citraka, Taila in the measure of half a Kudava, three Prasravi, crushed Pippalī, and Bheṣaja. After reducing them to ashes in a leha fire, they should mix it with honey, Gulma, Śvayathu, marśa, Paṇḍu roga, Grahani dosha, Kāma la, Viṣama jvara, Kuṣṭha, Plīhāna, anāhāma, hanyupasevitā niratyayaḥ, kramaḥ, āsyāh, drava, māṃsa, rasāh, udanaḥ. This is the method for preparing Harītakī.

sloka: siddhāḥ siddhiṣu vakṣyante nirūhāḥ kaphagulminām|  ariṣṭayogāḥ siddhāśca grahaṇyarśaścikitsite||161||
translation: The experts are spoken of as being made proficient in accomplishments within the realms of therapeutic treatment for kaphagulmina's symptoms, as well as in yogic practices associated with favorable omens and eclipses.

sloka: yaccūrṇaṃ guṭikā yāśca vihitā vātagulminām|  dviguṇakṣārahiṅgvamlavetasāstāḥ kaphe hitāḥ||162||
translation: The powder and pills, specifically prepared and each containing two measures of potent kshaara, hingu, and amla, have been found beneficial for kapha.

sloka: ya eva grahaṇīdoṣe kṣārāste kaphagulminām|  siddhā niratyayāḥ śastā dāhastvante praśasyate||163||
translation: The one who, in regard to the fault of being grasping, is free from it, and who, unsullied by phlegm and bile, has steadily and irreproachably attained success; whose burning actions will be praised at the very end.

sloka: prapurāṇāni dhānyāni jāṅgalā mṛgapakṣiṇaḥ|  kaulattho mudgayūṣaśca pippalyā nāgarasya ca||164||  śuṣkamūlakayūṣaśca bilvasya varuṇasya  ca|  cirabilvāṅkurāṇāṃ ca yavānyāścitrakasya ca||165||
translation: Of the ancient crops, wild-growing grains such as kulatha and mudga, pippalyaa of nagara, dried root of bilva, varuna's bilva with elongated shoots, yavani of citraka, and such.

sloka: bījapūrakahiṅgvamlavetasakṣāradāḍimaiḥ|  takreṇa tailasarpirbhyāṃ vyañjanānyupakalpayet||166||
translation: With the respective radicles of ginger, citrus, vetiver, and pomegranate, and using vinegar and two kinds of oils, one should cause additional flavors to be created.

sloka: pañcamūlīśṛtaṃ toyaṃ purāṇaṃ vāruṇīrasam|  kaphagulmī pibetkāle jīrṇaṃ mādhvīkameva vā||167||
translation: One should drink water drawn from a five-stream source, whether it is ancient or mixed with Varuni, at the proper time; whether it has become stale or tainted with phlegm.

sloka: yavānīcūrṇitaṃ takraṃ biḍena lavaṇīkṛtam|  pibet sandīpanaṃ vātakaphamūtrānulomanam ||168||
translation: Let one sip the buttermilk, agitated from curds, made salty with salt, and previously exhaled by the forces of wind and bile.

sloka: sañcitaḥ kramaśo gulmo mahāvāstuparigrahaḥ|  kṛtamūlaḥ sirānaddho yadā kūrma ivonnataḥ||169||  daurbalyārucihṛllāsakāsavamyaratijvaraiḥ  |  tṛṣṇātandrāpratiśyāyairyujyate na sa sidhyati||170||
translation: When a clump of sins accumulates over time, becoming as massive as a great burden, held together by the root and veins, if one becomes stooped like a tortoise, such a person cannot achieve success due to factors like debility, diminished luster, fickleness, desire for fame, and afflictions such as lethargy and fever.

sloka: gṛhītvā sajvaraśvāsaṃ vamyatīsārapīḍitam|  hṛnnābhihastapādeṣu śophaḥ karṣati gulminam||171||
translation: The charioteer, having taken hold of the reins, pulls on the horse, which is excited and afflicted by a severe cramp in the navel region, as it struggles beneath his feet.

sloka: raudhirasya tu gulmasya garbhakālavyatikrame|  snigdhasvinnaśarīrāyai dadyāt snehavirecanam||172||
translation: In the case of a swollen gourd, when there is a premature burst during its gestation period, one should make sure to apply a warm oil massage to the ripe body.

sloka: palāśakṣārapātre dve dve pātre tailasarpiṣoḥ|  gulmaśaithilyajananīṃ paktvā mātrāṃ prayojayet||173||
translation: On two palm leaves, one should apply twice a paste made from two ingredients: alkali and oil, as well as the juice of the gulma-shaithilya-janani plant. Furthermore, one should cause it to be cooked just enough.

sloka: prabhidyeta na yadyevaṃ dadyādyoniviśodhanam  |   kṣāreṇa yuktaṃ palalaṃ sudhākṣīreṇa vā punaḥ||174|| ābhyāṃ vā bhāvitān dadyādyonau kaṭukamatsyakān|  varāhamatsyapittābhyāṃ laktakān vā subhāvitān||175||  adhoharaiścordhvaharairbhāvitān vā samākṣikaiḥ|  kiṇvaṃ vā saguḍakṣāraṃ dadyādyoniviśodhanam||176||
translation: If it should not burst open, then one should meditate on the fermented mixture, prepared with salt or sugarcane juice, or on both, that have been properly treated. Alternatively, one should meditate on kaṭukamatsya and varāhamatsya, which have been well-prepared and cleansed in their yoni, when offered in the fermented mixture. Furthermore, one should meditate on a mixture of grains, either individually or together, that have been properly prepared and cleansed.

sloka: raktapittaharaṃ kṣāraṃ lehayenmadhusarpiṣā|  laśunaṃ madirāṃ tīkṣṇāṃ matsyāṃścāsyai pradāpayet||177||
translation: Prepare for her consumption a purgative that is cooling, made from honey and ghee, caused to be added with garlic, strong wine, and small pieces of fish.

sloka: bastiṃ sakṣīragomūtraṃ sakṣāraṃ dāśamūlikam|  adṛśyamāne rudhire dadyādgulmaprabhedanam||178||
translation: When the bladder can't see the witness of urine, it should discharge the liquid mixed with feces and roots in the presence of redness (i.e., blood).

sloka: pravartamāne rudhire dadyānmāṃsarasaudanam|  ghṛtatailena cābhyaṅgaṃ pānārthaṃ taruṇīṃ surām||179||
translation: At the onset of a battle, offer meat with ghee-infused rice as a meal and give the young woman wine to quench her thirst.

sloka: rudhire'tipravṛtte tu raktapittaharīḥ kriyāḥ|  kāryā vātarugārtāyāḥ sarvā vātaharīḥ punaḥ||180||
translation: In the case of excessive bleeding, should all therapeutic measures for alleviating wind-inflicted ailments, which have already been initiated during the onset of blood-purifying actions, be repeated or are they sufficient? (180)

sloka: ghṛtatailāvasekāṃśca tittirīṃścaraṇāyudhān|  surāṃ samaṇḍāṃ pūrvaṃ ca pānamamlasya sarpiṣaḥ||181||  prayojayeduttaraṃ vā jīvanīyena sarpiṣā|  atipravṛtte rudhire satiktenānuvāsanam||182||
translation: With sesame oil and ghee intended for initial anointment, as well as sesame seeds for massaging the feet, one should cause to be used first the ghee, or, as an alternative, oil that sustains life. In the event of profuse bleeding, buttermilk should be consumed.

sloka: tatra ślokāḥ  snehaḥ svedaḥ sarpirbastiścūrṇāni bṛṃhaṇaṃ guḍikāḥ|  vamanavirekau mokṣaḥ kṣatajasya ca vātagulmavatām||183||  sarpiḥ satiktasiddhaṃ kṣīraṃ prasraṃsanaṃ nirūhāśca|  raktasya cāvasecanamāśvāsanasaṃśamanayogāḥ||184||
translation: In the description of treatments, one finds: sweat as an expression of affection, oil for strengthening, excrement for reducing swelling, and cow dung for plastering; vomiting and purgation serve as means of liberation for a person afflicted with kṣataja disorder, similar to the removal of a splinter. Ghee, when properly prepared, aids in heart health; milk promotes semen discharge, growth, and nourishment; red substances pacify and alleviate bleeding.

sloka: upanāhanaṃ saśastraṃ pakvasyābhyantaraprabhinnasya|  saṃśodhanasaṃśamane pittaprabhavasya gulmasya||185||  snehaḥ svedo bhedo laṅghanamullekhanaṃ virekaśca|  sarpirbastirguṭikāścūrṇamariṣṭāśca sakṣārāḥ||186||
translation: In treating a fully ripe, internally split gulma (tumor) of pitta (bile) origin, one should apply means such as heating, using sharp instruments, expressing pus, removing decayed tissue, washing away exudation, and separating. Also, there are sarpirbastirguṭikāścūrṇamariṣṭāśca (medicinal substances like powders, pastes, decoctions etc.) which are applicable.

sloka: gulmasyānte dāhaḥ kaphajasyāgre'panītaraktasya|  gulmasya raudhirasya kriyākramaḥ strībhavasyoktaḥ||187||
translation: The prescribed regimen for a man with a yellowish tinge due to an excess of phlegm in his body, regarding his gulma, is as follows: apply a heating agent at the termination of the gulma. This is stated in the texts referring to the transformation into a female form .

sloka: pathyānnapānasevā hetūnāṃ varjanaṃ yathāsvaṃ ca|  nityaṃ cāgnisamādhiḥ snigdhasya ca sarvakarmāṇi||188||  heturliṅgaṃ siddhiḥ kriyākramaḥ sādhyatā na yogāśca|  gulmacikitsitasaṅgraha etāvān vyāhṛto'gniveśasya||189||
translation: Proper nourishment, hydration, and service; relinquishing them at the appropriate time, according to one's own discretion; daily fire worship and performing all actions with a friendly disposition—these serve as the causes, indicators, achievements, and methods for the officiant. The collection of remedies for treating tumors is also included in his designated duties.

sloka: ityagniveśakṛte tantre carakapratisaṃskṛte cikitsitasthāne  gulmacikitsitaṃ nāma pañcamo'dhyāyaḥ||5||
translation: Designated as "Gulmacikitsitam," the fifth chapter of Caraka's treatise describes the procedure and explanation of gulma treatment, having been composed and explained in the fire ritual-related text.

sloka: athāta unmādacikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: Now we shall explain the means of overcoming delusion. Thus the Lord Atreya had spoken.

sloka: buddhismṛtijñānataponivāsaḥ punarvasuḥ prāṇabhṛtāṃ śaraṇyaḥ|  unmādahetvākṛtibheṣajāni kāle'gniveśāya śaśaṃsa pṛṣṭaḥ||3||
translation: The refuge of those sustaining life, who have reestablished their buddhi (wisdom), smrti (memory), jnana (knowledge), and tapa (austerity) as their permanent abode, will be inquired about the remedies for overcoming the cause of insanity during the right time; and the one who asks is likely to be in second-person plural, indicating a group or community.

sloka: viruddhaduṣṭāśucibhojanāni pradharṣaṇaṃ devagurudvijānām|  unmādaheturbhayaharṣapūrvo mano'bhighāto viṣamāśca ceṣṭāḥ||4||
translation: Disputed foods, tainted and eaten, as well as their consumers, are severely criticized by the divine beings, gurus, and brahmins. Intoxication, fear, and joy precede such mental disturbances, which can be of various kinds and caused by different factors, and are marked by unevenness and agitation of the mind.

sloka: tairalpasattvasya malāḥ praduṣṭā buddhernivāsaṃ hṛdayaṃ pradūṣya|  srotāṃsyadhiṣṭhāya manovahāni pramohayantyāśu narasya cetaḥ||5||
translation: Through the insufficient development of the spirit, impurities taint the abode of understanding, and having taken hold of the faculties of perception, they quickly cause the person's consciousness to become deluded.

sloka: dhīvibhramaḥ sattvapariplavaśca paryākulā dṛṣṭiradhīratā ca|  abaddhavāktvaṃ hṛdayaṃ ca śūnyaṃ sāmānyamunmādagadasya liṅgam||6||  sa mūḍhacetā na sukhaṃ na duḥkhaṃ nācāradharmau kuta eva śāntim|  vindatyapāstasmṛtibuddhisañjño bhramatyayaṃ ceta itastataśca||7||
translation: With mental faculties and sattva overwhelmed, vision troubled , judgment impaired , speech uncontrolled , and heart vacant , resembling the symptoms of a common man ; such a deluded one does not experience happiness or distress, nor proper conduct or morals. Where, then, can peace be found for him? Having overcome forgetfulness and regaining consciousness , this mind of his wanders here and there.

sloka: samudbhramaṃ buddhimanaḥsmṛtīnāmunmādamāgantunijotthamāhuḥ| tasyodbhavaṃ pañcavidhaṃ pṛthak tu vakṣyāmi liṅgāni cikitsitaṃ ca||8||
translation: The wise indeed extol the disciplined emergence of intellect as superior. I will describe its five distinct types, along with their identifiers and appropriate treatments.

sloka: rūkṣālpaśītānnavirekadhātukṣayopavāsairanilo'tivṛddhaḥ|  cintādijuṣṭaṃ  hṛdayaṃ pradūṣya buddhiṃ smṛtiṃ cāpyupahanti śīghram||9||  asthānahāsasmitanṛtyagītavāgaṅgavikṣepaṇarodanāni|  pāruṣyakārśyāruṇavarṇatāśca jīrṇe balaṃ cānilajasya rūpam||10||
translation: Through excessive austerities, eating only dry and cold food, and eliminating certain elements, Anila (the wind) becomes excessively abundant. This, in turn, quickly stains the heart with anxieties and impairs both intellect and memory. Similarly, harshness, meagerness, and fiery qualities, as well as Anila's decayed physical appearance, negatively impact strength.

sloka: ajīrṇakaṭvamlavidāhyaśītairbhojyaiścitaṃ pittamudīrṇavegam|  unmādamatyugramanātmakasya hṛdi śritaṃ pūrvavadāśu kuryāt||11||  amarṣasaṃrambhavinagnabhāvāḥ santarjanātidravaṇauṣṇyaroṣāḥ  |  pracchāyaśītānnajalābhilāṣāḥ pītā ca bhāḥ pittakṛtasya liṅgam||12||
translation: One should, in the beginning, establish in the heart a digestion-promoting Pitta that is strengthened by consuming freshly cooked, non-putrid food items. For an individual whose nature is dominated by excessively aggressive manifestations such as anger, excitement, and heat, one should cool down these qualities and stimulate their thirst for water, which are indicative of a balanced Pitta. Additionally, one should purify their complexion, an outward sign of Pitta's equilibrium.

sloka: sampūraṇairmandaviceṣṭitasya soṣmā kapho marmaṇi sampravṛddhaḥ|  buddhiṃ smṛtiṃ cāpyupahatya cittaṃ pramohayan sañjanayedvikāram||13||  vākceṣṭitaṃ mandamarocakaśca nārīviviktapriyatā'tinidrā|  chardiśca lālā ca balaṃ ca bhuṅkte nakhādiśauklyaṃ ca kaphātmakasya||14||
translation: When the Kapha dosha, specifically, becomes exaggerated in a susceptible individual by the qualities of heaviness, etc., it can cause the loss of consciousness and delusion, as well as impair the use of one’s intellect and memory. It also results in a decreased desire for speech and movement. Furthermore, it can lead to increased sleep, excessive salivation, and a preference for solitude. Indigestion, cough, and cold are also symptoms that may arise, along with ailments related to the affected bodily parts. Additionally, the person may experience symptoms such as a lack of appetite or excessive laziness.

sloka: yaḥ sannipātaprabhavo'tighoraḥ sarvaiḥ samastaiḥ sa ca hetubhiḥ syāt|  sarvāṇi rūpāṇi bibharti tādṛgvirudghabhaiṣajyavidhirvivarjyaḥ||15||
translation: The one who is the powerful cause of gatherings and is extremely fearsome, who arises from all causes and bears all forms, is devoid of treatments that are opposite in nature (i.e. a true healer).

sloka: devarṣigandharvapiśācayakṣarakṣaḥpitṝṇāmabhidharṣaṇāni|  āgantuheturniyamavratādi mithyākṛtaṃ karma ca pūrvadehe||16||
translation: The acts of hostility, such as abduction, perpetrated by the celestials, sages, Gandharvas, Pishachas, Yakshas, and Rakshasas, as well as by ancestors, are caused by a specific motive; similarly, false actions, including misleading vows and rituals, were carried out in previous lives.

sloka: amartyavāgvikramavīryaceṣṭo jñānādivijñānabalādibhiryaḥ|  unmādakālo'niyataśca yasya bhūtotthamunmādamudāharettam||17||
translation: Who is that being, characterized by unwavering resolve and unrestricted time, possessing non-mortal courage, action, and knowledge along with its associated powers, and whose supreme exhilaration raises the elements?

sloka: adūṣayantaḥ puruṣasya dehaṃ devādayaḥ svaistu guṇaprabhāvaiḥ|  viśantyadṛśyāstarasā yathaiva cchāyātapau darpaṇasūryakāntau||18|| āghātakālo hi sa pūrvarūpaḥ prokto nidāne'tha surādibhiśca|  unmādarūpāṇi pṛthaṅnibodha kālaṃ ca gamyān puruṣāṃśca teṣām||19||
translation: The gods, with Indra at the fore, endow the virtuous man's body with their powers through their inherent qualities, just as coolness and heat permeate a mirror and the sun respectively. Indeed, this being's earlier form is declared to be the time of adversity. Recognize distinctly the forms of these beings and time itself.

sloka: tatra dvayorapi nijāgantunimittayorunmādayoḥ  samāsavistarābhyāṃ bheṣajavidhimanuvyākhyāsyāmaḥ||24||
translation: In that very context, we shall detail the method of treatment for both, the inducing causes and the "unnamed" causes, drawn from comprehensive descriptions.

sloka: unmāde vātaje pūrvaṃ snehapānaṃ viśeṣavit|  kuryādāvṛtamārge tu sasnehaṃ mṛdu śodhanam||25||
translation: At the onset of fainting caused by wind, he should administer an oil infusion as a special treatment; instead, on the well-trodden path, he should gently perform an affectionate cleansing.

sloka: kaphapittodbhave'pyādau vamanaṃ savirecanam|  snigdhasvinnasya kartavyaṃ śuddhe saṃsarjanakramaḥ||26||
translation: In the initial stages of a Kapha or Pitta disturbance, emesis and purgation are to be performed; for one who has experienced proper digestion, appropriate elimination should be carried out in a purified sequence.

sloka: nirūhaṃ snehabastiṃ ca śirasaśca virecanam|  tataḥ kuryādyathādoṣaṃ teṣāṃ bhūyastvamācaret||27||
translation: After performing the anointment of the head with oil and the ablution, one should ensure to correct any errors that occur during these rituals; such care should be increased.

sloka: hṛdindriyaśiraḥkoṣṭhe saṃśuddhe vamanādibhiḥ|  manaḥprasādamāpnoti smṛtiṃ sañjñāṃ ca vindati||28||
translation: By purifying the heart, senses, and mind locale through emetics and similar methods, one attains mental tranquility, as well as recalls memory and discernment.

sloka: śuddhasyācāravibhraṃśe tīkṣṇaṃ nāvanamañjanam|  tāḍanaṃ ca manobuddhidehasaṃvejanaṃ  hitam||29||  yaḥ sakto'vinaye  paṭṭaiḥ saṃyamya sudṛḍhaiḥ sukhaiḥ|  apetalohakāṣṭhādye saṃrodhyaśca tamogṛhe||30||
translation: The one who is devoted, endowed with firm determination and joy, skillfully restrains the sharp thorns of transgression from pure conduct using sturdy ropes. And, such a person also subdues, within the house of darkness (the body), the ironwood and other material tendencies; this one is fit for wisdom.

sloka: tarjanaṃ trāsanaṃ dānaṃ harṣaṇaṃ sāntvanaṃ bhayam|  vismayo vismṛterhetornayanti prakṛtiṃ manaḥ||31||  pradehotsādanābhyaṅgadhūmāḥ pānaṃ ca sarpiṣaḥ|  prayoktavyaṃ manobuddhismṛtisañjñāprabodhanam||32||  sarpiḥpānādirāgantormantrādiśceṣyate vidhiḥ|33|
translation: Gestures, instilling fear, giving, exciting joy, appeasing, and causing fear; these, together with astonishment and forgetfulness, alter the inherent disposition of the mind. Massaging, inducing sweating, fumigation, consuming ghee and beverages; all these should be employed for stimulating the senses, intellect, memory, and consciousness. Ghee, beverages, and related elements are to be utilized as per prescribed rules. The application of mantras and other accompanying elements is also recommended.

sloka: ataḥ siddhatamānyogāñchṛṇūnmādavināśanān||33||  hiṅgusauvarcalavyoṣairdvipalāṃśairghṛtāḍhakam|  caturguṇe gavāṃ mūtre siddhamunmādanāśanam||34||

viśālā triphalā kauntī  devadārvelavālukam|  sthirā nataṃ rajanyau dve sārive dve priyaṅgukā||35||  nīlotpalailāmañjiṣṭhādantīdāḍimakeśaram|  tālīśapatraṃ bṛhatī mālatyāḥ kusumaṃ navam||36||  viḍaṅgaṃ pṛśniparṇī ca kuṣṭhaṃ candanapadmakau|  aṣṭāviṃśatibhiḥ kalkairetairakṣasamanvitaiḥ||37||  caturguṇe  jale samyagghṛtaprasthaṃ vipācayet|
translation: In the vast Kunti's triple-fruit tree, two sturdy Rajanyau creeper plants, named Sārive and Priyaṅgukā, entwine with each other. The tree bears dark blue lotus, Elā, Mañjiṣṭhā, Dantī, and Dāḍima flowers, as well as large Bṛhatī and Mālatyāḥ blossoms, Viḍaṅga and Pṛśniparṇī leaves, Kuṣṭha and Candanapadmaka fruits. All these are endowed with thirty-two essential qualities. For sacred rituals, they must be carefully infused in ghee and boiled in water after being duly selected with kalka, a mixture made of eighteen types of auspicious substances.

sloka: apasmāre jvare kāse śoṣe mande'nale kṣaye||38||  vātarakte pratiśyāye tṛtīyakacaturthake|  chardyarśomūtrakṛcchreṣu visarpopahateṣu ca||39||  kaṇḍūpāṇḍvāmayonmādaviṣamehagadeṣu ca|  bhūtopahatacittānāṃ gadgadānāmacesām||40||  śastaṃ strīṇāṃ ca vandhyānāṃ dhanyamāyurbalapradam|  alakṣmīpāparakṣoghnaṃ sarvagrahavināśanam||41||  kalyāṇakamidaṃ sarpiḥ śreṣṭhaṃ puṃsavaneṣu caiti kalyāṇakaṃ ghṛtam
translation:
To those located in the realm of fainting, fever, thirst, weakness, lethargy, and emaciation,
Coughing, wheezing, dysuria, and other such ailments,
And to those suffering from itching, discoloration, diseases, epilepsy, and insanity,
This ghee, which is beneficial, is prescribed; it destroys all afflictions,
Promotes the well-being of men in their prime, and is excellent for use during sacrifices.
Similarly, this clarified butter is auspicious and the best to be used during rituals.

sloka: ebhya eva sthirādīni jale paktvaikaviṃśatim||42||  rase tasmin pacet sarpirgṛṣṭikṣīre caturguṇe|  vīrārdramāṣakākolīsvayaṅguptarṣabhardhibhiḥ||43||  medayā ca samaiḥ kalkaistat syāt kalyāṇakaṃ mahat|  bṛṃhaṇīyaṃ viśeṣeṇa sannipātaharaṃ param||44||  iti mahākalyāṇakaṃ ghṛtam
translation: Cook these stable ingredients for twenty minutes in water , the snake cooks in that sapid liquid . Combined with four qualities - virile, ardent, strong, and secretive - and further enhanced with mercy and equanimity, this ghee becomes highly auspicious and supremely augmenting, capable of aggregating all beneficial elements and reducing obstacles to a minimum. Thus, it is said to be the great elixir .

sloka: jaṭilāṃ pūtanāṃ keśīṃ cāraṭīṃ markaṭīṃ vacām|  trāyamāṇāṃ jayāṃ vīrāṃ corakaṃ kaṭurohiṇīm||45||  vayaḥsthāṃ śūkarīṃ chatrāmaticchatrāṃ palaṅkaṣām|  mahāpuruṣadantāṃ ca kāyasthāṃ nākulīdvayam||46||  kaṭambharāṃ vṛścikālīṃ sthirāṃ cāhṛtya tairghṛtam|  siddhaṃ cāturthakonmādagrahāpasmāranāśanam||47||  mahāpaiśācikaṃ nāma ghṛtametadyathā'mṛtam|  buddhismṛtikaraṃ caiva bālānāṃ cāṅgavardhanam||48||  iti mahāpaiśācikaṃ ghṛtam
translation: "Prepare the Mahapaisachika oil, which is like nectar for children's growth, which has the properties of cognition and memory, and which eliminates the fourth level of intoxication, by taking the oil having the names: Jaṭilā, Pūtanā, Keśī, Cāraṭī, Markaṭī, and Vacā, while they are being protected; as well as Jaya, Vīrā, Cora, Kaṭurohīṇī, Śūkarī, Chatrāmati-chatrā, Palaṅkaṣā, Mahāpuruṣa-dantā, Kāyasthā, Nākulī (dual form), Kaṭambhara, Vṛścikālī, and Sthirā, after having grasped it in their hands from Kaṭam, Bharā, and the other ingredients mentioned; this oil, similar to nectar, named Mahapaisachika, enhances the strength of children, just as Buddhi and Smṛti (cognition and memory) do for oneself."

sloka: laśunānāṃ śataṃ triṃśadabhayāstryūṣaṇāt palam|  gavāṃ carmamasīprastho dvyāḍhakaṃ kṣīramūtrayoḥ||49||  purāṇasarpiṣaḥ prastha ebhiḥ siddhaṃ prayojayet|  hiṅgucūrṇapalaṃ śīte dattvā ca madhumāṇikām||50||  taddoṣāgantusambhūtānunmādān viṣamajvarān|  apasmārāṃśca hantyāśu pānābhyañjananāvanaiḥ||51||  iti laśunādyaṃ ghṛtamlaśunasyāvinaṣṭasya tulārdhaṃ nistuṣīkṛtam|  tadardhaṃ daśamūlasya dvyāḍhake'pāṃ vipācayet||52||  pādaśeṣe ghṛtaprasthaṃ laśunasya rasaṃ tathā|  kolamūlakavṛkṣāmlamātuluṅgārdrakai rasaiḥ||53||  dāḍimāmbusurāmastukāñjikāmlaistadardhikaiḥ|  sādhayettriphalādārulavaṇavyoṣadīpyakaiḥ||54||  yavānīcavyahiṅgvamlavetasaiśca palārdhikaiḥ|  siddhametat pibecchūlagulmārśojaṭharāpaham||55||  bradhnapāṇḍvāmayaplīhayonidoṣajvarakṛmīn|  vātaśleṣmāmayān sarvānunmādāṃścāpakarṣati||56||  ityaparaṃ laśunādyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: With thirty-six roots of garlic, one should prepare a remedy to counter eighty types of afflictions that cause fear. The remaining portion of this preparation, when mixed with an equal amount of ghee (clarified butter) and the juice of fresh garlic, can be used to alleviate various ailments such as those of the spleen, phlegm, wind, bile, etc. Furthermore, by adding juices of kolamula, vrikshamla, tulunga, ardraka, dāḍima (pomegranate), ambu (water-lily), surā (liquor), kāñjika (a type of sour drink), triphala (three myrobalans), āmalaki (Indian gooseberry), vaṇa (forest herbs), lavana (salt), vyañjana (spices), and pala (fruit juice), one can create a concoction that eliminates doshas like krimi (worm infestation) and jvara (fever). Such is another use of garlic and ghee.

sloka: hiṅgunā hiṅguparṇyā ca sakāyasthavayaḥsthayā|  siddhaṃ sarpirhitaṃ tadvadvayaḥsthāhiṅgucorakaiḥ||57||  kevalaṃ siddhamebhirvā purāṇaṃ pāyayedghṛtam|  pāyayitvottamāṃ mātrāṃ śvabhre rundhyādgṛhe'pi vā||58||  viśeṣataḥ purāṇaṃ ca ghṛtaṃ taṃ pāyayedbhiṣak|  tridoṣaghnaṃ pavitratvādviśeṣādgrahanāśanam||59||  guṇakarmādhikaṃ pānādāsvādāt kaṭutiktakam|  ugragandhaṃ purāṇaṃ syāddaśavarṣasthitaṃ ghṛtam||60||  lākṣārasanibhaṃ śītaṃ taddhi sarvagrahāpaham|  medhyaṃ virecaneṣvagryaṃ prapurāṇamataḥ param||61||  nāsādhyaṃ nāma tasyāsti yat syādvarṣaśatasthitam|  dṛṣṭaṃ spṛṣṭamathāghrātaṃ taddhi sarvagrahāpaham||62||  apasmāragrahonmādavatāṃ śastaṃ viśeṣataḥ|63|
translation: By sipping ghee endowed with the qualities of hiingu (asafoetida), it becomes beneficial for the very body (sakāya) and eliminates disorders; it is especially purifying and disease-destroying if it has been aged. The ancient ghee, with a taste similar to lac (lākṣāra) and naturally cool, removes all afflictions and is the best among medicines. If consumed for a hundred years, it becomes difficult to obtain, and is called the remover of all afflictions (sarvagrahapaham). It is destructive for those suffering from insanity, epilepsy, and other such diseases.

sloka: etānauṣadhayogān vā vidheyatvamagacchati||63||  añjanotsādanālepanāvanādiṣu yojayet|  śirīṣo madhukaṃ hiṅgu laśunaṃ tagaraṃ vacā||64||  kuṣṭhaṃ ca bastamūtreṇa piṣṭaṃ syānnāvanāñjanam|  tadvadvyoṣaṃ haridre dve mañjiṣṭhāhiṅgusarṣapāḥ||65||  śirīṣabījaṃ conmādagrahāpasmāranāśanam|  piṣṭvā tulyamapāmārgaṃ  hiṅgvālaṃ hiṅgupatrikām||66||  vārtiḥ syānmaricārdhāṃśā pittābhyāṃ gośṛgālayoḥ|  tayā'ñjayedapasmārabhūtonmādajvarārditān||67||  bhūtārtānamarārtāṃśca narāṃścaiva dṛgāmaye|  maricaṃ cātape māṃsaṃ sapittaṃ sthitamañjanam||68||  vaikṛtaṃ paśyataḥ kāryaṃ doṣabhūtahatasmṛteḥ|  siddhārthako vacā hiṅgu karañjo devadāru ca||69||  mañjiṣṭhā triphalā śvetā kaṭabhītvak kaṭutrikam|  samāṃśāni priyaṅguśca śirīṣo rajanīdvayam||70||  bastamūtreṇa piṣṭo'yamagadaḥ pānamañjanam|  nasyamālepanaṃ caiva snānamudvartanaṃ tathā||71||  apasmāraviṣonmādakṛtyālakṣmījvarāpahaḥ|  bhūtebhyaśca bhayaṃ hanti rājadvāre ca śasyate||72||  sarpiretena siddhaṃ vā sagomūtraṃ tadarthakṛt|  praseke pīnase gandhairdhūmavartiṃ kṛtāṃ pibet||73||  vairecanikadhūmoktaiḥ śvetādyairvā sahiṅgubhiḥ|  śallakolūkamārjārajambūkavṛkabastajaiḥ||74||  mūtrapittaśakṛllomanakhaiścarmabhireva ca|  sekāñjanaṃ pradhamanaṃ nasyaṃ dhūmaṃ ca kārayet||75||  vātaśleṣmātmake prāyaḥ ...|76|
translation:
In these therapeutic regimens of combined medicines, one should administer:
