In collyrium concoctions, anointments, and washes, among others, apply aloe, black gram, and a powder derived from liquorice juice, kushta, and bitter salt, together with haridra and manjishtha juices.
The seed of shirisha treats insanity and memory loss, while an equal parts powder of licorice and sesame seeds can be utilized similarly.
An eighth portion each of black pepper, go-shrunga, and trikatu combined with a quarter of manjishtha, shveta, kaṭabhi, tvak, and kaṭutraya should be ground together, mixed with shirisha juice, and taken internally for medicinal purposes.
This is recommended for treating epilepsy, fainting, fever, and various human ailments, using long pepper, meat, pitta, and sthitam añjanam.
Observe the appropriate time and dosage, considering the patient's nature and physical condition before administering, to avoid any adverse effects such as fear or misfortune at the royal court.
Correctly prepared sagomūtra, used appropriately, can address various conditions caused by vata, kapha, and pitta doshas.
Employ gomūtra, dhūma, and other substances for nasya and nasyamālepana, beneficial in treating epilepsy, fainting, fever, and disorders caused by mūtra, pitta, loma, nakha, and carma.
Grind all these components, then prepare sekāñjana, nasya, dhūma, etc., as required for various ailments.
This is generally applicable in cases of vata, kapha, pitta doshas...

sloka: ... paittike tu praśasyate|  tiktakaṃ jīvanīyaṃ ca sarpiḥ snehaśca miśrakaḥ||76||  śītāni cānnapānāni madhurāṇi mṛdūni  ca|  śaṅkhakeśāntasandhau vā mokṣayejjño bhiṣak sirām|  unmāde viṣame caiva jvare'pasmāra eva ca||77||
translation: For a feverish patient, the knowledgeable physician should administer cool, sweet, and soothing drinks at the juncture of shell and hair (possibly a specific location or medicinal ingredient). In cases of unconsciousness, poisoning, delirium, or seizures, they should provide treatment as well.

sloka: ghṛtamāṃsavitṛptaṃ vā nivāte sthāpayet sukham|  tyaktvā matismṛtibhraṃśaṃ sañjñāṃ labdhvā pramucyate  ||78||
translation: Having eaten food containing ghee and having been satisfactorily filled, or even without it, one should establish oneself comfortably in a secluded place. After giving up the forgetfulness of one's resolve and obtaining mindfulness, one becomes liberated.

sloka: āśvāsayet suhṛdvā taṃ vākyairdharmārthasaṃhitaiḥ|  brūyādiṣṭavināśaṃ vā darśayedadbhutāni vā||79||  baddhaṃ sarṣapatailāktaṃ nyasedvottānamātape|  kapikacchvā'thavā taptairlohatailajalaiḥ spṛśet||80||  kaśābhistāḍayitvā vā subaddhaṃ vijane gṛhe|  rundhyācceto hi vibhrāntaṃ vrajatyasya tathā śamam||81||  sarpeṇoddhṛtadaṃṣṭreṇa dāntaiḥ siṃhairgajaiśca tam|  trāsayecchastrahastairvā taskaraiḥ śatrubhistathā||82||  athavā rājapuruṣā bahirnītvā susaṃyatam|  trāsayeyurvadhenainaṃ tarjayanto nṛpājñayā||83||  dehaduḥkhabhayebhyo hi paraṃ prāṇabhayaṃ smṛtam|  tena yāti śamaṃ tasya sarvato viplutaṃ manaḥ||84||
translation:
Console a well-wisher with words that harmonize with dharma and artha. Inform him of the preservation of what he cherishes; show him marvels; bind him with a paste made from safflower and sesame oil. Place him in a secure house, confined with ropes. Gently strike him with a small piece of wood. Once he is subdued, lead him to tranquility.

With a snake's fang that has been removed, tamed lions and elephants should intimidate him. Alternatively, great kings may drive him away using weapons or threaten him through royal authority. The fear of bodily distress is remembered as surpassing the fear of death itself, thus, through these means, his mind becomes pacified in all ways.

sloka: iṣṭadravyavināśāttu mano yasyopahanyate|  tasya tatsadṛśaprāptisāntvāśvāsaiḥ śamaṃ nayet||85||  kāmaśokabhayakrodhaharṣerṣyālobhasambhavān|  parasparapratidvandvairebhireva śamaṃ nayet||86||
translation:
When someone's mind is disturbed by the loss of cherished possessions, one should bring about peace by soothing and controlling the breath, similar to how one attains something comparable. (85)
In regard to the six emotions that arise from desire, sorrow, fear, anger, joy, and envy, one should individually pacify each pair of opposites. (86)

sloka: buddhvā deśaṃ vayaḥ sātmyaṃ doṣaṃ kālaṃ balābale|  cikitsitamidaṃ kuryādunmāde bhūtadoṣaje||87||
translation: Having comprehended the location, one's own age, temperament, faults, time, and relative strength, one should apply this remedy to treat a mental illness and its underlying root cause, being vigilant against influences from adverse elements.

sloka: devarṣipitṛgandharvairunmattasya tu buddhimān|  varjayedañjanādīni tīkṣṇāni krūrakarma ca||88||   sarpiṣpānādi tasyeha mṛdu bhaiṣajyamācaret|  pūjāṃ balyupahārāṃśca mantrāñjanavidhīṃstathā||89||   śāntikarmeṣṭihomāṃśca japasvastyayanāni ca|  vedoktān niyamāṃścāpi prāyaścittāni cācaret||90||
translation: The wise individual, unmoved by gods, seers, and ancestors in their divine states, should reject sharp and cruel substances, instead opting for gentle medicinal remedies such as ghee and butter. The learned one must perform rituals like worship, offerings, mantra application, as well as peace offerings, propitiations, and fire sacrifices according to the Vedic instructions. They must adhere to the rules, regulations, and atonements as outlined in the Vedas, together with recitation, well-being, and other practices.

sloka: bhūtānāmadhipaṃ devamīśvaraṃ jagataḥ prabhum|  pūjayan prayato nityaṃ jayatyunmādajaṃ bhayam||91||
translation: By daily worshiping devotionally the divine lord of beings, the god of gods, the ruler of the universe, and the imperishable one, one overcomes the delusion and fear that arise from intoxication.

sloka: rudrasya pramathā nāma gaṇā loke caranti ye|  teṣāṃ pūjāṃ ca kurvāṇa unmādebhyaḥ pramucyate||92||
translation: Those who in this world are known as the attendants of Rudra, by worshiping them, one is liberated from delusion and madness.

sloka: balibhirmaṅgalairhomairoṣadhyagadadhāraṇaiḥ|  satyācāratapojñānapradānaniyamavrataiḥ||93||  devagobrahmaṇānāṃ ca gurūṇāṃ pūjanena ca|  āgantuḥ praśamaṃ yāti siddhairmantrauṣadhaistathā||94||
translation:
With offerings made by faithful hands, auspicious symbols, medicinal herbs, and knowledgeable handling of remedies,
and through adhering to truth, right action, penance, wisdom, giving, discipline, and vows,
you may appease uninvited guests, as well as the gods, brahmanas, and revered teachers,
through powerful mantras and healing herbs. (93-94)

sloka: yaccopadekṣyate kiñcidapasmāracikitsite|  unmāde tacca kartavyaṃ sāmānyāddhetudūṣyayoḥ||95||
translation: Understood as a treatment for epilepsy, that which is indicated should certainly be done; this is the remedial action to be carried out, having discerned the cause. This is the general rule for both remedy and deterrent.

sloka: nivṛttāmiṣamadyo yo hitāśī prayataḥ śuciḥ|  nijāgantubhirunmādaiḥ sattvavān na sa yujyate||96||
translation: One who has abandoned meat and alcohol , is benevolent , diligent , and pure ; who is free from hypocrisy and guided by truthfulness ; such a self-controlled man of noble character is not to be associated with .

sloka: prasādaścendriyārthanāṃ buddhyātmamanasāṃ tathā|  dhātūnāṃ prakṛtisthatvaṃ vigatonmādalakṣaṇam||97||
translation: The grace of sense objects for sentient beings is due to the discriminative power of the intellect-self and mind; similarly, the inherent nature of the elements is characterized by being devoid of delusion.

sloka: tatra ślokaḥ  unmādānāṃ samutthānaṃ lakṣaṇaṃ sacikitsitam|  nijāgantunimittānāmuktavān bhiṣaguttamaḥ||98||
translation: In that context, the best physician skillfully diagnoses the emergence of intoxication by identifying its external causes, having been freed from their influences.

sloka: athātaḥ pramehacikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1|| iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: Now we shall explain the desired treatment of self-knowledge. This is what the revered Ātreyah declared.

sloka: nirmohamānānuśayo nirāśaḥ punarvasurjñānatapoviśālaḥ|  kāle'gniveśāya sahetuliṅgānuvāca mehāñśamanaṃ ca teṣām||3||
translation: Having freed yourself from delusion and infatuation, devoid of attachment, once again becoming dispassionate, vast in knowledge and austerities, O Vasu, you addressed me, seeking self-control and tranquility for those (monks).

sloka: āsyāsukhaṃ svapnasukhaṃ dadhīni grāmyaudakānūparasāḥ payāṃsi|  navānnapānaṃ guḍavaikṛtaṃ ca pramehahetuḥ kaphakṛcca sarvam||4||
translation: The transient joy derived from eating food and the pleasure of sleep arise from the combination of external water and internal liquids, as well as new digestion caused by consuming food and drink, and the accumulation of kapha (phlegm). All of these together constitute the cause of diabetes.

sloka: medaśca māṃsaṃ ca śarīrajaṃ ca kledaṃ kapho bastigataṃ pradūṣya| karoti mehān samudīrṇamuṣṇaistāneva pittaṃ paridūṣya cāpi||5|| kṣīṇeṣu doṣeṣvavakṛṣya bastau dhātūn pramehānanilaḥ karoti|  doṣo hi bastiṃ samupetya mūtraṃ sandūṣya mehāñjanayedyathāsvam||6||
translation: The bile,, along with fat and bodily fluids, causes inflammation when it corrupts them. Similarly, when it is drawn from the excreta, after being situated in the weakened bodily humors, it causes urine to flow and produce pus, just as it naturally does.

sloka: sādhyāḥ kaphotthā daśa pittajāḥ ṣaṭ yāpyā na sādhyaḥ pavanāccatuṣkaḥ||  samakriyatvādviṣamakriyatvānmahātyayatvācca yathākramaṃ  te||7||
translation: The ten Kapha-related disorders and the six Pitta-related disorders , which can be treated , as well as the four Vata-related ones that cannot be treated , should be treated in a timely manner according to their severity .

sloka: kaphaḥ sapittaḥ pavanaśca doṣā medo'sraśukrāmbuvasālasīkāḥ|  majjā rasaujaḥ piśitaṃ ca dūṣyāḥ[1] pramehiṇāṃ viṃśatireva mehāḥ||8||
translation: Of the twenty kinds of impurities, the salty, windy, bile-related, phlegm-related, sweat-related, urine-related, and excrement-related ones are the ones that primarily taint the bodies of living beings.

sloka: jalopamaṃ cekṣurasopamaṃ vā ghanaṃ ghanaṃ copari viprasannam|  śuklaṃ saśukraṃ śiśiraṃ śanairvā lāleva vā vālukayā yutaṃ vā||9||  vidyāt pramehān  kaphajān daśaitān
translation: Learn, in brief, of the ten qualities pertaining to kapha: like water or as clear as sugarcane juice, dense and cloud-like, located above the priest and shining brightly; pure, seminal, and cool; gradually approaching like a crawling insect, combined with grains of pollen.

sloka: kṣāropamaṃ kālamathāpi nīlam|  hāridramāñjiṣṭhamathāpi raktametān pramehān ṣaḍuśanti pittāt||10||
translation: Just as alkali wears down time in the same way, even now; similarly, bile neutralizes the six causes of impure thoughts, namely those tinged blue, yellow, or red.

sloka: majjaujasā vā vasayā'nvitaṃ vā lasīkayā vā satataṃ vibaddham|  caturvidhaṃ mūtrayatīha[1] vātāccheṣeṣu dhātuṣvapakarṣiteṣu||11||
translation: Bound either constantly by desire, habit, or through rash actions, a person is always ensnared, releasing four types of impurities into the subsiding elements of air, etc., that are being drawn out.

sloka: varṇaṃ rasaṃ sparśamathāpi gandhaṃ yathāsvadoṣaṃ bhajate pramehaḥ|  śyāvāruṇo vātakṛtaḥ saśūlo majjādisādguṇyamupaityasādhyaḥ||12||
translation: Even a colorblind person enjoys taste, touch, and scent just like a normal person does; similarly, this incurable disease called "prameha" (possibly diabetes) affects a person who has a combination of black and tawny colors, which is produced by wind and possesses qualities associated with marrow, etc. I, using the imperative form, make/become black and tawny too.

sloka: svedo'ṅgagandhaḥ śithilāṅgatā ca śayyāsanasvapnasukhe ratiśca|  hṛnnetrajihvāśravaṇopadeho ghanāṅgatā keśanakhātivṛddhiḥ||13|| śītapriyatvaṃ galatāluśoṣo mādhuryamāsye karapādadāhaḥ|  bhaviṣyato mehagadasya rūpaṃ mūtre'bhidhāvanti pipīlikāśca||14||
translation: The originating perspiration from my body, fragrant with its pleasant smell; the relaxation of the limbs; the pleasure derived from lying down, sitting, and sleeping; the attraction towards sense objects such as sight, taste, and hearing; the firmness of the body; the growth of hair, nails, and complexion; coolness, lightness, bitterness, astringency, and dryness; sweetness on the tongue; burning sensations in the hands and feet - all these constitute my future form as described in the Vedic hymns. Insects rush towards the sound of its utterance.

sloka: sthūlaḥ pramehī balavānihaikaḥ kṛśastathaikaḥ paridurbalaśca|  sambṛṃhaṇaṃ tatra kṛśasya kāryaṃ saṃśodhanaṃ doṣabalādhikasya||15||  snigdhasya yogā vividhāḥ prayojyāḥ kalpopadiṣṭā malaśodhanāya[1] | ūrdhvaṃ tathā'dhaśca male'panīte meheṣu santarpaṇameva kāryam||16||
translation: The gross element should be excited, while the lean one should be cleansed; for the one with more impurities than strength, various yogic practices should be applied; and scraping should be done for the weak one. In the case of the lean one, activation is to be done. Additionally, in the upward and downward flow of impurities in the channels, retention alone is to be practiced.

sloka: gulmaḥ kṣayo mehanabastiśūlaṃ mūtragrahaścāpyapatarpaṇena|  pramehiṇaḥ syuḥ paritarpaṇāni[2] kāryāṇi tasya[3] prasamīkṣya vahnim||17||
translation: For my ailments such as bloating , indigestion , constipation , abdominal tumor , and the urge to urinate , as well as other similar symptoms, one should carefully examine this person’s condition. Once observed, one should determine and carry out the necessary treatments for alleviating them, while considering the state of their digestive fire .

sloka: saṃśodhanaṃ nārhati yaḥ pramehī tasya kriyā saṃśamanī prayojyā|
translation: One who is unfit (for the process of purification) should not be made to undergo such a treatment, for his actions will surely be brought under control.

sloka: manthāḥ kaṣāyā yavacūrṇalehāḥ pramehaśāntyai laghavaśca bhakṣyāḥ||18|| ye viṣkirā ye pratudā vihaṅgāsteṣāṃ rasairjāṅgalajairmanojñaiḥ|  yavaudanaṃ rūkṣamathāpi vāṭyamadyāt[1] sasaktūnapi cāpyapūpān||19||  mudgādiyūṣairatha tiktaśākaiḥ purāṇaśālyodanamādadīta|  dantīṅgudītailayutaṃ pramehī tathā'tasīsarṣapatailayuktam||20||  saṣaṣṭikaṃ syāttṛṇadhānyamannaṃ yavapradhānastu bhavet pramehī|  yavasya bhakṣyān vividhāṃstathā'dyāt kaphapramehī madhusamprayuktān||21||
translation: "Barley, when ground into powder and mixed with fluids, promotes urination and is easy to digest. Likewise, an ancient rice dish, seasoned with a variety of spices such as pepper and salt, or lentils, or a concoction of bitter, astringent, and pungent tastes, or a preparation of sesame seeds and jaggery, or a beverage made from liquorice, or a gruel made from roasted barley flour, all help eliminate Kapha-related impurities. Furthermore, various other dishes derived from barley can also be consumed."

sloka: niśisthitānāṃ triphalākaṣāye syustarpaṇāḥ kṣaudrayutā yavānām|  tān sīdhuyuktān prapibet pramehī prāyogikānmehavadhārthameva||22||
translation: Of the mature pipal tree, established in its location, offering twigs yoked with grains, one should consume those that are processed and infused with medicinal decoction, which are combined with good health as their sole purpose.

sloka: ye śleṣmamehe vihitāḥ kaṣāyāstairbhāvitānāṃ ca pṛthagyavānām|  saktūnapūpān saguḍān sadhānān bhakṣyāṃstathā'nyān vividhāṃśca khādet||23||
translation: Who, for those imbued with impurities, have been prescribed by the scriptures specific foods like pungent, bitter, astringent tastes, grains, legumes, fruits, and vegetables, as well as other various kinds, to be consumed individually.

sloka: kharāśvagohaṃsapṛṣadbhṛtānāṃ tathā yavānāṃ vividhāśca bhakṣyāḥ|  deyāstathā veṇuyavā yavānāṃ kalpena godhūmamayāśca bhakṣyāḥ||24||
translation: Of kharas, horses, and geese that are fed, as well as various kinds of barley food, similarly of other grains; likewise, venus and barley are to be given through the godhuma custom.

sloka: saṃśodhanollekhanalaṅghanāni kāle prayuktāni kaphapramehān|  jayanti pittaprabhavān virekaḥ santarpaṇaḥ saṃśamano vidhiśca||25||
translation: In due course, the practices of purgation , elevation , and elimination , when properly employed at the appropriate time , lead to the aggravation of bile-related conditions while alleviating phlegm-related ailments; this is the prescribed method , as well as the pacification of both.

sloka: dārvīṃ surāhvāṃ triphalāṃ samustāṃ kaṣāyamutkvāthya pibet pramehī| kṣaudreṇa yuktāmathavā haridrāṃ pibedrasenāmalakīphalānām||26||
translation: One should drink the powder of triphala, made from three fruits, prepared by boiling it in water, from a dārvī cup, to eliminate sluggishness. Alternatively, one can also consume haridrā, mixed with water, or the juice of āmalakī fruits, prepared by crushing them.

sloka: harītakīkaṭphalamustalodhraṃ pāṭhāviḍaṅgārjunadhanvanāśca| ubhe haridre tagaraṃ viḍaṅgaṃ kadambaśālārjunadīpyakāśca||27|| dārvī viḍaṅgaṃ khadiro dhavaśca surāhvakuṣṭhāgurucandanāni|  dārvyagnimanthau triphalā sapāṭhā pāṭhā ca mūrvā ca tathā śvadaṃṣṭrā||28|| yavānyuśīrāṇyabhayāguḍūcīcavyābhayācitrakasaptaparṇāḥ|  pādaiḥ kaṣāyāḥ kaphamehināṃ te daśopadiṣṭā madhusamprayuktāḥ||29||

uśīralodhrāñjanacandanānāmuśīramustā malakābhayānām|  paṭolanimbāmalakāmṛtānāṃ mustābhayāpadmakavṛkṣakāṇām||30|| lodhrāmbukālīyakadhātakīnāṃ nimbārjunāmrātaniśotpalānām| śirīṣasarjārjunakeśarāṇāṃ priyaṅgupadmotpalakiṃśukānām||31|| aśvatthapāṭhāsanavetasānāṃ kaṭaṅkaṭeryutpalamustakānām|  paitteṣu meheṣu daśa pradiṣṭāḥ pādaiḥ kaṣāyā madhusamprayuktāḥ||32||
sarveṣu meheṣu matau tu pūrvau kaṣāyayogau vihitāstu sarve|  manthasya pāne yavabhāvanāyāṃ syurbhojane pānavidhau pṛthak ca||33||
translation: In all my habits, the two earlier prescribed austerities are established; in the contemplation of milk-consumption, there should be distinct rules for partaking and drinking.

sloka: siddhāni tailāni ghṛtāni caiva deyāni meheṣvanilātmakeṣu|  medaḥ kaphaścaiva kaṣāyayogaiḥ snehaiśca vāyuḥ śamameti teṣām||34||
translation: To those capable ones, sesame-derived oil and cow milk ghee should be offered as gifts, for through their anointment, the bodily humors of phlegm and fat, together with the wind, get pacified by the balancing action of these substances.

sloka: kampillasaptacchadaśālajāni  baibhītarauhītakakauṭajāni|  kapitthapuṣpāṇi ca cūrṇitāni kṣaudreṇa lihyāt kaphapittamehī||35||  pibedrasenāmalakasya cāpi kalkīkṛtānyakṣasamāni kāle|  jīrṇe ca bhuñjīta purāṇamannaṃ mehī rasairjāṅgalajairmanojñaiḥ||36||
translation: At an appropriate time, consume fruits of the Kapitha tree, shaken from their stalks and split, cleaned carefully with a small amount of water. Also, consume bitter and astringent fruits that alleviate kapha and pitta imbalances. When they have aged, consume grains relishing their ancient flavors and finding satisfaction in them.

sloka: dṛṣṭvā'nubandhaṃ pavanāt kaphasya pittasya vā snehavidhirvikalpyaḥ|  tailaṃ kaphe syāt svakaṣāyasiddhaṃ pitte ghṛtaṃ pittaharaiḥ kaṣāyaiḥ||37||
translation: After observing the bondage of phlegm caused by wind or the elimination of excess phlegm and bile, one should apply oil in cases of phlegm aggravation; in order to pacify kapha dosha, clarified butter should be used in cases of bile aggravation.

sloka: trikaṇṭakāśmantakasomavalkairbhallātakaiḥ sātiviṣaiḥ salodhraiḥ|  vacāpaṭolārjunanimbamustairharidrayā[1] padmakadīpyakaiśca||38|| mañjiṣṭhayā cāgurucandanaiśca sarvaiḥ samastaiḥ kaphavātajeṣu|  meheṣu  tailaṃ vipaced ghṛtaṃ tu paitteṣu miśraṃ triṣu lakṣaṇeṣu||39||
translation: With licorice (Mañjiṣṭhā), aguru, and candana, together with all remedies for phlegm- and wind-related disorders, the oil is extracted in the first of the three descriptions. The ghee is churned separately in the other two.

sloka: phalatrikaṃ dāruniśāṃ viśālāṃ mustāṃ ca niḥkvāthya niśāṃ sakalkām|  pibet kaṣāyaṃ madhusamprayuktaṃ sarvaprameheṣu samuddhateṣu||40||
translation: From the trees and large mustard seeds, having extracted the ripe fruits and mustard seeds at night, one should drink this concoction: the kaṣāya herbs mixed with honey, in all ailments as they manifest.

sloka: lodhraṃ śaṭīṃ puṣkaramūlamelāṃ mūrvāṃ  viḍaṅgaṃ triphalāṃ yamānīm|  cavyaṃ priyaṅguṃ kramukaṃ viśālāṃ kirātatiktaṃ kaṭurohiṇīṃ ca||41||  bhārṅgīṃ nataṃ citrakapippalīnāṃ mūlaṃ sakuṣṭhātiviṣaṃ sapāṭham|  kaliṅgakan keśaramindrasāhvāṃ nakhaṃ sapatraṃ maricaṃ plavaṃ ca||42||  droṇe'mbhasaḥ karṣasamāni paktvā pūte caturbhāgajalāvaśeṣe| rase'rdhabhāgaṃ madhunaḥ pradāya pakṣaṃ nidheyo ghṛtabhājanasthaḥ||43||
translation: The roots of puṣkara, lodhrā, śaṭī, mūrvā, viḍaṅga, triphala, yamānī, cavya, priyaṅgu, kramuka, and viśālā; the kirāta type of kaṭurohṇī, bhārṅgī, natā, citraka, pippalīna's root, sakuṣṭha+tiṣa, pāṭha, kaliṅga keśara, indrasāhvā, nakha, marica, and plava; after being cooked in four portions of pure water, drained of its water content, mixed with the top portion of honey, placed in a ghṛta-bhājana - this is the preparation process for the medicinal paste.

sloka: madhvāsavo'yaṃ[1] kaphapittamehān kṣipraṃ nihanyāddvipalaprayogāt|  pāṇḍvāmayārśāṃsyaruciṃ grahaṇyā doṣaṃ kilāsaṃ vividhaṃ ca kuṣṭham||44||  iti madhvāsavaḥ|
translation: "Thus teaches Madhvasa: 'Eradicate quickly this Kaphapittameha, Dvipala's remedy being efficacious for it. Similarly, eliminate disorders such as Pandu, Arshas, and various forms of Kushta, as well as Grahana Dosha.'""

sloka: kvāthaḥ sa evāṣṭapalaṃ ca dantyā bhallātakānāṃ ca catuṣpalaṃ syāt|  sitopalā tvaṣṭapalā viśeṣaḥ kṣaudraṃ ca tāvat pṛthagāsavau tau||45||
translation: Where indeed, at this very moment, can one find both the eight-armed one and the four-ballistic one, as there are distinct cups of sugar and ghee, along with a mere portion of ordinary liquid?

sloka: sārodakaṃ vā'tha kuśodakaṃ vā  madhūdakaṃ vā triphalārasaṃ vā|  sīdhuṃ pibedvā nigadaṃ pramehī mādhvīkamagryaṃ cirasaṃsthitaṃ vā||46||
translation: One may sip either pure water, or water mixed with kusha grass, or honey, or a drink made from the extract of three fruits. This indeed leads to steadfastness, quenches excessive thirst, and eliminates impurities, as per the ancient texts.

sloka: māṃsāni śūlyāni mṛgadvijānāṃ khādedyavānāṃ vividhāṃśca bhakṣyān|  saṃśodhanāriṣṭakaṣāyalehaiḥ santarpaṇotthāñ śamayet pramehān||47||
translation: One who consumes the flesh of various animals and birds, be it sporadic or routine, ought to pacify and regulate the resulting imbalances in bodily humors using an array of purifying and tranquilizing agents.

sloka: bhṛṣṭān yavān bhakṣayataḥ prayogācchuṣkāṃśca saktūnna bhavanti mehāḥ|  śvitraṃ ca kṛcchraṃ kaphajaṃ ca kuṣṭhaṃ tathaiva mudgāmalakaprayogān||48||
translation: "Consuming inadequately threshed barley makes one's urine thin, while also causing roughness; similarly, such consumption can lead to the emergence of rough husks.'Just as using mudga and āmalaka (types of pulses) can result in skin disorders such as leprosy, as well as other ailments associated with an imbalance of kapha (phlegm)."

sloka: santarpaṇottheṣu gadeṣu yogā medasvināṃ ye ca mayopadiṣṭāḥ|  virūkṣaṇārthaṃ kaphapittajeṣu siddhāḥ prameheṣvapi te prayojyāḥ||49||
translation: In cases of inflammation affecting obese individuals, the yoga practices that I have taught should be applied even in conditions related to phlegm and bile. These practices are accomplished and will be useful in such ailments.

sloka: vyāyāmayogairvividhaiḥ pragāḍhairudvartanaiḥ snānajalāvasekaiḥ| sevyatvagelāgurucandanādyairvilepanaiścāśu[1] na santi mehāḥ||50||
translation: With diverse, sophisticated yoga practices, profound obeisances, and ablutions with water, I am not quickly irritated when regularly served with sandalwood paste, etc., and the respectful attention of a teacher, as there are no signs of anger in me.

sloka: kledaśca medaśca kaphaśca vṛddhaḥ pramehahetuḥ prasamīkṣya tasmāt|  vaidyena pūrvaṃ kaphapittajeṣu meheṣu kāryāṇyapatarpaṇāni||51||
translation: Perceiving that phlegm, exudation, and old age are its causes, a wise physician should first attend to eliminating the root of ailments related to the bile and phlegm, as indicated by the context of the passage.

sloka: yā vātamehān prati pūrvamuktā vātolbaṇānāṃ vihitā kriyā sā|  vāyurhi meheṣvatikarśitānāṃ kupyatyasādhyān prati nāsti cintā||52||
translation: The wind, previously ordained as the foremost action of the fierce, agitates those who are weakened in their vital energies. As for the unattainable, there is no cause for anxiety.

sloka: yairhetubhirye prabhavanti mehāsteṣu prameheṣu na te niṣevyāḥ|  hetorasevā vihitā yathaiva jātasya rogasya bhaveccikitsā||53||
translation: By what causes are these manifestations of mine present in these living beings, not to be adopted, just as serving a prescribed course of treatment is appropriate for an already established disease.

sloka: hāridravarṇaṃ rudhiraṃ ca mūtraṃ vinā pramehasya hi pūrvarūpaiḥ|  yo mūtrayettaṃ na vadet pramehaṃ raktasya pittasya hi sa prakopaḥ||54||
translation: The one who fails to mention pus or fluid resembling blood and urine, instead of the initial secretion, will bring on the rage of semen, redness in the eyes, and bile.

sloka: dṛṣṭvā pramehaṃ madhuraṃ sapicchaṃ madhūpamaṃ syāddvividho vicāraḥ|  kṣīṇeṣu doṣeṣvanilātmakaḥ syāt  santarpaṇādvā kaphasambhavaḥ syāt||55||
translation: Upon observing a diabetes mellitus that is sweet and prized , resembling madhu, two considerations arise: when the wind-like symptoms weaken , it may suggest a decrease in the presence of dosha; alternatively, it could indicate the development of kapha due to heightened feelings of attachment .

sloka: sapūrvarūpāḥ kaphapittamehāḥ krameṇa ye vātakṛtāśca mehāḥ| sādhyā na te pittakṛtāstu yāpyāḥ sādhyāstu medo  yadi na praduṣṭam||56||
translation: Those, endowed with a balanced constitution of phlegm and bile since birth, who are later affected by disorders caused by imbalanced wind, their bile-related ailments can be treated. But, if there is an increase in fat tissue, it must not be corrupted, for those ailments caused by it can be treated, provided the fat increase is not already tainted.

sloka: jātaḥ pramehī madhumehino vā na sādhya uktaḥ sa  hi  bījadoṣāt|  ye  cāpi  kecit  kulajā  vikārā  bhavanti  tāṃśca pravadantyasādhyān||57||
translation: One who is born with or affected by a hereditary defect, be it minor or major , is considered incurable . Furthermore, any inheritable abnormalities that may arise are also classified as incurable . This is declared as an irrefutable truth .

sloka: pramehiṇāṃ yāḥ piḍakā mayoktā rogādhikāre pṛthageva sapta|  tāḥ śalyavidbhiḥ kuśalaiścikitsyāḥ  śastreṇa saṃśodhanaropaṇaiśca||58||
translation: The seven diseases, specifically identified by the expert [Pramehahara] as being associated with an enlarged spleen and excess fluid, should be skillfully treated by knowledgeable physicians using surgical methods such as excision and evacuation.

sloka: tatra ślokāḥ  heturdoṣo dūṣyaṃ mehānāṃ sādhyatānurūpaśca|  mehī dvividhastrividhaṃ[1] bhiṣagjitamatikṣapaṇadoṣaḥ||59|| ādyā yavānnavikṛtirmanthā mehāpahāḥ kaṣāyāśca|  tailaghṛtalehayogā bhakṣyāḥ pravarāsavāḥ siddhāḥ||60||  vyāyāmavidhirvividhaḥ snānānyudvartanāni gandhāśca|  mehānāṃ praśamārthaṃ cikitsite diṣṭametāvat||61||
translation: The initial treatment for disorders of fluids lies in the appropriate use of foods and drinks, such as properly prepared barley and wheat, which eliminate impurities and excess water. Additionally, oils, ghee, soups, wholesome beverages, condiments, and spices are recommended for alleviating fluid-related issues. This is what is appropriate for treating fluids.

sloka: athāto grahaṇīdoṣacikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: Now, we will explain the remedy for the disorder of grasping, as was previously stated by the revered Atreya.

sloka: āyurvarṇo balaṃ svāsthyamutsāhopacayau prabhā|  ojastejo'gnayaḥ prāṇāścoktā dehāgnihetukāḥ||3||
translation: Longevity, complexion, and strength, as well as health and digestive power, are all declared to be effects of the agni ("fire" or "digestive heat") within the body.

sloka: śānte'gnau mriyate yukte ciraṃ jīvatyanāmayaḥ|  rogī syādvikṛte mūlamagnistasmānnirucyate||4||
translation: In a state of tranquility, the one who has long been united with the sacrificial fire meets a death free from disease; identified as such, the disease-free one, when properly constituted, is described as 'the fire's root cause.'

sloka: yadannaṃ dehadhātvojobalavarṇādipoṣakam|  tatrāgnirheturāhārānna hyapakvādrasādayaḥ||5||
translation: When food serves as the nourisher of the body's physical components, it is fire that provides its cause, and unripe or ripened forms of food become its sustenance.

sloka: annamādānakarmā tu prāṇaḥ koṣṭhaṃ prakarṣati|  taddravairbhinnasaṅghātaṃ snehena mṛdutāṃ gatam||6||  samānenāvadhūto'gnirudaryaḥ pavanodvahaḥ|  kāle bhuktaṃ samaṃ samyak pacatyāyurvivṛddhaye||7||  evaṃ rasamalāyānnamāśayasthamadhaḥ sthitaḥ|  pacatyagniryathā sthālyāmodanāyāmbutaṇḍulam||8||
translation: The life force , indeed, expands the stomach by drawing in liquefied food that has been made gentle . Similarly, the digestive agent , located in the stomach along with water , digests food consumed at the appropriate time for maintaining health and promoting longevity . In the same manner, the digestive fire cooks soaked grains , causing them to swell , within the stomach container . Taste and other attributes of food undergo similar processing for the body's nourishment.

sloka: annasya bhuktamātrasya ṣaḍrasasya prapākataḥ|  madhurādyāt kapho bhāvāt phenabhūta  udīryate||9||
translation: The six tastes, after being consumed and fully digested, are manifested as phlegm due to their inherent quality of sweetness.

sloka: paraṃ tu pacyamānasya vidagdhasyāmlabhāvataḥ|  āśayāccyavamānasya pittamacchamudīryate||10||
translation: Indeed, for the discerning person, as they taste (examine) calmly, the true nature of the bitter behavior of the one who is intellectually agile becomes apparent, revealing their hidden inner qualities, for the reverential one's mind is uncovered.

sloka: pakvāśayaṃ tu prāptasya śoṣyamāṇasya vahninā|  paripiṇḍitapakvasya vāyuḥ syāt kaṭubhāvataḥ||11||
translation: Indeed, when the cooked food has become ready and is being dried by the agency of fire, then due to the sharpness of the air, it undergoes spoilage.

sloka: annamiṣṭaṃ hyupahitamiṣṭairgandhādibhiḥ pṛthak|  dehe prīṇāti gandhādīn ghrāṇādīnīndriyāṇi ca||12||
translation: "Indeed, properly prepared food, offered with added fragrances and such, separately gratifies, through their respective organs, the senses located within the body."

sloka: bhaumāpyāgneyavāyavyāḥ pañcoṣmāṇaḥ sanābhasāḥ|  pañcāhāraguṇānsvānsvānpārthivādīnpacanti hi||13||
translation: The five fires, specifically referring to the earth's fire, water's fire, the digestive fire, the wind, and the sun, indeed consume offerings made to them, each possessing their respective qualities. This applies to fires ranging from the earth to Indra.

sloka: yathāsvaṃ svaṃ ca puṣṇanti dehe dravyaguṇāḥ pṛthak|  pārthivāḥ pārthivāneva śeṣāḥ śeṣāṃśca kṛtsnaśaḥ||14||
translation: Just as individual material elements and qualities within the body sustain themselves, likewise, certain elements nourish other parts of the body completely, as do earthly elements nourish earthly components.

sloka: saptabhirdehadhātāro dhātavo dvividhaṃ punaḥ|  yathāsvamagnibhiḥ pākaṃ yānti kiṭṭaprasādavat ||15||
translation: The seven constituent principles of the body, designated as dhātāras, are of two distinct types, just as various cooking ingredients combine; similarly, they too integrate themselves into the body, in a manner akin to kiṭṭaprasāda (a type of cooked rice).

sloka: rasādraktaṃ tato māṃsaṃ māṃsānmedastato'sthi ca|  asthno majjā tataḥ śukraṃ śukrādgarbhaḥ prasādajaḥ||16||
translation: Derived from blood indeed is the flesh, then follows the fat; from this fat arises the bone, and from bones, the marrow; then from marrow, sustained by nourishment, emerges the embryo.

sloka: rasāt stanyaṃ tato raktamasṛjaḥ kaṇḍarāḥ sirāḥ|  māṃsādvasā tvacaḥ ṣaṭ ca medasaḥ snāyusambhavaḥ||17||
translation: Emerging from the fluid, what arises next is red blood; from flesh come muscles, tendons, and skin; from fat, six organs develop.

sloka: kiṭṭamannasya viṇmūtraṃ rasasya tu kapho'sṛjaḥ|  pittaṃ māṃsasya khamalā malaḥ svedastu medasaḥ||18||  syātkiṭṭaṃ keśalomāsthno majjñaḥ sneho'kṣiviṭtvacām|  prasādakiṭṭe dhātūnāṃ pākādevaṃvidharcchataḥ ||19||  parasparopasaṃstabdhā dhātusnehaparamparā |
translation: Of the body, what are the byproducts of phlegm , mucus , bile , and flesh ? What arises from hair , skin , and bones , as well as the fluids within the joints and marrow ? When they are properly combined , these constituents form a harmonious bond in the body, nourished by the internal fire that promotes their transformation . This is the natural process of bodily functions .

sloka: vṛṣyādīnāṃ prabhāvastu puṣṇāti balamāśu hi||20||
translation: Invigorates the strength of the herd animals instantly. (Referring to the future, as indicated by the use of the future passive participle "vṛṣyā")

sloka: ṣaḍbhiḥ kecidahorātrairicchanti parivartanam|  santatyā bhojyadhātūnāṃ parivṛttistu cakravat||21||
translation: Some select individuals engage in nourishment cycles using six days, whereas the cycle of sustenance for all consumable elements keeps happening continuously, analogous to a wheel.

sloka: (ityuktavantamācāryaṃ śiṣyastvidamacodayat|  rasādraktaṃ visadṛśāt kathaṃ dehe'bhijāyate||22||  rasasya ca na rāgo'sti sa kathaṃ yāti raktatām|  dravādraktātsthiraṃ māṃsaṃ kathaṃ tajjāyate nṛṇām||23||  dravadhātoḥ sthirānmāṃsānmedasaḥ sambhavaḥ katham|  ślakṣṇābhyāṃ māṃsamedobhyāṃ kharatvaṃ kathamasthiṣu||24||  khareṣvasthiṣu majjā ca kena snigdho mṛdustathā|  majjñaśca pariṇāmena yadi śukraṃ pravartate||25||  sarvadehagataṃ śukraṃ pravadanti manīṣiṇaḥ|  tathā'sthimadhyamajjñaśca śukraṃ bhavati dehinām||26||  chidraṃ na dṛśyate'sthnāṃ ca tanniḥsarati vā katham|
translation: "How can this fluid appear tinged red in the body?" "In what manner does semen arise from solidified flesh in humans?" "How do soft flesh and fat turn into hard bones?" "Under what circumstances do bones become the dwelling of marrow and fat?" "When fat and semen undergo transformation, how does hardness manifest in them?" "How can there be oiliness and softness in bones?" "Moreover, when semen transforms, how does it generate marrow within bones?" "Scholars maintain that semen exists throughout the body." "How does it exist in the middle of the bones?" "If there is no visible opening, then how does it depart from solid parts?"

sloka: evamuktastu śiṣyeṇa guruḥ prāhedamuttaram||27||  tejo rasānāṃ sarveṣāṃ manujānāṃ yaducyate|  pittoṣmaṇaḥ sa rāgeṇa raso raktatvamṛcchati||28||
translation: In this manner, addressed by the disciple, the teacher revealed what is superior: the vital essence of all people is called "pitta"; it becomes tinged with redness due to heat in the body. (evam uktastu śiṣyeṇa guruḥ prāhedamuttaram||27|| tejo rasānāṃ sarveṣāṃ manujānāṃ yaducyate| pittoṣmaṇaḥ sa rāgeṇa raso raktatvamṛcchati||28||)

sloka: vāyvambutejasā raktamūṣmaṇā cābhisaṃyutam|  sthiratāṃ prāpya māṃsaṃ syāt svoṣmaṇā pakvameva tat ||29||
translation: Becoming firmly established with vital air and heat, as well as the redness derived from water and fire, that fleshy substance becomes fully cooked by its own nature.

sloka: svatejo'mbuguṇasnigdhodriktaṃ medo'bhijāyate|
translation: From its own radiance and the water, combined with favorable qualities, fat becomes generated.

sloka: pṛthivyagnyanilādīnāṃ saṅghātaḥ svoṣmaṇā kṛtaḥ||30||  kharatvaṃ prakarotyasya jāyate'sthi tato nṛṇām|
translation: The combination of earth, fire, and wind, formed by its own heat, generates mobility in humans.

sloka: karoti tatra sauṣiryamasthnāṃ madhye samīraṇaḥ||31||  medasastāni pūryante sneho majjā tataḥ smṛtaḥ|
translation: There, in the very midst of charm, the breeze becomes active, filling the fatty portions with affection, as is remembered; the coolness (samirana) becoming manifest in the center of attractiveness (sausiryam sthanam), it fills those fatty parts (medasah tani) with love (sneha).

sloka: tasmānmajjñastu yaḥ snehaḥ śukraṃ sañjāyate tataḥ||32||  vāyvākāśādibhirbhāvaiḥ sauṣiryaṃ jāyate'sthiṣu|  tena sravati tacchukraṃ navāt kumbhādivodakam||33||  srotobhiḥ syandate dehāt samantācchukravāhibhiḥ |  harṣeṇodīritaṃ vegāt saṅkalpācca manobhavāt||34||  vilīnaṃ ghṛtavadvyāyāmoṣmaṇā sthānavicyutam|  bastau sambhṛtya niryāti sthalānnimnādivodakam)||35||
translation: Therefore, the one who is knowledgeable, from him affectionately arises semen; through vital airs and other existences, sexual desire is generated in bodies. Through this, the semen flows, becoming new at times, in pots and the like. It bubbles up through the veins, arising from the body all around, mixed with the fluid of sexual arousal, due to the mind's resolve and thought. When it is diminished, churned by the movements of sexual desire, it solidifies into an embryo, drawn into the womb, combined with menstrual fluid.

sloka: vyānena rasadhāturhi vikṣepocitakarmaṇā|  yugapat sarvato'jasraṃ dehe vikṣipyate sadā||36||
translation: Through the action instigated by the bodily constituents and the vital air (vyana), the senses are continually and simultaneously set in motion in all directions.

sloka: kṣipyamāṇaḥ khavaiguṇyādrasaḥ sajjati yatra saḥ|  karoti vikṛtiṃ tatra khe varṣamiva toyadaḥ||37||
translation: When forcefully impelled, it assumes the form of that place where it is, just as a rain cloud in the sky combines with the region that lacks its own qualities; such is the nature of the wind.

sloka: doṣāṇāmapi caivaṃ syādekadeśaprakopaṇam |
translation: Even a region can become prone to the emergence of faults at times, as well.

sloka: iti bhautikadhātvannapaktṝṇāṃ karma bhāṣitam||38||
translation: Thus, the transformation of food has been spoken of as the action pertaining to the elements of material nature.

sloka: annasya paktā sarveṣāṃ paktṝṇāmadhipo mataḥ|  tanmūlāste hi tadvṛddhikṣayavṛddhikṣayātmakāḥ||39||
translation: The one in charge of cooking is considered the master of all cooked items; indeed, the very root of their increase or decrease lies in those ingredients.

sloka: tasmāttaṃ vidhivadyuktairannapānendhanairhitaiḥ|  pālayet prayatastasya sthitau hyayurbalasthitiḥ||40||
translation: Therefore, one should carefully maintain the body's nourishment, hydration, and fuel through prescribed methods, for the sustenance and growth of life depend on them.

sloka: yo hi bhuṅkte vidhiṃ tyāktvā grahaṇīdoṣajān gadān|  sa laulyāllabhate śīghraṃ vakṣyante'taḥ paraṃ tu te||41||
translation: The one who, in the present, quickly develops greed and consumes what has been given, having discarded proper procedure and tainted by the faults of accepting gifts - such a person will soon be spoken of negatively by others.

sloka: abhojanādajīrṇātibhojanādviṣamāśanāt| asātmyaguruśītātirūkṣasanduṣṭabhojanāt||42||  virekavamanasnehavibhramādvyādhikarṣaṇāt|  deśakālartuvaiṣamyādvegānāṃ ca vidhāraṇāt||43||  duṣyatyagniḥ sa duṣṭo'nnaṃ na tat pacati laghvapi|  apacyamānaṃ śuktatvaṃ yātyannaṃ viṣarūpatām  ||44||
translation: Neglecting suitable nourishment, partaking of food that is overly spoiled or unwholesome, consuming that which is excessively heated or cooled, or eating at inappropriate times or in irregular intervals can cause a weakened digestive fire (agni), faulty digestion, and the accumulation of waste products, ultimately leading to disease. The one who engages in such imprudent behavior will find their food poorly digested, their lightness of being diminished, and their form taking on the quality of waste products.

sloka: tasya liṅgamajīrṇasya viṣṭambhaḥ sadanaṃ tathā|  śiraso ruk ca mūrcchā ca bhramaḥ pṛṣṭhakaṭigrahaḥ||45||  jṛmbhā'ṅgamardastṛṣṇā ca jvaraśchardiḥ pravāhaṇam|  arocako'vipākaśca ghoramannaviṣaṃ ca tat||46||
translation: For the decaying one, constipation serves as a symptom, as well as stiffness of the head, fainting, and vertigo. Additionally, there are gripping pains in the back and sides, yawning, tremors, thirst, fever, vomiting, and the excretion of undigested food. Indeed, all of these—undigested food, poor digestion, terrible signs—manifest as afflictions.

sloka: saṃsṛjyamānaṃ pittena dāhaṃ tṛṣṇāṃ mukhāmayān|  janayatyamlapittaṃ ca pittajāṃścāparān gadān||47||  yakṣmapīnasamehādīn kaphajān kaphasaṅgatam|  karoti vātasaṃsṛṣṭaṃ vātajāṃśca gadān bahūn||48||  mūtrarogāṃśca mūtrasthaṃ kukṣirogān śakṛdgatam|  rasādibhiśca saṃsṛṣṭaṃ kuryādrogān rasādijān||49||
translation: The sperm, being generated, becomes a flame consuming thirst, having a mouth-like appearance, ignited by the father. It generates sour and bile-related afflictions, as well as various pitta-wielding weapons. Similarly, phlegm-related afflictions arise when influenced by kapha, and many vata-wielding weapons arise from air. Urine-related diseases and those situated in the abdomen are caused by urine and feces respectively. By fluids like rasa, diseases caused by them are generated.

sloka: viṣamo dhātuvaiṣamyaṃ karoti viṣamaṃ pacan|  tīkṣṇo mandendhano dhātūn viśoṣayati pāvakaḥ||50||
translation: An unequal agent causes disparity; he who cooks makes the digestion unequal. A sharp and mild fuel ignites and refines the elements.

sloka: yuktaṃ bhuktavato yukto dhātusāmyaṃ samaṃ pacan|
translation: Having consumed food, one should be equally yoked, that is, maintain a balanced state with regard to the bodily constituents, as well as be even-tempered during the digestive process.

sloka: durbalo vidahatyannaṃ tadyātyūrdhvamadho'pi vā||51||
translation: Even a weak person can consume food, be it upwards, downwards, or to the side, as well.

sloka: adhastu pakvamāmaṃ vā pravṛttaṃ grahaṇīgadaḥ|  ucyate sarvamevānnaṃ prāyo hyasya vidahyate||52||  atisṛṣṭaṃ vibaddhaṃ vā dravaṃ tadupadiśyate|  tṛṣṇārocakavairasyaprasekatamakānvitaḥ||53||  śūnapādakaraḥ sāsthiparvaruk chardanaṃ jvaraḥ|  lohāmagandhistiktāmla [17] udgāraścāsya jāyate||54||
translation: That which is overripe or recently cooked is primarily declared as food when consumed, while that which is spilled or scattered is considered food in a secondary sense. From it arises, as a result of thirst, a rejuvenating and cooling fluid that is fragrant; as well as fevers, diarrhea, and symptoms of poisoning such as a metallic taste, bad smell, or bitterness.

sloka: pūrvarūpaṃ tu tasyedaṃ tṛṣṇā''lasyaṃ balakṣayaḥ|  vidāho'nnasya pākaśca cirāt kāyasya gauravam||55||
translation: Indeed, this was its initial state: the exhaustion of vigor and the quenching of thirst; subsequently, after a prolonged period, the heaviness of the body; and finally, the preparation of food for it.

sloka: agnyadhiṣṭhānamannasya grahaṇādgrahaṇī matā|  nābheruparyahyagnibalenopaṣṭabdhopabṛṃhitā [18] ||56||  apakvaṃ dhāratyannaṃ pakvaṃ sṛjati pārśvataḥ|  durbalāgnibalā duṣṭā [19] tvāmameva vimuñcati||57||
translation: The one who oversees the agnihotra ritual, identified as the grasper and releaser, does not have a weak or unskilled agnihotra fire. They release an offering that is not fully ripened and retain one that is fully ripened; they release what is foul-smelling and pungent as an offering, solely for you (the fire).

sloka: vātāt pittāt kaphācca syāttadrogastribhya eva ca|  hetuṃ liṅgaṃ rūpabhedāñ śṛṇu tasya pṛthak pṛthak||58||
translation: Learn, I say, the distinct causes, symptoms, and forms of diseases that originate from wind, bile, and phlegm, each of them separately.

sloka: kaṭutiktakaṣāyātirūkṣaśītalabhojanaiḥ|  pramitānaśanātyadhvaveganigrahamaithunaiḥ||59||  karoti kupito mandamagniṃ sañchādya mārutaḥ [22] |
translation: Angered, a person, whose digestive power has increased, performs excessive asceticism by reducing intake to bitter, pungent, and astringent foods, having controlled hunger, thirst, movement, and sexual desires, becoming emaciated and cooled down due to previous practices of austerities.

sloka: tasyānnaṃ pacyate duḥkhaṃ śuktapākaṃ kharāṅgatā||60|| kaṇṭhāsyaśoṣaḥ kṣuttṛṣṇā timiraṃ karṇayoḥ svanaḥ|  pārśvoruvaṅkṣaṇagrīvārujo'bhīkṣṇaṃ visūcikā||61||  hṛtpīḍā kārśyadaurbalyaṃ vairasyaṃ parikartikā|  gṛddhiḥ sarvarasānāṃ ca manasaḥ sadanaṃ tathā||62||  jīrṇe jīryati cādhmānaṃ bhukte svāsthyamupaiti ca|  sa vātagulmahṛdrogaplīhāśaṅkī ca mānavaḥ||63||  cirāduḥkhaṃ dravaṃ śuṣkaṃ tanvāmaṃ śabdaphenavat|  punaḥ punaḥ sṛjedvarcaḥ kāsaśvāsārdito'nilāt||64||
kaṭvajīrṇavidāhyamlakṣārādyaiḥ pittamulbaṇam|  agnimāplāvayaddhanti [23] jalaṃ taptamivānalam||65||
translation: They churn the oblation with a mixture of cow dung, urine, clarified butter, and other substances, making the water behave like boiling fire. (65)

sloka: so'jīrṇaṃ nīlapītābhaṃ pītābhaḥ sāryate dravam|  pūtyamlodgārahṛtkaṇṭhadāhārucitṛḍarditaḥ||66||
translation: He causes the aged, blue-black hued gold to gleam, turning it into shining yellow by extracting impurities; he has it refined through fire.

sloka: gurvatisnigdhaśītādibhojanādatibhojanāt|  bhuktamātrasya ca svapnāddhantyagniṃ kupitaḥ kaphaḥ||67||
translation: Consuming food excessively, beyond what is moderate, nourishing, and agreeable as recommended by the guru, once the angered kapha, one of the three bodily humors, is provoked, it destroys the digestive fire, even during sleep.

sloka: tasyānnaṃ pacyate duḥkhaṃ hṛllāsacchardyarocakāḥ|  āsyopadehamādhuryakāsaṣṭhīvanapīnasāḥ||68||  hṛdayaṃ manyate styānamudaraṃ stimitaṃ guru|  duṣṭo madhura udgāraḥ sadanaṃ strīṣvaharṣaṇam||69||  bhinnāmaśleṣmasaṃsṛṣṭaguruvarcaḥpravartanam|  akṛśasyāpi daurbalyamālasyaṃ ca kaphātmake||70||
translation: His food fails to digest for one whose heart considers something other than eating as sweet; the countenance turns pale, strength wanes, and phlegm increases in the body. The emission becomes foul, and the body unappealing. Vigor and enthusiasm for work diminish in one who has a phlegmatic disposition (kapha prakriti) and is also afflicted with laziness (alasya).

sloka: yaścāgniḥ pūrvamuddiṣṭo rogānīke caturvidhaḥ|  taṃ cāpi grahaṇīdoṣaṃ samavarjaṃ pracakṣmahe||71||
translation: We indeed declare that very grahaṇī dosa of agni, pointed out earlier and multifaceted in kinds, to be avoidable; it manifests as diverse diseases in the army.

sloka: pṛthagvātādinirdiṣṭahetuliṅgasamāgame|  tridoṣaṃ nirdiśetteṣāṃ bheṣajaṃ [24] śṛṇvataḥ param||72||
translation: For those gathered who are distinguished in their unique physical components, the supreme instruction to be heard is the identification of the remedy for the three doshas.

sloka: grahaṇīmāśritaṃ doṣaṃ vidagdhāhāramūrcchitam|  saviṣṭambhaprasekārtividāhārucigauravaiḥ||73|| āmaliṅgānvitaṃ dṛṣṭvā sukhoṣṇenāmbunoddharet|  phalānāṃ vā kaṣāyeṇa pippalīsarṣapaistathā||74||
translation: Upon observing an individual struck by a seizure-like affliction, traced back to one who has sought refuge in grahaṇīm, they should be lifted up using water, either warm or infused with kaṣāya, as well as with pippalī and sarṣapa duo.

sloka: līnaṃ pakvāśayasthaṃ vā''pyāmaṃ srāvyaṃ sadīpanaiḥ|  śarīrānugate sāme rase laṅghanapācanam||75||
translation: Even a ripe fruit, whether lying down or being eaten, can be illuminated by lamps; similarly, food that has been consumed or digested should serve to nourish and support the body.

sloka: viśuddhāmāśayāyāsmai pañcakolādibhiḥ śṛtam|  dadyāt peyādi laghvannaṃ punaryogāṃśca dīpanān||76||
translation: To him with a purified inner self, offer using the five oblations, starting with "kola," as well as mild food; additionally, rekindle the sacrificial fires.

sloka: jñātvā tu paripakvāmaṃ mārutagrahaṇīgadam|  dīpanīyayutaṃ sarpiḥ pāyayetālpaśo bhiṣak||77||
translation: After realizing the fully ripened significance of "mārutagrahaṇīgadam" (an entity that captures or draws in wind), the physician should cautiously make the patient ingest a modestly measured amount of ghee that has been lit/kindled.

sloka: kiñcitsandhukṣite tvagnau saktaviṇmūtramārutam|  dvyahaṃ tryahaṃ vā saṃsnehya svinnābhyaktaṃ nirūhayet||78||
translation: Only after carefully preparing a little or a significant amount of kindling in the fire should one ignite it, having combined it with air, either in equal or greater amounts, with a mind focused on the task.

sloka: tata eraṇḍatailena sarpiṣā tailvakena vā|  sakṣāreṇānile śānte srastadoṣaṃ virecayet||79||
translation: Using sesame oil from the eranda plant, or ghee, or even oil from a cow's tail, one should cause impurities resulting from past actions to be expelled through the act of cleansing oneself in a state of tranquility; thus, it is proclaimed.

sloka: śuddhaṃ rūkṣāśayaṃ baddhavarcasaṃ cānuvāsayet|  dīpanīyāmlavātaghnasiddhātailena mātrayā||80||
translation: With a single measure of sesame oil, capable of enkindling the digestive fire and destroying bitterness/harshness, should one fill and purify a hardened heart; this is capable of eliminating any previous stiffness.

sloka: nirūḍhaṃ ca viriktaṃ ca samyak caivānuvāsitam|  laghvannaṃ pratisambhuktaṃ sarpirabhyāsayet punaḥ||81||
translation: Having fully restrained and abandoned it, one should cause a snake to eat light, properly digested food again after a period of fasting or restraint.

sloka: dve pañcamūle saralaṃ devadāru sanāgaram|  pippalīṃ pippalīmūlaṃ citrakaṃ hastipippalīm||82||  śaṇabījaṃ yavān kolan kulatthān suṣavīṃ tathā [27] | pācayedāranālena dadhnā sauvīrakeṇa vā||83||  caturbhāgāvaśeṣeṇa pacettena ghṛtāḍhakam|  svarjikāyāvaśūkākhyau kṣārau dattvā ca yuktitaḥ||84||  saindhavaudbhidasāmudrabiḍānāṃ romakasya ca|  sasauvarcalapākyānāṃ bhāgāndvipalikān pṛthak||85||  vinīya cūrṇitān tasmāt pāyayet prasṛtaṃ budhaḥ|  karotyagniṃ balaṃ varṇaṃ vātaghnaṃ bhuktapācanam||86||  iti daśamūlādyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: With twofold selection, namely two of pure devadaru, pippalii, citraka, and hastipippali, along with shana seed, rice grains, kolan, and kulatha that are individually cleaned and soaked; after incorporating salt, ghee should be thoroughly cooked with a quarter of the remaining portion in a controlled fire. Then, separately prepared ingredients such as sea salts, black salt, lime juice, and spices should be added one by one to the ghee. The intelligent person should then filter, heat it, preparing digestive fire, strength, complexion, wind control, and digestion, concluding the decimation of the ten roots known as ghrita.

sloka: tryūṣaṇatriphalākalke bilvamātre guḍāt pale|  sarpiṣo'ṣṭapalaṃ paktvā mātrāṃ mandānalaḥ pibet||87||  iti tryūṣaṇādyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: After cooking ghee with eight parts of milk and three triphala fruits, mixed with a bilva leaf and a bit of jaggery, one should make the mild fire drink (i.e., bring it to a boil). This opening procedure in making ghee is known as tryūṣaṇādyam.

sloka: pañcamūlābhayāvyoṣapippalīmūlasaindhavaiḥ|  rāsnākṣāradvayājājīviḍaṅgaśaṭibhirghṛtam||88||  śuktena mātuluṅgasya svarasenārdrakasya ca|  śuṣkamūlakakolāmbucukrikādāḍimasya ca||89||  takramastusurāmaṇḍasauvīrakatuṣodakaiḥ|  kāñjikena ca tat pakvamagnidīptikaraṃ param||90||  śūlagulmodaraśvāsakāsānilakaphāpaham|  sabījapūrakarasaṃ siddhaṃ vā pāyayedghṛtam||91||  siddhamabhyañjanārthaṃ ca tailametaiḥ prayojayet|  eteṣāmauṣadhānāṃ vā pibeccūrṇaṃ sukhāmbunā||92||  vāte śleṣmāvṛte sāme kaphe vā vāyunoddhate|  dadyāccūrṇaṃ pācanārthamagnisandīpanaṃ param||93||  iti pañcamūlādyaṃ ghṛtaṃ cūrṇaṃ ca
translation:
Prepare a decoction using the following five ingredients: 
1. With the use of roots of pippalī, freed from fear, along with rock salt, 
2. The previously cooked and dried extracts of mātuluṅga, ārdraka, and śuṣkamūla, 
3. Takramastu, surāmaṇḍa, sauvīraka, and tuṣodaka, all cooked together, 
4. Along with the extract of gulma, udara, śvāsa, kāsa, and ānila, 
5. And mix it well, making it a siddha decoction, 
6. Use this, along with suitable medicinal oils, for the purpose of internal application, 
7. Or consume this blended decoction, if suitable, for therapeutic purposes, 
8. If suffering from phlegm congestion or when aggravated by wind, consume this blended decoction, 
9. And if the phlegm is hard to liquefy, administer this blended decoction for digestion and to kindle the digestive fire. 
This concoction, prepared from these five ingredients, should be used in this manner.

sloka: majjatyāmā gurutvādviṭ pakvā tūtplavate jale|  vinā'tidravasaṅghātaśaityaśleṣmapradūṣaṇāt||94||
translation: These beans, upon reaching full maturity, sink in water due to their heaviness. However, if they become overripe, they start floating on the surface of water. This is because their natural adhesion is lost, and they get polluted.

sloka: parīkṣyaivaṃ purā sāmaṃ nirāmaṃ cāmadoṣiṇam|  vidhinopācaret samyak pācanenetareṇa vā||95||
translation: After examining this Sama hymn, which was previously silent and free from defects, you all in the past should have properly maintained it either through ritual offerings or through some other means.

sloka: citrakaṃ pippalīmūlaṃ dvau kṣārau lavaṇāni ca|  vyoṣaṃ hiṅgvajamodāṃ ca cavyaṃ caikatra cūrṇayet||96||  guṭikā mātuluṅgasya dāḍimasya rasena vā|  kṛtā vipācayatyāmaṃ dīpayatyāśu cānalam||97||  iti citrakādyā guṭikā
translation: Prepare Citraka root and Pippali root, as well as two alkalis and salts, Vyosa, Hingu, Modaka, and Cavya, all ground together at once; or prepare a paste from Takra or buttermilk or from Dadima's extract with its juice; such is called "Citraka-adiyah Guptika," an Ayurvedic medicine.

sloka: nāgarātiviṣāmustakvāthaḥ syādāmapācanaḥ|  mustāntakalkaḥ pathyā vā nāgaraṃ coṣṇavāriṇā||98||
translation: A city should never have its water supply tainted with snake venom, nor should it be contaminated by alkalies or salts, not even at summer's end or due to excessive heat.

sloka: devadāruvacāmustanāgarātiviṣābhayāḥ|  vāruṇyāmāsutāstoye koṣṇe vā'lavaṇāḥ pibet||99|| varcasyāme saśūle ca pibedvā dāḍimāmbunā|
translation: In the sacred grove, should one drink from the rain-born river, which is cool, warm, and free from serpents, where the divine tree aspires to speak? Indeed, one should drink the water, likened to nectar, that is extracted from the Bilva fruit.

sloka: viḍena [29] lavaṇaṃ piṣṭaṃ bilvaṃ citrakanāgaram||100||  sāme vā sakaphe vāte koṣṭhaśūlakare pibet|
translation: Either from the squeezed juice of citron or from a vessel, whether made of a bamboo hollow or not, one may sip (the liquid).

sloka: kaliṅgahiṅgvativiṣāvacāsauvarcalābhayāḥ||101||  chardyarśogranthiśūleṣu pibeduṣṇena vāriṇā|  pathyāsauvarcalājājīcūrṇaṃ maricasaṃyutam||102||
translation: In the Kalinga region, let them sip a concoction, made from a mixture of turmeric and lime, combined with hot water, using a sharpened arrowhead as a vessel. This antiseptic mixture is recommended for use.

sloka: abhayāṃ pippalīmūlaṃ vacāṃ kaṭukarohiṇīm|  pāṭhāṃ vatsakabījāni citrakaṃ viśvabheṣajam||103||  pibenniṣkvāthya cūrṇaṃ vā kṛtvā koṣṇena vāriṇā|  pittaśleṣmābhibhṛtāyāṃ grahaṇyāṃ śūlanuddhitam||104||
translation: When afflicted by an excess of bile and phlegm, one should drink the decoction, made by boiling with warm water, of Pippali root, Kaṭuka, Rohiṇī, Pāṭhā, Vatsaka seeds, Citraka, and Viśva-bheṣaja. Specifically, it should be prepared by crushing or grinding them and then consuming it with warm water or by simply mixing it with warm water.

sloka: sāme sātiviṣaṃ vyoṣaṃ lavaṇakṣārahiṅgu ca|  niḥkvāthya pāyayeccūrṇaṃ kṛtvā vā koṣṇavāriṇā||105||
translation: Who, having drained it of impurities, would mix equally and properly the curry made from the finest herbs and salty water, and then add hot water to it?

sloka: pippalīṃ nāgaraṃ pāṭhāṃ sārivāṃ bṛhatīdvayam|  citrakaṃ kauṭajaṃ bījaṃ lavaṇānyatha pañca ca||106||  taccūrṇaṃ sayavakṣāraṃ dadhyuṣṇāmbusurādibhiḥ|  pibedagnivivṛddhyarthaṃ koṣṭhavātaharaṃ naraḥ||107||
translation: To enhance digestive agni, a man should consume a concoction prepared by grinding together equal parts of black gram, long pepper, white rice, barley, Indian aloe, plumbago zeylanica, holarrhena antidysentrica, and five salts, mixed with curd, warm water, and fermented liquor.

sloka: maricaṃ kuñcikāmbaṣṭhāvṛkṣāmlāḥ kuḍavāḥ pṛthak|  palāni [30] daśa cāmlasya vetasasya palārdhikam||108||  sauvarcalaṃ biḍaṃ pākyaṃ yavakṣāraḥ sasaindhavaḥ|  śaṭīpuṣkaramūlāni hiṅgu hiṅguśivāṭikā||109||  tat sarvamekataḥ sūkṣmaṃ cūrṇaṃ kṛtvā prayojayet|  hitaṃ vātābhibhūtāyāṃ grahaṇyāmarucau tathā||110||  iti maricādyaṃ cūrṇam
translation: Grind finely and thoroughly the following: sauvarcala salt, biḍa salt, pākya-prepared ingredient, yavakṣāra salt, sasaindhava salt, śaṭīpuṣkaramūlāni plants, hiṅgu, and āṭikā. Once all these ingredients have been reduced to a fine powder, apply this remedy during episodes of vāta imbalance to alleviate it, as well as during meals and while undergoing emesis therapy. This composition is known as marica and similar substances in their powdered form.

sloka: caturṇāṃ prasthamamlānāṃ tryūṣaṇasya palatrayam|  lavaṇānāṃ ca catvāri śarkarāyāḥ palāṣṭakam|  sañcūrṇya śākasūpānnarāgādiṣvavacārayet||111||  kāsājīrṇāruciśvāsāhṛtpāṇḍvāmayaśūlanut|
translation: Of the four types of grains and three types of tryushana, having mixed together with four kinds of salts and eight varieties of sugar, one should prepare dishes using vegetables, soups, and other ingredients. Similarly, one should cause to prepare various foods for those afflicted by old age, loss of appetite, respiratory issues, heart disease, anemia, and imbalance of bodily humors using sharp, flat, and blunt implements.

sloka: cavyatvakpippalīmūladhātakīvyoṣacitrakān||112||  kapitthaṃ bilvamambaṣṭhāṃ śālmalaṃ hastipippalīm|  śilodbhedaṃ tathā'jājīṃ piṣṭvā badarasammitam||113||  paribharjya ghṛte dadhnā yavāgūṃ sādhayedbhiṣak| rasaiḥ kapitthacukrīkāvṛkṣāmlairdāḍimasya ca||114||  sarvātisāragrahaṇīgulmārśaḥplīhanāśinī|
translation: The physician should carefully prepare and administer a concoction made from grinding together the barks of Cavya and Vyosa, the roots of Pippali, Citraka, and Dhataki, as well as the fruits of Kapittha, Bilva, Amla, Shalmali, and Hastipippali, mixed with stone Silaudbhedam, milk, and ghee. Additionally, decoctions should be made from the bark and leaves of Kapitthacukri, Vrksamla, and Dadi. This remedy, when administered, will destroy all symptoms of disease arising from dietary and behavioral excesses.

sloka: pañcakolakayūṣaśca mūlakānāṃ ca soṣaṇaḥ||115||  snigdho dāḍimatakrāmlo jāṅgalaḥ saṃskṛto rasaḥ|  kravyādasvarasaḥ śasto bhojanārthe sadīpanaḥ||116||  takrāranālamadyāni pānāyāriṣṭa eva ca|
translation: The churning of the five substances is the extraction of their sap; it is unctuous, astringent, and sour. Cultivated in the wilderness, it has a pleasant taste and is transformed into a refined seasoning for use in food. It also serves as the essence of flesh-eating animals and illuminates as alcoholic beverages in a specific context.

sloka: takraṃ tu grahaṇīdoṣe dīpanagrāhilāghavāt||117||  śreṣṭhaṃ madhurapākitvānna ca pittaṃ prakopayet|  kaṣāyoṣṇavikāśitvādraukṣyāccaiva kaphe hitam||118||  vāte svādvamlasāndratvāt sadyaskamavidāhi tat|  tasmāt takraprayogā ye jaṭharāṇāṃ tathā'rśasām||119||  vihitā grahaṇīdoṣe sarvaśastān prayojayet|
translation: In the event of grahaṇī dosha (a kind of indigestion), one should administer buttermilk that is light to digest and superior in sweet taste. It mitigates pitta (bile) but benefits kapha (phlegm) due to its hot and thin qualities. It also suits vata (wind) due to its unctuousness, sourness, and cold potency. Therefore, in the case of grahaṇī dosha, one should administer buttermilk to all patients, considering it a recommended remedy.

sloka: yavānyāmalake pathyā maricaṃ tripalaṃśikam||120||  lavaṇāni palāṃśāni pañca caikatra cūrṇayet|  takre tadāsutaṃ [31] jātaṃ takrāriṣṭaṃ pibennaraḥ|  dīpanaṃ śothagulmārśaḥkrimimehodarāpaham||121||  iti takrāriṣṭaḥ
translation: With āmalaka fruits, one should consume powders of marica and triputaga; then, drink buttermilk blended with salts and powdered hingu. This concoction, known as takrāriṣṭa, removes Kapha-Pitta doshas when consumed.

sloka: svasthānagatamutkliṣṭamagninirvāpakaṃ bhiṣak|  pittaṃ jñātvā virekeṇa nirharedvamanena vā||122||
translation: Upon recognizing the excessively aggravated bile that has accumulated in its proper location, the doctor should prudently eliminate it, either through therapeutic emesis or purgation.

sloka: avidāhibhirannaiśca laghubhistiktasaṃyutaiḥ|  jāṅgalānāṃ rasairyūṣairmudgādīnāṃ khaḍairapi||123||  dāḍimāmlaiḥ sasarpiṣkairdīpanagrāhisaṃyutaiḥ|  tasyāgniṃ dīpayeccūrṇaiḥ sarpirbhiścāpi tiktakaiḥ||124||
translation: With a small amount of alkali-like substances, mixed in by the uneducated, the juices of wild plants and grains like mudga, along with lime and sour substances, are kindled by grinding and adding pungent substances to them, just as fuel for lamps. The fire is kindled in this manner from the juices of jangalas and grains like mudga, mixed with alkali-like substances from uneducated persons, as well as lime, sour substances, and pungent substances, similar to how fuel is ground up for lamps.

sloka: candanaṃ padmakośīraṃ pāṭhāṃ mūrvāṃ kuṭannaṭam|  ṣaḍgranthāsārivāsphotāsaptaparṇāṭarūṣakān||125||  paṭolodumbarāśvatthavaṭaplakṣakapītanān|  kaṭukāṃ rohiṇīṃ mustaṃ nimbaṃ ca dvipalāṃśikam||126||  droṇe'pāṃ sādhayet pādaśeṣe prasthaṃ ghṛtāt pacet|  kirātatiktendrayavavīrāmāgadhikotpalaiḥ||127||  kalkairakṣasamaiḥ peyaṃ tat pittagrahaṇīgade|  iti candanādyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: One should prepare sandalwood, padmakoshira, patha, mura, kuta, nata, and shadgranthi-asri plants, as well as patala, udumbara, ashvattha, vata, plaksha, peeta, nimba, and dvipalashika. In the remaining portion of a vessel, cause ghee to be cooked with kiratatikta, indrayava, vira, ama, agadhi, kaa, utpala, kalki, and aksha, combined in a samah composition. This ghee, prepared with sandalwood as its primary ingredient, is suitable for consumption and beneficial in treating pitta-agrahani diseases.

sloka: tiktakaṃ yadghṛtaṃ coktaṃ kauṣṭhike tacca dāpayet||128||
translation: When butter has been churned and turned sour, one should offer it in the Kaushtiki fire.

sloka: nāgarātiviṣe mustaṃ dhātakīṃ ca rasāñjanam|  vatsakatvakphalaṃ bilvaṃ pāṭhāṃ kaṭukarohiṇīm||129||  pibet samāṃśaṃ taccūrṇaṃ sakṣaudraṃ taṇḍulāmbunā|  paittike grahaṇīdoṣe raktaṃ yaccopaveśyate||130||  arśāṃsi ca gude śūlaṃ jayeccaiva pravāhikām|  nāgarādyamidaṃ cūrṇaṃ kṛṣṇātreyeṇa pūjitam||131||  iti nāgarādyaṃ cūrṇam
translation: One should drink the powdered ingredients, namely musta, dhātaki, rasāñjana, bilva, pāṭhā, kaṭurohiṇī, mixed with saffron, kṣaudra, and taṇḍula, in the case of paittika grahaṇīdoṣa, after causing the red color to appear, as well as the arśāṃsi in the case of pravāhika, and the previous parts of compound words like nāgara-ādya, which is dark and consecrated with kṛṣṇa ātreya.

sloka: bhūnimbakaṭukāvyoṣamustakendrayavān samān|  dvau citrakādvatsakatvagbhāgān ṣoḍaśa cūrṇayet||132||  guḍaśītāmbunā pītaṃ grahaṇīdoṣagulmanut|  kāmalājvarapāṇḍutvamehārucyatisāranut||133||  iti bhūnimbādyaṃ cūrṇam
translation: Consisting of sixteen parts, the mixture is made with two citraka seeds and a portion equal to that of Indra, along with nimba, bitter katuka, ōṣa, and mustaka. Additionally, it includes pīta, formed from guḍa, śīta, ambu, and eliminates the impurities of grahaṇī, dosas, and gulma. This mixture, beginning with bhū, is also known to counter kāma, jvara, pāṇḍutva, meha, aruci, and atisāra.

sloka: vacāmativiṣāṃ pāṭhāṃ saptaparṇaṃ rasāñjanam|  syonākodīcyakaṭvaṅgavatsakatvagdurālabhāḥ||134||  dārvīṃ parpaṭakaṃ pāṭhāṃ yavānīṃ madhuśigrukam|  paṭolapatraṃ siddhārthān yūthikāṃ jātipallavān||135||  jambvāmrabilvamadhyāni nimbaśākaphalāni ca|  tadrogaśamamanvicchan bhūnimbādyena yojayet||136||
translation:
Consider the sequence of words as the preeminent path among the various speech paths. Gather the seven-leaved one (Saptaparṇa), and color it with the juices of Syonāka, Dīcyaka, Kaṭu, Vatsaka, and Durālabha.

Prepare the Darvi and Parpaṭaka paths, as well as Yavānī mixed with Madhu and Śigru. Utilize Patola leaves, Tram leaves, and Siddhārtha fruits to alleviate diseases and soothe the mind.

Gather fresh Jambu, Āmra, Bilva, Nimba, and Śāka fruits for this purpose. Apply these individually or combined as required to pacify disorders and promote tranquility.

sloka: kirātatiktaḥ ṣaḍgranthā trāyamāṇā kaṭutrikam|  candanaṃ padmakośīraṃ dārvītvak kaṭurohiṇī||137||  kuṭajatvakphalaṃ mustaṃ yavānī devadāru ca|  paṭolanimbapatrailāsaurāṣṭrayativiṣātvacaḥ||138||  madhuśigrośca bījāni mūrvā parpaṭakastathā|  taccūrṇaṃ madhunā lehyaṃ peyaṃ madyairjalena vā||139||  hṛtpāṇḍugrahaṇīrogagulmaśūlārucijvarān|  kāmalāṃ sannipātaṃ ca mukharogāṃśca nāśayet||140||  iti kirātādyaṃ cūrṇam
translation: The six Granthas, previously treated by the Kiratas, are now being treated with pungent drugs, such as candana and padmakosha, as well as dargvatvak, kutajaphala, musta, yavani, devadaru, and patolanimpapattrailasaurayatvisat, along with their seeds; these, when ground up and mixed with honey, madhu, or alcohol, can cure heart pain, fever, and other ailments, as well as various skin diseases, and even the most severe types of oral diseases. This is the first part of the Kirata treatment.

sloka: grahaṇyāṃ śleṣmaduṣṭāyāṃ vamitasya yathāvidhi|  kaṭvamlalavaṇakṣāraistiktaiścāgniṃ vivardhayet||141||
translation: In the correct way, one should increase the fire using the kaṭu, amla, lavaṇa, and tikta constituents of something that is to be evacuated , which is afflicted with impure phlegm , in accordance with the method prescribed .

sloka: palāśaṃ citrakaṃ cavyaṃ mātuluṅgaṃ harītakīm|  pippalīṃ pippalīmūlaṃ pāṭhāṃ nāgaradhānyakam||142||  kārṣikāṇyudakaprasthe paktvā pādāvaśeṣitam|  pānīyārthaṃ prayuñjīta yavāgūṃ taiśca sādhayet||143||
translation: Using ingredients such as palāśa, citraka, cavya, mātuluṅga, harītakī, pippalī, pippalīmūla, and pāṭhā, as well as grains like nāgaradhānyaka, first cook the kārṣikā grains near the water's edge. Then, prepare a drink by mixing in barley, and use this for proper sipping and accomplishment.

sloka: śuṣkamūlakayūṣeṇa kaulatthenāthavā punaḥ|  kaṭvamlakṣārapaṭunā laghūnyannāni bhojayet||144||  amlaṃ cānu pibettakraṃ takrāriṣṭamathāpi vā|  madirāṃ madhvariṣṭaṃ vā nigadaṃ sīdhumeva vā||145||
translation: Should one nourish oneself with light foods such as roots stripped of their moisture, or again with those that are bitter, astringent, and pungent in taste, consuming them in small quantities? Or should one sip (drink) wine, superior wine, strong drink, or even a refined and aged alcoholic beverage?

sloka: droṇaṃ madhūkapuṣpāṇāṃ viḍaṅgānāṃ tato'rdhataḥ|  citrakasya tato'rdhaṃ syāttathā bhallātakāḍhakam||146||  mañjiṣṭhāṣṭapalaṃ [32] caiva tridroṇe'pāṃ vipācayet|  droṇaśeṣaṃ tu tacchītaṃ madhvardhāḍhakasaṃyutam||147||  elāmṛṇālāgurubhiścandanena ca rūṣite|  kumbhe māsasthitaṃ jātamāsavaṃ taṃ prayojayet||148|| grahaṇīṃ dīpayatyeva bṛṃhaṇaḥ [33] kaphapittajit|  śothaṃ kuṣṭhaṃ kilāsaṃ ca pramehāṃśca praṇāśayet||149||  iti madhūkāsavaḥ
translation: Prepare in a pot a mixture of the following: three-fourths of a drona measure of madhūka flowers, citraka flowers, bhallātakāḍhaka, a quarter each of mṛṇāla and aguru; add to it a month-old āsava measure. Apply this mixture to the affected area to reduce kapha, pitta, and disorders like grahaṇī, shotha, kuṣṭha, kilāsa, and pramehā. This is the recipe for madhūkāsava.

sloka: madhūkapuṣpasvarasaṃ śṛtamardhakṣayīkṛtam|  kṣaudrapādayutaṃ śītaṃ pūrvavat sannidhāpayet||150||  taṃ piban grahaṇīdoṣāñjayet sarvān hitāśanaḥ|  tadvaddrākṣekṣukharjūrasvarasānāsutān [34] pibet||151||
translation: Having extracted the essence from Madhūka-puṣpa flowers, one should prepare a cool concoction, mixed equally with water. The benevolent one should administer this to others, thereby eliminating all digestive ailments. They too should consume it, along with their offspring, after squeezing out the juice from sugarcane.

sloka: prasthau durālabhāyā dvau pasthamāmalakasya ca|  dantīcitrakamuṣṭī [35] dve pratyagraṃ cābhayāśatam||152||  caturdroṇe'mbhasaḥ paktvā śītaṃ droṇāvaśeṣitam|  saguḍadviśataṃ pūtaṃ madhunaḥ kuḍavāyutam||153||  tadvat priyaṅgoḥ pippalyā viḍaṅgānāṃ ca cūrṇitaiḥ|  kuḍavairghṛtakumbhasthaṃ pakṣājjātaṃ tataḥ pibet||154||  grahaṇīpāṇḍurogārśaḥkuṣṭhavīsarpamehanut|  svaravarṇakaraścaiṣa raktapittakaphāpahaḥ||155||  iti durālabhāsavaḥ
translation: Having cooked four handfuls of rice in a pot with water, strain off the excess; mix it with one hundred and twenty grains of sugar and ghee from a pot. This drink, made of pippali and dried ginger processed together, should be consumed. It alleviates disorders such as grahaṇī, pāṇḍu, roga, arśa, kuṣṭha, vīsarpa, meha, and eliminates rakta, pitta, and kapha doshas. This truly is the hard-to-find elixir.

sloka: haridrā pañcamūle dve vīrarṣabhakajīvakam|  eṣāṃ [36] pañcapalān bhāgāṃścaturdroṇe'mbhasaḥ pacet||156||  droṇaśeṣe rase pūte guḍasya dviśataṃ bhiṣak|  cūrṇitān kuḍavārdhāṃśān prakṣipecca samākṣikān||157||  priyaṅgumustamañjiṣṭhāviḍaṅgamadhukaplavān|  lodhraṃ śābarakaṃ caiva māsārdhasthaṃ pibettu tam||158||  eṣa mūlāsavaḥ siddho dīpano raktapittajit|  ānāhakaphahṛdrogapāṇḍurogāṅgasādanut||159||  iti mūlāsavaḥ
translation: With the remaining dough ball, the physician should cook in four droṇas of clarified butter the portions of five ingredients each, in two sets. Once this mixture is purified and strained, he should add a concoction of priyangu, musta, mañjiṣṭhā, viḍaṅga, madhuka plavān, lodhram, and śābarakam. This mūlāsava, now potent and raktapitta-defeating, eliminates impurities related to kapha in the heart, pāṇḍura in the skin, and gāṅgasāda in the body. Thus is prepared the mūlāsava elixir.

sloka: prāsthikaṃ [37] pippalīṃ piṣṭvā guḍaṃ madhyaṃ bibhītakāt|  udakaprasthasaṃyuktaṃ yavapalle nidhāpayet||160||  tasmāt palaṃ sujātāttu salilāñjalisaṃyutam|  pibetpiṇḍāsavo hyeṣa rogānīkavināśanaḥ||161||  svastho'pyenaṃ pibenmāsaṃ naraḥ snigdharasāśanaḥ [38] |  icchaṃsteṣāmanutpattiṃ rogāṇāṃ ye'tra kīrtitāḥ||162|| iti piṇḍāsavaḥ
translation: Therefore, one should drink this *pinda-asava*, which, being prepared by mixing well-ground sugar, jujube paste, and water in joined palms, is a most wholesome beverage that destroys diseases. Even a healthy person who regularly consumes unctuous foods should drink it once a month as a preventative measure, for such diseases as have been mentioned. This *pinda-asava* is so called.

sloka: nave pippalimadhvākte kalase'gurudhūpite|  madhvāḍhakaṃ jalasamaṃ cūrṇānīmāni dāpayet||163||  kuḍavārdhaṃ viḍaṅgānāṃ pippalyāḥ kuḍavaṃ tathā|  caturthikāṃśāṃ tvakkṣīrīṃ keśaraṃ maricāni ca||164||  tvagelāpatrakaśaṭīkramukātiviṣāghanān|  hareṇvelvālutejohvāpippalīmūlacitrakān||165||  kārṣikāṃstat sthitaṃ māsamata ūrdhvaṃ prayojayet|  mandaṃ sandapayatyagniṃ karoti viṣamaṃ samam||166||  hṛtpāṇḍugrahaṇīrogakuṣṭhārśaḥśvayathujvarān|  vātaśleṣmāmayāṃścānyānmadhvariṣṭo vyapohati||167||  iti madhvariṣṭaḥ
translation: In the current context, one should offer a mixture, known as madhvariṣṭaḥ, in a water-infused pot containing fresh pippali (long pepper) and madhva (honey). This mixture includes crushed samit (unbroken rice grains), powders from kuḍava (black pepper), viḍaṅgānām (cloves), pippalyāḥ (long pepper), kuḍavam (black pepper), tvakkṣīrīm (cinnamon), keśaram (cardamom), and maricāni (dry ginger). Additionally, it contains saffron strands, roots of pippalī, tejohva, and citraka plants, tree barks, costus, herbs promoting digestion, and other similar herbs. This concoction treats various ailments, such as heart diseases, cough, fever, indigestion, and those caused by vāta (wind), śleṣma (phlegm), or āma (toxins).

sloka: samūlāṃ pippalīṃ kṣārau dvau pañca lavaṇāni ca|  mātuluṅgābhayārāsnāśaṭīmaricanāgaram||168||  kṛtvā samāṃśaṃ taccūrṇaṃ pibet prātaḥ sukhāmbunā|  śleṣmike grahaṇīdoṣe balavarṇāgnivardhanam||169||  etairevauṣadhaiḥ siddhaṃ sarpiḥ peyaṃ samārute|
translation: Having crushed and mixed together the dried root of pippalí, two kinds of kshára, five salty substances, mātuluṅga, abhayārāsnāśaṭīmari, and nāgaram, one should drink this concoction in the morning, combined with a pleasant beverage made of water. This mixture effectively treats kapha and agni imbalances. With these medicinal ingredients, clarified butter is indeed prepared.

sloka: gaulmike ṣaṭpalaṃ proktaṃ bhallātakaghṛtaṃ ca yat||170||
translation: In the Gaumika tradition, the measurement for Bhallataka poison has been mentioned as six palm lengths.

sloka: biḍaṃ kālotthalavaṇaṃ sarjikāyavaśūkajam|  saptalāṃ kaṇṭakārīṃ ca citrakaṃ ceti dāhayet||171||  saptakṛtvaḥ srutasyāsya kṣārasya [39] dvyāḍhakena tu|  āḍhakaṃ sarpiṣaḥ paktvā pibedagnivivardhanam||172||  iti kṣāraghṛta
translation: The one who has understanding should ignite and cause to burn with a fire fueled by ghee produced from the churning of seven measures of water, mixed with salt, sarjikaa, vasuka, and jama substances, as well as the citraka plant; this process should be repeated seven times. Drinking the ghee left over after boiling curdled milk aids in enhancing the digestive fire.

sloka: samūlāṃ pippalīṃ pāṭhāṃ cavyendrayavanāgaram|  citrakātiviṣe hiṅgu śvadaṃṣṭrāṃ kaṭurohiṇīm||173||  vacāṃ ca kārṣikaṃ pañcalavaṇānāṃ palāni ca|  dadhnaḥ prasthadvaye tailasarpiṣoḥ kuḍavadvaye||174||  khaṇḍīkṛtāni niṣkvāthya śanairantargate rase|  antardhūmaṃ tato dagdhavā cūrṇaṃ kṛtvā ghṛtāplutam||175||  pibet pāṇitalaṃ tasmiñjīrṇe syānmadhurāśanaḥ|  vātaśleṣmāmayānsarvānhanyādviṣagarāṃśca saḥ||176||
translation: Consuming the powdered dry fruits of Pippalii and Samula, along with a mixture of five salty flavors, one should evenly grind and mix clarified butter into well-cooked, dried, and crushed remnants of curd that have been reduced by fire, then cooked in their own smoke, burned, and reduced to ashes. One should drink this concoction in small amounts, as it destroys all ailments caused by wind and phlegm, sweetens the food, and eliminates poisonous substances.

sloka: bhallātakaṃ trikaṭukaṃ triphalāṃ lavaṇatrayam| antardhūmaṃ dvipalikaṃ gopurīṣāgninā dahet||177||  sa kṣāraḥ sarpiṣā pīto bhojye vā'pyavacūrṇitaḥ|  hṛtpāṇḍugrahaṇīdoṣagulmodāvartaśūlanut||178||
translation: The pungent poison, the three-pointed and bitter-tasting fruit, the group of three salts; the internal smoke, the cow dung cake, when offered in fire, consume; the alkali, when mixed with ghee or consumed in food, that which causes burning in the heart, removal of phlegm, bile, and intestinal worms – all these completely destroy.

sloka: durālabhāṃ karañjau dvau saptaparṇaṃ savatsakam|  ṣaḍgranthāṃ madanaṃ mūrvāṃ pāṭhāmāragvadhaṃ tathā||179||  gomūtreṇa samāṃśāni kṛtvā cūrṇāni dāhayet|  dagdhvā ca taṃ pibet kṣāraṃ grahaṇībalavardhanam||180||
translation: Securely acquire these two *karanj* flowers and the *savatsaka* plant with seven leaves, as well as the *madana* herb, characterized by its six bundles, and the *murcha* plant. Having ground them together with cow’s urine, reduce them to ashes; then consume those ashes, which bolster digestive capacity.

sloka: bhūnimbaṃ rohiṇīṃ tiktāṃ paṭolaṃ nimbaparpaṭam|  dahenmāhiṣamūtreṇa kṣāra eṣo'gnivardhanaḥ||181||
translation: This alkaline *bhūnimba* and bitter *rohiṇī*, as well as *paṭola* and sour *nimba-parpaṭa*, when combined with the emission of a male animal's "dahenmāhiṣa" and the alkali *kṣāra*, enhance the strength of the *agni*.

sloka: dve haridre vacā kuṣṭhaṃ citrakaḥ kaṭurohiṇī|  mustaṃ ca bastamūtreṇa dahet kṣāro'gnivardhanaḥ||182||
translation: With turmeric (haridre) and black cumin seeds (kustham), as well as citraka, kaṭu, and rohiṇī, musta being the two ingredients; when cooked together with bastamūtreṇa, it can eliminate kṣāra and increase the heat of agni.

sloka: catuṣpalaṃ sudhākāṇḍāttripalaṃ lavaṇatrayāt|  vārtākīkuḍavaṃ cārkādaṣṭau dve citrakāt pale||183||  dagdhāni vārtākurase guṭikā bhojanottarāḥ|  bhuktaṃ bhuktaṃ pacantyāśu kāsaśvāsārśasāṃ hitāḥ||184||  visūcikāpratiśyāyahṛdrogaśamanāśca tāḥ|  ityeṣā kṣāraguṭikā kṛṣṇātreyeṇa kīrtitā||185||  iti kṣāraguḍikā
translation: The medicinal preparation, known as vārtākīkuḍava, is made from four ingredients, including sugar and three types of salt. It is advised to quickly consume it after mixing with water, as this has been proven to alleviate Kapha-related ailments such as diarrhea, cough, and dyspnea. This preparation, referred to as kṣāraguṭikā, has been described in the Ātreya text and is known to prevent and cure hydropsy symptoms.

sloka: vatsakātiviṣe pāṭhāṃ duḥsparśāṃ hiṅgu citrakam|  cūrṇīkṛtya palāśāgrakṣāre mūtrasrute pacet||186||  āyase bhājane sāndrāttasmāt [40] kolaṃ sukhāmbunā|  madyairvā grahaṇīdoṣaśothārśaḥpāṇḍumān pibet||187||  iti caturthakṣāraḥ
translation: After milking the calf, one should churn curd using a citraka wood pestle and, having finely crushed palasha tree bark, mix it with water containing urine and cook it. Then, on the fourth day of this process, strain the liquid through a kola plant filter, smoothened with sukhambu juice, and let an alcohol-free person drink it to remove any impurities caused by alcohol. (186-187)

sloka: triphalāṃ kaṭabhīṃ cavyaṃ bilvamadhyamayorajaḥ|  rohiṇīṃ kaṭukāṃ mustaṃ kuṣṭhaṃ pāṭhāṃ ca hiṅgu ca||188||  madhukaṃ muṣkakayavakṣārau trikaṭukaṃ vacām|  viḍaṅgaṃ pippalīmūlaṃ svarjikāṃ nimbacitrakau||189||  mūrvājamodendrayavān guḍūcīṃ devadāru ca|  kārṣikaṃ lavaṇānāṃ ca pañcānāṃ palikānpṛthak||190||  bhāgān dadhni trikuḍave ghṛtatailena mūrcchitam|  antardhūmaṃ śanairdagdhvā tasmāt pāṇitalaṃ pibet||191||  sarpiṣā kaphavātārśograhaṇīpāṇḍurogavān|  plīhamūtragrahaśvāsahikkākāsakrimijvarān||192||  śoṣātisārau śvayathuṃ pramehānāhahṛdgrahān|  hanyāt sarvaviṣaṃ [41] caiva kṣāro'gnijanano varaḥ||193||  jīrṇe rasairvā madhurairaśnīyāt payasā'pi vāiti pañcamakṣāraḥ
translation: Consuming a mixture of the three fruits, namely kaṭabhī, cavya, and bilva, together with the juices of madhyamaya, rohiṇī, musta, kuṣṭha, pāṭhā, hiṅgu, madhuka, muṣkakayavakṣarau, trikaṭukam, vacam, viḍaṅga, pippalīmūla, nimba, and citraka, combined with powdered forms of mūrvā, indra, guḍūcī, devadāru, kārṣika, and lavaṇānām, each in equal parts, taken with ghee and milk when digestive fires are subdued, purifies the body by eliminating all impurities, phlegm, wind, bile, piles, urinary disorders, cough, hiccoughs, and fevers. It destroys all toxins and cures old age and diseases caused by imbalances in the three doshas: kapha, vāta, and pitta. The fifth kṣāra, prepared from the juices of madhura fruits, is beneficial when consumed along with payasā.

sloka: tridoṣe vidhividvaidyaḥ pañca karmāṇi kārayet||194||  ghṛtakṣārāsavāriṣṭān dadyāccāgnivivardhanān|  kriyā yā cānilādīnāṃ nirdiṣṭā grahaṇīṃ prati||195||  vyatyāsāttāṃ samastāṃ vā kuryāddoṣaviśeṣavit|
translation: In the context of the three doshas, the specialist should perform five treatments: ghee, kshara, asava, and arishta should be administered; furthermore, those that are suitable for conditions like vata should be prescribed; one who is knowledgeable about the specifics of dosha should cause all relevant treatments or only the appropriate ones to be implemented.

sloka: snehanaṃ svedanaṃ śuddhirlaṅghanaṃ dīpanaṃ ca yat||196||  cūrṇāni lavaṇakṣāramadhvariṣṭasurāsavāḥ|  vividhāstakrayogāśca dīpanānāṃ ca sarpiṣām||197||  grahaṇīrogibhiḥ sevyāḥ
translation: The measures that rejuvenate consist of sweat-inducing and oleation , as well as purification , ingestion , and stimulation .
