The mind should consume the siddha substances, which are sweet , astringent , and salty , which are properly prepared, pure, and free from impurities, which destroy unsatisfactory results even if they are associated with smoke . This is the method of preparation .

sloka: paittike sakaphe kāse vamanaṃ sarpiṣā hitam |  tathā madanakāśmaryamadhukakvathitairjalaiḥ ||83||  yaṣṭyāhvaphalakalkairvā vidārīkṣurasāyutaiḥ |  hṛtadoṣastataḥ śītaṃ madhuraṃ ca kramaṃ bhajet ||84||
translation:
In the context of a domestic ritual, one should consume rice cooked with barley, wheat, and gram, combined with sesame seeds, honey, and goat's milk mixed with salt, ghee, and various spices like nagara, citraka, rasna, ajaji, pṛthakparṇī, patāla, and palāśa. This diet, which is beneficial for the body, eliminates impurities, alleviates vata, and reduces fatigue, should be taken in the present or ongoing time.

Additionally, one should enjoy fresh fruits such as mūlaka, suniṣaṇṇaka, sneha, elā, ayaḥ, kṣīra, ikṣu rasa, gauḍikā, dadhi, āra, nāla phala, which contribute to maintaining good health and treating diseases like kāsa.

Therefore, consuming a balanced, nutritious diet in moderate quantities, using fresh, wholesome ingredients, will promote health, strength, and longevity.

sloka: paitte tanukaphe kāse trivṛtāṃ madhurairyutām |  dadyādghanakaphe tiktairvirekārthe yutāṃ bhiṣak ||85||
translation: When there is poisoning, the healer should give to the patient a mixture of ghee, butter, and sugarcane juice, endowed with the qualities of being mixed with previously ground medicinal substances like vidāra, ikṣu, and kalka, in order to counteract it. Then, one should gradually administer cool and sweet substances.

sloka: snigdhaśītastanukaphe rūkṣaśītaḥ kaphe ghane |  kramaḥ kāryaḥ paraṃ bhojyaiḥ snehairlehaiśca śasyate ||86||  śṛṅgāṭakaṃ padmabījaṃ nīlīsārāṇi pippalī |  pippalīmustayaṣṭyāhvadrākṣāmūrvāmahauṣadham ||87|| lājā'mṛtaphalā drākṣā tvakkṣīrī pippalī sitā |  pippalīpadmakadrākṣā bṛhatyāśca phalādrasaḥ ||88||  kharjūraṃ pippalī vāṃśī śvadaṃṣṭrā ceti pañca te |  ghṛtakṣaudrayutā lehāḥ ślokārdhaiḥ pittakāsinām ||89||  śarkarācandanadrākṣāmadhudhātrīphalotpalaiḥ |  paitte samustamaricaḥ sakaphe saghṛto'nile ||90||  mṛdvīkārdhaśataṃ triṃśatpippalīḥ śarkarāpalam |  lehayenmadhunā gorvā kṣīrapaṃ ca śakṛdrasam ||91||  tvagelāvyoṣamṛdvīkāpippalīmūlapauṣkaraiḥ |  lājāmustaśaṭīrāsnādhātrīphalabibhītakaiḥ ||92||  śarkarākṣaudrasarpirbhirlehaḥ kāsavināśanaḥ |  śvāsaṃ hikkāṃ kṣayaṃ caiva hṛdrogaṃ ca praṇāśayet ||93||  pippalyāmalakaṃ drākṣāṃ lākṣāṃ lājāṃ sitopalām |  kṣīre paktvā ghanaṃ śītaṃ lihyāt kṣaudrāṣṭabhāgikam ||94||  vidārīkṣumṛṇālānāṃ rasān kṣīraṃ sitopalām |  pibedvā madhusaṃyuktaṃ pittakāsaharaṃ param ||95||  madhurairjāṅgalarasaiḥ śyāmākayavakodravāḥ |  mudgādiyūṣaiḥ śākaiśca tiktakairmātrayā hitāḥ ||96||  ghanaśleṣmaṇi lehāstu tiktakā madhusaṃyutāḥ |  śālayaḥ syustanukaphe ṣaṣṭikāśca rasādibhiḥ ||97||  śarkarāmbho'nupānārthaṃ drākṣekṣūṇāṃ rasāḥ payaḥ |  sarvaṃ ca madhuraṃ śītamavidāhi praśasyate ||98||  kākolībṛhatīmedāyugmaiḥ savṛṣanāgaraiḥ |  pittakāse rasān kṣīraṃ yūṣāṃścāpyupakalpayet ||99||  śarādipañcamūlasya pippalīdrākṣayostathā |  kaṣāyeṇa śṛtaṃ kṣīraṃ pibet samadhuśarkaram ||100||  sthirāsitāpṛśniparṇīśrāvaṇībṛhatīyugaiḥ |  jīvakarṣabhakākolītāmalakyṛddhijīvakaiḥ ||101||  śṛtaṃ payaḥ pibet kāsī jvarī dāhī kṣatakṣayī |  tajjaṃ vā sādhayet sarpiḥ sakṣīrekṣurasaṃ bhiṣak ||102||  jīvakādyairmadhurakaiḥ phalaiścābhiṣukādibhiḥ |  kalkaistrikārṣikaiḥ siddhe pūtaśīte pradāpayet ||103||  śarkarāpippalīcūrṇaṃ tvakkṣīryā maricasya ca |  śṛṅgāṭakasya cāvāpya kṣaudragarbhānpalonmitān ||104||  guḍān godhūmacūrṇena kṛtvā khādeddhitāśanaḥ |  śukrāsṛgdoṣaśoṣeṣu kāse kṣīṇakṣateṣu ca ||105||  śarkarānāgarodīcyaṃ kaṇṭakārīṃ śaṭīṃ samam |  piṣṭvā rasaṃ pibetpūtaṃ vastreṇa ghṛtamūrcchitam ||106||  mahiṣyajāvigokṣīradhātrīphalarasaiḥ samaiḥ |  sarpiḥ siddhaṃ pibedyuktyā pittakāsanibarhaṇam ||107||  iti pittakāsacikitsā |
translation: "For the person who has become emaciated and weakened due to an excess of bodily fluids, a medicinal concoction should be administered, which is made by cooking rice flour well, mixing it with honey, liquorice, and sugar, and is suitable for consumption."

sloka: balinaṃ vamanairādau śodhitaṃ kaphakāsinam |  yavānnaiḥ kaṭūrūkṣoṣṇaiḥ kaphaghnaiścāpyupācaret ||108||  pippalīkṣārikairyuṣaiḥ kaulatthairmūlakasya ca |  laghūnyannāni bhuñjīta rasairvā kaṭukānvitaiḥ ||109||  dhānvabailarasaiḥ snehaistilasarṣapabilvajaiḥ |  madhvamloṣṇāmbutakraṃ vā madyaṃ vā nigadaṃ pibet ||110||  pauṣkarāragvadhaṃ mūlaṃ paṭolaṃ tairniśāsthitam |  jalaṃ madhuyutaṃ peyaṃ kāleṣvannasya vā triṣu ||111||
translation: For a person afflicted by phlegm-related ailments, it is recommended to consume at the beginning of the season, in increasing quantities, foods such as bitter and astringent pomegranates, myrobalans, dry ginger, dry saffron, and light foods processed with clarified butter and rock salt. Also consume decoctions made from the bark and roots of belleric myrobalan, chebulic myrobalan, Indian madder, and drumstick tree; water mixed with honey; and buttermilk or milk, preferably soured. Regularly consume rice cooked with turmeric and sitaphala (a type of fruit). Drink a mixture of sugarcane juice, munakka raisins, and sugar candy. For phlegm-related diseases, use kaphaghna (phlegm-reducing) drugs such as drākṣā (Indian jujube), lāja (barley), musta (cyperus rotundus), pauṣkarāra (ficus hispida), and arica (anacyclus pyrethrum). Avoid cold, heavy foods. Regularly consume foods that are sweet, sour, and salty in taste. Also take kaphaghna drugs such as śarkarā (sugar), candana (sandalwood), madhu (honey), dhātrī (emblica officinalis), utpalaiḥ (a type of lotus), mustam (black gram), and sakaphe (horsegram) that are mixed with ghṛta (clarified butter). Regularly consume foods such as madhvamloṣṇāmbutakraṃ (sour milk or yogurt), vā (or) kṣīraṃ (milk), pibet (drink) pam (or) śakṛt (buttermilk), rasam (a type of soup made from spices and tamarind). Also consume pitta-reducing foods such as āmalakam (Indian gooseberry), drākṣām ( Indian jujube), lākṣām (cocoa), lājām (barley), sitaṃ (sugarcane), upalām (a type of turmeric plant), kṣīre (

sloka: kaṭphalaṃ kattṛṇaṃ bhārgīṃ mustaṃ dhānyaṃ vacābhaye |  śuṇṭhīṃ parpaṭakaṃ śṛṅgīṃ surāhvaṃ ca śṛtaṃ jale ||112||  madhuhiṅguyutaṃ peyaṃ kāse vātakaphātmake |  kaṇṭharoge mukhe śūne śvāsahikkājvareṣu ca ||113||  pāṭhāṃ śuṇṭhīṃ śaṭīṃ mūrvāṃ gavākṣīṃ mustapippalīm |  piṣṭvā gharmāmbunā hiṅgusaindhavābhyāṃ yutāṃ pibet ||114||  nāgarātiviṣe mustaṃ śṛṅgīṃ karkaṭakasya ca |  harītakīṃ śaṭīṃ caiva tenaiva vidhinā pibet ||115||  tailabhṛṣṭaṃ ca pippalyāḥ kalkākṣaṃ sasitopalam |  pibedvā śleṣmakāsaghnaṃ kulattharasasaṃyutam ||116||  kāsamardāśvaviṭbhṛṅgarājavārtākajo rasaḥ |  sakṣaudraḥ kaphakāsaghnaḥ surasasyāsitasya ca ||117||  devadāru śaṭī rāsnā karkaṭākhyā durālabhā |  pippalī nāgaraṃ mustaṃ pathyādhātrīsitopalāḥ ||118||  madhutailayutāvetau lehau vātānuge kaphe |  pippalī pippalīmūlaṃ citrako hastipippalī ||119||  pathyā tāmalakī dhātrī bhadramustā ca pippalī |  devadārvabhayā mustaṃ pippalī viśvabheṣajam ||120||  viśālā pippalī mustaṃ trivṛtā ceti lehayet |  caturo madhunā lehān kaphakāsaharān bhiṣak ||121||  sauvarcalābhayādhātrīpippalīkṣāranāgaram |  cūrṇitaṃ sarpiṣā vātakaphakāsaharaṃ pibet ||122|| daśamūlāḍhake prasthaṃ ghṛtasyākṣasamaiḥ pacet |
translation: "In the beginning, consume a balanced diet prepared with purgatives, possessing qualities of being light, alleviating kapha, and consisting of barley, rice, and other grains, together with pippali and its various forms, which include ari, airi, uṣā, etc., having bitter, pungent, and other tastes. Also, consume milk, curd, ghee, butter, and beverages like takra, madya, and nigada at proper intervals. For medicinal purposes, consume decoctions made from the roots of balinam, vamanaiḥ, dhānvabailarasa, tila, sarṣapa, bilva, madhva, etc., that possess scraping, cleansing, and other healing properties."

sloka: puṣkarāhvaśaṭībilvasurasavyoṣahiṅgubhiḥ ||123||  peyānupānaṃ tat peyaṃ kāse vātakaphātmake |  śvāsarogeṣu sarveṣu kaphavātātmakeṣu ca ||124||  iti daśamūlādighṛtam |
translation: "One should consume a concoction made from the roots of ten plants, namely blue water lily, etc., which, when taken, alleviates phlegm-related ailments such as respiratory diseases, as well as those caused by an imbalance of wind and phlegm in the body."

sloka: samūlaphalapatrāyāḥ kaṇṭakāryā rasāḍhake |  ghṛtaprasthaṃ balāvyoṣaviḍaṅgaśaṭicitrakaiḥ ||125||  sauvarcalayavakṣārapippalīmūlapauṣkaraiḥ |  vṛścīrabṛhatīpathyāyavānīdāḍimardhibhiḥ ||126||  drākṣāpunarnavācavyadurālambhāmlavetasaiḥ |  śṛṅgītāmalakībhārgīrāsnāgokṣurakaiḥ pacet ||127||  kalkaistat sarvakāseṣu hikkāśvāseṣu śasyate |  kaṇṭakārīghṛtaṃ hyetat kaphavyādhinisūdanam ||128||  iti kaṇṭakārīghṛtam |
translation: Prepared from the buds of blue water lily , red water lily , and white lotus , along with other ingredients such as cardamom, lavang, cinnamon, and nutmeg; mixed with honey and sugar; further processed with ingredients like camphor, clove, and cassia bark; combined with various decoctions such as those of draksha , punarnava, durva, and brihati; and seasoned with peppermint, tamalaki, bhargi, raktakarpura, and krsna pepper: this is kaṇṭakārīghṛta. It is beneficial in all vata and kapha diseases, alleviating hiccups and other respiratory ailments.

sloka: kulattharasayuktaṃ vā pañcakolaśṛtaṃ ghṛtam |  pāyayet kaphaje kāse hikkāśvāse ca śasyate ||129||  iti kulatthādighṛtam |
translation: The ghee, cooked with sugarcane, pomegranate, and other ripe fruits, flavored with cardamom, camphor, and other similar substances, prepared from a mixture of well-ripened fruits, thorns removed, of superior quality, combined with five kinds of juices, alleviates hiccups and breathlessness in kaphaja diseases. Indeed, this is known as "ghee originating from the best of families."

sloka: dhūmāṃstāneva dadyācca ye proktā vātakāsinām |  kośātakīphalānmadhyaṃ pibedvā samanaḥśilam ||130||
translation: When advised, one should feed someone afflicted by vātakaphala (a type of respiratory disorder) a drink made from the middle portion of kośa fruit, mixed with ghee, and juice extracted from panca-kola and kulattha fruits. Such a person will become tranquil, as it is said to alleviate hiccups and breathlessness.

sloka: tamakaḥ kaphakāse tu syāccet pittānubandhajaḥ |  pittakāsakriyāṃ tatra yathāvasthaṃ prayojayet ||131||  vāte kaphānubandhe tu kuryāt kaphaharīṃ kriyām |  pittānubandhayorvātakaphayoḥ pittanāśinīm ||132||  ārdre virūkṣaṇaṃ śuṣke snigdhaṃ vātakaphātmake |  kāse'nnapānaṃ kaphaje sapitte tiktasaṃyutam ||133||  iti kaphajakāsacikitsā |
translation: For a person of phlegmatic constitution, if it becomes bound by wind or bile, one should apply treatments that reduce kapha (phlegm) and eliminate the cause. If wind and phlegm are prevalent, causing emaciation, then in that state, one should drink a decoction consisting of equal parts of dried mango kernel and sugarcandy. This is the therapeutic approach for ailments caused by an imbalance of phlegm.

sloka: kāsamātyayikaṃ matvā kṣatajaṃ tvarayā jayet |  madhurairjīvanīyaiśca balamāṃsavivardhanaiḥ ||134||  pippalī madhukaṃ piṣṭaṃ kārṣikaṃ sasitopalam |  prāsthikaṃ gavyamājaṃ ca kṣīramikṣurasastathā ||135||  yavagodhūmamṛdvīkācūrṇamāmalakādrasaḥ |  tailaṃ ca prasṛtāṃśāni tat sarvaṃ mṛdunā'gninā ||136||  pacellehaṃ ghṛtakṣaudrayuktaḥ sa kṣatakāsahā |  śvāsahṛdrogakārśyeṣu hito vṛddhe'lparetasi ||137||
translation: If one perceives that there is a disorder in the body caused by kapha (phlegm), then one should apply a treatment accordingly. Similarly, if there is a disorder caused by vata (wind), then one should use a remedy that will reduce both vata and kapha. If there is a heating and drying condition in the body, then one should use a snigdha (oily) and atmake (nourishing) substance. When kapha is dominant and causing disease, one should consider using pippalii, madhukam, kārṣikam, sasitopalam, prāsthikam, gavyamājam, kṣīramikṣuram, yavam, godhūmam, tailam, and such substances. When cooked with ghṛta (ghee) and kṣaudram (oil), these substances are useful in treating diseases caused by an imbalance of kapha and vata, such as shvāsa, hṛtroga, kārśyeṣu, vṛddhe, and alparetaasi.

sloka: kṣatakāsābhibhūtānāṃ vṛttiḥ syāt pittakāsikī |  kṣīrasarpirmadhuprāyā saṃsarge tu viśeṣaṇam ||138||  vātapittārdite'bhyaṅgo gātrabhede ghṛtairhitaḥ |  tailairmārutarogaghnaiḥ pīḍyamāne ca vāyunā ||139||  hṛtpārśvārtiṣu pānaṃ syājjīvanīyasya sarpiṣaḥ |  sadāhaṃ kāsino raktaṃ ṣṭhīvataḥ sabale'nale ||140||  māṃsocitebhyaḥ kṣāmebhyo lāvādīnāṃ rasā hitāḥ |  tṛṣṇārtānāṃ payaśchāgaṃ śaramūlādibhiḥ śṛtam ||141||  rakte srotobhya āsyādvā'pyāgate kṣīrajaṃ ghṛtam |  nasyaṃ pānaṃ yavāgūrvā śrānte kṣāme hatānale ||142||  stambhāyāmeṣu mahatīṃ mātrāṃ vā sarpiṣaḥ pibet |  kuryādvā vātarogaghnaṃ pittaraktāvirodhi yat ||143||  nivṛtte kṣatadoṣe tu kaphe vṛddha uraḥ kṣate |  dālyate kāsino yasya sa dhūmānnā pibedimān ||144||  dve mede madhukaṃ dve ca bale taiḥ kṣaumalaktakaiḥ |  vartitairdhūmamāpīya jīvanīyaghṛtaṃ pibet ||145||  manaḥśilāpalāśājagandhātvakkṣīrināgaraiḥ |  bhāvayitvā pibet kṣaumamanu cekṣuguḍodakam ||146||  piṣṭvā manaḥśilāṃ tulyāmārdrayā vaṭaśuṅgayā |  sasarpiṣkaṃ pibeddhūmaṃ tittiripratibhojanam ||147||  bhāvitaṃ jīvanīyairvā kuliṅgāṇḍarasāyutaiḥ |  kṣaumaṃ dhūmaṃ pibet kṣīraṃ śṛtaṃ cāyoguḍairanu ||148||  iti kṣatajakāsacikitsā |
translation: By determining the appropriate and timely treatment, one should overcome injury-inflicted ailments with sweet and life-sustaining substances such as sugar, meat that strengthens muscles, long pepper, honey, rice, barley, wheat, munakka, green gram, Phyllanthus emblica (amalaki) oil, and ghee prepared from cow's milk. These should be properly cooked over moderate heat and combined with rock salt. This treatment is applicable for kṣatajā, which aids in alleviating cough, consumption, debility, and other respiratory issues.

sloka: sampūrṇarūpaṃ kṣayajaṃ durbalasya vivarjayet |  navotthitaṃ balavataḥ pratyākhyāyācaret kriyām ||149||  tasmai bṛṃhaṇamevādau kuryādagneśca dīpanam |  bahudoṣāya sasnehaṃ mṛdu dadyādvirecanam ||150||  śampākena trivṛtayā mṛdvīkārasayuktayā |  tilvakasya kaṣāyeṇa vidārīsvarasena ca ||151||  sarpiḥ siddhaṃ pibedyuktyā kṣīṇadeho viśodhanam |  (hitaṃ taddehabalayorasya saṃrakṣaṇaṃ matam ) ||152||  pitte kaphe ca saṅkṣīṇe parikṣīṇeṣu dhātuṣu |  ghṛtaṃ karkaṭakīkṣīradvibalāsādhitaṃ pibet ||153||  vidārībhiḥ kadambairvā tālasasyaistathā śṛtam |  ghṛtaṃ payaśca mūtrasya vaivarṇye kṛcchranirgame ||154||  śūne savedane meḍhre pāyau saśroṇivaṅkṣaṇe |  ghṛtamaṇḍena madhunā'nuvāsyo miśrakeṇa vā ||155||  jāṅgalaiḥ pratibhuktasya vartakādyā bileśayāḥ |  kramaśaḥ prasahāścaiva prayojyāḥ piśitāśinaḥ ||156||  auṣṇyāt pramāthibhāvācca srotobhyaścyāvayanti te |  kaphaṃ śuddhaiśca taiḥ puṣṭiṃ kuryātsamyagvahanrasaḥ ||157||
translation: The nourishment suitable for various bodily constituents should be chosen according to their specific qualities. For those weakened by a vata disorder, ghee is recommended; for those afflicted by a pitta disorder, buttermilk is advised; for those suffering from a kapha disorder, honey should be consumed. In case of a mixture of doshas or heart pain, always opt for ghee. In case of diarrhea, drink hot water; if constipated, consume buttermilk; and if there are obstructions in the digestive tract, consume cow's urine mixed with honey. For bleeding disorders, use a concoction made from sendana, madhuka, and kulattha. In case of poisoning or alcohol intoxication, mix together equal parts of powdered barley, candy sugar, and water. For mental disorders, consume dhūmra prepared with bala, tila, and vasa. Consume ghee in large quantities when there is excessive thirst or when the doshas are aggravated due to seasonal changes. Use honey in small quantities for nourishing the body. In case of intoxication caused by consumption of fish, meat, or alcohol, consume a mixture of kulinga andanda with kshudra patra. For diseases caused by an excess of bile, use a mixture of madana, tila, and triphala. Use castor oil for constipation and to alleviate vata disorders. In case of poisoning, consume a mixture of haritala, yavakshara, and gomutra. For skin diseases, consume a mixture made from the bark of madhuka tree with honey and water. These are some of the therapeutic uses of various food items and drinks according to Ayurvedic principles.

sloka: dvipañcamūlītriphalācavikābhārgicitrakaiḥ |  kulatthapippalīmūlapāṭhākolayavairjale ||158||  śṛtairnāgaraduḥsparśāpippalīśaṭipauṣkaraiḥ |  kalkaiḥ karkaṭaśṛṅgyā ca samaiḥ sarpirvipācayet ||159|| siddhai'smiṃścūrṇitau kṣārau dvau pañca lavaṇāni ca |  dattvā yuktyā pibenmātrāṃ kṣayakāsanipīḍitaḥ ||160||  iti dvipañcamūlādighṛtam |
translation: With a form perfected by abandoning the decay of the weak and adopting the strength of the newly arisen, one should perform actions for one's own benefit. First, make Agni bright and eliminate excess flaws gently. When the six tastes, along with the two salts, have been reduced through a mixture with the powder of sesame seeds, kidney beans juice, rice cakes, karkataki fruit, and milk, and then consumed with the fibers of kidney beans or belleric myrobalan, only then should one consume food. After eating, excrement becomes solidified, urine acquires a yellowish tint, and flatulence occurs, indicating that the digestion process has begun. As the digested food moves through the intestines, it stimulates the srotas, causing Kapha to be expelled through sweating, which purifies the doshas and leads to proper nourishment.

sloka: guḍūcīṃ pippalīṃ mūrvāṃ haridrāṃ śreyasīṃ vacām |  nidigdhikāṃ kāsamardaṃ pāṭhāṃ citrakanāgaram ||161||  jale caturguṇe paktvā pādaśeṣeṇa tatsamam |  siddhaṃ sarpiḥ pibedgulmaśvāsārtikṣayakāsanut ||162||  iti guḍūcyādighṛtam |
translation: Take equal parts of

sloka: kāsamardābhayāmustapāṭhākaṭphalanāgaraiḥ |  pippalīkaṭukādrākṣākāśmaryasurasaistathā ||163||  akṣamātrairghṛtaprasthaṃ kṣīradrākṣārasāḍhake |  pacecchoṣajvaraplīhasarvakāsaharaṃ śivam ||164||  dhātrīphalaiḥ kṣīrasiddhaiḥ sarpirvā'pyavacūrṇitam |  dviguṇe dāḍimarase vipakvaṃ vyoṣasaṃyutam ||165||  pibedupari bhaktasya yavakṣāraghṛtaṃ naraḥ |  pippalīguḍasiddhaṃ vā cchāgakṣīrayutaṃ ghṛtam ||166||  etānyagnivivṛddhyarthaṃ sarpīṃṣi kṣayakāsinām |  syurdoṣabaddhakoṣṭhoraḥsrotasāṃ ca viśuddhaye ||167||
translation: In a water-filled container, combine a mixture of Guḍūcī, Pippalī, Mūrvā, Haridrā, Śreyasī, Vacā, and Nidigdhikā, first filtered through a cloth, then cooked well and blended with Siddha milk from a cow that exclusively consumes Kāsa grass. This concoction, when consumed, helps alleviate the eight types of Kṣaya and disorders of the throat and chest. Featuring Guḍūcī as the primary ingredient, this mixture aids digestion, reduces bloating, and promotes longevity.

sloka: harītakīryavakvāthadvyāḍhake viṃśatiṃ pacet |  svinnā mṛditvā tāstasmin purāṇaṃ guḍaṣaṭpalam ||168||  dadyānmanaḥśilākarṣaṃ karṣārdhaṃ ca rasāñjanāt |  kuḍavārdhaṃ ca pippalyāḥ sa lehaḥ śvāsakāsanut ||169||  iti harītakīlehaḥ |
translation: "One should cook haritaki, belleric myrobalan, and bel fruit with twenty portions of water, along with a handful each of chebulic myrobalan, pippali, dried ginger, liquorice, rock salt, and sugar, in the form of a decoction. To this, add equal parts of cured long pepper, dried ginger, and pippali rinds. This preparation, known as haritaki lehya, should be consumed by those suffering from indigestion, diarrhea, fever, skin diseases, various disorders, poison, or by those seeking longevity. It should be taken mixed with ghee, honey, and sugarcane juice, or curd, for the benefit of agni, reducing doshas binding the intestines, stomach, and channels, and for their purification."

sloka: śvāvidhaḥ sūcayo dagdhāḥ saghṛtakṣaudraśarkarāḥ |  śvāsakāsaharā barhipādau vā kṣaudrasarpiṣā ||170||
translation: "One should prepare a decoction by boiling Haritaki and Yava twenty-four times, adding to it a previously prepared decoction made from Kshaudra, and a mixture of powdered Barhi and Sarpiṣa."

sloka: eraṇḍapatrakṣāraṃ vā vyoṣatailaguḍānvitam |  lihyādetena vidhinā surasairaṇḍapatrajam ||171||
translation: "Let the oblation, prepared with mustard seeds and pungent taste, and accompanied by curd and ghee, be offered as a sacrificial fee to the lord of elephants in heaven, as prescribed by the rule."

sloka: drākṣāpadmakavārtākapippalīḥ kṣaudrasarpiṣā |  lihyāttryūṣaṇacūrṇaṃ vā purāṇaguḍasarpiṣā ||172||
translation: Prepared with rice flour, Drākṣā fruit leaves, rock salt, and sesame oil, or alternatively, with aged ghee, this should be consumed as a remedy for eye ailments.

sloka: citrakaṃ triphalājājī karkaṭākhyā kaṭutrikam |  drākṣāṃ ca kṣaudrasarpirbhyāṃ lihyādadyādguḍena vā ||173||
translation: Should Citraka, adorned with the three kinds of fruits, either mix powder made from the old Karkataka or, after crushing licorice and barley, add sugar or ghee to it instead.

sloka: padmakaṃ triphalāṃ vyoṣaṃ viḍaṅgaṃ suradāru ca |  balāṃ rāsnāṃ ca tulyāni sūkṣmacūrṇāni kārayet ||174||  sarvairebhiḥ samaṃ cūrṇaiḥ pṛthak kṣaudraṃ ghṛtaṃ sitām |  vimathya lehayellehaṃ sarvakāsaharaṃ śivam ||175||  jīvantīṃ madhukaṃ pāṭhāṃ tvakkṣīrīṃ triphalāṃ śaṭīm |  mustaile padmakaṃ drākṣāṃ dve bṛhatyau vitunnakam ||176|| sārivāṃ pauṣkaraṃ mūlaṃ karkaṭākhyāṃ rasāñjanam |  punarnavāṃ loharajastrāyamāṇāṃ yavānikām ||177||  bhārgīṃ tāmalakīmṛddhiṃ viḍaṅgaṃ dhanvayāsakam |  kṣāracitrakacavyāmlavetasavyoṣadāru ca ||178||
translation: Prepare today a mixture of specified fruits and herbs: three fruits including citraka, triphala, and ājāja; two types of sharp and pungent karkaṭa-akhyā herbs; drākṣā; sarpirbhyām; and sweetened with sugar.

sloka: cūrṇīkṛtya samāṃśāni lehayet kṣaudrasarpiṣā |  cūrṇātpāṇitalaṃ pañca kāsānetad vyapohati ||179||  iti padmakādilehaḥ |
translation:
Having reduced the eight *padmakam*'s* petal-like sections into fine powder, one should cause it to be evenly mixed with cow's ghee, refined sugar, and liquified jaggery, using the powder derived from it. This mixture, when consumed, eliminates impurities in the body, nourishes all tissues, is sweet, agreeable, life-giving, and rejuvenating. It also enhances appetite, improves digestion, and eliminates toxins, while promoting strength, complexion, and intellect.

*Referring to a lotus-like object, possibly a plant or a symbolic representation.

sloka: lihyānmaricacūrṇaṃ vā saghṛtakṣaudraśarkaram |  badarīpatrakalkaṃ vā ghṛtabhṛṣṭaṃ sasaindhavam ||180||
translation: Should one expertly squeeze out the curds mixed with turmeric and water, or should they crush tulasi leaves on a badari patra, along with rock salt and saunf, and then mix it all with ghee?

sloka: svarabhede ca kāse ca lehametaṃ prayojayet |  patrakalkaṃ ghṛtairbhṛṣṭaṃ tilvakasya saśarkaram ||181||  peyā cotkārikā ccharditṛṭkāsāmātisāranut |  gaurasarṣapagaṇḍīraviḍaṅgavyoṣacitrakān |  sābhayān sādhayettoye yavāgūṃ tena cāmbhasā ||182||  sasarpirlavaṇāṃ kāse hikkāśvāse sapīnase |  pāṇḍvāmaye kṣaye śothe karṇaśūle ca dāpayet ||183||
translation: In the event that pepper is identified as the root cause of an ailment, one should consume a paste prepared from roasted barley flour, rock salt, and a hint of long pepper, combined with honey and ghee. Additionally, one should take in a mixture of licorice, black salt, and roasted cumin powder in hot water. Furthermore, for alleviating ear swelling, apply a paste consisting of roasted barley flour, licorice, rock salt, and boiled banyan tree bark juice.

sloka: kaṇṭakārīrase siddho mudgayūṣaḥ susaṃskṛtaḥ |  sagaurāmalakaḥ sāmlaḥ sarvakāsabhiṣagjitam ||184||  vātaghnauṣadhaniṣkvāthaṃ kṣīraṃ yūṣān rasānapi |  vaiṣkirapratudān bailān dāpayet kṣayakāsine ||185||  kṣatakāse ca ye dhūmāḥ sānupānā nidarśitāḥ |  kṣayakāse'pi tāneva yathāvasthaṃ prayojayet ||186||
translation: For individuals with equal taste, one should mix lemon juice, ghee clarified from curdled milk, and a bit of sugar into buttermilk; this should be given to those suffering from biliousness, flatulence, or fever. Likewise, one should apply clarified butter to the ears and chest in cases of excessive earwax or blockages.

sloka: dīpanaṃ bṛṃhaṇaṃ caiva srotasāṃ ca viśodhanam |  vyatyāsātkṣayakāsibhyo balyaṃ sarvaṃ hitaṃ bhavet ||187||
translation: The stimulator and enhancer of [the senses'] functioning, as well as the cleansing agent for the channels, should become, in a beneficial way, increasingly potent for all—both mild and strong—overcoming the causes of ailments such as indigestion, mudga, etc., by being pure, free from impurities, and having a slightly sour taste. It is also beneficial to give out juices, even bitter ones, and administer smoke-emitting medicinal substances according to the condition of those who are sick.

sloka: sannipātabhavo'pyeṣa kṣayakāsaḥ sudāruṇaḥ |  sannipātahitaṃ tasmāt sadā kāryaṃ bhiṣagjitam ||188||  doṣānubalayogācca haredrogabalābalam |  kāseṣveṣu garīyāṃsaṃ jānīyāduttarottaram ||189|| bhojyaṃ pānāni sarpīṃṣi lehāśca saha pānakaiḥ |  kṣīraṃ sarpirguḍā dhūmāḥ kāsabhaiṣajyasaṅgrahaḥ ||190||
translation: This sannipāta brings about illumination, expansion, and purification of the channels. It also reduces the harmful effects caused by poisonous substances. One should always seek to understand the most excellent remedy for dosas, along with appropriate consumption of food, drinks, and other items like ghee, rice, smoke, and kāsabha medicines. This knowledge and appropriate consumption should be undertaken in certain cases.

sloka: tatra ślokaḥ  saṅkhyā nimittaṃ rūpāṇi sādhyāsādhyatvameva ca |  kāsānāṃ bheṣajaṃ proktaṃ garīyastvaṃ ca kāsinaḥ ||191||
translation: In this context, the verse states that the means of determining the manifestation of various entities, their accomplished and unaccomplished nature, and the most effective cure for what ails them, is through the power of yoga and the elimination of faults. This indeed is referred to as the highest form of knowledge, along with nourishing food and drinks enhanced with ghee, sugar, smoke, and medicinal herbs.

sloka: ityagniveśakṛte tantre carakapratisaṃskṛte'prāpte dṛḍhabalasampūrite  cikitsāsthāne kāsacikitsitaṃ nāmāṣṭādaśo'dhyāyaḥ ||18||
translation: In the eighteenth chapter, named "The Treatment," of Caraka's well-known text, when discussing the situation where treatment that is firm and robust has been established, what should be administered as the respective remedy for those eighteen described conditions?

sloka: athāto'bhayāmalakīyaṃ rasāyanapādaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: After completing the preliminary rites of Agni, we, Bhagavan Atreya and colleagues, will explain this chapter on remedies from the Caraka Tantra, previously untaught, now ready for instruction, and located in the section titled "Kasa Cikitsitam" consisting of eighteen parts.

sloka: cikitsitaṃ vyādhiharaṃ pathyaṃ sādhanamauṣadham|  prāyaścittaṃ praśamanaṃprakṛtisthāpanaṃ hitam||3||  vidyādbheṣajanāmāni...|4|
translation: Then Bhagavan Atreya began to explain, "Fear not, the appropriate diet, therapeutic treatment, and medicine form the remedy for a disease, along with expiation, tranquilizer, and restoration of the natural state, all of which are beneficial. The names of knowledge and medicine"..

sloka: bheṣajaṃ dvividhaṃ ca tat|  svasthasyorjaskaraṃ kiñcit kiñcidārtasya roganut||4||
translation: Therapy is twofold: for a healthy person, it is a measure to strengthen their vitality, while for a suffering person, it is a remedy for their affliction.

sloka: abheṣajaṃ ca dvividhaṃ bādhanaṃ sānubādhanam||
translation: The healing is twofold : one that strengthens , applicable to a healthy person; and the other that alleviates the suffering of a distressed person afflicted with disease.

sloka: svasthasyorjaskaraṃ yattu tadvṛṣyaṃ tadrasāyanam||5|| prāyaḥ prāyeṇa rogāṇāṃ dvitīyaṃ praśamematam|  prāyaḥśabdoviśeṣārtho hyubhayaṃ hyubhayārthakṛt||6||
translation: The two means of achieving well-being, namely medical treatment and spiritual practices, are indeed primarily what is most conducive to alleviating afflictions.

sloka: dīrghamāyuḥ smṛtiṃ medhāmārogyaṃ taruṇaṃvayaḥ|  prabhāvarṇasvaraudāryaṃ dehendriyabalaṃ param||7||  vāksiddhiṃ praṇatiṃkāntiṃ labhate nā rasāyanāt|  lābhopāyo hi śastānāṃ rasādīnāṃ rasāyanam||8||
translation: For a healthy person, longevity, memory, intellect, and youthfulness; complexion, luster, voice, dignity, and physical strength are, in general, the culminating results of excellent merits; not through medicine but due to their inherent nature do riches and other benefits derived from sense objects accrue to those who are skilled in their use.

sloka: apatyasantānakaraṃ yat sadyaḥ sampraharṣaṇam|  vājīvātibalo yenayātyapratihataḥ striyaḥ||9||  bhavatyatipriyaḥ strīṇāṃ yena yenopacīyate|  jīryato'pyakṣayaṃ śukraṃ phalavadyena dṛśyate||10||  prabhūtaśākhaḥ śākhīva yena caityo yathā mahān|  bhavatyarcyobahumataḥ prajānāṃ subahuprajaḥ||11||  santānamūlaṃ yeneha pretya cānantyamaśnute|  yaśaḥ śriyaṃ balaṃ puṣṭiṃ vājīkaraṇameva tat||12||
translation: Through one's own meritorious deeds, the gainers of longevity, good memory, intelligence, strength, and freedom from debts reside in heaven. Such results are attained through generosity, a healthy body, strong sense organs, and supreme speech. The taste of legitimately earned wealth serves as the elixir for those who are downtrodden.

sloka: svasthasyorjaskaraṃ tvetaddvividhaṃ proktamauṣadham|  yadvyādhinirghātakaraṃ vakṣyate taccikitsite||13||  cikitsitārtha etāvān vikārāṇāṃ yadauṣadham|  rasāyanavidhiścāgre vājīkaraṇameva ca||14||
translation: The means of preserving one's own offspring are twofold, as declared here: the remedy preventing untimely death and promoting joy is referred to as the one that remedies afflictions. The medicine that fulfills the purpose of treatment is described as the one that enhances semen, making it inexhaustible and conspicuous in large quantities, similar to a tree's widespread branches. One who uses such a remedy becomes highly respected, gaining fame, prosperity, strength, and nourishment, comparable to an unfailing bull.

sloka: abheṣajamiti jñeyaṃ viparītaṃ yadauṣadhāt|  tadasevyaṃ niṣevyaṃ tu pravakṣyāmi yadauṣadham||15||
translation: The antidote must be known as that which is opposite to poison; I will explain what it is and how it should be used as a remedy and a tonic, for it increases strength and stimulates vigor.

sloka: rasāyanānāṃ dvividhaṃ prayogamṛṣayo viduḥ|  kuṭīprāveśikaṃ caiva vātātapikameva ca||16||
translation: The sages know the twofold application of remedies in their dual nature, namely internal (through entry into the body's cavities) and external (through exposure to wind and sun). Indeed, they are well-versed in how to utilize and apply these remedies.

sloka: kuṭīprāveśikasyādau vidhiḥ samupadekṣyate|  nṛpavaidyadvijātīnāṃ sādhūnāṃpuṇyakarmaṇām||17||  nivāse nirbhaye śaste prāpyopakaraṇe pure|  diśi pūrvottarasyāṃ ca subhūmau kārayet kuṭīm||18||
translation: In the beginning, a rule is established for the virtuous and meritorious members of the twice-born, physician, and brahmin classes, that they should construct a hut in a secluded and secure location, on level ground in the northeastern direction, using materials from rasayana plants, at the start of their spiritual journey.

sloka: vistārotsedhasampannāṃ trigarbhāṃ sūkṣmalocanām|  ghanabhittimṛtusukhāṃ suspaṣṭāṃ manasaḥ priyām||19||  śabdādīnāmaśastānāmagamyaṃ strīvivarjitām|  iṣṭopakaraṇopetāṃ sajjavaidyauṣadhadvijām||20||
translation: The king should have a hermitage constructed for the tranquil sage of the physician caste, possessing fine vision and subtle intellect, who is established in the primary duty of treating people with medicines, and who is pure, virtuous, and detached. She has realized the meaning of names and sounds, and is devoid of femininity, having attained a state free from such attributes. She is endowed with all necessary tools and resources, and should be accommodated in a clean, auspicious location to the east or north of the city. (19-20)

sloka: athodagayane śukle tithinakṣatrapūjite|  muhūrtakaraṇopete praśastekṛtavāpanaḥ||21||  dhṛtismṛtibalaṃ kṛtvā śraddadhānaḥ samāhitaḥ|  vidhūya mānasān doṣān maitrīṃ bhūteṣu cintayan||22||
translation:
Endowed with excellent expansiveness in this bright phase of the moon, having thoroughly refined the three gross and subtle senses, with a clear and sharp intellect, fond of solitude, and devoid of attachment to sound and other objects, equipped with necessary instruments, accompanied by a celibate doctor and medicinal herbs, a twice-born (learned person),

You should perform the ablution, establishing yourself in steadfastness, mindfulness, strength, and faith, contemplating on friendship towards all beings after abandoning mental impurities.

sloka: devatāḥpūjayitvā'gre dvijātīṃśca pradakṣiṇam|  devagobrāhmaṇān kṛtvā tatastāṃ praviśetkuṭīm||23||  tasyāṃ saṃśodhanaiḥ śuddhaḥ sukhī jātabalaḥ punaḥ|  rasāyanaṃ prayuñjīta tatpravakṣyāmiśodhanam||24||
translation: Having worshiped the deities and, after properly performing the ritual on an auspicious day during a suitable lunar constellation in a consecrated location and time, with a focused mind, devoid of impurities, and filled with faith, one should perform purification measures. I shall explain the means of purification through this ritual. Then, having become pure and happy, he can be reborn in that dwelling.

sloka: harītakīnāṃ cūrṇāni saindhavāmalake guḍam|  vacāṃ viḍaṅgaṃ rajanīṃ pippalīṃ viśvabheṣajam||25||  pibeduṣṇāmbunā jantuḥsnehasvedopapāditaḥ|  tena śuddhaśarīrāya kṛtasaṃsarjanāya ca||26||  trirātraṃ yāvakaṃ dadyāt pañcāhaṃvā'pi sarpiṣā|  saptāhaṃ vā purāṇasya yāvacchuddhestu varcasaḥ||27||
translation: Having worshiped the deities, after making offerings to brahmins and a cow, one should circle around and then enter the house. Once the house has been purified using various methods, becoming pure, happy, and strong, one may utilize the rejuvenating properties. I will now describe the means of purification.

sloka: śuddhakoṣṭhaṃ tu taṃ jñātvā rasāyanamupācaret|  vayaḥprakṛtisātmyajño yaugikaṃ yasya yadbhavet||28||
translation: Having known 'that' to be the purest form of the mixture of powdered haritaki, salt, amalaka, guda, vidanga, rajani, pippalii, and vaaca, which serves as a universal remedy, 'one' should consume it along with warm water, referred to as ushna ambu. This practice, when followed for three consecutive nights while being accompanied by cow's ghee, results in the enhancement of tejas' purity until the completion of purana shuddhi.

sloka: harītakīṃ pañcarasāmuṣṇāmalavaṇāṃ śivām|  doṣānulomanīṃ laghvīṃvidyāddīpanapācanīm||29||  āyuṣyāṃ pauṣṭikīṃ dhanyāṃ vayasaḥ sthāpanīṃ parām|  sarvarogapraśamanīṃbuddhīndriyabalapradām||30||
translation: Recognizing the pure qualities of Haritaki, a wise person should use it as a rejuvenative, having five tastes, which is soothing, not heavy, enlightening understanding and enhancing strength, known to alleviate all ailments, promoting longevity, nourishment, and intelligence.

sloka: kuṣṭhaṃ gulmamudāvartaṃ śoṣaṃ pāṇḍvāmayaṃmadam|  arśāṃsi grahaṇīdoṣaṃ purāṇaṃ viṣamajvaram||31||  hṛdrogaṃ saśirorogamatīsāramarocakam|  kāsaṃ pramehamānāhaṃ plīhānamudaraṃ navam||32||  kaphaprasekaṃ vaisvaryaṃ vaivarṇyaṃ kāmalāṃ krimīn|  śvayathuṃ tamakaṃ chardiṃ klaibyamaṅgāvasādanam||33||
translation: Haritaki, when made into a decoction with five ingredients, namely, panca rasas, uṣṇa, alavaṇa, śivā, and doṣanulomani, which are light to digest and enhance the digestive fire, it increases lifespan, nourishes, benefits old age, and strengthens the mind, senses, and body. It alleviates all diseases and is known as sarva-rogahara, the cure for all ailments. Specifically, it can treat kusṭha, gulma, udāvarta, śoṣa, pāṇḍu, arśāṃsi, grahaṇīdosa, purāṇa, viṣama jvara, hṛtroga, saśiroroga, atīsāra, measles (kāsa), prameha, mānāha, plīhana, udara, kaphapraśeka, vaivarṇya, kāmalā, kṛmī, śvayathu, tamaka, chardi, and klama, as mentioned in the verse.

sloka: srotovibandhān vividhān pralepaṃ hṛdayorasoḥ|  smṛtibuddhipramohaṃ ca jayecchīghraṃ harītakī||34||  (ajīrṇino rūkṣabhujaḥ strīmadyaviṣakarśitāḥ|  severannābhayāmete kṣuttṛṣṇoṣṇārditāścaye)||35||  tān guṇāṃstāni karmāṇi vidyādāmalakīṣvapi|  yānyuktāni harītakyā vīryasya tu viparyayaḥ||36||
translation: I wish to quickly overcome various blockages of the channels, such as indigestion, emaciation, and others, along with conditions like heart disease, head diseases, tuberculosis, diabetes, jaundice, leprosy, vitiligo, chronic fever, seminal debility, old age, and debility due to imbalance, by the power of Haritaki. Learn about these qualities and actions associated with Haritaki, as well as those spoken of in relation to Haritaki in various scriptures, for they are the opposite of weakness.

sloka: ataścāmṛtakalpāni vidyāt karmabhirīdṛśaiḥ|  harītakīnāṃ śasyāni bhiṣagāmalakasya ca||37||
translation: Then, one should understand the qualities of those deathless states that can be attained through such fitting actions , regarding the therapeutic application of both Haritaki herbs and the Āmalaki fruit .

sloka: oṣadhīnāṃ parā bhūmirhimavāñ śailasattamaḥ|  tasmātphalāni tajjāni grāhayetkālajāni tu||38||  āpūrṇarasavīryāṇi kāle kāle yathāvidhi|  ādityapavanacchāyāsalilaprīṇitāni ca||39||  yānyajagdhānyapūtīni nirvraṇānyagadāni ca|  teṣāṃ prayogaṃ vakṣyāmi phalānāṃ karma cottamam||40||
translation: Therefore, one should gather the fruits of those elixir-like plants, which are produced at the right time, as prescribed by the scriptures, including Haritaki and Amlaka, which are well-known to the wise physician, being always fresh, pure, clean, and unbroken. I will describe their usage, as well as the most excellent result of their effects.

sloka: pañcānāṃ pañcamūlānāṃ bhāgān daśapalonmitān|  harītakīsahasraṃ ca triguṇāmalakaṃ navam||41||
translation: Of the five major therapeutic plants, one should gather during appropriate seasons the ripe fruits of haritaki by the hundred, fresh leaves of amalaki by nine, endowed with full potency and nourished by sun, wind, shade, and water. Additionally, consider their uses for purification, cleansing, and healing, which are regarded as the best applications of these plants.

sloka: vidārigandhāṃ bṛhatīṃ pṛśniparṇīṃ nidigdhikām|  vidyādvidārigandhādyaṃ śvadaṃṣṭrāpañcamaṃ gaṇam||42||  bilvāgnimanthaśyonākaṃ kāśmaryamatha pāṭalām|  punarnavāṃ śūrpaparṇyau balāmeraṇḍameva ca||43||  jīvakarṣabhakau medāṃ jīvantīṃ saśatāvarīm|  śarekṣudarbhakāśānāṃ śālīnāṃ mūlameva ca||44||  ityeṣāṃ pañcamūlānāṃ pañcānāmupakalpayet|  bhāgān yathoktāṃstatsarvaṃ sādhyaṃ daśaguṇe'mbhasi||45||
translation: Of the five roots, one should assign a fifteenth portion to each of the following divisions, as detailed: the previous five, characterized by fragrance, large, falling leaves, and thoroughly concealed; the six, consisting of gandha, beginning with śva and daṃṣṭra; bilva, agni, mantha, śyonāka, aśmarī; two, punaḥnavā, śūrpa, parṇyau; jīvakarṣabhakau, medā, jīvantī, saśatāvarī; śara, ikṣu, darbhakāśānām, śālīnām, mūlam; these constitute the five parts, which should be distributed in accordance with what has been stated, making a total of fifty parts in the water.

sloka: daśabhāgāvaśeṣaṃ tu pūtaṃ taṃ grāhayedrasam|  harītakīśca tāḥ sarvāḥ sarvāṇyāmalakāni ca||46||  tāni sarvāṇyanasthīni phalānyāpothya kūrcanaiḥ|  vinīya tasminniryūhe cūrṇānīmānidāpayet||47||  maṇḍūkaparṇyāḥ pippalyāḥ śaṅkhapuṣpyāḥ plavasyaca|  mustānāṃ saviḍaṅgānāṃ candanāguruṇostathā||48||  madhukasya haridrāyā vacāyāḥ kanakasya ca|  bhāgāṃścatuṣpalān kṛtvā sūkṣmailāyāstvacastathā||49||  sitopalāsahasraṃ ca cūrṇitaṃtulayā'dhikam|  tailasya dvyāḍhakaṃ tatra dadyāttrīṇi ca sarpiṣaḥ||50||
translation:
One should take the residual portion of the decasperma fruit, which is divided, swollen, and has a large pepal leaf, and is pure. Also, gather all types of amla fruits growing on trees, including haritaki, belleric myrobalan, beleric myrobalan, chebulic myrobalan, and chebulic myrobalan. Thoroughly cleanse all these fruits, then dry and grind them into a powder. To this, add one-eighth of the powder's weight in sesame oil and three times its weight in ghee.

The five ingredients to be used are: madhuca juice, haridra, vidanga, musta, and kustha. Each should be reduced to a fine powder and then combined in specified proportions. After carefully sieving the mixture, use it according to established principles for preparing medicinal compounds.

sloka: sādhyamaudumbare pātre tat sarvaṃ mṛdunā'gninā|  jñātvālehyamadagdhaṃ ca śītaṃ kṣaudreṇa saṃsṛjet||51||  kṣaudrapramāṇaṃ snehārdhaṃ tat sarvaṃ ghṛtabhājane|  tiṣṭhetsammūrcchitaṃ tasya mātrāṃ kāle prayojayet||52||  yā noparundhyādāhāramekaṃ mātrā jarāṃprati|  ṣaṣṭikaḥ payasā cātra jīrṇe bhojanamiṣyate||53||
translation: Having determined the remainder of the medicine, first divide it into ten equal parts. Then, consume one part of it with Haritaki and all Amlaka fruits, as well as all other edible fruits. Grind together the remaining equal parts with ghee that has been cooled down to a semi-solid state, using a pestle in a mortar. At the appropriate time, apply this preparation to the patient. Consume one part of this mixture daily, neither exceeding nor falling short of this measure, as doing so may lead to aging or deterioration of the remaining food mixture.

sloka: vaikhānasā vālakhilyāstathā cānye tapodhanāḥ|  rasāyanamidaṃ prāśyababhūvuramitāyuṣaḥ||54||  muktvā jīrṇaṃ vapuścāgryamavāpustaruṇaṃ vayaḥ|  vītatandrāklamaśvāsā nirātaṅkāḥ samāhitāḥ||55||
translation: Offering this elixir, regarded as a means of liberation, to the ascetics such as Vaikhānasas, Valakhilyas, and others who diligently seek penance, one should do so having understood all aspects of the Audumbari pot. They, after discarding their old, worn-out bodies, become youthful and radiant, freed from fatigue, sleep, and distractions, with their senses fully controlled. At the time of consuming food, one should present a measured quantity of ghee mixed with a quarter part of sneha in front of them. They do not desire more than a measure of food at a time, and even this gets reduced during old age. Here, jīrṇe refers to the elixir that has grown old due to disuse over time, losing its effectiveness and thus becoming unsuitable for consumption.

sloka: medhāsmṛtibalopetāścirarātraṃ tapodhanāḥ|  brāhmaṃ tapo brahmacaryaṃ ceruścātyantaniṣṭhayā||56||  rasāyanamidaṃ brāhmamāyuṣkāmaḥ prayojayet|  dīrghamāyurvayaścāgryaṃ kāmāṃśceṣṭān samaśnute||57||  (iti brāhmarasāyanam)|
translation: Indeed, certain individuals, endowed with wisdom, memory, and strength, steadfastly engaging in night-long austerities and celibacy, should cause others to undertake this Brahma tapas. This Brahma rasa, when consumed, grants long life, excellence, fulfillment of desires, control over vital airs, elimination of fatigue, freedom from languor, and perfect mental focus. (Thus ends the Brahma Rasayana.)

sloka: bhavanti cātra  idaṃ rasāyanaṃ brāhmaṃ maharṣigaṇasevitam|  bhavatyarogo dīrghāyuḥ prayuñjāno mahābalaḥ||59|| kāntaḥ prajānāṃsiddhārthaścandrādityasamadyutiḥ|  śrutaṃ dhārayate sattvamārṣaṃ cāsya pravartate||60||  dharaṇīdharasāraśca vāyunā samavikramaḥ|  sa bhavatyaviṣaṃ cāsya gātre sampadyate viṣam||61||  (iti dvitīyaṃ brāhmarasāyanam)|
translation: Scholars versed in the spiritual path, endowed with intelligence, memory, strength, wealth, and austerity, indeed partake of this Brahminical elixir, which is served here. By doing so, they become free from illness, gain longevity, and engage in majestic actions. They become the desirable fulfillment of people's aspirations, shining like the combined brilliance of the sun and the moon. Their intellect, now established in the scriptural teachings, retains and nurtures their pure consciousness. The essence of the earth, combined with that of air, permeates their body, eliminating impurities and establishing a healthy balance within. (Chapter 2, Brahmarasayana)

sloka: bilvo'gnimanthaḥ śyonākaḥ kāśmaryaḥ pāṭalirbalā|  parṇyaścatasraḥ pippalyaḥ śvadaṃṣṭrā bṛhatīdvayam||62||  śṛṅgī tāmalakī drākṣā jīvantī puṣkarāguru|  abhayā cāmṛtā ṛddhirjīvakarṣabhakau śaṭī||63||  mustaṃ punarnavā medā sailā candanamutpalam|  vidārī vṛṣamūlāni kākolī kākanāsikā||64||  eṣāṃ palonmitān bhāgāñchatānyāmalakasya ca|  pañca dadyāttadaikadhyaṃ jaladroṇe vipācayet||65||
translation: By becoming the revered drink, "Soma," praised by the assembly of great seers, served to Atri, becoming a source of health and longevity for people, carrying the virtues and fame of Chandra and Diti, holding the essence of truth, initiating the sacred flow within the body, becoming the equal strength of the wind, becoming the irregular growth on the body, these are the transformations undergone by the juices of the following: Bilva, Agnimantha, Śyonāka, Kāśmarya, Pāṭali, Balā, Parṇya (fourfold), Pippalya, Śvadaṃṣṭrā, Bṛhatī (twice), Śṛṅgī, Tāmalakī, Drākṣā, Jīvantī, Puṣkara-aguru, Abhayā, Cāmṛtā-ṛddhirjīvakarṣabhakau, Śaṭī, Musta, Punarnavā, Medā, Sā, Elā, Candana, Utpala, Vidārī, Vṛṣa-mūlāni, Kākolī, Kāka-nāsikā. Of these, one sixth of Pala, Unmitān, Bhāgān, Śatāni, belonging to Āmalaka, along with five more, should be offered in a golden vessel during the ablution process.

sloka: jñātvā gatarasānyetānyauṣadhānyatha taṃ rasam|  taccāmalakamuddhṛtya niṣkulaṃ tailasarpiṣoḥ||66||  paladvādaśake bhṛṣṭvā dattvā cārdhatulāṃ bhiṣak|  matsyaṇḍikāyāḥ pūtāyā lehavatsādhu sādhayet||67||  ṣaṭpalaṃ madhunaścātra siddhaśīte pradāpayet|  catuṣpalaṃ tugākṣīryāḥ pippalīdvipalaṃ tathā||68||  palamekaṃ nidadhyācca tvagelāpatrakeśarāt|  ityayaṃ cyavanaprāśaḥ paramukto rasāyanaḥ||69||
translation: Having understood these other medicinal plants such as bilva, agnimantha, shyonaka, etc., one should extract the tasteless pulp of amalaki, rid of impurities and seeds. Then, it should be mixed with an equal quantity of sesame oil, heated in a paladwaasa, and given to a patient. One should further administer six palmfuls each of honey, sugar, musta, punarnava, meda, sa, ela, Chandan, utpala, vidari, vrisa roots, kakoli, and kaka's naasika, as well as the powdered equal parts of these in hundred (of amalaki). This, described as Cyavana prāśaḥ, is a renowned rasāyana.

sloka: kāsaśvāsaharaścaiva viśeṣeṇopadiśyate|  kṣīṇakṣatānāṃ vṛddhānāṃ bālānāṃcāṅgavardhanaḥ||70||  svarakṣayamurorogaṃ hṛdrogaṃ vātaśoṇitam|  pipāsāṃ mūtraśukrasthān doṣāṃścāpyapakarṣati||71||
translation: "The one known as Cyavana has specially described a healer as follows: For those who are debilitated by wasting diseases or afflicted by ailments such as consumption, abdominal swelling, heart disease, impurities in the blood, and thirst, the juice of āmalaka fruits is extracted, mixed with sesame oil and ghee, and divided into sixteen parts. One part of this mixture, when combined with a fish from the matsyaṇḍika species, serves as a remedy. Following this, a prepared medicine consisting of madhuña, siddha śīta, tugākṣīryā, pippalī, two parts of ilā leaves, and keśarāt is consumed. The āmalaka fruit's juice is highly acclaimed as a remarkable rejuvenating therapy."

sloka: asya mātrāṃprayuñjīta yoparundhyānna bhojanam|  asya prayogāccyavanaḥsuvṛddho'bhūtpunaryuvā||72||  medhāṃ smṛtiṃ kāntimanāmayatvamāyuḥprakarṣaṃ balamindriyāṇām|  strīṣu praharṣaṃ paramagnivṛddhiṃ varṇaprasādaṃpavanānulomyam||73|| rasāyanasyāsya naraḥ prayogāllabheta jīrṇo'pi kuṭīpraveśāt|  jarākṛtaṃ rūpamapāsya sarvaṃ bibharti rūpaṃ navayauvanasya||74|| (iti cyavanaprāśaḥ)|
translation: The one who is proficient in imparting instruction should make use of this means to strengthen the vital breath (prana) that may be weakened, damaged, or excessive in the elderly, children, and the infirm. This method eliminates decay and diseases caused by imbalances in wind, bile, phlegm, and other bodily humors. It also removes the causes of thirst, urine, and semen impurities. Indeed, when properly applied to a weakened person, this practice rejuvenates them, making them appear youthful and full of vitality.

sloka: bhavanticātra yathā'marāṇāmamṛtaṃ yathā bhogavatāṃsudhā|  tathā'bhavanmaharṣīṇāṃ rasāyanavidhipurā||78|| na jarāṃ na ca daurbalyaṃ nāturyaṃ nidhanaṃ na ca|  jagmurvarṣasahasrāṇi rasāyanaparāḥ purā||79||  na kevalaṃ dīrghamihāyuraśnute rasāyanaṃ yovidhivanniṣevate|  gatiṃ sa devarṣiniṣevitāṃ śubhāṃ prapadyate brahma tatheti cākṣayam||80||
translation: Just as nourishment is obtained by mortals from food and enjoyers from nectar, in the same way, the great sages found the elixir of life in their practices. They did not experience aging, weakness, impotence, death, or any other decline in faculties for thousands of years, for they had adopted the practice that brings rejuvenation, enhancing intelligence, memory, beauty, vigor, complexion, strength, joy with women, agni (digestive fire), semen, and luster. Indeed, whoever correctly practices this method, even if their body is old, becomes youthful again, casting off all signs of aging and preserving all their faculties.

sloka: tatraślokaḥ  abhayāmalakīye'smin ṣaḍyogāḥ parikīrtitāḥ|  rasāyanānāṃ siddhānāmāyuryairanuvartate||81||
translation: In this context, the six yogic practices referred to in the Abhayāmalakīya are described as elixirs of supernatural abilities for those who follow them. Just as the nectar grants immortality to the celestial beings, these practices, when followed in accordance with scriptural guidelines, lead one to attain the sacred and auspicious destination of the gods, endowing an infinite lifespan like that of Brahma.

sloka: ityagniveśakṛte tantre carakapratisaṃskṛtecikitsāsthānerasāyanādhyāye'bhayāmalakīyo nāma rasāyanapādaḥ prathamaḥ||1||
translation: In the section of the treatise concerning fire rituals, composed by Caraka, the initial chapter of the therapeutics book is named "Abhayamalakii," as it is the first part of the compound words, derived from the six therapeutic approaches described, which promote fearlessness and longevity.

sloka: athātaḥ prāṇakāmīyaṃ rasāyanapādaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: "Now we of noble intent shall explain this treatment for preserving life, as was previously stated by Bhagavan Atreya in the authoritative Caraka Samhita, which includes a description of āmalakī's therapeutic use."

sloka: bhallātakatailapātraṃ sapayaskaṃ madhukena kalkenākṣamātreṇa śatapākaṃ kuryāditi samānaṃ pūrveṇa||15||  (iti bhallātakatailam)|
translation: Now, you should cook the rejuvenating concoction, referred to as bhallātakatailapātra, using one hundred equal parts of madhuka and kalkeya, each weighed using a mass equal to a single mustard seed, as instructed by Lord Atreya in the past.

sloka: bhallātakasarpiḥ bhallātakakṣīraṃ bhallātakakṣaudraṃ guḍabhallātakaṃ bhallātakayūṣaḥ bhallātakatailaṃ bhallātakapalalaṃ bhallātakasaktavaḥ bhallātakalavaṇaṃbhallātakatarpaṇam iti bhallātakavidhānamuktaṃ bhavati||16||
translation: The method for preparing bhallātaka is described as follows: one should cook it with a hundred akṣas of madhuka oil, as well as kalka made from bhallātaka fruits, roots, bark, sap, kṣaudra, flowers, and saktu. Additionally, one should add one paTRA of bhallātaka tila oil. This is the recipe for bhallātaka as previously mentioned.

sloka: bhavanticātra  bhallātakāni tīkṣṇāni pākīnyagnisamānica| bhavantyamṛtakalpāni prayuktāni yathāvidhi||17||  ete daśavidhāstveṣāṃ prayogāḥparikīrtitāḥ|  rogaprakṛtisātmyajñastān prayogān prakalpayet||18||
translation: These are the ten methods of using bhallataka: applying the ripened fruits, extracting the juice, tapping the milky sap, drawing out the latex, using the root, bark, leaf, flower, and the whole plant, as described. One should apply these methods appropriately, making use of them in a medicinal capacity according to the specific nature of the ailment.

sloka: kaphajo na sa rogo'sti na vibandho'sti kaścana|  yaṃ na bhallātakaṃ hanyācchīghraṃ medhāgnivardhanam||19||  (iti bhallātakavidhiḥ)|  prāṇakāmāḥ purā jīrṇāścyavanādyā maharṣayaḥ|  rasāyanaiḥ śivairetairbabhūvuramitāyuṣaḥ||20||  brāhmaṃ tapo brahmacaryamadhyātmadhyānameva ca|  dīrghāyuṣo yathākāmaṃ sambhṛtya tridivaṃ gatāḥ||21||  tasmādāyuḥprakarṣārthaṃ prāṇakāmaiḥsukhārthibhiḥ|  rasāyanavidhiḥ sevyo vidhivatsusamāhitaiḥ||22||
translation: Here, the kaphaja illness does not exist, nor does any constraint; nothing at all impedes one who, being sharp and powerful, does not swiftly destroy this bhallataka. The sages of yore, desiring length of life, consumed this, prepared via auspicious methods, together with brahmacarya, tapas, and introspection. Therefore, for the purpose of enhancing lifespan, one should carefully follow, in accordance with the rules, the regimen of using bhallataka, being mindful and attentive.

sloka: tatra ślokaḥ  rasāyanānāṃ saṃyogāḥ siddhābhūtahitaiṣiṇā|  nirdiṣṭāḥ prāṇakāmīye saptatriṃśanmaharṣiṇā ||23||
translation: In that context, the sage Saptatriṃśa has outlined the formation of combinations for rejuvenative substances (rasāyanānāṃ), which, when accomplished, bring about optimal health and well-being. These combinations, having been elaborated, serve to eliminate afflictions such as kaphaja rogaḥ and vibandhaḥ through methods that enhance intelligence, agni, brahma tapas, and atmic dhyana. Moreover, following this method leads to a long life, fulfillment of desires, and happiness in accordance with one's wishes. Therefore, it is recommended to follow the guidelines for using rasāyana substances appropriately.

sloka: ityagniveśakṛte tantre carakapratisaṃskṛte cikitsāsthāne rasāyanādhyāye prāṇakāmīyo nāma rasāyanapādo dvitīyaḥ||2||
translation: In the section concerning fire rituals, compiled by Caraka, in the therapeutic context, specifically in the rejuvenation chapter, the second type of rejuvenation is described for those seeking to enhance their vitality and longevity, as revealed by the sage. (Refining the basic translation using morphological tags and word splits.)

sloka: athātaḥ karapracitīyaṃ rasāyanapādaṃvyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: Now we will explain the subsequent step concerning the concoction of the elixir, as stated by the sage Bhagavān Ātreya in the well-revised chapter on cikitsā in the Caraka Tantra.

sloka: bhavanticātra  etadrasāyanaṃ pūrvaṃ vasiṣṭhaḥkaśyapo'ṅgirāḥ| jamadagnirbharadvājo bhṛguranye ca tadvidhāḥ||4||  prayujya prayatā muktāḥ śramavyādhijarābhayāt| yāvadaicchaṃstapastepustatprabhāvānmahābalāḥ||5||  idaṃ rasāyanaṃ cakre brahmā vārṣasahasrikam|  jarāvyādhipraśamanaṃ buddhīndriyabalapradam||6||  (ityāmalakāyasaṃ brāhmarasāyanam)|
translation: Now these [bhavanti] illustrious beings will explain this elixir, previously conceived by seers such as Vasistha, Kashyapa, Angiras, Jamadagni, Bharadvaja, and others [anye]. Having resolved their minds and freed themselves from fatigue, disease, old age, and fear [prayatā muktāḥ śramavyādhijarābhayāt], they created this rejuvenating elixir that strengthens mental and physical faculties. This elixir was created by Brahma, enduring for thousands of years, mitigating aging’s effects, and enhancing cognition and sense perception [buddhīndriyabalapradam].

sloka: tapasā brahmacaryeṇa dhyānena praśamena ca|  rasāyanavidhānena kālayuktena cāyuṣā||7||  sthitā maharṣayaḥ pūrvaṃ nahikiñcidrasāyanam|  grāmyānāmanyakāryāṇāṃ sidhyatyaprayatātmanām||8||
translation: Through austerity, celibacy, meditation, tranquility, adhering to proper diet, and optimally utilizing their lifespan, great sages of the past, such as Vasishtha, Vishvamitra, Angiras, Bharadwaja, and Bhrugu, have established themselves, becoming powerful and free from exhaustion, disease, old age, and fear. This rejuvenation, known as rasayana, was created by Brahma during a thousand divine years, primarily enhancing intellect, strength, and senses.

sloka: saṃvatsaraṃ payovṛttirgavāṃ madhye vaset sadā|  sāvitrīṃ manasā dhyāyan brahmacārī yatendriyaḥ||9||
translation: With a controlled mind, practicing brahmacharya and constantly meditating on Savitri, a steadfast great rishi, who has synchronized his lifespan with the solar cycle through austerities, remains engaged in rejuvenation techniques in the midst of cows. Such a one, endowed with the qualities of being unnamed and using medicinal remedies, is currently opting to make them effective through earnest efforts.

sloka: saṃvatsarānte pauṣīṃ vā māghīṃ vā phālgunīṃ tithim|  tryahopavāsī śuklasya praviśyāmalakīvanam||10||  bṛhatphalāḍhyamāruhya drumaṃ śākhāgataṃ phalam|  gṛhītvā pāṇinā tiṣṭhejjapan brahmāmṛtāgamāt||11||  tadā hyavaśyamamṛtaṃ vasatyāmalake kṣaṇam|  śarkarāmadhukalpāni snehavanti mṛdūni ca||12||  bhavantyamṛtasaṃyogāttāni yāvanti bhakṣayet|  jīvedvarṣasahasrāṇi tāvantyāgatayauvanaḥ||13||  sauhityameṣāṃ gatvā tu bhavatyamarasannibhaḥ|  svayaṃ cāsyopatiṣṭhante śrīrvedā vāk ca rūpiṇī||14||  (iti kevalāmalakarasāyanam)|
translation: Engaging in cattle tending throughout the year, either during Pausha, Magha, or Phalguna, one who meditates on sage Savitri must enter the Amalaki grove. Ascending the great-fruited tree and plucking its fruit with his hand, he should stand while repeating the mantra "Brahmamrtagamat." By doing so, he partakes of the nectar of immortality and remains in that state for a moment. The sugar-like and soft substances become like nectar to him, remaining so as long as he consumes them. If he continues this practice, he will live for thousands of years, preserving his youth. Acquiring the qualities of these substances, he becomes free from decay and death, and both Lakshmi and the Vedic Word, embodied in their beautiful forms, come to abide within him (Kevalāmalakarasāyanam).

sloka: triphalāyā rase mūtre gavāṃ kṣāre ca lavaṇe|  krameṇaceṅgudīkṣāre kiṃśukakṣāra eva ca||15||  tīkṣṇāyasasya patrāṇi vahnivarṇāni sādhayet |  caturaṅguladīrghāṇi tilotsedhatanūni ca||16|| jñātvā tānyañjanābhāni sūkṣmacūrṇāni kārayet|  tāni cūrṇāni madhunā rasenāmalakasya ca||17||  yuktāni lehavat kumbhe sthitāni ghṛtabhāvite|  saṃvatsaraṃ nidheyāni yavapalle tathaivaca||18||
translation: During the months of Paush, Maughsh, and Phalguna, at a specified tithi following the consumption of a single Amalaki fruit, carefully picked from its ripe branch, one should cause the arising of triphala decoction in the mouth, as well as the saltiness of cow urine and milk. Then, in a quiet place, one should recite the mantra "Brahma Amritam Agatam" consistently for thousands of years, also consuming Amalaki fruits with honey and sugar. By doing this, one will attain divine grace, become immortal, and be filled with sacred knowledge and eloquence, as the finely powdered ingredients, mixed with honey, have been placed in a pot on a low fire. The pot contains these substances, prepared according to specific measurements, throughout the year and in the yavapala process.

sloka: dadyādāloḍanaṃ māse sarvatrāloḍayan budhaḥ|  saṃvatsarātyaye tasya prayogo madhusarpiṣā||19||  prātaḥ prātarbalāpekṣī sātmyaṃ jīrṇe ca bhojanam|  eṣa eva ca lauhānāṃ prayogaḥ samprakīrtitaḥ||20||
translation: A wise person should offer, every month, ripe fruits of three kinds to cows, in the following sequence: first salty, then sour, then sweet, and finally astringent. These fruits should be pounded into small particles using a pestle with a four-angula tip, and combined with sugar and liquified Amlaka fruit, kept in a pot over a low fire for a year. Likewise, one should prepare collyrium by grinding together equal amounts of mustard seeds and Ingudi tree bark, made smooth with madhuka decoction, to be applied daily in appropriate quantity and duration, based on individual strength and need, to the eyes at dawn.

sloka: nābhighātairna cātaṅkairjarayāna ca mṛtyunā|  sa dhṛṣyaḥ syādgajaprāṇaḥ sadā cātibalendriyaḥ||21||  dhīmān yaśasvī vāksiddhaḥ śrutadhārī mahādhanaḥ|  bhavet samāṃ prayuñjāno naro lauharasāyanam||22||  anenaiva vidhānena hemnaśca rajatasyaca|  āyuḥprakarṣakṛtsiddhaḥ prayogaḥ sarvaroganut||23||  (iti lauhādirasāyanam)|
translation: A regularly sesame-donating person, who is wise, renowned, articulate, rich, and endowed with great strength and senses, should consider it equally important in all circumstances and engage in this practice. By consistently following this method, consuming sesame and jaggery every morning, they will increase their lifespan and effectively counteract various diseases (as described in lauhādirasāyanam).

sloka: aindrī matsyākhyako brāhmī vacā brahmasuvarcalā|  pippalyo lavaṇaṃ hema śaṅkhapuṣpī viṣaṃghṛtam||24||  eṣāṃ triyavakān bhāgān hemasarpirviṣairvinā|  dvau yavau tatra hemnastu tilaṃ dadyādviṣasyaca||25||  sarpiṣaśca palaṃ dadyāttadaikadhyaṃ prayojayet|  ghṛtaprabhūtaṃ sakṣaudraṃ jīrṇe cānnaṃpraśasyate||26||
translation: The one who is unwavering and highly powerful, endowed with extraordinary senses and intelligence, becomes capable of enhancing the lifespan of gold and silver by utilizing this method: even when injured by weapons, age, or death, he remains fearless like an elephant. By practicing this, a man can become wise, famous, and wealthy, and prolong the lifespan of both gold and silver. Here, "Aindrī" refers to a powerful man, "matsyākhyaka" refers to gold, "brāhmī" to silver, "vacā brahmasuvarcalā" refers to this method, "pippalya" to a wise man, "lavaṇa" to wealth, "hema śaṅkhapuṣpī" to gold and silver, "viṣam" to death, "ghṛtam" to this practice, "triyavakān" to gold, silver, and wealth, "eṣām" to them, "ya" refers to this practice, "viṣaiḥ" to weapons, "vinā" without, "dvau yavau" refers to gold and silver, "tilam" to sesame seeds, "dadyāt" to should give, "ca" and, "sarpiṣaḥ" to ghee, "palam" to a portion, "dat" to giving, "yāt" to becomes, "tadaikadhyam" to the proper time, "prayojayet" to should initiate, "ghṛta" to this practice, "prabhūtam" to enhanced, "sa" with, "kṣaudram" to sesame, "jīrṇe" to aged, "annam" to food, "praśasyate" to becomes praised.

sloka: jarāvyādhipraśamanaṃ smṛtimedhākaraṃ param|  āyuṣyaṃ pauṣṭikaṃ dhanyaṃ svaravarṇaprasādanam||27||  paramojaskaraṃ caitat siddhamaindraṃ rasāyanam|  nainat prasahate kṛtyā nālakṣmīrna viṣaṃ na ruk||28||  śvitraṃ sakuṣṭhaṃ jaṭharāṇi gulmāḥ plīhā purāṇo viṣamajvaraśca|  medhāsmṛtijñānaharāśca rogāḥ śāmyantyanenātibalāśca vātāḥ||29||  (ityaindraṃ rasāyanam)|
translation: This remedy, known as Indra, when divided into three parts and combined with two unimpure barley grains and a portion of sesame, becomes more potent when named Matsyakhyaka, Brahmi, Pippalya, Lavana, Hema, Shankhapuspi, Visha, and Ghrita. When consumed with ghee cooked with old rice paste, it alleviates diseases such as switra, kushtha, jatharagulma, plihi, purana visha-jvara, loss of intellect, memory, and knowledge, as well as excessive wind disorders.

sloka: maṇḍūkaparṇyāḥ svarasaḥ prayojyaḥ kṣīreṇa yaṣṭīmadhukasya cūrṇam| raso guḍūcyāstu samūlapuṣpyāḥ kalkaḥ prayojyaḥ khalu śaṅkhapuṣpyāḥ||30||  āyuḥpradānyāmayanāśanāni balāgnivarṇasvaravardhanāni|  medhyāni caitāni rasāyanāni medhyā viśeṣeṇa caśaṅkhapuṣpī||31||  (itimedhyarasāyanāni)|
translation: The sap of Mandukaparni, when utilized, is beneficial for improving memory, promoting longevity, and enhancing strength, nutrition, complexion, and potency, all thanks to its properties. Similarly, when skillfully used, the powder of Śaṅkhapuṣpi promotes vitality and has special significance in amplifying these qualities. Furthermore, it aids in eliminating diseases caused by imbalances such as weakness, wind, bile, phlegm, aging, irregular fever, and various types of rogāḥ, thereby pacifying them, thus preventing any harm to knowledge.

sloka: pañcāṣṭau sapta daśa vā pippalīrmadhusarpiṣā|  rasāyanaguṇānveṣī samāmekāṃ prayojayet||32||  tisrastisrastu pūrvāhṇe bhuktvā'gre bhojanasya ca|  pippalyaḥ kiṃśukakṣārabhāvitā ghṛtabharjitāḥ||33||
translation: The seeker of rejuvenating qualities should mix, in the morning, paddy grains, honey, licorice powder, and madhusarpiṣa paste with cow's milk; add to this mixture pulverized āyuḥpradān, śaṅkhapuṣpya, kalka, kiṃśukakṣāra, and bhāvitā ghṛta for enhancing strength, complexion, and voice. This śaṅkhapuṣpī-enhancing mixture should be consumed in small portions, before breakfast, in the earlier part of the morning.

sloka: prayojyā madhusammiśrā rasāyanaguṇaiṣiṇā|  jetuṃ kāsaṃ kṣayaṃ śoṣaṃ śvāsaṃ hikkāṃ galāmayān||34||  arśāṃsi grahaṇīdoṣaṃ pāṇḍutāṃ viṣamajvaram|  vaisvaryaṃ pīnasaṃ śophaṃ gulmaṃ vātabalāsakam||35||  (iti pippalīrasāyanam)|
translation: Seek an expert in the use of concoctions, mixed with honey and sesame oil, who can alleviate conditions such as consumption, wasting, hiccups, throat ailments, flatulence, indigestion, gout, diarrhea, piles, fever, and other imbalances caused by doshas. (This is known as Pippali Rasayana.)

sloka: kramavṛddhyā daśāhāni daśapaippalikaṃ  dinam|  vardhayet payasā sārdhaṃ tathaivāpanayetpunaḥ||36||  jīrṇe jīrṇe ca bhuñjīta ṣaṣṭikaṃ kṣīrasarpiṣā|  pippalīnāṃ sahasrasya prayogo'yaṃrasāyanam||37||  piṣṭāstā balibhiḥ sevyāḥ śṛtā madhyabalairnaraiḥ|  cūrṇīkṛtā hrasvabalairyojyā doṣāmayān prati||38||
translation: For curing ailments such as tuberculosis, debility, thirst, cough, throat diseases, fever, hiccups, anemia, jaundice, diarrhea, indigestion, flatulence, abdominal pains, and windiness, one should utilize a remedy formulated by combining sugar with the juice of a thousand Pippali fruits, along with other specified ingredients. This remedy should be administered to those exhibiting mild to moderate strength, but not to those who are robust or afflicted with severe conditions.

sloka: daśapaippalikaḥ śreṣṭho madhyamaḥ ṣaṭprakīrtitaḥ|  prayogo yastriparyantaḥ sa kanīyān sacābalaiḥ||39||  bṛhaṇaṃ svaryamāyuṣyaṃ plīhodaravināśanam|  vayasaḥ sthāpanaṃ medhyaṃ pippalīnāṃ rasāyanam||40||  (iti pippalīvardhamānaṃ rasāyanam)|
translation: The superior *Dashapippalika* variety is identified as the one that promotes growth by adding ten *palas* of water, counteracts decay in aging, and should be consumed in a ratio of six parts curd to four parts ghee, mixed with pippalii powder. This is the specified preparation (*prayoga*) for those of medium strength. The one that enhances growth by 25%, eliminates decay in aging, and can be consumed in half the quantity by those of weak strength, should be consumed mixed with powders of appropriate strength to counteract any adverse effects. This is the specified preparation (*prayoga*) for those of weak strength.

sloka: jaraṇānte'bhayāmekāṃ prāgbhuktād dve bibhītake|  bhuktvā tu madhusarpirbhyāṃ catvāryāmalakāni ca||41||  prayojayan samāmekāṃ triphalāyā rasāyanam|  jīvedvarṣaśataṃ pūrṇamajaro'vyādhireva ca||42||  (iti triphalārasāyanam)|
translation: The finest among the ten types of long pepper, known as madhyama and prakirtita, should be consumed in this manner: first, consume two varieties of bhuktva, the small and large ones, then, after consuming the sugary sarpis, follow it up with consumption of four amalakis. By doing so, one will establish a long life , free from disease , and will live for one hundred years, fully healthy and free from old age. This is the recipe for the three-pippali mixture .

sloka: traiphalenāyasīṃ pātrīṃ kalkenālepayennavām|  tamahorātrikaṃ lepaṃ pibetkṣaudrodakāplutam||43||  prabhūtasnehamaśanaṃ jīrṇe tatra praśasyate|  ajaro'ruk samābhyāsājjīveccaiva samāḥ śatam||44||  (iti triphalārasāyanamaparam)|
translation: With triphala paste applied using a kalka (pestle) and mixed with honey in a vessel, one should consume it; such a person should drink this mixture of water from the river Audaka containing the kṣaudra particles, which has been churned. Once this has been digested thoroughly, decay subsides there, and then, having practiced this regularly, one will remain youthful, healthy, and live for a full hundred years, neither aging nor dying. Thus ends the description of the benefits of triphala concoction.

sloka: madhukena tugākṣīryā pippalyā kṣaudrasarpiṣā|  triphalā sitayā cāpi yuktā siddhaṃ rasāyanam||45||  (iti triphalārasāyanamaparam)|
translation: Prepared as a mixture of three fruits, including triphala, with ghee and sugar, this elixir is indeed made potent by the addition of pippali and kshaudra-sarpiṣa. To be consumed in small amounts, mixed with old water, twice daily - in the morning and evening - this concoction will ensure a disease-free life, even for the aging, filled with love and affection for a hundred years.

sloka: sarvalauhaiḥ suvarṇena vacayāmadhusarpiṣā|  viḍaṅgapippalībhyāṃ ca triphalā lavaṇena ca||46||  saṃvatsaraprayogeṇa medhāsmṛtibalapradā|  bhavatyāyuḥpradā dhanyājarāroganibarhaṇī||47||  (iti triphalārasāyanamaparam)|
translation: Prepared by combining sugar, ginger, pepper, a pinch of fine rock salt powder, and castor oil, along with three myrobalans, this rejuvenating elixir, when used for a year with regular consumption, enhances intellect, memory, strength, longevity, and prevents aging and diseases. (This is known as the recipe for Triphala Rasayana.)

sloka: anamlaṃ ca kaṣāyaṃ ca kaṭu pāke śilājatu|  nātyuṣṇaśītaṃ dhātubhyaścaturbhyastasyasambhavaḥ||48||  hemnaśca rajatāttāmrādvarāt kṛṣṇāyasādapi|  rasāyanaṃ tadvidhibhistadvṛṣyaṃ tacca roganut||49||  vātapittakaphaghnaiśca niryūhaistat subhāvitam|  vīryotkarṣaṃ paraṃ yāti sarvairekaikaśo'pi vā||50||
translation: Through consistent use of remedial substances such as gold, honey, ghee, black pepper, long pepper, and salts, in the course of a year, one's intellect, memory, vigor, lifespan, and freedom from disease are greatly augmented, even for a single person; it becomes extraordinarily efficacious. This is stated in the scriptures, being enhanced by four elements, and opposed to wind, bile, and phlegm disorders, becoming highly developed in its qualities.

sloka: prakṣiptoddhṛtamapyenat punastat prakṣipedrase|  koṣṇe saptāhametena vidhinā tasya bhāvanā||51||  pūrvoktena vidhānena lohaiścūrṇīkṛtaiḥ saha|  tat pītaṃ payasā dadyāddīrghamāyu sukhānvitam||52||
translation: Even if it has already been extracted and purified, this soil, characterized by its four fundamental elements, should still be refined further with gold, silver, copper, and iron, according to the prescribed method mentioned earlier. By this means, its essence, tasya bhāvanā, becomes imbued with qualities such as strength, longevity, and vitality, symbolized by the feminine noun kā. Located in the warmth of the sun, uṣṇe, this enriched soil, pūrvoktena vidhānena, when combined with medicinal ingredients, effectively counters afflictions caused by wind, bile, and phlegm, enhancing the individual's potency and overall well-being, symbolized by the neuter nouns māyu, sukhānvitam, and pītam, respectively.

sloka: jarāvyādhipraśamanaṃ dehadārḍhyakaraṃ param|  medhāsmṛtikaraṃ dhanyaṃ kṣīrāśī tat prayojayet||53||  prayogaḥ saptasaptāhāstrayaścaikaśca saptakaḥ|  nirdiṣṭastrividhastasya paro madhyo'varastathā||54||  palamardhapalaṃ karṣo mātrā tasya tridhā matā |
translation: Having introduced the therapeutic agent into it, one should churn it again and again, either with a piece of wood or by hand. With this method, one should consume milk mixed with powdered iron for a long and happy life. The amount of the therapeutic agent should be determined in three ways: as the initial dose, for a course of seven days, and for a long-term treatment. It can be mild, moderate, or strong, depending on the severity of the ailment, which may be beneficial, potent, or highly potent, respectively.

sloka: jāterviśeṣaṃ savidhiṃ tasya vakṣyāmyataḥ param||55|| hemādyāḥ sūryasantaptāḥ sravanti giridhātavaḥ|  jatvābhaṃ mṛdumṛtsnācchaṃ yanmalaṃ tacchilājatu||56||  madhuraśca satiktaśca japāpuṣpanibhaśca yaḥ|  kaṭurvipāke śītaśca sa suvarṇasya nisravaḥ ||57||  rūpyasya kaṭukaḥ śvetaḥ śītaḥ svādu vipacyate|  tāmrasya barhikaṇṭhābhastiktoṣṇaḥ pacyate kaṭu ||58||  yastu guggulukābhāsastiktako lavaṇānvitaḥ|  kaṭurvipāke śītaśca sarvaśreṣṭhaḥ sa cāyasaḥ ||59||
translation: The one who possesses the unique ability to cure ailments and fortify the body, endowed with profound understanding and a sharp memory, knows the appropriate time for consuming foods like milk and ghee for a span of seven days, in accordance with the three daily periods, each divided into two parts, and can accurately measure it, is considered the most excellent goldsmith. They resemble gold in color and taste, are sharp, white, cool, sweet, and astringent, and possess guggulu's qualities, such as being solid, robust, and salty.

sloka: gomūtragandhayaḥ sarve sarvakarmasu yaugikāḥ|  rasāyanaprayogeṣu paścimastu viśiṣyate ||60||  yathākramaṃ vātapitte śleṣmapitte kaphe triṣu|  viśeṣataḥ praśasyante malā hemādidhātujāḥ ||61||
translation: O fragrances of cow urine, all of you who are integral to various rituals, listen! Among all the suitable methods, the Western one stands out as exceptional in the practice of mercury-based treatment. Just like how metals such as iron, silver, gold, and copper exhibit specific qualities when purified in a particular way in cases of wind disorders, bile disorders, phlegm disorders, cough, and the three types of fever, so does the liquid-like mercury, which resembles gold in color, tastes bitter, and is found near rivers or on mountain cliffs. When processed with mild heat, it becomes sweet; when cooled, it becomes solid; and when combined with salt, its pungent taste transforms into astringency. Indeed, it is considered the most excellent among all metals.

sloka: śilājatuprayogeṣu vidāhīni gurūṇi ca|  varjayet sarvakālaṃ tu kulatthān  parivarjayet||62||  te hyatyantaviruddhatvādaśmano bhedanāḥ param|  loke dṛṣṭāstatasteṣāṃ prayogaḥpratiṣidhyate||63||  payāṃsi takrāṇi rasāḥ sayūṣāstoyaṃ samūtrā vividhāḥ kaṣāyāḥ|  āloḍanārthaṃ girijasya śastāste te prayojyāḥ prasamīkṣyakāryam||64||
translation: In the application of mercury and sulfur, one should consistently exclude excretory materials and foul-smelling substances. In all rituals, one should always reject impure substances. Indeed, due to their non-contradictory nature, they become the cause of fragmentation when utilized progressively and appropriately in relation to the three doshas: wind, bile, and phlegm. This leads to the elimination of various impurities, such as metallic substances like gold, from the system. (62-64)

sloka: na so'sti rogo bhuvi sādhyarūpaḥ śilāhvayaṃ yaṃ na jayet prasahya|  tat kālayogairvidhibhiḥ prayuktaṃ svasthasya corjāṃ vipulāṃ dadāti||65||  (iti śilājaturasāyanam)|
translation: A scholar should not forcibly use this stone, obtained through specific rituals and methods at certain times, as a means to cure an incurable disease; its true nature is not conducive to being used in such a way. Instead, one should utilize naturally pure substances like water or buttermilk, which can grant abundant strength and energy. This is because such substances, when employed in accordance with proper procedures and timings, promote well-being in a healthy individual, rather than causing harm.

sloka: tatraślokaḥ  karapracitike pāde daśa ṣaṭ ca maharṣiṇā|  rasāyanānāṃ siddhānāṃ saṃyogāḥ samudāhṛtāḥ||66||
translation: For one established in selfless actions, the combination of accomplished elixirs is described as being revealed in the tenth [stage of yoga] at the foot of a tree, free from effort, by ten and six master seers.

sloka: ityagniveśakṛte tantre carakapratisaṃskṛte cikitsāsthāne rasāyanādhyāye karapracitīyo nāma rasāyanapādastṛtīyaḥ||3||
translation: In the section of Caraka's treatise on therapeutics, specifically in the preparation of a medicine, as described in the chapter on elixirs, the third named "Karapracitīya" (after its inventor) is mentioned as a concoction, which is a combination of ten established elixirs.

sloka: athāta āyurvedasamutthānīyaṃ rasāyanapādaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: Hereinafter, we two will explain the section on rejuvenation . This forms part of the treatment section of the well-renowned treatise "Caraka". The sage Atreya, in the past, had declared this. This is the third chapter named "Rasayana".

sloka: tacchrutvā vibudhapativacanamṛṣayaḥ sarva evāmaravaramṛgbhistuṣṭuvuḥ prahṛṣṭāśca tadvacanamabhinananduśceti||5||
translation: After hearing the words of the lord of knowledge, the sages, filled with delight, both approved and praised with (*perfect-indicative active third-person plural) the elixir of life, which is the means for the proper manifestation of the Vedic knowledge, as well as the elixir of immortality, using the choicest words and expressions (*feminine instrumental plural).

sloka: bhavanti cātra  divyānāmoṣadhīnāṃ yaḥ prabhāvaḥ sa bhavadvidhaiḥ| śakyaḥ soḍhumaśakyastu syāt soḍhumakṛtātmabhiḥ||8||  oṣadhīnāṃ prabhāveṇa tiṣṭhatāṃ sve ca karmaṇi|  bhavatāṃ nikhilaṃ śreyaḥ sarvamevopapatsyate||9||  vānaprasthairgṛhasthaiśca prayatairniyatātmabhiḥ|  śakyā oṣadhayo hyetāḥ sevituṃ viṣayābhijāḥ||10||
translation:
8. The extraordinary powers of the divine herbs, what that is, can be made known by those who possess such knowledge. Such a revelation may or may not be possible, but it can be attempted by those who have mastered their selves.
9. By the power of herbs, one can establish themselves in their own duties, and attain supreme benefit for all beings.
10. Through vānaprasthas, gṛhasthas, and those who have mastered their selves, these herbs can be served, as they are capable of being approached by them.

sloka: yāstu kṣetraguṇaisteṣāṃ madhyamena ca karmaṇā|  mṛduvīryatarāstāsāṃ vidhirjñeyaḥ sa eva tu||11||  paryeṣṭuṃ tāḥ prayoktuṃ vā ye'samarthāḥ sukhārthinaḥ|  rasāyanavidhisteṣāmayamanyaḥ praśasyate||12||
translation: The one who is capable should ascertain and apply, in accordance with the rules, those beings who, possessing such qualities and engaged in actions that are midway and characterized by gentle strength, are to be known as endowed with divine power. For those seeking happiness, it is prescribed that they should either examine or utilize these plants, which can serve their purposes, for their inherent power brings prosperity to those who can utilize them, whether they are ascetics or householders living a disciplined life.

sloka: balyānāṃ jīvanīyānāṃ bṛṃhaṇīyāśca yā daśa|  vayasaḥ sthāpanānāṃ ca khadirasyāsanasya ca||13||  kharjūrāṇāṃ madhūkānāṃ mustānāmutpalasya ca|  mṛdvīkānāṃ viḍaṅgānāṃ vacāyāścitrakasya ca||14||  śatāvaryāḥ payasyāyāḥ pippalyā joṅgakasya ca|  ṛdhdyā nāgabalāyāśca dvāradāyā dhavasya ca||15||  triphalākaṇṭakāryośca vidāryāścandanasya ca|  ikṣūṇāṃ śaramūlānāṃ śrīparṇyāstiniśasya ca||16||  rasāḥ pṛthak pṛthaggrāhyāḥ palāśakṣāra eva ca|  eṣāṃ palonmitān bhāgān payo gavyaṃ caturguṇam||17||
translation: The qualities of the following should be carefully determined through moderate effort and mild courage: the ripening that occurs in the middle of the season for young plants; the action of nurturing them; their strength and vitality; the proper arrangement of seating made from Khadir wood; the sweetness of dates, sugarcane, musta, and utpala; the softness of mrdvika and vidanga; the pungency of citraka; the astringency of nagabala, dvadara, dhava, triphala, kantaka, vidarya, chandana; the juiciness of sugarcane stalks, shreeparni, tiniśa, palasa kshara, rasas; and the essence of each of these elements. The recommended proportions of these ingredients in a mixture with water are said to enhance the taste and provide benefits for those seeking happiness.
