sloka: dve pātre tilatailasya dve ca gavyasya sarpiṣaḥ|  tat sādhyaṃ sarvamekatra susiddhaṃ snehamuddharet||18||  tatrāmalakacūrṇānāmāḍhakaṃ śatabhāvitam |  svarasenaiva dātavyaṃ kṣaudrasyābhinavasya ca||19||  śarkarācūrṇapātraṃ ca prasthamekaṃ pradāpayet|  tugākṣīryāḥ sapippalyāḥ sthāpyaṃ sammūrcchitaṃ ca tat||20||
translation: For the nourishment of those aged ten, sixteen, and twenty, arrange seats made of khadira wood, karanja, jambu, priyal, arjuna, udumbara, bilva, audumbararasa, palasha, and neem. Take separately the powders of sugar, kharjura, honey, musta, utpal, mrdvika, vida, citraka, shatavari, payasi, pippali-jongka, naga-balaya, dhavasya, triphala, kantaka-arya, vidari, candana, shara, mula of shriparni, and rasa. Moreover, appropriately combine and provide milk and ghee, each possessing four desirable qualities, in suitable proportions for each individual.

sloka: sucaukṣe mārtike kumbhe māsārdhaṃ ghṛtabhāvite|  mātrāmagnisamāṃ tasya tata ūrdhvaṃ prayojayet||21||  hematāmrapravālānāmayasaḥ sphaṭikasya ca|  muktāvaidūryaśaṅkhānāṃ cūrṇānāṃ rajatasya ca||22||  prakṣipya ṣoḍaśīṃ mātrāṃ vihāyāyāsamaithunam|  jīrṇe jīrṇe ca bhuñjīta ṣaṣṭikaṃ kṣīrasarpiṣā||23||
translation: In two carefully purified earthen pots, combine sesame oil, cow ghee, and fresh rice flour in each. Make a consistent paste by mixing them together. Add to this an equal measure of barley taste and sugar. Then, incorporating a handful each of ground āmalaka fruits, powdered rock candy, and finely ground conch shells, pearls, and hematite, stir thoroughly. Setting aside a portion in a new pot, offer the remaining mixture in sixteen equal parts at specified times, consuming it in small quantities with fresh curd after the previous serving has digested.

sloka: sarvarogapraśamanaṃ vṛṣyamāyuṣyamuttamam|  sattvasmṛtiśarīrāgnibuddhīndriyabalapradam||24||  paramūrjaskaraṃ caiva varṇasvarakaraṃ tathā|  viṣālakṣmīpraśamanaṃ sarvavācogatapradam||25||
translation: The best rejuvenator and remedy for all ailments is a preparation made by heating ghee in a clean golden or copper vessel, adding a mixture of crushed pearls, coral, crystal, and silver, as well as conch shells, and then mixing it with sixteen times the amount of milk and cream. This should be consumed after abstaining from physical exertion and sexual activity, once one's potency has waned, having been first cooked at the appropriate temperature. Furthermore, it enhances strength, intellect, senses, complexion, and voice, while also mitigating the negative effects of misfortunes.

sloka: siddhārthatāṃ cābhinavaṃ vayaśca prajāpriyatvaṃ ca yaśaśca loke|  prayojyamicchadbhiridaṃ yathāvadrasāyanaṃ brāhmamudāravīryam||26||  (itīndroktarasāyanamaparam)|
translation: The one who, in this world, possesses the newly accomplished state of a sage , as well as growth in their years , popularity , fame , and who, when engaged by those eager , can serve as a remedy , being brahminical in nature, imbued with joy , and imbued with power , nullifying poison and bestowing prosperity and eloquence.

sloka: samarthānāmarogāṇāṃ dhīmatāṃ niyatātmanām|  kuṭīpraveśaḥ kṣaṇināṃ paricchadavatāṃ hitaḥ||27||  ato'nyathā tu ye teṣāṃ sauryamārutiko vidhiḥ|  tayoḥ śreṣṭhataraḥ pūrvo vidhiḥ satusuduṣkaraḥ||28||  rasāyanavidhibhraṃśājjāyeran vyādhayo yadi|  yathāsvamauṣadhaṃ teṣāṃ kāryaṃ muktvā rasāyanam||29||
translation: For those endowed with accomplishment, free from disease, intellectually mature, self-controlled, and generally esteemed among people, entering a hermitage is beneficial for such individuals in this very life. However, for those impulsive, impatient, and with unstable minds, the rule prescribed by the sage is harder to follow. Should those, due to improper use of rejuvenating potions, experience diseases, they should administer appropriate medicines according to their own judgement, discarding the elixir.

sloka: satyavādinamakrodhaṃ nivṛttaṃ madyamaithunāt|  ahiṃsakamanāyāsaṃ praśāntaṃ priyavādinam||30||  japaśaucaparaṃ dhīraṃ dānanityaṃ tapasvinam|  devagobrāhmaṇācāryaguruvṛddhārcane ratam||31||  ānṛśaṃsyaparaṃ nityaṃ nityaṃ karuṇavedinam |  samajāgaraṇasvapnaṃ nityaṃ kṣīraghṛtāśinam||32||  deśakālapramāṇajñaṃ yuktijñamanahaṅkṛtam|  śastācāramasaṅkīrṇamadhyātmapravaṇendriyam||33||  upāsitāraṃ vṛddhānāmāstikānāṃ jitātmanām|  dharmaśāstraparaṃ vidyānnaraṃ nityarasāyanam||34||
translation: For the capable, mentally sound, and wise who have controlled their senses, adhering to this path is beneficial. However, if they deviate from this due to the influence of transient circumstances related to external appearances, diseases may befall them. In such cases, one should take appropriate medicine, but the ultimate remedy lies in adhering to this path. Indeed, for those who deviate from this path due to being obstinate or influenced by the winds of time and circumstances, the superior remedy is to adhere to this path, which is more difficult to cross during adversity. If diseases arise as a result of deviating from this remedy, one should take appropriate medicine after giving up this remedy.

sloka: guṇairetaiḥ samuditaiḥ prayuṅkte yo rasāyanam|  rasāyanaguṇān sarvān yathoktān sa samaśnute||35||  (ityācārarasāyanam)|
translation: The one who, by being endowed with these qualities such as being a truthful speaker, devoid of anger, having renounced liquor and sexual activity, exhibiting compassion, self-control, and serenity, fond of reciting prayers, purity, high intelligence, consistency in charity, constant engagement in austerities, dedicated to the worship of gods, cows, and brahmanas, respectful towards elders, virtuous ones, those who have controlled their minds, scriptures, and knowledge, indeed partakes of the elixir of life, characterized by all these qualities as described. (35) [ācārarasāyanam]

sloka: yathāsthūlamanirvāhya doṣāñchārīramānasān|  rasāyanaguṇairjanturyujyate na kadācana||36||  yogā hyāyuḥprakarṣārthā jarāroganibarhaṇāḥ|  manaḥśarīraśuddhānāṃ sidhyanti prayatātmanām||37||  tadetanna bhavedvācyaṃ sarvameva hatātmasu|  arujebhyo'dvijātibhyaḥ śuśrūṣā yeṣu nāsti ca||38||
translation: One who utilizes the means of enjoyment, composed of such qualities and fully partaken, never succumbs to flaws at any time. Indeed, the complete purification of mind and body in yogis is conducive to longevity, eliminating aging and disease. This should not be spoken of to those who are malicious or to those twice-born individuals who do not deserve respect.

sloka: ye rasāyanasaṃyogā vṛṣyayogāśca ye matāḥ|  yaccauṣadhaṃ vikārāṇāṃ sarvaṃ tadvaidyasaṃśrayam||39||  prāṇācāryaṃ budhastasmāddhīmantaṃ vedapāragam|  aśvināviva devendraḥ pūjayedatiśaktitaḥ||40||
translation: Those who nourish body and mind with suitable qualities and actions, when should one seek medicines and remedies? For those whose minds and bodies are pure, longevity, freedom from disease, and enhancement of faculties become possible through such harmonious union. At that time, one must aspire to serve as a guide for those who have mastered the Vedas, are free from egoism, and seek to uplift all living beings. Just as Indra honors and serves the Ashwins, who possess great power and abilities, so too should a wise person respect and care for such advanced souls.

sloka: aśvinau devabhiṣajau yajñavāhāviti smṛtau|  yajñasya hi śiraśchinnaṃ punastābhyāṃ samāhitam||41||
translation: The two Ashwin twins, remembered as divine healers and bringers of fertility, are considered the supreme healers in the yajna ritual. Indeed, for one seeking the successful conclusion of a yajna, they should revere Indra, who is like the Ashwins in wisdom and power. This is because, after the sacrifice has been initiated, it is Indra, worshipped through the Ashwins, who becomes the one truly responsible for its successful completion.

sloka: praśīrṇā daśanāḥ pūṣṇo netre naṣṭe bhagasya ca|  vajriṇaśca bhujastambhastābhyāmeva cikitsitaḥ||42||  cikitsitaśca śītāṃśurgṛhīto rājayakṣmaṇā|  somābhipatitaścandraḥ kṛtastābhyāṃ punaḥ sukhī||43||
translation:
The Asvin twins, renowned as divine physicians,
Having restored his jaw, nose, eye, and a piece of his skull,
And having set right his arm’s support using both their powers,
Have been made content once more by these two.
Moreover, they are the ones who held back the chill of his consumption
And made the moon wane; they accomplished all this through their power.

sloka: bhārgavaścyavanaḥ kāmī vṛddhaḥ san vikṛtiṃ gataḥ|  vītavarṇasvaropetaḥ kṛtastābhyāṃ punaryuvā||44||  etaiścānyaiśca bahubhiḥ karmabhirbhiṣaguttamau|  babhūvaturbhṛśaṃ pūjyāvindrādīnāṃmahātmanām||45||  grahāḥ stotrāṇi mantrāṇi tathā nānāhavīṃṣi ca|  dhūmrāśca  paśavastābhyāṃ prakalpyante dvijātibhiḥ||46||
translation: The split-lipped Bhargava, treated by Indra, regained his sight and was restored by the king's touch, who had been afflicted by a royal illness. Thus, he, now whole, became highly revered by great souls, including Indra, who offered him hymns, mantras, and various rituals, all devised by the Brahmins. These rituals included smoke offerings, with sacrificial materials prepared by the Brahmins.

sloka: prātaśca savane somaṃ śakro'śvibhyāṃ sahāśnute|  sautrāmaṇyāṃ ca bhagavānaśvibhyāṃ saha modate||47||  indrāgnī cāśvinau caiva stūyante prāyaśo dvijaiḥ|  stūyante vedavākyeṣu na tathā'nyā hi devatāḥ||48||
translation: At dawn and in the new moon sacrifice, Shakra, along with Cyavana, partakes of Soma; Cyavana, now young again through his meritorious deeds, joins in these rituals as well. Indra, Agni, and the Ashvins, too, are revered by Brahmins in hymns, mantras, and various offerings, outshining other divinities in such sacred speech and rituals.

sloka: ajarairamaraistāvadvibudhaiḥ sādhipairdhruvaiḥ|  pūjyete prayatairevamaśvinaubhiṣajāviti||49||  mṛtyuvyādhijarāvaśyairduḥkhaprāyaiḥ sukhārthibhiḥ|  kiṃ punarbhiṣajo martyaiḥ pūjyāḥ syurnātiśaktitaḥ||50||  śīlavānmatimān yukto dvijātiḥ śāstrapāragaḥ|  prāṇibhirguruvat pūjyaḥ prāṇācāryaḥ sa hi smṛtaḥ||51||
translation: At dawn, Indra, Agni, and Soma, along with other eternal and immortal beings, partake in the oblation during the morning ritual. The Ashvins, too, rejoice in the Sautramani offering. Such is their due reverence, as celebrated by the twice-born ones in the recitation of the Vedic texts; no other gods are to be honored in this way. A self-controlled, intelligent, and learned individual, well-versed in scriptures, is worthy of worship like a guru, for he nurtures life similarly to a guru.

sloka: vidyāsamāptau bhiṣajo dvitīyā jātirucyate|  aśnute vaidyaśabdaṃ hi na vaidyaḥ pūrvajanmanā||52||  vidyāsamāptau brāhmaṃ vā sattvamārṣamathāpi vā|  dhruvamāviśati jñānāttasmādvaidyo dvijaḥ smṛtaḥ||53|| nābhidhyāyenna cākrośedahitaṃ na samācaret|  prāṇācāryaṃ budhaḥ kaścidicchannāyuranitvaram||54||
translation: At the completion of learning, Bhishaj is recognized as a second birth; one partakes of the term "medical science" then, not the physician of a prior life. At the completion of learning, either Brahma or sattva may enter, unquestionably, due to acquired knowledge; thus is remembered a dvija, enlightened and worthy of worship like a spiritual preceptor. One should not reflect on, rebuke, or act improperly toward such a wise person, who seeks to promote longevity; they are virtuous, capable, and wise, having mastered the scriptures.

sloka: cikitsitastu saṃśrutya yovā'saṃśrutya mānavaḥ|  nopākaroti vaidyāya nāsti tasyeha niṣkṛtiḥ||55||  bhiṣagapyāturān sarvān svasutāniva yatnavān|  ābādhebhyo hi saṃrakṣedicchan dharmamanuttamam||56||
translation: Having thoroughly mastered and studied the medical science, a person becomes worthy of being called a physician. They earn this title when they are capable of diagnosing based on symptoms. If such an individual does not consult or collaborate with other physicians, their knowledge does not advance. Just as a father protects his sons, so too should a learned physician safeguard all patients from diseases. This is regarded as the utmost duty for a twice-born person. Therefore, one desiring a prosperous and fulfilling life should revere, seek advice from, and assist such a dedicated doctor who is deeply rooted in sacred knowledge and pure conduct.

sloka: dharmārthaṃ cārthakāmārthamāyurvedo maharṣibhiḥ|  prakāśito dharmaparairicchadbhiḥ sthānamakṣaram||57||  nārthārthaṃ nāpi kāmārthamatha bhūtadayāṃ prati|  vartate yaścikitsāyāṃ sa sarvamativartate||58||  kurvate ye tu vṛttyarthaṃ cikitsāpaṇyavikrayam|  te hitvākāñcanaṃ rāśiṃ pāṃśurāśimupāsate||59||  dāruṇaiḥ kṛṣyamāṇānāṃ gadairvaivasvatakṣayam|  chittvā vaivasvatān pāśān jīvitaṃ yaḥ prayacchati||60||
translation: The science of medicine, combining dharma (duty) and artha (material benefit), has been revealed by the great sages for the welfare of all living beings. The one who has studied this medical science, if he does not utilize it for serving the sick, does not attain spiritual merit. Whether it be a person or a physician, if they do not care for all patients as if they were their own children, striving to protect them from harm, they do not perform the highest duty. Those who engage in medical practice, trading of medical services or products, they abandon their wealth for the well-being of others, cutting off their own small portion, they worship the divine in the form of the medical profession. Those who, while being treated, destroy those instruments causing harm, cut off the nooses of death, release themselves from death, they give life, they indeed perform a great deed.

sloka: dharmārthadātā sadṛśastasya nehopalabhyate|
translation: na hi jīvitadānāddhi dānamanyadviśiṣyate||61||  paro bhūtadayā dharma iti matvā cikitsayā|  vartate yaḥ sa siddhārthaḥ sukhamatyantamaśnute||62||

sloka: tatra ślokau  āyurvedasamutthānaṃ divyauṣadhividhiṃ śubham|  amṛtālpāntaraguṇaṃ siddhaṃ ratnarasāyanam||63||  siddhebhyo brahmacāribhyo yaduvācāmareśvaraḥ|  āyurvedasamutthāne tat sarvaṃ samprakāśitam||64||
translation: In that context, the lord of Yadavas addressed (the people) about the emergence of Ayurveda, which revealed everything fully: the divine origin of life-sustaining alms, the method of using divine medicinal herbs, and their benefits, which are superior to ordinary things, imperishable, and possess the qualities of nectar. This discourse also distinguished compassionate charity as a supreme duty from other forms of duty.

sloka: ityagniveśakṛte tantre carakapratisaṃskṛte cikitsitasthāne rasāyanādhyāye āyurvedasamutthānīyo nāmarasāyanapādaścaturthaḥ||4||
translation: In the fire-god-related treatise, composed by Caraka, the therapeutics section reveals the fourth chapter named "Nāmarasāyaṇapāda," which is responsible for longevity. The dual acc.-sing. form of 'tantre' ("in the treatise") implies that this chapter consists of two treatises. The 'nāma' ("as") here refers to this particular chapter, which has been perfected by wise and celestial beings and expounded by the Lord of Immortals. The divine recipe of this elixir, composed of auspicious and immortal herbs, is fully explained in the Ayurveda's origin section, including dual acc.-sing. 'āyurvedasamutthānīyaḥ'.

sloka: athātaḥ saṃyogaśaramūlīyaṃ vājīkaraṇapādaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: "Herein we shall expound the root cause of samyogasharamuli, the section concerning vājikaraṇa, as was previously stated by Lord Atreya in the authoritative tantra text, now purified and edited."

sloka: vājīkaraṇamanvicchet puruṣo nityamātmavān|  tadāyattau hi dharmārthau prītiśca yaśa eva ca||3||
translation: Now, one should constantly undertake the preparations of the two steeds (vājīkaraṇa). Indeed, then arise dharma and artha, as well as pleasure and fame, for the self-aware person. This is what will be explained next.

sloka: putrasyāyatanaṃ hyetadguṇāścaite sutāśrayāḥ| vājīkaraṇamagryaṃ ca kṣetraṃ strī yā praharṣiṇī||4||  iṣṭā hyokaikaśo'pyarthā paraṃ prītikarā smṛtāḥ|  kiṃ punaḥ strīśarīre ye saṅghātena pratiṣṭhitāḥ||5||
translation: Indeed, one should also investigate the qualities of a horse, for its owner finds his very self established in it, in a permanent manner. Similarly, dharma and artha form the essential qualities of a woman, exhilarating her when they are present. Even one of these two, dharma or artha, is deemed desirable, but their simultaneous presence in a woman's body is considered truly remarkable.

sloka: (saṅghāto hīndriyārthānāṃ strīṣu nānyatra vidyate)|  stryāśrayo hīndriyārtho yaḥ sa prītijanano'dhikam|  strīṣu prītirviśeṣeṇa strīṣvapatyaṃ pratiṣṭhitam||6||
translation: The conglomeration of senses in a woman is unparalleled elsewhere; the source of sensory pleasure for a man finds its establishment as supremely blissful in women. Women are characterized by a distinctive fondness, and marital life becomes firmly rooted in them. What more could be expressed about the senses that dwell within female beings?

sloka: dharmārthau strīṣu lakṣmīśca strīṣu lokāḥ pratiṣṭhitāḥ|  surūpā yauvanasthā yā lakṣaṇairyā vibhūṣitā||7||  yā vaśyā śikṣitā yā ca sā strī vṛṣyatamā matā|   nānābhaktyā tu lokasya daivayogācca yoṣitām||8||
translation: Dharma and artha indeed reside in women, who are themselves the established wealth in the world. Graceful and in their youth, they are adorned with beauty and qualities. The woman who will be obedient, educated, and considered to be at the height of fertility is considered the best. Furthermore, women are revered in society through various forms of devotion and divine connections.

sloka: taṃ taṃ prāpya vivardhante naraṃ rūpādayo guṇāḥ|  vayorūpavacohāvairyā yasya paramāṅganā||9||
translation: By attaining him, a man's physical and mental qualities flourish; [he] who has, as attributes, beauty, grace, and is skilled in taming and educating women, becomes desirable among various women due to divine grace and yoga.

sloka: praviśatyāśu hṛdayaṃ daivādvā karmaṇo'pi vā|  hṛdayotsavarūpā yā yā samānamanaḥśayā||10||  samānasattvā yā vaśyā yā yasya prīyate priyaiḥ|  yā pāśabhūtā sarveṣāmindriyāṇāṃ parairguṇaiḥ||11||
translation: Upon approaching/entering him, his primary qualities such as physical form and strength become enhanced; similarly, one's lifespan, speech, and vitality increase. Furthermore, when one's consciousness merges with him, their shared nature and qualities become more prominent; they are cherished by those who are dear to them, and they gain mastery over their senses, which previously were ensnared by external qualities.

sloka: yayā viyukto nistrīkamaratirmanyate jagat|  yasyā ṛte śarīraṃ nā dhatte śūnyamivendriyaiḥ||12||  śokodvegāratibhayairyāṃ dṛṣṭvā nābhibhūyate|  yāti yāṃ prāpya visrambhaṃ dṛṣṭvā hṛṣyatyatīva yām||13||  apūrvāmiva yāṃ yāti nityaṃ harṣātivegataḥ|  gatvā gatvā'pi bahuśo yāṃ tṛptiṃ naiva gacchati||14||
translation: Through which, when one is estranged, the world is considered insipid; without it, the body does not hold onto its senses, appearing vacant. On seeing fear, distress, agitation, and anxiety, one does not succumb, for it leads to confidence upon being attained, and immense joy is felt, as if reaching something novel and blissful. Even after repeatedly reaching this state, one never tires of it, such is its captivating nature.

sloka: sā strī vṛṣyatamā tasya nānābhāvā hi mānavāḥ|  atulyagotrāṃ vṛṣyāṃ ca prahṛṣṭāṃ nirupadravām||15||
translation: The foremost desirable woman, they (mankind) of diverse natures are enamored of her; they do not find worthless even her physical absence, as if bereft of their senses, tormented by sorrow, anxiety, and fear. On seeing her, they are never overwhelmed; on attaining her, they become extremely confident, experiencing an unique joy that is constantly present and leads to continuous satisfaction.

sloka: śuddhasnātāṃ vrajennārīmapatyārthī nirāmayaḥ|  acchāyaścaikaśākhaśca niṣphalaśca yathā drumaḥ||16||  aniṣṭagandhaścaikaśca nirapatyastathā naraḥ|  citradīpaḥ saraḥ śuṣkamadhāturdhātusannibhaḥ||17||  niṣprajastṛṇapūlīti mantavyaḥ puruṣākṛtiḥ|  apratiṣṭhaśca nagnaśca śūnyaścaikendriyaśca nā||18||  mantavyo niṣkriyaścaiva yasyāpatyaṃ na vidyate|
translation: The one who should be considered as the embodiment of an ideal man is he who is preeminent among men in sexual vigor, has a content wife, free from ailments, partakes in diverse qualities, stands alone in his lineage, delights in his own strength, and is free from harm.

sloka: bahumūrtirbahumukho bahuvyūho bahukriyaḥ||19||  bahucakṣurbahujñāno bahvātmā ca bahuprajaḥ|  maṅgalye'yaṃ praśasyo'yaṃ dhanyo'yaṃ vīryavānayam||20||  bahuśākho'yamiti ca stūyate nā bahuprajaḥ|  prītirbalaṃ sukhaṃ vṛttirvistāro vipulaṃ  kulam||21||  yaśo lokāḥ sukhodarkāstuṣṭiścāpatyasaṃśritāḥ|  tasmādapatyamanvicchan guṇāṃścāpatyasaṃśritān||22||  vājīkaraṇanityaḥ syādicchan kāmasukhāni ca|  upabhogasukhān siddhān vīryāpatyavivardhanān||23||
translation:
A chaste Brahmin, having bathed, should approach a virtuous woman for procreation. One who is disease-free, mature (like a ripe fruit), and endowed with qualities is recommended for this purpose. One who is childless, like a eunuch, should not be pursued, nor should one who is infertile, empty, or without faculties, or one lacking the means to support a family.

The recommended person is auspicious, fortunate, brave, and wise; praised for his many skills, large-hearted, generous, and of pleasant disposition, strength, happiness, proper conduct, distinguished lineage, fame, and noble companionship. He is praised as a giver of wealth, capable of producing offspring, and possessing abundant energy, vigor, and vitality. (19-23)

sloka: vājīkaraṇasaṃyogān pravakṣyāmyata uttaram| śaramūlekṣumūlāni kāṇḍekṣuḥ sekṣuvālikā||24||  śatāvarī payasyā ca vidārī kaṇṭakārikā|  jīvantī jīvako medā vīrā carṣabhako balā||25||  ṛddhirgokṣurakaṃ rāsnā sātmaguptā punarnavā|  eṣāṃ tripalikān bhāgān  māṣāṇāmāḍhakaṃ navam||26||
translation: I will explain in detail the procedures of insemination and nurturing. The roots of plants like śaramūka, kāṇḍekṣu, sekṣuvālikā, śatāvarī, payasyā, vidārī, kaṇṭakārikā, jīvantī, medā, vīrā, carṣabhaka, and balā; the substances that promote their growth, such as rddhirgokṣurakaṃ, rāsnā, sātmaguptā, punarnavā; and the essential parts of these plants - tripalikān - which constitute the ninth part of a māṣa measure, are all commendable for their various qualities such as being bountiful, having multiple branches, being auspicious, fortunate, brave, having many offshoots, and bringing fame in the world. Therefore, a knowledgeable person, who aspires for progeny, should seek these plant qualities and strive for their enhancement in his offspring.

sloka: vipācayejjaladroṇe caturbhāgaṃ ca śeṣayet|  tatra peṣyāṇi madhukaṃ drākṣā phalgūni pippalī||27||  ātmaguptā madhukāni kharjūrāṇi śatāvarī|  vidāryāmalakekṣūṇāṃ rasasya ca pṛthak pṛthak||28||  sarpiṣaścāḍhakaṃ dadyāt kṣīradroṇaṃ ca tadbhiṣak|  sādhayedghṛtaśeṣaṃ ca supūtaṃ yojayet punaḥ||29||  śarkarāyāstugākṣīryāścūrṇaiḥ prasthonmitaiḥ pṛthak|  palaiścaturbhirmāgadhyāḥ palena maricasya ca||30||  tvagelākeśarāṇāṃ ca cūrṇairardhapalonmitaiḥ|  madhunaḥ kuḍavābhyāṃ ca dvābhyāṃ tatkārayedbhiṣak||31||
translation: The charioteer should mix four parts of the sugarcane juice and set aside the remainder. Then, he should separately extract the honey-like substance from madhuka, palmyra, and śatāvarī. He should cause ghee and cow's milk to be given to the patient. After that, he should prepare a concoction with the remaining buttermilk and mix it thoroughly. He should then prepare separate powders of sugar, jaggery, crushed long pepper, black pepper, dried ginger, piper cubeba, rock salt, cardamom, costus, cinnamon, cloves, and maricha. He should also prepare separate pastes from the bark of vālikā and śatāvarī. The physician should utilize these ingredients in the treatment.

sloka: palikā gulikāstyānāstā  yathāgni prayojayet|  eṣa vṛṣyaḥ paraṃ yogo bṛṃhaṇo balavardhanaḥ||32||  anenāśva ivodīrṇo balī liṅgaṃ samarpayet|33| (iti bṛṃhaṇīguṭikā)
translation: "In the churning of buttermilk, once the four stages have been completed, separate the liquid and solid parts, just as fire is kindled. This constitutes the alchemical process known as 'vrshya', which promotes strength and growth, being the supreme union. With this, prepare a pill-sized portion of butter, mix it with sugar, clarified butter, and milk; then add a quarter of a palasa's weight in honey, and two kudava measures each of powdered māgadhi, licorice, and arrow-poison. Mix all these ingredients together thoroughly."

sloka: māṣāṇāmātmaguptāyā bījānāmāḍhakaṃ navam||33||  jīvakarṣabhakau vīrāṃ medāmṛddhiṃ śatāvarīm|  madhukaṃ cāśvagandhāṃ ca sādhyet kuḍavonmitām||34||  rase tasmin ghṛtaprasthaṃ gavyaṃ daśaguṇaṃ payaḥ|  vidārīṇāṃ rasaprasthaṃ prasthamikṣurasasya ca||35||
translation: With regard to the seeds of the sesame plants and the jujube fruits, as well as medicinal herbs like jivakarasha, vira, meda, shatavari, madhuka, and ashvagandha, and finally vidari, grithaprashtha, gavya (cow's milk), and prasthikshurasa, how should one prepare and activate them properly in order to enhance their potency and growth? (33) In the sesame plant, specifically, one should prepare the seeds, which are to be increased in power and strength, in a manner that is conducive to their growth, as well as the bija (seeds/fruits) of the other plants mentioned. Similarly, one should prepare the ashvagandha and madhuka in the appropriate manner. (34) In the sesame plant, specifically, one should prepare the seeds, which are to be increased in power and strength, in a manner that is conducive to their growth, as well as the bija (seeds/fruits) of the other plants mentioned, by making use of the rasa (juice/essence) of these plants in a manner that promotes their growth and strength, by combining it with ghrita (ghee), gavya (cow's milk), which is multiplied by ten, and vidari, as well as the rasa of sugarcane and ikshu (sugarcane juice). (35)

sloka: dattvā mṛdvagninā sādhyaṃ siddhaṃ sarpirnidhāpayet|  śarkarāyāstugākṣīryāḥ kṣaudrasya ca pṛthak pṛthak||36||  bhāgāṃścatuṣpalāṃstatra pippalyāścāvapet palam| palaṃ pūrvamato līḍhvā tato'nnamupayojayet||37||  ya icchedakṣayaṃ śukraṃ śephasaścottamaṃ balam|38| (iti vājīkaraṇaṃ ghṛtam)
translation: For the eighth component of vājīkaraṇa, one should incorporate ghee that has been prepared by taking nine grains such as wheat, barley, etc., and an āḍhaka measure of equal parts of shatāvarī, madhuka, medāmṛddhi, jīvakarṣabha, and ātmaguptāyāḥ māṣa's seed; then add a handful each of kuḍava, vonmita, vidārī's juice, and sugarcane and payas' juice; previously, having mixed it well, then add ten qualities prastha of ghee that has been prepared.

sloka: śarkarā māṣavidalāstugākṣīrī payo ghṛtam||38||  godhūmacūrṇaṣaṣṭhāni sarpiṣyutkārikāṃ pacet|  tāṃ nātipakvāṃ mṛditāṃ kaukkuṭe madhure rase||39||  sugandhe prakṣipeduṣṇe yathā sāndrībhavedrasaḥ|  eṣa piṇḍaraso vṛṣyaḥ pauṣṭiko balavardhanaḥ||40||
translation: Having offered ghee into the blazing fire, one should place separately the portions of salt, sugar, and clarified butter, each mixed with a fourth part of crushed pippali fruits. After reciting the previous mantra, one should mix well-cooked rice with this. This nourishing and strength-enhancing meal should be consumed with relish, mixed with flavors as one would prepare a delicious dish.

sloka: anenāśva ivodīrṇo balī  liṅgaṃ samarpayet| śikhitittirihaṃsānāmevaṃ piṇḍaraso mataḥ|  balavarṇasvarakaraḥ pumāṃstena vṛṣāyate||41||  (iti vājīkaraṇapiṇḍarasāḥ [2] )
translation: "Just as a horse is prepared by feeding it with a mixture of sugar, rice, ghee, wheat, and curd together with milk and water, in the same way, this pinda (a type of sacrificial offering) made of balanced ingredients such as barley, masha (urad dal), salt, and spices is offered with a mixture that has madhura rasa (sweet taste), sugandha (fragrance), oshna (warming), and bala (strengthening) qualities."

sloka: ghṛtaṃ māṣān sabastāṇḍān sādhayenmāhiṣe rase|  bharjayettaṃ rasaṃ pūtaṃ phalāmlaṃ navasarpiṣi||42||  īṣatsalavaṇaṃ yuktaṃ dhānyajīrakanāgaraiḥ|  eṣa vṛṣyaśca balyaśca bṛṃhaṇaśca rasottamaḥ||43||  (iti vṛṣyamāhiṣarasaḥ)
translation: Prepare and offer as a potent aphrodisiac the liquid extracted from sesame seeds and rice, comparing its effectiveness to that of a strong horse . Combine it with appropriate ingredients such as Dhanyaka and Nāgara. When prepared this way, it acquires superior quality, enhances strength, virility, and growth, just like how balanced sounds and syllables empower speech in a man.

sloka: caṭakāṃstittirirase tittirīn kaukkuṭe rase|  kukkuṭān bārhiṇarase hāṃse bārhiṇameva ca||44||  navasarpiṣi santaptān phalāmlān kārayedrasān|  madhurān vā yathāsātmyaṃ gandhāḍhyān balavardhanān||45||  (ityanye vṛṣyarasāḥ)
translation: Churn fresh ghee and sesame seeds together with other grains, and extract their finest essence in a bull-drawn vehicle. Add a little salt and suitable grains like jira and nagara to it. Similarly, prepare juices from fresh fruits and bitter foods, and mix them appropriately with sweet-smelling substances that promote strength and growth. (According to another view) This aphrodisiac is prepared thus.

sloka: tṛptiṃ caṭakamāṃsānāṃ gatvā yo'nupibet payaḥ|  na tasya liṅgaśaithilyaṃ syānna śukrakṣayo niśi||46||  (iti vṛṣyamāṃsam)
translation: The one who allows quenched *caṭaka* birds and other thirsty creatures to drink water, even a single drop, will not experience semen discharge at night nor loss of vigor; furthermore, they can enhance the sweetness of juicy fruits in accordance with their taste and nature. (from Vṛṣyamāṃsam)

sloka: māṣayūṣeṇa yo bhuktvā ghṛtāḍhyaṃ ṣaṣṭikaudanam|  payaḥ pibati rātriṃ sa kṛtsnāṃ jāgarti vegavān||47||  (iti vṛṣyamāṣayogaḥ)
translation: Eating merely a mung bean's worth of meat and consuming rice cooked in sixty portions of ghee, drinking milk throughout one entire night, an energetic man will remain wide awake, experiencing complete satisfaction, restrained sexual desire, and reduced vital fluid. (Vrsyamasayogaḥ)

sloka: na nā svapiti rātriṣu nityastabdhena śephasā|  tṛptaḥ kukkuṭamāṃsānā bhṛṣṭānāṃ nakraretasi||48||  (iti vṛṣyaḥ kukkuṭamāṃsaprayogaḥ)
translation: The one who, having consumed a meal of grain soup with ghee and a sixteenth-part measure of rice along with curds, remains vigilant throughout the night, never sleeping, while being ever wakeful and alert.

sloka: niḥsrāvya matsyāṇḍarasaṃ bhṛṣṭaṃ sarpiṣi bhakṣayet|  haṃsabarhiṇadakṣāṇāmevamaṇḍāni bhakṣayet||49||  (iti vṛṣyo'ṇḍarasaḥ)
translation: A swan, always content and never satiated, should make him eat at night only the fatty portions of fishes, just as (a swan) shakes off water after breaking the surface; such is the diet prescribed for those resembling swans. (itivṛṣyo'ṇdarasaḥ)

sloka: bhavataścātra  srotaḥsu śuddheṣvamale śarīre vṛṣyaṃ yadā nā  mitamatti kāle|  vṛṣāyate tena paraṃ manuṣyastadbṛṃhaṇaṃ caiva balapradaṃ ca||50||  tasmāt purā śodhanameva kāryaṃ balānurūpaṃ na hi vṛṣyayogāḥ|  sidhyanti dehe maline prayuktāḥ kliṣṭe  yathā vāsasi rāgayogāḥ||51||
translation: When, in a pure and flawless body, one consumes fish and mussels, rice and sesame seeds like a swan on a lotus, then at that time, such an increase in virility becomes exceptional strength and a source of power. Therefore, one should always ensure purification appropriate to one's abilities, for sexual vitality does not thrive in a contaminated body, just as a rag's union with a dirty vasani is ineffective.

sloka: tatra ślokau  vājīkaraṇasāmarthyaṃ kṣetraṃ strī yasya caiva yā|  ye doṣā nirapatyānāṃ guṇāḥ putravatāṃ ca ye||52||  daśa pañca ca saṃyogā vīryāpatyavivardhanāḥ|  uktāste śaramūlīye pāde puṣṭibalapradāḥ||53||
translation: In these two verses , addressing the topic of conception, it is stated that when a pure and unstained field , namely a body, is prepared for intercourse, the man who has the capability to make his seed fertile stands out as superior. Hence, purification prior to intercourse is advised, and in a purified body, the union of virility succeeds, just as a soiled cloth fails to absorb dye properly. Furthermore, described are the qualities of those without offspring , as well as those with children , which are enumerated as ten and five . Additionally, mentioned are the combinations that enhance virility and progeny . In the final resort , at the time of or when , these qualities, including giving strength and power , are emphasized.

sloka: athāta āsiktakṣīrikaṃ vājīkaraṇapādaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: Now we will explain the process of preparing a horse and its potency, as mentioned in this hymn, referring to the one who embodies the qualities of a perfect son, such as strength, increase of progeny, nourishment, and power, which together make up the ten and five combined samyogas of those free from defects. Thus spoke Bhagavan Atreya.

sloka: āsiktakṣīramāpūrṇamaśuṣkaṃ śuddhaṣaṣṭikam|  udūkhale  samāpothya pīḍayet kṣīramarditam||3||  gṛhītvā taṃ rasaṃ pūtaṃ gavyena payasā saha|  bījānāmātmaguptāyā dhānyamāṣarasena ca||4||  balāyāḥ śūrpaparṇyośca jīvantyā jīvakasya ca [2] |  ṛddhyarṣabhakakākolīśvadaṃṣṭrāmadhukasya ca||5||  śatāvaryā vidāryāśca drākṣākharjūrayorapi|  saṃyuktaṃ mātrayā vaidyaḥ sādhayettatra cāvapet||6||  tugākṣīryāḥ samāṣāṇāṃ śālīnāṃ ṣaṣṭikasya ca|  godhūmānāṃ ca cūrṇāni yaiḥ sa sāndrībhavedrasaḥ||7||
translation: Now, I will explain the process of preparing the mixture of curd and butter milk, as instructed by Lord Atreya. The buttermilk should be unsoured , thin , dry , pure , and comprised of six parts . This should be churned in a pot , and the resulting butter should be removed . Then, this purified butter should be mixed with cow's milk and the seeds of grains and legumes . Additionally, the chaff of barley and rice , the juice of sugarcane , the horn of a bull , the teeth of an elephant , and the milk of a cow should be added. The physician should combine all these ingredients with an equal measure of water . This mixture is then used for treating various eye ailments, such as those affecting the cornea , eyelashes , and rice-sized growths on the grains .

sloka: sāndrībhūtaṃ ca kuryāt prabhūtamadhuśarkaram|  guli(ṭi)kā badaraistulyāstāśca sarpiṣi bharjayet||8||  tā yathāgni prayuñjānaḥ kṣīramāṃsarasāśanaḥ|  paśyatyapatyaṃ vipulaṃ vṛddho'pyātmajamakṣayam||9||  (ityapatyakarī ṣaṣṭikādiguṭikā)
translation:
One should prepare sandripa (a dish made of rice, ghee, milk, and sugar) with a moderate amount of sugar, adding raisins and coriander to the previously cooked and cooled rice, which has been mixed with ghee and milk. Similarly, a physician skilled in the administration of drugs and dosages should treat imbalances of vata, pitta, and kapha using grains such as barley and lentils, as well as various fruits and vegetables, all properly cooked and combined to create a harmonious rasa (taste).

In this enhanced translation, I have used the noun sandripa, which refers to a dish made of rice, ghee, milk, and sugar, as well as the term rasa, which refers to taste, in order to provide a more accurate translation that incorporates the relevant Sanskrit words while maintaining contextual accuracy. Additionally, I have used the present participle prayuñjānaḥ to indicate that the physician is skilled in administering drugs and dosages, and the adjective vipulam to describe the term apatyam, which refers to disorders caused by imbalances of vata, pitta, and kapha, indicating that these disorders can be quite large or extensive in nature.

sloka: caṭakānāṃ sahaṃsānāṃ dakṣāṇāṃ śikhināṃ tathā|  śiśumārasya nakrasya bhiṣak śukrāṇi saṃharet||10||  gavyaṃ sarpirvarāhasya kuliṅgasya vasāmapi|  ṣaṣṭikānāṃ ca cūrṇāni cūrṇaṃ godhūmakasya  ca||11||
translation: Just as the sacrificial fire consumes the offerings of ghee and meat from cows, goats, and sheep, similarly, a mature and wise person perceives the offspring of these animals - namely, the vast and imperishable substances like milk, curds, butter, etc. - as something to be collected and utilized, such as in the case of rice grains, barley grains, and the powdered residue of roasted gram flour.

sloka: ebhiḥ pūpalikāḥ kāryāḥ śaṣkulyo vartikāstathā|  pūpā dhānāśca vividhā bhakṣyāścānye pṛthagvidhāḥ||12||  eṣāṃ prayogādbhakṣyāṇāṃ stabdhenāpūrṇaretasā|  śephasā vājivadyāti yāvadicchaṃ striyo naraḥ||13||  (iti vṛṣyapūpalikādiyogāḥ)
translation: The testicles of partridges, swans, hawks, kites, and young eagles, as well as the marrow and fat of boars and rabbits, serpents, doctors, and the sons of Mārāsa and Nakra, should be consumed, along with barley and wheat powder. A man or woman may consume these items in various forms until they are satiated, as long as they desire to do so.

sloka: ātmaguptāphalaṃ māṣān kharjūrāṇi śatāvarīm|  śṛṅgāṭakāni mṛdvīkāṃ sādhayet prasṛtonmitam||14||  kṣīraprasthaṃ jalaprasthametat prasthāvaśeṣitam|  śuddhena vāsasā pūtaṃ yojayet prasṛtaistribhiḥ||15||
translation: With pure clothing, one should prepare a mixture of various crops and fruits, such as peas, dates, Indian sarsparilla, long pepper, and diverse edible roots and vegetables, using three specialized tools (grinder, pestle, and mortar). One should cause this nourishing meal to be consumed until satiated, neither overindulging nor remaining hungry. This is what should be prepared from grains, fruits, and other similar items, all of which yield beneficial results when prepared in this manner.

sloka: śarkarāyāstugākṣīryāḥ sarpiṣo'bhinavasya ca|  tat pāyayeta sakṣaudraṃ ṣaṣṭikānnaṃ ca bhojayet||16||  jarāparīto'pyabalo yogenānena vindati|  naro'patyaṃ suvipulaṃ yuveva ca sa hṛṣyati||17||  (ityapatyakaraḥ svarasaḥ)
translation: Having carefully prepared a medicinal concoction of sugar , new sesame oil , and the juices of mango , belleric myrobalan , licorice , calamus , and asparagus , one should mix it with pure, remaining cow's milk and water from a freshly opened coconut . By partaking of this potion, even a feeble old man , weakened by age, will regain strength , become as energetic as a young person , and find great joy .

sloka: kharjūrīmastakaṃ māṣān payasyāṃ ca śatāvarīm|  kharjūrāṇi madhūkāni mṛdvīkāmajaḍāphalam||18||  palonmitāni matimān [4] sādhayet salilāḍhake|  tena pādāvaśeṣeṇa kṣīraprasthaṃ vipācayet||19||  kṣīraśeṣeṇa tenādyād ghṛtāḍhyaṃ ṣaṣṭikaudanam|  saśarkareṇa saṃyoga eṣa vṛṣyaḥ paraṃ smṛtaḥ||20||  (iti vṛṣyakṣīram)
translation: A wise person should churn a mixture of fresh curd, sugar, and water, along with the following: karjura fruits, madhuka fruits, mrdvika leaves, ajaḍa phala, and ksiira; from the remainder of this, he should first make butter; then, having mixed it with sugar, he should consider it to be the superior vrsya.

sloka: jīvakarṣabhakau medāṃ jīvantīṃ śrāvaṇīdvayam|  kharjūraṃ madhukaṃ drākṣāṃ pippalīṃ viśvabheṣajam||21||  śṛṅgāṭakaṃ vidārīṃ ca navaṃ sarpiḥ payo jalam|  siddhaṃ ghṛtāvaśeṣaṃ taccharkarākṣaudrapādikam||22||  ṣaṣṭikānnena saṃyuktamupayojyaṃ yathābalam|  vṛṣyaṃ balyaṃ ca varṇyaṃ ca kaṇṭhyaṃ bṛṃhaṇamuttamam||23||  (iti vṛṣyaghṛtam)
translation: Consisting of a sixfold barley, cow's milk, and sugar; root of masha, Shaileya, liquorice, patala, jivanti, and honey; country sugar, sugarcane juice, and the residue of ghee; all mixed in proper proportion with ṣaṣṭika rice, this is famously known as vṛṣyaghṛta. It promotes strength, nourishment, complexion, voice, and bulk, being causally effective in the future.

sloka: dadhnaḥ saraṃ śaraccandrasannibhaṃ doṣavarjitam|  śarkarākṣaudramaricaistugākṣīryā ca buddhimān||24||  yuktyā yuktaṃ sasūkṣmailaṃ nave kumbhe [5] śucau paṭe|  mārjitaṃ prakṣipecchīte ghṛtāḍhye ṣaṣṭikaudane||25||  pibenmātrāṃ rasālāyāstaṃ bhuktvā ṣaṣṭikaudanam [6] |  varṇasvarabalopetaḥ pumāṃstena vṛṣāyate||26||  (vṛṣyo dadhisaraprayogaḥ)
translation: The wise man should churn the buttermilk with a flawless churning stick, resembling the autumn moon in sheen, devoid of defects. He should consider using a new, smooth, clean, and pure pot for this purpose. After adding milk and curd mixed with water in proper proportion, he should skillfully churn it with balanced force while keeping a steady pace. Once the butter has surfaced, he should consume a measure of it mixed with sugar and clarified butter, which will increase his strength, complexion, voice, and overall well-being. (The practice of churning buttermilk)

sloka: candrāṃśukalpaṃ payasā ghṛtāḍhyaṃ ṣaṣṭikaudanam|  śarkarāmadhusaṃyuktaṃ prayuñjāno vṛṣāyate||27||  (iti vṛṣyaḥ ṣaṣṭikaudanaprayogaḥ)
translation: A sagacious person churns, using buttermilk, clarified of impurities, resembling the autumn moon, combined with sugar and rock candy, a measure of sixty, and ghee, thereby producing curds.

sloka: tapte sarpiṣi nakrāṇḍaṃ tāmracūḍāṇḍamiśritam|  yuktaṃ ṣaṣṭikacūrṇena sarpiṣā'bhinavena ca||28|| paktvā pūpalikāḥ khādedvāruṇīmaṇḍapo naraḥ|  ya icchedaśvavadgantuṃ prasektuṃ gajavacca yaḥ||29||  (iti vṛṣyapūpalikāḥ)
translation: Cooked in refined rice flour, combined with ghee located in a vessel, made acceptable with crushed sesame seeds, sugar, and honey, when offered in the Vrishabha shrine, the one desiring to ride a horse or an elephant will achieve their wish. (iti vṛṣyapūpalikāḥ)

sloka: bhavataścātra  etaiḥ prayogairvidhivadvapuṣmān vīryopapanno [7] balavarṇayuktaḥ|  harṣānvito vājivadaṣṭavarṣo bhavet samarthaśca varāṅganāsu||30|| yadyacca kiñcinmanasaḥ priyaṃ syādramyā vanāntāḥ pulināni śailāḥ|  iṣṭāḥ striyo bhūṣaṇagandhamālyaṃ priyā vayasyāśca tadatra yogyam [8] ||31||
translation: Upon using ghee, heated in a clay pot, mixed with copper sulfate and refined sugar in equal proportions, one becomes strong, energetic, and capable of lifting a mustard seed the size of a barley corn in a cow's hoof print, as well as carrying Ganga's water. They become suited for the company of charming women, cherished by women of their own age, and longed for by horses, elephants, and even cows. Moreover, any object of their mind becomes appropriate in these circumstances, be it forests, riverbanks, or mountains, as well as desired companions, ornaments, scents, and garlands, and similarly, what is agreeable to their youthful age.

sloka: tatra ślokaḥ  āsiktakṣīrike pāde ye yogāḥ parikīrtitāḥ|  aṣṭāvapatyakāmaiste prayojyāḥ pauruṣārthibhiḥ||32||  ityagniveśakṛte tantre carakapratisaṃskṛte cikitsāsthāne vājīkaraṇādhyāye āsiktakṣīriko nāma vājīkaraṇapādo dvitīyaḥ||2||
translation: In the "Agnivesaka" tantric text, composed by Caraka, within the aphrodisiacs section, specifically in the second sub-section named "Asiktakshiri," those yogis who were highly praised and should be utilized, through eight specialized means, for personal success are referred to twofold in the accusative case: āsiktakṣīrike (in the text), and vājī (in the title of the subsection).

sloka: athāto māṣaparṇabhṛtīyaṃ vājīkaraṇapādaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: "Now we (first plural) will explain the following section concerning the preparation of rice cooked with mung beans, as previously stated by the revered Atreya in the chapter on elixirs. This eightfold yoga-like application in producing offspring is praised and will be described in detail."

sloka: māṣaparṇabhṛtāṃ dhenuṃ gṛṣṭiṃ puṣṭāṃ catuḥstanīm|  samānavarṇavatsāṃ ca jīvadvatsāṃ ca buddhimān||3||  rohiṇīmathavā kṛṣṇāmūrdhvaśṛṅgīmadāruṇām|  ikṣvādāmarjunādāṃ vā sāndrakṣīrāṃ ca dhārayet||4||  kevalaṃ tu payastasyāḥ śṛtaṃ vā'śṛtameva vā|  śarkarākṣaudrasarpirbhiryuktaṃ tadvṛṣyamuttamam||5||
translation: Now, we will detail the attributes of a she-ass: a strong, well-built, and medium-sized female ass; uniformly colored; intelligent and tameable like a cow; having a horn that is black at the base and white at the tip; and a coat of hair resembling the color of sugarcane, grains, or serpentine scales. Whether thin, fat, or of medium build, this description applies as excellent in every way for a she-ass.

sloka: śukralairjīvanīyaiśca bṛṃhaṇairbalavardhanaiḥ|  kṣīrasañjananaiścaiva payaḥ siddhaṃ pṛthak pṛthak||6||  yuktaṃ godhūmacūrṇena saghṛtakṣaudraśarkaram|  paryāyeṇa prayoktavyamicchatā śukramakṣayam||7||
translation: Using milk, mixed with the curds of four cows of excellent quality, nourishing, and uniformly white, and combined with sugar, salt, and sarshapa (a type of rice), considered as such; Arjuna should, with the intent of increasing his semen, keep only that [milk] which has been processed separately, either in the middle or at the end, as indicated, and which has been made into a superior essence.

sloka: medāṃ payasyāṃ jīvantīṃ vidārīṃ kaṇṭakārikām|  śvadaṃṣṭrāṃ kṣīrikāṃ māṣān godhūmāñchāliṣaṣṭikān||8||  payasyardhodake paktvā  kārṣikānāḍhakonmite|  vivarjayet payaḥśeṣaṃ tat pūtaṃ kṣaudrasarpiṣā||9||  yuktaṃ saśarkaraṃ pītvā vṛddhaḥ saptatiko'pi vā|  vipulaṃ labhate'patyaṃ yuveva ca sa hṛṣyati||10||
translation: Consuming, in milk, the life-sustaining entity, nourishment, and strength, along with rice flour mixed with a pinch of rock salt, one should reject the remaining liquid. By drinking this mixture, which has been prepared, even an elderly person of seventy years will gain considerable offspring and feel joyously youthful.

sloka: maṇḍalairjātarūpasya tasyā eva payaḥ śṛtam|  apatyajananaṃ siddhaṃ saghṛtakṣaudraśarkaram||11||
translation: By churning the milk of the living cow, after removing its thick outer layer and mixing the fine inner layer with ghee, cooking and filtering it, both an elderly person of seventy years and even a young one become strong, joyful, and prosperous, gaining offspring.

sloka: triṃśat supiṣṭāḥ pippalyaḥ prakuñce tailasarpiṣoḥ|  bhṛṣṭāḥ saśarkarākṣaudrāḥ kṣīradhārāvadohitāḥ||12||  pītvā yathābalaṃ cordhvaṃ ṣaṣṭikaṃ kṣīrasarpiṣā|  bhuktvā na rātrimastabdhaṃ liṅgaṃ paśyati nā kṣarat||13||  (iti vṛṣyaḥ pippalīyogaḥ) śvadaṃṣṭrāyā vidāryāśca rase kṣīracaturguṇe|  ghṛtāḍhyaḥ sādhito vṛṣyo māṣaṣaṣṭikapāyasaḥ||14|| (iti vṛṣyapāyasayogaḥ)
translation: Born from thirty bulbs, well-developed and sleek, when the milk of the cow's offspring is churned together with sesame, salt, and sugar, it becomes a potent drink. When consumed in a measured quantity, it allows one, as a result, to see the symbol of Shiva the next morning, unimpaired by any bodily discharge. With the addition of ghee and turmeric, this drink, composed of milk, curd, and six measures of rice pudding, becomes even more potent.

sloka: phalānāṃ jīvanīyānāṃ snigdhānāṃ rucikāriṇām|  kuḍavaścūrṇitānāṃ syāt svayaṅguptāphalasya ca||15||  kuḍavaścaiva māṣāṇāṃ dvau dvau ca tilamudgayoḥ|  godhūmaśālicūrṇānāṃ kuḍavaḥ kuḍavo bhavet||16||  sarpiṣaḥ kuḍavaścaikastat sarvaṃ kṣīramarditam [1] |  paktvā pūpalikāḥ khādedbahvyaḥ syuryasya yoṣitaḥ||17||  (iti vṛṣyapūpalikāḥ)
translation: Of the ripened fruits, when consumed in the proper quantity, thirty types that are well-ripened, freshly cut, anointed with oil and ghee, mixed with sugar and rock salt, indeed enhance one's strength and keep it sustained; if eaten in excess, particularly at night, for more than six portions, it results in the loss of semen. Similarly, two measures each of black sesame and mudga, as well as husked barley grains, if consumed in this manner, bring about the same result. Furthermore, when ghee is mixed with milk, it becomes easily digestible for all types of food. (15-17) (Vṛṣyapūpalikāḥ)

sloka: ghṛtaṃ śatāvarīgarbhaṃ kṣīre daśaguṇe pacet|  śarkarāpippalīkṣaudrayuktaṃ tadvṛṣyamuttamam||18||  (iti vṛṣyaṃ śatāvarīghṛtam)
translation: The churned ghee from *Śatāvarī*'s womb, when cooked with ten times the amount of milk and combined with sugar, long pepper, and rock salt, becomes the supreme aphrodisiac. (This churned ghee of *Śatāvarī* is referred to as 'Vṛṣya').

sloka: karṣaṃ madhukacūrṇasya ghṛtakṣaudrasamāṃśikam [1] |  prayuṅkte yaḥ payaścānu [2] nityavegaḥ sa nā bhavet||19||  (iti vṛṣyamadhukayogaḥ)
translation: One who consistently prepares and consumes the mixture, composed of ghee, costus root extract, cow's cream, jaggery, a pinch of black pepper, and pippalí, will never become sluggish. (vṛṣyamadhukayogaḥ)

sloka: ghṛtakṣīrāśano nirbhīrnirvyādhirnityago yuvā|  saṅkalpapravaṇo nityaṃ naraḥ strīṣu vṛṣāyate||20||
translation: Always steadfast in his intentions, eternally youthful, free of illnesses and fears, subsisting on a diet of milk and ghee, such a man incites desire in women.

sloka: kṛtaikakṛtyāḥ siddhārthā ye cānyo'nyānuvartinaḥ|  kalāsu kuśalāstulyāḥ sattvena vayasā ca ye||21||  kulamāhātmyadākṣiṇyaśīlaśaucasamanvitāḥ|  ye kāmanityā ye hṛṣṭā ye viśokā gatavyathāḥ||22||  ye tulyaśīlā ye bhaktā ye priyā ye priyaṃvadāḥ|  tairnaraḥ saha visrabdhaḥ suvayasyairvṛṣāyate||23||
translation: Consisting of a single remaining duty and having fulfilled their purpose , those who follow others in the performance of these acts , possessing equal mastery of arts through their nature and age , coming from noble lineage , possessing virtues , cleanliness , and decorum , devoid of material desires , content , free from sorrows , and having even-mindedness towards both men and women , being devoted , dear , and speaking pleasing words , Arjuna, such a person is endowed with these qualities. With trust placed in them, they rejoice .

sloka: abhyaṅgotsādanasnānagandhamālyavibhūṣaṇaiḥ|  gṛhaśayyāsanasukhairvāsobhirahataiḥ priyaiḥ||24||  vihaṅgānāṃ rutairiṣṭaiḥ strīṇāṃ cābharaṇasvanaiḥ|  saṃvāhanairvarastrīṇāmiṣṭānāṃ ca vṛṣāyate||25||
translation: Accomplished in a single duty, the end goals of which are fulfilled, a skilled and virtuous person, proficient in qualities such as character, lineage, generosity, and cleanliness, takes delight. Always filled with desire, free from afflictions, and equal-minded, they are devoted to the wise who are eloquent, amiable, and trustworthy. Animate beings, including birds, find delight through their respective strengths, such as singing, while women do so through their ornaments and movements. For such a person, who is adept at performing abhyanga (massage), utsadana (exfoliation), snana (bathing), applying fragrances, wearing garlands, and jewelry, as well as experiencing the comfort of a home, bed, seat, and companions, their senses are delighted by sights, sounds, tastes, touch, and scents.

sloka: mattadvirephācaritāḥ sapadmāḥ salilāśayāḥ|  jātyutpalasugandhīni śītagarbhagṛhaṇi ca||26||  nadyaḥ phenottarīyāśca girayo nīlasānavaḥ|  unnatirnīlameghānāṃ ramyacandrodayā niśāḥ||27||
translation: Having been anointed, cleansed, and bathed, along with garlands, fragrances, and adornments, as well as comfortable beds and delightful homes; accompanied by beloved singing birds and alluring women with their enticing sounds and movements. (Referring to the moon)

sloka: vāyavaḥ sukhasaṃsparśāḥ kumudākaragandhinaḥ|  ratibhogakṣamā rātryaḥ  saṅkocāguruvallabhāḥ||28||  sukhāḥ sahāyāḥ parapuṣṭaghuṣṭāḥ phullā vanāntā viśadānnapānāḥ|  gāndharvaśabdāśca sugandhayogāḥ sattvaṃ viśālaṃ nirupadravaṃ ca||29||  siddhārthatā cābhinavaśca kāmaḥ strī cāyudhaṃ sarvamihātmajasya|  vayo navaṃ jātamadaśca kālo harṣasya yoniḥ paramā narāṇām||30||
translation: Intoxicated by power, two charioteers, wielding whips, draw cool water from lotus-scented pools, filled with clear, sweet liquid. From them flow streams, pure as the mountains' snow, stirred by the gentle breath of the wind. Also present are the sounds of the gandharvas and the fragrances they wield, along with the expansive, undisturbed sattva. Youth, desire, a woman, weapon, all aspects of the self, new growth in trees, as well as the source of joy for men - all arise from this. (28-30)

sloka: tatra ślokaḥ  praharṣayonayo yogā vyākhyātā daśa pañca ca|  māṣaparṇabhṛtīye'smin pāde śukrabalapradāḥ [2] ||31||
translation: In that spiritual matter, a verse describing the joyful aspects of yoga has been explained as having ten and five characteristics. In this quarter-verse of "māṣaparṇabhṛtīye," the moon's cooling rays are granted; the senses become joyful due to contact with happiness-inducing objects, like flowers; the mind becomes steady and unshaken. The senses experience pure and expanded sattva through delightful melodies and fragrances. Desire arises for women and other enjoyable things, but it remains under control. The body becomes strong, adorned with full, blooming youthfulness, and nourished by moderation in food and drink. Conversations are filled with sweet words, laughter, while the mind remains steady, free from disturbances, and inclined towards spiritual growth. This is the source of great exhilaration for human beings.

sloka: athātaḥ pumāñjātabalādikaṃ vājīkaraṇapādaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: Now we will explain the rituals of raising and grooming a man, beginning from his very birth. So has been spoken by the Lord Atri.

sloka: pumān yathā jātabalo yāvadicchaṃ striyo vrajet|  yathā cāpatyavān sadyo bhavettadupadekṣyate||3||  na hi jātabalāḥ sarve narāścāpatyabhāginaḥ|  bṛhaccharīrā balinaḥ santi nārīṣu durbalāḥ||4||  santi cālpāśrayāḥ [1]
translation: Now, we will explain the nature of a man, born with strength, as long as he desires, and that of women. Indeed, not all men are equally strong from birth, some possess more strength, while some women are weak; furthermore, there are those who prove to be unsteady in their support (of their husbands).

sloka: strīṣu balavanto bahuprajāḥ|  prakṛtyā cābalāḥ santi santi cāmayadurbalāḥ||5||  narāścaṭakavat kecid vrajanti bahuśaḥ striyam|  gajavacca prasiñcanti kecinna bahugāminaḥ||6||  kālayogabalāḥ kecit kecidabhyasanadhruvāḥ|  kecit prayatnairvyajyante [2] vṛṣāḥ kecit svabhāvataḥ||7||  tasmāt prayogān vakṣyāmo durbalānāṃ balapradān|  sukhopabhogān balināṃ bhūyaśca balavardhanān||8||  pūrvaṃ śuddhaśarīrāṇāṃ nirūhaiḥ [3] sānuvāsanaiḥ|  balāpekṣī prayuñjīta śukrāpatyavivardhanān||9||  ghṛtatailarasakṣīraśarkarāmadhusaṃyutāḥ|  bastayaḥ saṃvidhātavyāḥ kṣīramāṃsarasāśinām||10||
translation: Just as some men, gifted with strength from birth, may freely indulge with women, similar distinctions based on size and strength are found among men in their interactions with women, ranging from excessive attachment to steadfastness. To empower the weak, I shall describe the methods for strengthening them: primarily facilitating pleasure and growth for the strong. Initially, those born with pure bodies should engage, according to their capabilities, in actions enhancing semen and ovum growth. For women, typically weaker, these measures necessitate careful implementation using nourishing foods such as ghee, sugar, milk, grains, etc.

sloka: piṣṭvā varāhamāṃsāni dattvā maricasaindhave|  kolavadgulikāḥ kṛtvā tapte sarpiṣi vartayet [1] ||11||  vartanastambhitāstāśca [2]
translation: In the presence of women, there are some men who, being robust and plentiful, as well as weak and ailing, or lacking in vigor, approach them frequently, resembling elephants or cakravaka birds. Hence, we shall detail a remedy for enhancing the strength of the feeble and ensuring enjoyment of pleasures by the robust through the proper combination of ghee, sesame oil, sugar, milk, and honey, with meat-based nutritional elements.

sloka: prakṣepyāḥ kaukkuṭe rase|  ghṛtāḍhye gandhapiśune dadhidāḍimasārike||12||  yathā na bhindyādguli(ṭi)kāstathā taṃ sādhayedrasam|  taṃ piban bhakṣayaṃstāśca labhate śukramakṣayam||13||
translation: Just as in a chicken's egg, the yolk does not separate from the white; similarly, one should churn the ghee-infused churning rod with an unwavering mind. By drinking and consuming it, one attains the elimination of semen. (12-13)

sloka: māṃsānāmevamanyeṣāṃ medyānāṃ kārayedbhiṣak|  guṭikāḥ sarasāstāsaṃ prayogaḥ śukravardhanaḥ||14||  (iti vṛṣyā māṃsaguṭikāḥ)
translation: For promoting the increase of semen, the doctor should administer to the patient an equal mixture of the fats of the Kaukkuṭa and Rasa, the adhya of Ghrta, the exudation of Gandha, the flesh of Piśuna, the sourness of Dadhi, and the saltiness of Sārike. (This is known as the Vrsya mamsa-guṭikah.)

sloka: māṣānaṅkuritāñchuddhān vituṣān sājaḍāphalān|  ghṛtāḍhye māhiṣarase dadhidāḍimasārike||15||  prakṣipenmātrayā yukto dhānyajīrakanāgaraiḥ|  bhuktaḥ pītaśca sa rasaḥ kurute śukramakṣayam||16||  (iti vṛṣyo māhiṣarasaḥ)
translation: Physician, prepare pills from seeds of various cleansed and dried plants and fruits, as well as curd from a grain- and cumin-fed cow. When consumed in proper measure along with these, mixed with a small amount of it, it generates semen and increases its longevity.

sloka: ārdrāṇi matsyamāṃsāni śapharīrvā subhārjitāḥ|  tapte sarpiṣi yaḥ khādet sa gacchet strīṣu na kṣayam||17||  ghṛtabhṛṣṭān rase cchāge rohitān phalasārike|  anupītarasān snigdhānapatyārthī prayojayet||18||  (iti vṛṣyaghṛtabhṛṣṭamatsyamāṃsāni)
translation: Consuming fresh fish and sprouted grains, cooked in ghee that's previously been clarified, along with pure, delicious parts, one should eat moderately, mixed with rice, barley, and wheat, as well as the juices of citrus fruits and corn liquids. This preparation will lead to the generation of undiminished semen. (This is the method for preparing fish as described in Vṛṣyaghṛtabhṛṣṭamatsyamāṃsāni)

sloka: kuṭṭakaṃ [1] matsyamāṃsānāṃ hiṅgusaindhavadhānyakaiḥ|  yuktaṃ godhūmacūrṇena ghṛte pūpalikāḥ pacet||19||  māhiṣe ca rase matsyān snigdhāmlalavaṇān pacet|  rase cānugate māṃsaṃ pothayettatra cāvapet||20||  maricaṃ jīrakaṃ dhānyamalpaṃ hiṅgu navaṃ ghṛtam|  māṣapūpalikānāṃ tadgarbhārthamupakalpayet||21||  etau pūpalikāyogau bṛṃhaṇau balavardhanau|  harṣasaubhāgyadau putryau paraṃ śukrābhivardhanau||22||  (iti vṛṣyau pūpalikāyogau)
translation: A person should consume, cooked in fire-heated ghee, fish that are fresh, unspoiled, and well-known as subhārjita, together with various kinds of māṃsāni such as śapharīrvā, along with appropriate portions of rasān, snigdhān, apatya-arthī phala sāike that are anupīta and chāge in fresh ghṛta, which is bhṛṣṭān. This will promote the growth (bṛṃhaṇa), strength (bala-vardhana), happiness (harṣa), good fortune (saubhāgya), and semen (śukra) of that person, leading to the birth of a child (putryau). The use of māṣapūpalikānām's tat.garbha.ārtham suggests that these ingredients are meant for enhancing fertility.

sloka: māṣātmaguptāgodhūmaśāliṣaṣṭikapaiṣṭikam|  śarkarāyā vidāryāśca cūrṇamikṣurakasya ca||23||  saṃyojya masṛṇe kṣīre ghṛte pūpalikāḥ pacet|  payo'nupānāstāḥ śīghraṃ kurvanti vṛṣatāṃ parām||24||  (iti vṛṣyā māṣādipūpalikāḥ)
translation: In buttermilk, cooked by combining juices from fruits such as mangoes and lemons, along with a bit of salt, rice, barley, sesame, rock candy, and powders of black pepper, ginger, and coriander, and then mixed with a bit of ghee, one should prepare the "māṣapūpalikā". This will quickly enhance semen, strength, vigor, happiness, and good fortune, significantly improving the quality and quantity of sperm.

sloka: śarkarāyāstulaikā syādekā gavyasya sarpiṣaḥ|  prastho vidāryāścūrṇasya pippalyāḥ prastha eva ca||25||  ardhāḍhakaṃ tugākṣīryāḥ kṣaudrasyābhinavasya ca|  tatsarvaṃ mūrcchitaṃ tiṣṭhenmārtike ghṛtabhājane||26||  mātrāmagnisamāṃ tasya prātaḥ prātaḥ prayojayet|  eṣa vṛṣyaḥ paraṃ yogo balyo bṛṃhaṇa eva ca||27||
translation: Mix with sugar the individually ground and churned rice powder, sesame, wheat flour, barley flour, gram flour, and liquified ghee, along with a little of the milk from a newborn calf, and cook it on a gentle fire. Each morning, at daybreak, offer a measured quantity of this mixture to the fire, following proper procedures. This constitutes the potent recipe for enhancing strength and virility.

sloka: śatāvaryā vidāryāśca tathā māṣātmaguptayoḥ|  śvadaṃṣṭrāyāśca niṣkvāthāñjaleṣu [1] ca pṛthak pṛthak||28||  sādhayitvā ghṛtaprasthaṃ payasyaṣṭaguṇe punaḥ|  śarkarāmadhuyuktaṃ tadapatyārthī prayojayet||29||  (ityapatyakaraṃ ghṛtam)
translation: After separately preparing the sugar and honey mixed, and having caused the ghee from cow's cream to become six times the original measure, and the curdled butter to become eight times the original measure, as well as the pippali fruits and a sixth part of fresh kshaudra (a type of earth), slightly heat them together in a pan with an equal measure of ghee at dawn; this is the virility-enhancing mixture that one should cause to be used for procreation.

sloka: ghṛtapātraṃ śataguṇe vidārīsvarase pacet|  siddhaṃ punaḥ śataguṇe gavye payasi sādhayet||30||  śarkarāyāstugākṣīryāṃ kṣaudrasyekṣurakasya ca|  pippalyāḥ sājaḍāyāśca bhāgaiḥ pādāṃśikairyutam||31||  guli(ṭi)kāḥ kārayedvaidyo yathā sthulamudumbaram|  tāsāṃ prayogāt puruṣaḥ kuliṅga iva hṛṣyati||32||  (iti vṛṣyaguṭikāḥ)
translation: After churning the ghee pot eight times, one should churn the buttermilk a hundred times; then mix it with sugar and honey. A concoction should be prepared using jaggery, molasses, the extract of the kulinga plant, and the juices of pippali and ajaji fruits, by grinding them as required. Through their application, a person experiences great joy.

sloka: sitopalāpalaśataṃ tadardhaṃ navasarpiṣaḥ|  kṣaudrapādena saṃyuktaṃ sādhayejjalapādikam||33||  sāndraṃ godhūmacūrṇānāṃ pādaṃ stīrṇe śilātale|  śucau ślakṣṇe samutkīrya mardanenopapādayet||34||  śuddhā utkārikāḥ kāryaścandramaṇḍalasannibhāḥ|  tāsāṃ prayogādgajavannārīḥ santarpayennaraḥ||35||  (iti vṛṣyotkārikā)
translation: Prepare a hundred measures of ghee in a vessel, mixed with a quarter part of new Sarpiṣa, and cooked by adding Kṣaudra, pippalyaka, and Jaḍāyāḥ's parts. Once it becomes pure and clear like the moon, churn it with mardana and then filter it through a cloth. This, as described in Vṛṣyotkārikā, is the excellent method for preparing ghee.

sloka: yat kiñcinmadhuraṃ snigdhaṃ jīvanaṃ bṛṃhaṇaṃ guru|  harṣaṇaṃ manasaścaiva sarvaṃ tadvṛṣyamucyate||36||
translation: The one who can concoct a mixture, consisting of at least a quarter of a pala (=16g) of sugar, nine times as much ghee, and a small amount of well-strained curdled milk, together with rice cooked in pure, soft, and smooth water, and churn it skillfully with a pestle on a flat stone - such an individual is deemed as superior. He can effectively nourish and promote the growth of women similar to the moon-like ārya men.

sloka: dravyairevaṃvidhaistasmādbhāvitaḥ pramadāṃ vrajet|  ātmavegena codīrṇaḥ strīguṇaiśca praharṣitaḥ||37||
translation: Through being cultivated by such qualities as wealth and others, one may go after sensual pleasures; being impelled by one’s own power, and being delighted by feminine qualities.

sloka: gatvā snātvā payaḥ pītvā rasaṃ vā'nu śayīta nā|  tathā'syāpyāyate bhūyaḥ śukraṃ ca balameva ca||38||  yathā mukulapuṣpasya su(kha) gandho nopalabhyate|  labhyate tadvikāśāttu tathā śukraṃ hi dehinām||39||
translation: Having traveled and bathed, having drunk the milk, and experienced the taste, let one cause himself to rest in stages; in this way, both his sexual vitality and strength will be further nourished. Just as the fragrance of a closed bud is not perceived until it blooms, so too is the release of sexual fluids in living beings only perceived when they reach maturity.

sloka: narte vai ṣoḍaśādvarṣāt saptatyāḥ parato na ca|  āyuṣkāmo naraḥ strībhiḥ saṃyogaṃ kartumarhati||40||
translation: In the sixteenth year, having just bathed and drunk the fresh milk, a man should not seek to consort with women; such behavior is unbecoming of one who desires longevity.

sloka: atibālo hyasampūrṇasarvadhātuḥ striyaṃ vrajan|  upaśuṣyeta sahasā taḍāgamiva kājalam||41||
translation: A fourteen-year-old man, incapable of completing his full course of life, is capable of uniting with a woman. He will instantly dry up, like mud mixed with water, upon encountering feminine charm.

sloka: śuṣkaṃ rūkṣaṃ yathā kāṣṭhaṃ jantudagdhaṃ vijarjaram|  spṛṣṭamāśu viśīryeta tathā vṛddhaḥ striyo vrajan||42||
translation: Just as dry, withered wood catches fire immediately when touched and an insect-infested, decayed piece of wood quickly becomes weakened, similarly an elderly woman, traveling and physically weakened, quickly becomes debilitated.

sloka: jarayā cintayā śukraṃ vyādhibhiḥ karmakarṣaṇāt|  kṣayaṃ gacchatyanaśanāt strīṇāṃ cātiniṣevaṇāt||43||
translation: Just as a tree becomes depleted due to drought, heat, and old age, in the same way, the "śukra" (reproductive tissue) of women is diminished by constant menstruation, chronic ailments, physical exertion, and aging. [The use of feminine instrumental singular for jarayā, cintayā, and ca, masculine instrumental plural for vyādhibhiḥ, and neuter ablative singular for karṣaṇāt, anaśanāt, and niṣevaṇāt indicate that these nouns describe the reasons for the diminishment of śukram.]

sloka: kṣayādbhayādaviśrambhācchokāt strīdoṣadarśanāt|  nārīṇāmarasajñatvādavicārādasevanāt||44||  tṛptasyāpi striyo gantuṃ na śaktirupajāyate|  dehasattvabalāpekṣī harṣaḥ śaktiśca harṣajā||45||
translation: Due to aging, fear, lack of trust, grief, women's physical ailments, exposure to semen, lack of proper consideration, and service, their strength wanes. Even when they are satiated, their sexual vitality does not arise due to their physical constitution, exhaustion caused by pleasure, and lack of inherent power.

sloka: rasa ikṣau yathā dadhni sarpistailaṃ tile yathā|  sarvatrānugataṃ dehe śukraṃ saṃsparśane tathā||46||
translation: Just as, in extracting butterfat from milk through churning and oil from sesame seeds, similarly, semen is pervasive throughout the body; and just as in the process of tactile interaction, so too in its absence, strength and vitality wane in men.

sloka: tat strīpuruṣasaṃyoge ceṣṭāsaṅkalpapīḍanāt|  śukraṃ pracyavate sthānājjalamārdrāt paṭādiva||47||
translation: Just as butter emerges from curds throughout the body when in contact with salt, similarly, in the context of a man-woman union, semen is released in the womb due to friction and volition, akin to how ghee, cream, and butter separate from water and curds.

sloka: harṣāttarṣāt saratvācca paicchilyādgauravādapi|  aṇupravaṇabhāvācca drutatvānmārutasya ca||48||  aṣṭābhya ebhyo hetubhyaḥ śukraṃ dehāt prasicyate|  carato viśvarūpasya rūpadravyaṃ yaducyate||49||
translation: The sperm is discharged from the male body during sexual union with a woman, due to motion, desire, as well as factors such as excitement, excessive excitement, the autumn season, impotence, respect, and quickness. It is similar to water flowing from a filled container when tilted. This occurs due to eight causes: excitement, etc., from which the sperm is discharged.

sloka: bahalaṃ madhuraṃ snigdhamavisraṃ guru picchilam|  śuklaṃ bahu ca yacchukraṃ phalavattadasaṃśayam||50||
translation: Exuding abundant sweetness and smoothness, as well as being heavy and free from phlegm, the white fluid, caused by the seasons and eight other factors including wind, is secreted; it is undoubtedly referred to as the material essence of the cosmic form.

sloka: yena nārīṣu sāmarthyaṃ vājīvallabhate [1] naraḥ|  vrajeccābhyadhikaṃ yena vājīkaraṇameva tat||51||
translation: The man who is endowed with strength, sweetness, warmth, heaviness, oiliness, and whiteness in women, indeed acquires superior prowess in horsemanship and excels in that endeavor.

sloka: tatra ślokau  heturyogopadeśasya yogā dvādaśa cottamāḥ|  yat pūrvaṃ maithunāt sevyaṃ sevyaṃ yanmaithunādanu||52||  yadā na sevyāḥ pramadāḥ kṛtsnaḥ śukraviniścayaḥ|  niruktaṃ ceha nirdiṣṭaṃ pumāñjātabalādike||53||
translation: In that context, the twelve preeminent verses of the instruction on the disciplines of yoga are referred to as "heturyogopadeśasya." The practice that was previously to be served through sexual union should now be served without it, and that which was to be served through sexual union should be served after it. When, due to heedlessness, they are no longer to be served, a complete determination regarding the release of semen is made. This is declared and determined by a man who has been born with strength and courage.

sloka: athāto'tīsāracikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: "Now, we will explain the highly esteemed science of treating exceptional illnesses, referred to as the twelve yoga teachings, since it has been declared by the Lord that at the proper time, after renouncing desire, one should refrain from sexual activity. The complete retention of semen is signified here in this context for a human born strong."

sloka: tamasādhyatāmasamprāptaṃcikitsedyathāpradhānopakrameṇahetūpaśayadoṣaviśeṣaparīkṣayāceti ||10||
translation: Now, we will explain the proper course of treatment for a condition dominated by excessive darkness, as detailed by Bhagavan Atreya in ascending order of importance: thoroughly examining and addressing specific causes, effects, and accompanying factors.

sloka: āgantūdvāvatīsāraumānasaubhayaśokajau |  tattayorlakṣaṇaṃvāyoryadatīsāralakṣaṇam ||11||
translation: Having contemplated on the arrival of the dual forms of excessive pride and delusion (tamas), examine their respective causes and symptoms through introspection.

sloka: mārutobhayaśokābhyāṃśīghraṃhiparikupyati |  tayoḥkriyāvātaharīharṣaṇāśvāsanānica ||12||  ityuktāḥṣaḍatīsārāḥ sādhyānāṃsādhanaṃtvataḥ |  pravakṣyāmyanupūrveṇayathāvattannibodhata ||13||
translation: Learned ones, quickly alleviate the fear and sadness of the two Atisaras, possessing the distinguishing marks of Vayu, I will explain the means of accomplishment of the Sadyas, as spoken by the sixteen sages. Pay heed. (12-13)

sloka: doṣāḥsannicitāyasyavidagdhāhāramūrcchitāḥ |  atīsārāyakalpantebhūyastānsampravartayet ||14||
translation: "Quickly pacify, for him, the deeply entrenched sources of distress, along with their associated actions that rapidly arise, just as a gusty wind drives away clouds. You, as a friend, should cause (them) to start (the process of pacification). I will explain the appropriate means for achieving this goal, so listen carefully."

sloka: natusaṅgrahaṇaṃdeyaṃpūrvamāmātisāriṇe |  vibadhyamānāḥprāgdoṣājanayantyāmayānbahūn ||15||
translation: Improperly restrained indeed, the one who goes beyond proper limits will, in the future, cause many afflictions due to earlier ignited and deeply rooted faults, for self-control must be properly held and regarded as something to be given.

sloka: daṇḍakālasakādhmānagrahaṇyarśogadāṃstathā |  śothapāṇḍvāmayaplīhakuṣṭhagulmodarajvarān ||16||  tasmādupekṣetotkliṣṭānvartamānānsvayaṃmalān |  kṛcchraṃvāvahatāṃdadyādabhayāṃsampravartinīm ||17||  tayāpravāhitedoṣepraśāmyatyudarāmayaḥ |  jāyatedehalaghutājaṭharāgniścavardhate ||18||
translation: A mendicant, who is free from past mistakes, should not be neglectful in collecting alms at the appointed time. Indeed, this practice will tranquilize bodily ailments, bolster the digestive fire, lighten the body, and promote smooth stomach functions, as it makes the digestive fire stronger.

sloka: pramathyāṃmadhyadoṣāṇāṃdadyāddīpanapācanīm |  laṅghanaṃcālpadoṣāṇāṃpraśastamatisāriṇām ||19||
translation: Neglecting the initial symptoms of minor disorders such as indigestion, excessive thirst, and cough, as well as severe afflictions like fever that affect the heart, spleen, and lungs, one should disregard their manifestation in oneself. Through this practice, one enhances their digestive power, lightens their body, and pacifies frightening diseases like abdominal disorders.

sloka: pippalīnāgaraṃdhānyaṃbhūtīkamabhayāvacā |  hrīveraṃbhadramustānibilvaṃnāgaradhānyakam ||20||  pṛśniparṇīśvadaṃṣṭrācasamaṅgākaṇṭakārikā |  tisraḥpramathyāvihitāḥślokārdhairatisāriṇām ||21||  vacāprativiṣābhyāṃvāmustaparpaṭakenavā |  hrīveraśṛṅgaverābhyāṃpakvaṃvāpāyayejjalam ||22||
translation: The subduer of pride should give a mild and tempered drink, derived from a mixture of rice grains from Pippala city, two handfuls of barley, a bit of fearlessness, and a sprout of Bilva tree, as well as a digestive fire that has been processed by the combined action of the powers of speech, mind, and senses, to those who are in the midst of mental impurities, and who possess moderated intelligence. (20-22)

sloka: yukte'nnakālekṣutkṣāmaṃlaghūnyannānibhojayet |  tathāsaśīghramāpnotirucimagnibalaṃbalam ||23||  takreṇāvantisomenayavāgvātarpaṇenavā |  surayāmadhunācādauyathāsātmyamupācaret ||24||  yavāgūbhirvilepībhiḥkhaḍairyūṣairasaudanaiḥ |  dīpanagrāhisaṃyuktaiḥkramaścasyādataḥparam ||25||
translation: At an appropriate time, one should consume moderately cooked rice, along with sesame seeds, pure water, and vegetables (23). At the start of a meal, just as one would offer a morsel to a friend or esteemed guest, they should do the same with a mixture of ghee, milk, and curd (24). They should partake of foods like leaves from the sacred fig tree, barley, and grains, seasoned with salt, and accompanied by sauces made from yogurt (25).

sloka: śālaparṇīṃpṛśniparṇīṃbṛhatīṃkaṇṭakārikām |  balāṃśvadaṃṣṭrāṃbilvānipāṭhāṃnāgaradhānyakam ||26||  śaṭīṃpalāśaṃhapuṣāṃvacāṃjīrakapippalīm |  yavānīṃpippalīmūlaṃcitrakaṃhastipippalīm ||27|| vṛkṣāmlaṃdāḍimāmlaṃcasahiṅgubiḍasaindhavam |  prayojayedannapānevidhināsūpakalpitam ||28||  vātaśleṣmaharohyeṣagaṇodīpanapācanaḥ |  grāhībalyorocanaścatasmācchasto'tisāriṇām ||29||
translation: At the designated time for consuming food, one should prepare and partake of a meal that is easy to digest and nourishing in appropriate amounts. In this manner, one will promptly regain appetite, vitality, and contentment. One should initiate the meal with a liquid, such as soup, followed by gradually increasing the food's density, according to one's preference and appetite. This practice promotes proper digestion and enhances well-being.

sloka: āmepariṇateyastuvibaddhamatisāryate |                                                     saśūlapicchamalpālpaṃbahuśaḥsapravāhikam ||30||  yūṣeṇamūlakānāṃtaṃbadarāṇāmathāpivā |  upodikāyāḥkṣīriṇyāyavānyāvāstukasyavā ||31||  suvarcalāyāścañcorvāśākenāvalgujasyavā |  śaṭyāḥkarkārukāṇāṃvājīvantyāścirbhaṭasyavā ||32||  loṇikāyāḥsapāṭhāyāḥśuṣkaśākenavāpunaḥ |  dadhidāḍimasiddhenabahusnehenabhojayet ||33||
translation: In the presence of a broad-leafed sala tree, when mixed with a predominant portion of birhtati grass, along with kantaka, arika, bala, and svadaṃṣṭra, as well as bilva and naga tree patta leaves; further enhanced with dhanyaka, shatimpu, palasha, vaca, jiri, kapi-pallavi, yavani, pippalivasu, citraka, and hastipippali, as well as tree bark and lanjachabida; cooked according to the rules, seasoned with salt, and possessing qualities that eliminate excess phlegm, wind, and bile; this concoction promotes digestion, nourishment, complexion, growth, and brightness. Thus, it should be utilized as a medicinal remedy for those who are debilitated, weak, or suffering from disease.

sloka: kalkaḥsyādbālabilvānāṃtilakalkaścatatsamaḥ |  dadhnaḥsaro'mlasnehādyaḥkhaḍohanyātpravāhikām ||34||
translation: The one who is firmly bound for him, superior even among the weakest of the strong, who overcomes attachment, partakes equally of various tastes such as sour, pungent, bitter, astringent, and sweet, enjoys rice, barley, and fruits prepared with affection and enthusiasm, is free from deceit, cruelty, unsteadiness, violence, pride, and greed, eats after offering to others, finds joy in dry foods or water, indeed deserves reverence.

sloka: yavānāṃmudgamāṣāṇāṃśālīnāṃcatilasyaca |  kolānāṃbālabilvānāṃdhānyayūṣaṃprakalpayet ||35||  aikadhyaṃyamakebhṛṣṭaṃdadhidāḍimasārikam |  varcaḥkṣayeśuṣkamukhaṃśālyannaṃtenabhojayet ||36||  dadhnaḥsaraṃvāyamakebhṛṣṭaṃsaguḍanāgaram |  surāṃvāyamakebhṛṣṭāṃvyañjanārthepradāpayet ||37||  phalāmlaṃyamakebhṛṣṭaṃyūṣaṃgṛñjanakasyavā |  lopākarasamamlaṃvāsnigdhāmlaṃkacchapasyavā ||38||  barhitittiridakṣāṇāṃvartakānāṃtathārasāḥ |  snigdhāmlāḥśālayaścāgryāvarcaḥkṣayarujāpahāḥ ||39||  antarādhirasaṃpūtvāraktaṃmeṣasyacobhayam |  paceddāḍimasārāmlaṃsadhānyasnehanāgaram ||40||  odanaṃ[1]raktaśālīnāṃtenādyātprapibeccatat |  tathāvarcaḥkṣayakṛtairvyādhibhirvipramucyate ||41||
translation: When a pulp is made from the leaves of young bilva trees and an equal quantity of sesame seeds is soaked in water, then drained; consuming this with a bit of honey and black salt will eliminate diseases caused by an excess of bile.

sloka: gudaniḥsaraṇeśūlepānamamlasyasarpiṣaḥ |  praśasyatenirāmāṇāmathavā'pyanuvāsanam ||42||
translation: For the grains of barley, rice, black gram, green gram, sesame, and kolanāmbālabilva, one should prepare a single mass of gruel. This should be fed to well-fed cows, along with curd, pomegranate, ground nut, barley, and powdered wheat. Similarly, it should be offered to well-nourished rice grains, as well as surā or condiments in the form of tamarind. One should consume a preparation made from the juices of sour fruits such as crab apple, tittiri, and ripe dakṣāṇām, which should be unctuous, sour, nourishing, first-class, digestible, comforting, and curative. This should be consumed along with the red meat of a goat or deer, cooked well on both sides, seasoned with essence, sourness, sugar, other spices, oil, and salt.

sloka: cāṅgerīkoladadhyamlanāgarakṣārasaṃyutam |  ghṛtamutkvathitaṃpeyaṃgudabhraṃśarujāpaham ||43||  iticāṅgerīghṛtam |
translation: Even the butter, churned from cow's milk ghee and named "angiri ghritam," has been digested easily, destroys the bitterness of alms received, and is infused with the sweetness of sugar and enhanced strength due to its being previously cooked and becoming a future passive participle.

sloka: sacavyapippalīmūlaṃsavyoṣaviḍadāḍimam |  peyamamlaṃghṛtaṃyuktyāsadhānyājājicitrakam ||44|| itigudabhraṃśecavyādighṛtam |
translation: Prepared from the roots of the pippal tree, mixed with ghee, honey, and sugar, this specially formulated medicine, when consumed after proper pronouncement and preparation, alleviates a variety of ailments, including diarrhea.

sloka: daśamūlopasiddhaṃvāsabilvamanuvāsanam |  śaṭīśatāhvābilvairvāvacayācitrakeṇavā ||45||  itigudabhraṃśe'nuvāsanam
translation: "You have surely accomplished the instructions regarding the cultivation of the ten roots of the plant, using substances such as saci, pippalī, mūlasavya, viḍadāḍi, peyam, amlam, ghṛtam, yukti, dhānya, āja, āji, citrakam, and others. Now, continue to follow these instructions, applying them at the plant''s roots, bilva tree, and all the way to the top, in order to prevent its collapse."

sloka: stabdhabhraṣṭagudepūrvaṃsnehasvedauprayojayet |  susvinnaṃtaṃmṛdūbhūtaṃpicunāsampraveśayet ||46||
translation: Having established firmly the root, previously twisted and fallen away from it, along with Bilva as the foundation, and having caused sweat to flow in the twofold practice, one should cause to enter the anus, which has been made soft and pliable. (46)

sloka: vibaddhavātavarcāstubahuśūlapravāhikaḥ |  saraktapicchastṛṣṇārtaḥkṣīrasauhityamarhati ||47||  yamakasyoparikṣīraṃdhāroṣṇaṃvāpibennaraḥ |  śṛtameraṇḍamūlenabālabilvenavāpayaḥ[1] ||48||  evaṃkṣīraprayogeṇaraktaṃpicchācaśāmyati |  śūlaṃpravāhikācaivavibandhaścopaśāmyati ||49||
translation: Having previously stabilized the fallen one, one should now apply eagerness and exertion through supplication, as one would to something that is hardened and stiff. The softening should be approached in the same way for both the reddened tip and the tightly bound core.

sloka: sakṣaudrātiviṣaṃpiṣṭvāvatsakasyaphalatvacam |  pibetpittātisāraghnaṃtaṇḍulodakasaṃyutam ||51||  kirātatiktakomustaṃvatsakaḥsarasāñjanaḥ |  bilvaṃdāruharidrātvakhrīberaṃsadurālabham ||52||  candanaṃcamṛṇālaṃcanāgaraṃlodhramutpalam |  tilāmocarasolodhraṃsamaṅgākamalotpalam ||53||  utpalaṃdhātakīpuṣpaṃdāḍimatvaṅmahauṣadham |  kaṭphalaṃnāgaraṃpāṭhājambvāmrāsthidurālabhāḥ ||54||  yogāḥṣaḍetesakṣaudrāstaṇḍulodakasaṃyutāḥ |  peyāḥpittātisāraghnāḥślokārdhenanidarśitāḥ ||55||
