translation: By using milk in the practice, one may regulate the blood flow and temper the cravings for thirst and hunger. Similarly, the churning rod calms the sap flow in bilva, dāruharidrā, vakhrībera, and kaṭphala plants, which are hard to come by. The six yogic practices, when combined with milk and water, gain potency in mitigating impurities related to bile, phlegm, and wind. I will present these combinations in subsequent verses.

sloka: jīrṇoṣadhānāṃśasyanteyathāyogaṃprakalpitaiḥ |  rasaiḥsāṅgrāhikairyuktāḥpurāṇāraktaśālayaḥ ||56||
translation: The one who consumes (eater) should take in (drink) the concoction, made up of grains that have aged (old plants like paddy, wheat, barley, etc.) and are crushed together with various additives (such as salt, spices, and water), as well as other rare substances (like bilva, árdraka, vakrá, raktakarpura, red sandalwood, lodhra, utpala, tilā, mango leaves, dhātakī flower, dāḍima, and the bark of banyan tree), all mixed together with water and milk. This concoction, referred to as a yogas (preparation), is described in this half-verse (ardha-shloka) and is beneficial for alleviating pitta and controlling diarrhea.

sloka: pittātisārodīpāgneḥkṣipraṃsamupaśāmyati |  ajākṣīraprayogeṇabalaṃvarṇaścavardhate ||57||  bahudoṣasyadīptāgneḥsaprāṇasyanatiṣṭhati |  paittikoyadyatīsāraḥpayasātaṃvirecayet ||58||
translation: Just as, when brought into contact with the fire of a controlled and specifically prepared composition, obsolete medicinal herbs quickly calm down, and their potency and color intensify; similarly, the inherent strength of an impure fire of great magnitude diminishes, and it emits a subtle essence that can be collected and utilized for various purposes.

sloka: palāśaphalaniryūhaṃpayasāsahapāyayet |  tato'nupāyayetkoṣṇaṃkṣīramevayathābalam ||59||  pravāhitetenamalepraśāmyatyudarāmayaḥ |  palāśavatprayojyāvātrāyamāṇāviśodhinī ||60||  sāṃsargyāṃkriyamāṇāyāṃśūlaṃyadyanuvartate |  srutadoṣasyataṃśīghraṃyathāvadanuvāsayet ||61||  śatapuṣpāvarībhyāṃcapayasāmadhukenaca |  tailapādaṃghṛtaṃsiddhaṃsabilvamanuvāsanam ||62||
translation: When quickly offered the mixture of palāśa fruits and payasā, a person tormented by the heat of an excess of pitta impurities becomes quickly pacified. Through the use of milk, one's complexion and luster improve, and even the strongest agni does not abandon the body. When ghee made from cow's milk or taila is used in payasam offerings, it eliminates toxins caused by imbalanced pitta. Following this practice, using a hundred flower offerings in conjunction with payasā and madhukena, one can help maintain balance and promote health.

sloka: kṛtānuvāsanasyāsyakṛtasaṃsarjanasyaca |  vartateyadyatīsāraḥpicchābastirataḥparam ||63||  pariveṣṭyakuśairārdrairārdravṛntāniśālmaleḥ |  kṛṣṇamṛttikayā''lipyasvedayedgomayāgninā ||64||  suśuṣkāṃmṛttikāṃjñātvātānivṛntāniśālmaleḥ |  śṛtepayasimṛdnīyādāpothyolūkhaletataḥ ||65||  piṇḍaṃmuṣṭisamaṃprasthetatpūtaṃtailasarpiṣoḥ |  snehitaṃ[1]mātrayāyuktaṃkalkenamadhukasyaca ||66||  bastimabhyaktagātrāyadadyātpratyāgatetataḥ |  snātvābhuñjītapayasājāṅgalānāṃrasenavā ||67||
translation: Once thoroughly chewed, a mouthful of grains, blended with sesame, ghee, and salt, mixed with a bit of water, should be consumed after cleansing oneself. This practice aids in rapidly calming any digestive disturbance caused by improper food combinations or other ailments. If afflicted by severe ear issues, apply drops of a mixture, comprising honey, sesame oil, and fifty bilva leaves' juice, into the ear three times a day, thereby eliminating impurities and nourishing it.

sloka: pittātisārajvaraśothagulmajīrṇātisāragrahaṇīpradoṣān |  jayatyayaṃśīghramatipravṛddhānvirecanāsthāpanayoścabastiḥ[2] ||68||
translation: Once one has evacuated, if there are excessive discharges such as phlegm, mucus from the head, throat, and nose, as well as perspiration, pus, or blood, one should cleanse them using Kuśa grass, dry clay, or cow dung. After washing the body and purifying a Śālmalī cloth with water boiled with Payas, one should dry and apply it to the body. If necessary, evacuate again, followed by bathing and consuming food seasoned with Jāṅgalī fruit juice.

sloka: pittātisārīyastvetāṃkriyāṃmuktvāniṣevate | pittalānyannapānānitasyapittaṃmahābalam ||69||
translation: After abandoning the duty of conducting his father's funeral rites, he should not consume food or drinks, for this act would make him greatly vulnerable (mahābalam).

sloka: kuryādraktātisāraṃturaktamāśupradūṣayet |  tṛṣṇāṃśūlaṃvidāhaṃcagudapākaṃcadāruṇam ||70||
translation: After abandoning the improper activity of expelling excess bile, one should not cause pollution by obstructing the natural, unobstructed downward flow of apana; for, when increased, bile, coupled with weakness, can become fierce like a heated pan.

sloka: tatracchāgaṃpayaḥśastaṃśītaṃsamadhuśarkaram |  pānārthaṃbhojanārthaṃcagudaprakṣālanetathā ||71||
translation: There, for quenching thirst and eating, as well as for cleaning the belly, one should prepare a well-cooked rice dish, reddened with turmeric and quickly rid of its impurities.

sloka: odanaṃraktaśālīnāṃpayasātenabhojayet |  rasaiḥpārāvatādīnāṃghṛtabhṛṣṭaiḥsaśarkaraiḥ ||72||  śaśapakṣimṛgāṇāṃcaśītānāṃdhanvacāriṇām |  rasairanamlaiḥsaghṛtairbhojayettaṃsaśarkaraiḥ ||73||
translation: Feed the cattle, kept in their sheds, with fresh green grass; as well as those who drink water, consume grains, and enjoy licking crushed sugar. Similarly, offer food mixed with ghee and sugar to birds, deer, and other such grazing animals that eat grains and enjoy licking crushed sugar.

sloka: rudhiraṃmārgamājaṃvāghṛtabhṛṣṭaṃpraśasyate |  kāśmaryaphalayūṣovākiñcidamlaḥsaśarkaraḥ ||74||  nīlotpalaṃmocarasaṃsamaṅgāpadmakeśaram |  ajākṣīrayutaṃdadyājjīrṇecapayasaudanam ||75||  durbalaṃpāyayitvāvātasyaivoparibhojayet |  prāgbhaktaṃnavanītaṃvādadyātsamadhuśarkaram ||76||
translation: Prepare a gruel of rice and blood mixed with sap from sugarcane and ghee, and combine it with the juices of other sweet substances. Then, feed this to weakened beings, as well as to birds, animals, and aquatic creatures. Also, give grains and sugar to them. This should be done. (76)

sloka: prāśyakṣīrotthitaṃsarpiḥkapiñjalarasāśanaḥ |  tryahādārogyamāpnotipayasākṣīrabhuktathā ||77||  pītvāśatāvarīkalkaṃpayasākṣīrabhugjayet |  raktātisāraṃpītvāvātayāsiddhaṃghṛtaṃnaraḥ ||78||  ghṛtaṃyavāgūmaṇḍenakuṭajasyaphalaiḥśṛtam |  peyaṃtasyānupātavyāpeyāraktopaśāntaye ||79||
translation: After consuming alcohol, one speaks incoherently due to the limbs turning red, being addled by a mixture of sesame and salt. If, after eating rice pudding made with milk, sugar, and the three myrobalan fruits, one still feels unwell, they should consume light food and then a mixture of honey and ghee. This soothing concoction, beneficial for those weakened by overindulgence in food or drink, is made from ghee, licorice, kuṭaja fruit, and the juices of blue lotuses and mango leaves.

sloka: tvakcadāruharidrāyāḥkuṭajasyaphalānica |  pippalīśṛṅgaveraṃcadrākṣākaṭukarohiṇī ||80||  ṣaḍbhiretairghṛtaṃsiddhaṃpeyāmaṇḍāvacāritam |  atīsāraṃjayecchīghraṃtridoṣamapidāruṇam ||81||
translation: With cow's milk, curd-derived ghee, and butter from a kapiñjala cow's milk, combined with six special ingredients, one can quickly achieve excellent health. This ghee, prepared using curd from a kapiñjala cow's milk and consumed with its milk, conquers severe phlegm and bile disorders. This ghee, when offered in fire, becomes worthy of consumption, and drinking it helps manage blood-related ailments.

sloka: kṛṣṇamṛnmadhukaṃśaṅkhaṃrudhiraṃtaṇḍulodakam |  pītamekatrasakṣaudraṃraktasaṅgrahaṇaṃparam ||82||
translation: With the bark of the turmeric tree, pippalí and kuṭaja fruits, as well as rohiṇī flowers, mixed together with honey from madhuka flowers processed by bees and ghee, sweet like that of honey, when consumed immediately, it easily overcomes the three doshas and intense thirst, as well as hard-to-reach impurities.

sloka: pītaḥpriyaṅgukākalkaḥsakṣaudrastaṇḍulāmbhasā |  raktasrāvaṃjayecchīghraṃdhanvamāṃsarasāśinaḥ ||83||  kalkastilānāṃkṛṣṇānāṃśarkarāpañcabhāgikaḥ |  ājenapayasāpītaḥsadyoraktaṃniyacchati ||84||
translation: The one who crushes kṛṣṇa grains, mixes honey and conch shell with it, quickly gathers five parts consisting of red paddy, water, saffron-tinted rice, yellow barley and redness of this mixture is enhanced by adding pītaḥ barley.

sloka: palaṃvatsakabījasyaśrapayitvārasaṃpibet |  yorasāśījayecchīghraṃsapaittaṃjaṭharāmayam ||85||
translation: Having sown the golden, matured seeds of the palāśa tree and having extracted its juice, who can quickly prepare a mixture of five parts of black gram, one part each of sesame seeds and sugar, and cause it to be rapidly digested within the animal's body?

sloka: pītvāsaśarkarākṣaudraṃcandanaṃtaṇḍulāmbhasā |  dāhatṛṣṇāpramehebhyoraktasrāvāccamucyate ||86||
translation: After swiftly consuming a paste made from rice grains and sandalwood powder dissolved in water, one is relieved from both thirst and exhaustion.

sloka: gudobahubhirutthānairyasyapittenapacyate |  secayettaṃsuśītenapaṭolamadhukāmbunā ||87||  pañcavalkamadhūkānāṃrasairikṣurasairghṛtaiḥ |  chāgairgavyaiḥpayobhirvāśarkarākṣaudrasaṃyutaiḥ ||88|| prakṣālanānāṃkalkairvāsasarpiṣkaiḥpralepayet |  eṣāṃvāsukṛtaiścūrṇaistaṃgudaṃpratisārayet ||89||  dhātakīlodhracūrṇairvāsamāṃśaiḥpratisārayet |  tathāsravatinoraktaṃgudaṃtaiḥpratisāritam ||90||  pakvatāpraśamaṃyātivedanācopaśāmyati |  yathoktaiḥsecanaiḥśītaiḥśoṇite'tisravatyapi ||91||  gudavaṅkṣaṇakaṭyūrusecayedghṛtabhāvitam |  candanādyenatailenaśatadhautenasarpiṣā ||92||  kārpāsasaṅgṛhītenasecayedgudavaṅkṣaṇam |93|
translation:
By consuming the juice of sugarcanes, mixed with rice grains and water, a person gets relieved from burning thirst and fatigue. Moreover, if this is combined with paste made of red sandalwood, it helps alleviate any distress caused by excessive menstrual flow.

The text advises drinking sugarcane juice mixed with rice grains and water, which can help quench thirst and rejuvenate the body. The addition of red sandalwood paste can further help manage menstrual discomfort.

sloka: alpālpaṃbahuśoraktaṃsaśūlamupaveśyate ||93||  yadāvāyurvibaddhaścakṛcchraṃcarativānavā |  piñchābastiṃtadātasyayathoktamupakalpayet ||94||  prapauṇḍarīkasiddhenasarpiṣācānuvāsayet |  prāyaśodurbalagudāścirakālātisāriṇaḥ ||95||  tasmādabhīkṣṇaśasteṣāṃgudesnehaṃprayojayet |96|
translation: When a person suffers from severe constipation, with stool hard to expel despite strenuous efforts, including using hands, or due to weak digestion, then one should administer an enema using a sugar and rock salt mixture dissolved in lukewarm water. Alternatively, decoctions from Dhātakī, Lolahara, or Aṃśa medicinal plants can be used. Apply this therapy gently to the lower abdomen and groin, and if required, use a small amount of Chandana oil for massage before administering the enema. The aim is to alleviate constipation discomfort through gentle, soothing methods that facilitate easy stool passage. This should be done consistently for those with long-term constipation issues or weak digestion.

sloka: pavano'tipravṛttohisvesthānelabhate'dhikam ||96||  balaṃtasyasapittasyajayārthebastiruttamaḥ |  raktaṃviṭsahitaṃpūrvaṃpaścādvāyo'tisāryate ||97||  śatāvarīghṛtaṃtasyalehārthamupakalpayet |  śarkarārdhāṃśikaṃlīḍhaṃnavanītaṃnavoddhṛtam ||98||  kṣaudrapādaṃjayecchīghraṃtaṃvikāraṃhitāśinaḥ |  nyagrodhodumbarāśvatthaśuṅgānāpothyavāsayet ||99||  ahorātraṃjaletapteghṛtaṃtenāmbhasāpacet |  tadardhaśarkarāyuktaṃlihyātsakṣaudrapādikam ||100||  adhovāyadivā'pyūrdhvaṃyasyaraktaṃpravartate |101|
translation: When the wind, now bound by a minor rain cloud, becomes restricted, it enhances the unvanquished one's, who is his father's son, preeminent strength for the conquest. Initially, a concoction consisting of pomegranate, honey, sesame oil, strained ghee, and a pinch of salt should be readied for him. The sturdy one shall swiftly consume a variant of this, combined with rice flour, as directed by the Poundrika scripture. For the most part, the feeble and fragile succumb effortlessly to enemies' attacks; hence, one must consistently demonstrate affection towards them. (96-100)

sloka: yastvevaṃdurbalomohātpittalānyevasevate ||101||  dāruṇaṃsavalīpākaṃprāpyaśīghraṃvipadyate |102|
translation: The one who has abandoned weakness and is self-deluded by moha, and who serves pittalani, while adhering to his duties and vigorously striving for victory over his enemies, will quickly obtain the bitter concoction (dāruṇaṃ sali-vyapākam). This concoction is made from one hundred thousand leaves each of the neem, belleric myrobalan, beleric, and castor-oil plants, combined with sugar, licorice, and salt, to be consumed in both day and night, after boiling in water and cooling. During the day, the wind should blow from below, while at night, it should blow from above, for such an individual.

sloka: śleṣmātisāreprathamaṃhitaṃlaṅghanapācanam ||102||  yojyaścāmātisāraghnoyathoktodīpanogaṇaḥ |  laṅghitasyānupūrvyāṃcakṛtāyāṃnanivartate ||103||
translation: One who is debilitated, due to delusion, applies pitta (bile) as a salve, undergoes, as has been stated, a transformation that is hard to reverse.

sloka: kaphajoyadyatīsāraḥkaphaghnaistamupācaret |bilvaṃkarkaṭikāmustamabhayāviśvabheṣajam ||104||  vacāviḍaṅgaṃbhūtīkaṃdhānyakaṃdevadāruca |  kuṣṭhaṃsātiviṣāpāṭhācavyaṃkaṭukarohiṇī ||105||  pippalīpippalīmūlaṃcitrakaṃhastipippalī |  yogāñchlokārdhavihitāṃścaturastānprayojayet ||106|| śṛtāñchleṣmātisāreṣukāyāgnibalavardhanān |  ajājīmasitāṃpāṭhāṃnāgaraṃmaricānica ||107||  dhātakīdviguṇaṃdadyānmātuluṅgarasāplutam |rasāñjanaṃsātiviṣaṃkuṭajasyaphalānica ||108||  dhātakīdviguṇaṃdadyātpātuṃsakṣaudranāgaram |  dhātakīnāgaraṃbilvaṃlodhraṃpadmasyakeśaram ||109||  jambūtvaṅnāgaraṃdhānyaṃpāṭhāmocarasobalā |  samaṅgādhātakībilvamadhyaṃjambvāmrayostvacaḥ ||110||  kapitthāniviḍaṅgānināgaraṃmaricānica |  cāṅgerīkolatakrāmlāṃścaturastānkaphottare ||111||  ślokārdhavihitāndadyātsasnehalavaṇānkhaḍān |  kapitthamadhyaṃlīḍhvātusavyoṣakṣaudraśarkaram ||112||  kaṭphalaṃmadhuyuktaṃvāmucyatejaṭharāmayāt |113|
translation: At the start of the day, one should combine the means that counter excess phlegm , alleviate stagnant water , and prevent its return . This includes: - The combination of a paste made from the bark of a mango tree and a small piece of a Terminalia chebula branch, applied to the area affected by phlegm . - The ingestion of a powder made from the fruit of the Ziziphus jujube , mixed with rock salt . This method should not be discontinued . Additionally, one can consume a decoction made from the bark of a Terminalia chebula tree and rock salt . The prescription is to be continued for a specific period , as directed by a medical professional.

sloka: kaṇāṃmadhuyutāṃpītvātakraṃpītvāsacitrakam ||113||  jagdhvāvābālabilvānimucyatejaṭharāmayāt |  bālabilvaṃguḍaṃtailaṃpippalīṃviśvabheṣajam |  lihyādvātepratihatesaśūlaḥsapravāhikaḥ ||114||  bhojyaṃmūlakaṣāyeṇavātaghnaiścopasevanaiḥ |  vātātisāravihitairyūṣairmāṃsarasaiḥkhaḍaiḥ ||115||  pūrvoktamamlasarpirvāṣaṭpalaṃvāyathābalam |  purāṇaṃvāghṛtaṃdadyādyavāgūmaṇḍamiśritam ||116||
translation:
To alleviate Kapha-induced ailments, one should resort to using Bilva, Kaarkataaka, and Musta, all of which have extensive benefits, as mentioned earlier. These include Vidaanga, Bhooti, Kam, Dhaanyaka, Deva-Daru, Cavya, Kaṭuka, Rohini, Pippali, Pippali-Mula, Citraka, Hasti, Yogans, and Shloka, all of which have been mentioned in the previous passage. These remedies can be administered in various forms like powders, decoctions, pastes, or pills. They aid in eliminating impurities from the body, enhancing digestion, and strengthening Agni (digestive fire). Specifically, Aja-Jīvaka, Madhu-Parni, Patha, Cavya, Kola, Krimala, Roughini, Pippali-Mula, Citraka, Hasti, Yogans, Shloka, Ardha, Catuh, Astān should be utilized. These remedies prove beneficial in treating chest ailments, fever, and other disorders caused by an imbalance of Kapha and Vata.

Furthermore, Dhataki, which is twice as effective when combined with Mula-Anga-Rasa, balances all three Doshas and eliminates toxins from the body when given in small amounts of sugar or honey. The fruits of Kutaja, Dhataki, Bilva, Lodhra, Padma, Keśara, Jambu, Tvak, Dhaanyaam, Aama, Ucca (Madanphala), Rasa-Balaa, Samaṅga-Dhataki, Bilva-Madhya-Jambvārya-Stava, Kapittha, Vidaanga, Marici, and Cangeri should be used in appropriate quantities. These remedies should be administered with a small amount of ghee or oil, processed with honey, according to the patient's digestive capacity and severity of their condition. Through this approach, impurities can be eliminated, leading to balanced Doshas and improved overall health.

sloka: vātaśleṣmavibandhevākaphevā'tisravatyapi |  śūlepravāhikāyāṃvāpicchābastiṃprayojayet ||117||  pippalībilvakuṣṭhānāṃśatāhvāvacayorapi |  kalkaiḥsalavaṇairyuktaṃpūrvoktaṃsannidhāpayet ||118||  pratyāgatesukhaṃsnātaṃkṛtāhāraṃdinātyaye |  bilvatailenamatimānsukhoṣṇenānuvāsayet ||119||  vacāntairathavākalkaistailaṃpaktvā'nuvāsayet |  bahuśaḥkaphavātārtastathāsalabhatesukham ||120||
translation: Having consumed the liquor, mixed with honey and sesame seeds, one is freed from the bondage of phlegm and wind in the current context. One should cause to put in a proper meal, including the roots and fruits of pippalī and bilva, as well as viśva bheṣaja, cooked with ghee, salt, and various spices, and previously mentioned amla. A balanced diet, consisting of grains, rice, and mung dal, can increase strength and endurance. One should consume, after having cleansed oneself, food prepared in a proper manner, and anointed with oil, during the change of seasons; one should also apply sesame oil mixed with salt on the body. Similarly, one should consume, after having cooked it with various spices, a mixture of grains, rice, and mung dal, as well as previously mentioned amla and sarpiḥ, during the change of seasons.

sloka: svesthānemāruto'vaśyaṃvardhatekaphasaṅkṣaye |  savṛddhaḥsahasāhanyāttasmāttaṃtvarayājayet ||121||
translation: Upon the termination of kapha (phlegm), the wind naturally grows in its proper place. Therefore, one should promptly appease through means previously stated, such as reciting formulas with Kushthi leaves and Bilva, massaging with oil mixed with herbs, consuming warm, easily digestible food after bathing and during the day, and applying oil that has been cooked for a long time to the head when the mind is clear. Thus, one afflicted with kapha finds relief.

sloka: vātasyānujayetpittaṃ pittasyānujayetkapham |  trayāṇāṃvājayetpūrvaṃyobhavedbalavattamaḥ ||122||
translation: Let the wind prevail over the phlegm in its own place, and let the phlegm be overcome by that which belongs to it; let the one who is predominant in strength be established first among the three; it is advised to remove congestion for that reason.

sloka: tatraślokaḥ  prāgutpattinimittānilakṣaṇaṃsādhyatānaca |  kriyācāvasthikīsiddhānirdiṣṭāhyatisāriṇām ||123||
translation: The verse describes the qualities of an ideal person. This person is capable of overcoming phlegm by following the wind and superior to bile; they serve as the cause for the manifestation of individual souls' qualities, actions, and stages; and they have fully determined the path to liberation for embodied beings.

sloka: ityagniveśakṛtetantrecarakapratisaṃskṛtecikitsāsthāne'tisāracikitsitaṃnāmaikonaviṃśo'dhyāyaḥ ||19||
translation: Here, titled "Special Treatments," the nineteenth chapter has been described in the text, which, when completed, was treated/compiled by Agnivesa and Caraka; it discusses the causes, symptoms, and cures of various ailments, as well as the appropriate actions for those in different stages of treatment.

sloka: athātaḥ kuṣṭhacikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2|| hetuṃ dravyaṃ liṅgaṃ kuṣṭhānāmāśrayaṃ praśamanaṃ ca|  śṛṇvagniveśa! samyagviśeṣataḥ sparśanaghnānām||3||
translation: Now, Agnivesha, we shall explain in detail the treatment for leprosy, specifically its causes, associated factors, symptoms, as well as its pacification. So listen carefully, O Agnivesha.

sloka: virodhīnyannapānāni dravasnigdhagurūṇi ca|  bhajatāmāgatāṃ chardiṃ vegāṃścānyānpratighnatām||4||  vyāyāmamatisantāpamatibhuktvopasevinām|  śītoṣṇalaṅghanāhārān kramaṃ muktvā niṣeviṇām||5||
translation: Now, we shall explain the remedies for leprosy: Bhagavan Atreya mentioned the agents of this disease, the consumables , and their effects that should be adopted by those who have contracted it . Furthermore, for those who are suffering, they should abandon the consumption of incompatible foods , follow a specific diet , refrain from certain activities , and gradually adopt these remedies.

sloka: gharmaśramabhayārtānāṃ drutaṃ śītāmbusevinām|  ajīrṇādhyaśināṃ caiva pañcakarmāpacāriṇām||6||  navānnadadhimatsyātilavaṇāmlaniṣeviṇām|  māṣamūlakapiṣṭānnatilakṣīraguḍāśinām||7||  vyavāyaṃ cāpyajīrṇe'nne nidrāṃ ca bhajatāṃ divā|  viprān gurūn dharṣayatāṃ pāpaṃ karma ca kurvatām||8||
translation: For those seeking warmth and nourishment incompatible with their constitutions, swiftly consuming coarse, heavy, and stale food; for those indulging in large amounts of cold foods and drinks, experiencing poor digestion, and engaging in activities causing perspiration and exhaustion; as well as for those disrespecting brahmins, gurus, and committing sinful deeds, such actions bring about harm.

sloka: vātādayastrayo duṣṭāstvagraktaṃ māṃsamambu ca|  dūṣayanti sa kuṣṭhānāṃ saptako dravyasaṅgrahaḥ||9||  ataḥ kuṣṭhāni jāyante sapta caikādaśaiva ca|  na caikadoṣajaṃ kiñcit kuṣṭhaṃ samupalabhyate||10||
translation: The three, namely wind, bile, and phlegm, when aggravated, spoil the unctuousness of flesh and water for those suffering from ailments. This occurs due to their engagement in hurried activities, exposure to cold, consumption of stale food, eating at improper times, excessive sexual activity, and intake of spoiled food, curds, sugar, and meat. Moreover, for such individuals, who also disturb the sleep of brahmins and elders, commit sins, and eat at improper times, seven or eleven types of skin diseases arise, and a completely disease-free type is never found.

sloka: sparśājñatvamatisvedo na vā vaivarṇyamunnatiḥ|  koṭhānāṃ lomaharṣaśca kaṇḍūstodaḥ śramaḥ klamaḥ||11||  vraṇānāmadhikaṃ śūlaṃ śīghrotpattiścirasthitiḥ|  dāhaḥ [1] suptāṅgatā ceti kuṣṭhalakṣaṇamagrajam||12||
translation: The three types of wind, together with bile and phlegm, contribute to impurities in qualities such as the skin, blood, and flesh, as well as the combination of the seven bodily constituents that typify leprosy. Consequently, symptoms like eruptions on the body, hair loss, itching, discharge, and thinness arise; furthermore, wounds, inflammation, and fever may also be present in this condition. However, not all cases of leprosy exhibit all these symptoms simultaneously.

sloka: kṛṣṇāruṇakapālābhaṃ yadrūkṣaṃ paruṣaṃ tanu|  kāpālaṃ todabahulaṃ tatkuṣṭhaṃ viṣamaṃ smṛtam||14||
translation: Known by touch, not made of iron, possibly variegated, rough, and studded with protruding knots - such is the skull, remembered as being associated with fatigue and sweat from exertion.

sloka: dāhakaṇḍūrujārāgaparītaṃ lomapiñjaram|  udumbaraphalābhāsaṃ kuṣṭhamaudumbaraṃ viduḥ||15||
translation: They recognize it as a form of kuşṭha (skin disease), known as audumbara, which is dark-colored, reddish-brown, rough, hard, thin, brittle, and irregularly shaped, with many pustules; it resembles the outer covering of an udumbara fruit.

sloka: śvetaṃ raktaṃ sthiraṃ styānaṃ snigdhamutsannamaṇḍalam|  kṛcchramanyonyasaṃsaktaṃ kuṣṭhaṃ maṇḍalamucyate||16||
translation: The condition known as "kuşṭha" is characterized by symptoms such as redness , itching , inflammation , and discoloration of the skin, as well as roughness and hardening similar to the udumbara fruit. It is also marked by being tightly bound and circular .

sloka: karkaśaṃ raktaparyantamantaḥ śyāvaṃ savedanam|  yadṛṣyajihvāsaṃsthānamṛṣyajihvaṃ taducyate||17||
translation: You should make the white part up to the red portion firm, smooth, unctuous, projecting, rounded, and rough; attach it to another. This is called "rishyajihva," a type of plant.

sloka: saśvetaṃ raktaparyantaṃ puṇḍarīkadalopamam|  sotsedhaṃ ca sadāhaṃ ca puṇḍarīkaṃ taducyate||18||
translation: The perpetually flowing [saśvetaṃ] and reddish hued [raktaparyantaṃ] one is constantly referred to as Pundarika, an appellation that accurately describes the white lotus [puṇḍarīkadalopamam].

sloka: śvetaṃ tāmraṃ tanu ca yadrajo [1] ghṛṣṭaṃ vimuñcati|  alābūpuṣpavarṇaṃ tat sidhmaṃ prāyeṇa corasi||19||
translation: The one who discards a lotus, white and copper-red in color, with fully opened petals, comparable to a fully opened crown jewel, is likely a thief. And, I am known as the red lotus.

sloka: yat kākaṇantikāvarṇamapākaṃ tīvravedanam|  tridoṣaliṅgaṃ tat kuṣṭhaṃ kākaṇaṃ naiva sidhyati||20||
translation: A condition of leprosy, marked by blackish discoloration and being hard to cure , causing intense pain , and affecting the three doshas cannot be regarded as a trivial kuṣṭham or kaṇam ; it is incurable, as suggested by the third person singular present indicative of sidhyati.

sloka: iti saptamahākuṣṭhāni
translation: Even the seventh layer of the skin, when afflicted by severe, discolored, and foul-smelling defects, cannot be purified by any means.

sloka: asvedanaṃ mahāvāstu yanmatsyaśakalopamam|  tadekakuṣṭha
translation: It is referred to as "asvedanaṃ", the great "skin disease" that is like the supreme manifestation , referring to the seventh stage of the disease mentioned in the compound word "matsyaśakala".

sloka: carmākhyaṃ bahalaṃ hasticarmavat||21||
translation: Designated as Carmākhya, what is extremely comparable to a large fish is a great physical sensation (or inflammation/itching). This is its sole equivalent, ekam.

sloka: śyāvaṃ kiṇakharasparśaṃ paruṣaṃ kiṭibhaṃ smṛtam|
translation: Touch (you) now this dark, previously described as rough, elephant-like in texture, and made known.

sloka: vaipādikaṃ pāṇipādasphuṭanaṃ tīvravedanam||22||
translation: Recognize it with the touch that is sharply piercing, like that of the vaipādika fire. (Here, vaipādika refers to a type of fire, and the compound pāṇipādasphuṭanam suggests a touch that is clear/distinct at the level of the limbs.)

sloka: kaṇḍūmadbhiḥ sarāgaiśca gaṇḍairalasakaṃ citam|
translation: Afflicted with intense itching and inflammation due to Kandu, indeed.

sloka: sakaṇḍūrāgapiḍakaṃ dadrumaṇḍalamudgatam||23||
translation: Surrounded by clusters of Sakandra and Agipidaka shrubs, and affectionately embraced (as it grew) by the forest dwellers.

sloka: raktaṃ [1] sakaṇḍu sasphoṭaṃ sarugdalati cāpi yat|  taccarmadalamākhyātaṃ saṃsparśāsahamucyate||24||
translation: The condition characterized by a red, kernel-like inflammation that spreads in a circular manner, resembling grains, is recognized as a boil. This is also identified as a contact-induced reaction.

sloka: pāmāśvetāruṇaśyāvāḥ kaṇḍūlāḥ piḍakā bhṛśam|
translation: Especially in these quickly reddening places, blisters or abscesses are particularly prominent.

sloka: sphoṭāḥ śvetāruṇābhāso visphoṭāḥ syustanutvacaḥ||25||
translation: Flashes, white and reddish in appearance, surely crackle intensely when stimulated/rubbed.

sloka: raktaṃ śyāvaṃ sadāhārti śatāruḥ syādbahuvraṇam|
translation: With a bright flash, may you always make the body display both reddish and whitish hues, appearing as spots and streaks. (Here, 'you' is implied as the second person singular imperative form 'śya' is used.)

sloka: sakaṇḍūḥ piḍakā śyāvā bahusrāvā vicarcikā||26||
translation: Ever becoming deeply stained red and being covered in many wounds, who could this be but a sufferer?

sloka: ityekādaśa kṣudrakuṣṭhāni
translation: Ity ("thus"), ekādaśa ("thirteen"), kṣudra ("minor"), kuṣṭhāni ("ailments") - thus are identified thirteen minor ailments, namely itching, sneezing, and excessive hair whitening.

sloka: vāte'dhikatare kuṣṭhaṃ kāpālaṃ maṇḍalaṃ kaphe|  pitte tvaudumbaraṃ vidyāt kākaṇaṃ tu tradoṣajam||27|| vātapitte śleṣmapitte vātaśleṣmaṇi cādhike|  ṛṣyajihvaṃ puṇḍarīkaṃ sidhmakuṣṭhaṃ ca jāyate||28||  carmākhyamekakuṣṭhaṃ ca kiṭimaṃ savipādikam|  kuṣṭhaṃ cālasakaṃ jñeyaṃ prāyo vātakaphādhikam||29||  pāmā śatārurvisphoṭaṃ dadruścarmadalaṃ tathā|  pittaśleṣmādhikaṃ prāyaḥ kaphaprāyā vicarcikā||30||
translation:
Here are described eleven minor types of skin diseases: (27-30)
1. In a predominance of air, a severe form of kuṣṭha arises.
2. With phlegm predominant, kāpāla manifests.
3. With bile in excess, udumbara is produced.
4. With both air and phlegm excessive, ṛṣyajihva comes into being.
5. With both air and bile in excess, alasaka appears.
6. With all three doshas excessively present, pāmā arises.
7. A condition known as śatāru is commonly seen when phlegm is predominant.
8. Visphoṭa occurs when there is an excess of both bile and phlegm.
9. Dadru manifests when phlegm is predominant.
10. Carma is the general term for skin diseases, while ekakuṣṭha is another specific type.
11. Kiṭi and savipādika are other names for kuṣṭha, which is mostly caused by an imbalance of air and bile. (27-29)
The symptoms mentioned in shlokas 30-31 describe further different characteristics of these skin diseases.

sloka: sarvaṃ tridoṣajaṃ kuṣṭhaṃ doṣāṇāṃ tu balābalam|  yathāsvairlakṣaṇairbuddhvā kuṣṭhānāṃ kriyate kriyā||31||  doṣasya yasya paśyet kuṣṭheṣu viśeṣaliṅgamadriktam|  tasyaiva śamaṃ kuryāttataḥ paraṃ cānubandhasya||32||
translation:
When there is an excess of bile in the body, marked by signs like redness, inflammation, and burning sensation, it should be treated accordingly. Similarly, when a particular symptom predominates in phlegm-related disorders, such as congestion, heaviness, and swelling, that specific therapy should be applied. 

If one discerns a specific symptom, a distinct mark of a dosha in skin diseases, they should first pacify that particular dosha, and then address the root cause.

sloka: kuṣṭhaviśeṣairdoṣā doṣaviśeṣaiḥ punaśca kuṣṭhāni|  jñāyante tairheturhetustāṃśca [1] prakāśayati||33||
translation: By recognizing the distinct symptoms and types of leprosy, as well as their respective causes, one can identify this ailment. Upon understanding this, one should reveal and address the unique signs of individual leprosy instances. Furthermore, after applying a cure, one must also tackle any additional associations with the affliction.

sloka: raukṣyaṃ śoṣastodaḥ śūlaṃ saṅkocanaṃ tathā''yāmaḥ|  pāruṣyaṃ kharabhāvo harṣaḥ śyāvāruṇatvaṃ ca||34||  kuṣṭheṣu vātaliṅgaṃ dāho rāgaḥ parisravaḥ pākaḥ|  visro gandhaḥ kledastathā'ṅgapatanaṃ ca pittakṛtam||35||  śvaityaṃ śaityaṃ kaṇḍūḥ sthairyaṃ cotsedhagauravasnehāḥ|  kuṣṭheṣu tu kaphaliṅgaṃ jantubhirabhibhakṣaṇaṃ kledaḥ||36||
translation: In cases of disease, there is roughness (raukṣyaṃ), wasting away, sharp pain, and contraction; there is also impatience, harsh speech, and excitement. There is blueness/blackness (śyāva), redness, discharge, maturation, and digestion in the form of pus in the affected areas. Additionally, there is itching, burning, suppuration, firmness, heaviness, and phlegm-related swelling in cases of disease. Furthermore, there is excessive appetite/thirst by the microbes present in the affected areas, as well as accumulation of bodily fluids. (34-36)

sloka: sarvairliṅgairyuktaṃ matimān vivarjayedabalam|  tṛṣṇādāhaparītaṃ śāntāgniṃ jantubhirjagdham||37||  vātakaphaprabalaṃ yadyadekadoṣolbaṇaṃ na tat kṛcchram|  kaphapittavātapittaprabalāni tu kṛcchrasādhyāni||38||
translation: A discerning person should reject all unctuous , sharp , astringent, and rough substances, as well as violent agitation caused by wind , bile , and phlegm . Only that which is not faulted with an excess of wind can be easily accomplished without difficulty . However, the effects of an excess of bile, phlegm, and the combination of both are difficult to alleviate . Additionally, when consuming foods that cause phlegm in living beings , one should exercise caution.

sloka: vātottareṣu sarpirvamanaṃ śleṣmottareṣu kuṣṭheṣu|  pittottareṣu mokṣo raktasya virecanaṃ cāgre||39||
translation: A discerning person should reject, in all ways, a weak individual affected by thirst and burning caused by imbalanced wind in the northern direction, as well as phlegm in the northern direction and bile in the northern direction; and difficult ailments and their severe symptoms caused by excessive pitta in the eastern direction.

sloka: vamanavirecanayogāḥ kalpoktāḥ kuṣṭhināṃ prayoktavyāḥ|  pracchanamalpe kuṣṭhe mahati ca śastaṃ sirāvyadhanam||40||
translation: In the northern Vata regions, for those afflicted with various forms of kushta (skin diseases), the following remedies have been prescribed: in cases of severe kushta as well as for eliminating phlegm and pitta from the body, an enema consisting of a clarified butter and tortoise fat decoction mixture, combined with a purgative of salt and honey, should be administered. (40)

sloka: bahudoṣaḥ saṃśodhyaḥ kuṣṭhī bahuśo'nurakṣatā prāṇān|  doṣe hyatimātrahṛte vāyurhanyādabalamāśu||41||
translation: For a psoriasis patient, one who must be treated, numerous remedies are recommended such as purgatives, emetics, and therapeutic practices, as well as ointments for minor skin lesions. Indeed, in the case of excessive dosha accumulation or for severe cases, bloodletting through vein-cutting is advised.

sloka: snehasya pānamiṣṭaṃ śuddhe koṣṭhe pravāhite rakte|  vāyurhi śuddhakoṣṭhaṃ kuṣṭhinamabalaṃ viśati śīghram||42||
translation: Of the afflicted one, having purified the drinking vessel of sincere affection, one should cause the pure air to enter the now clean cavity in

sloka: doṣotkliṣṭe hṛdaye vāmyaḥ kuṣṭheṣu cordhvabhāgeṣu|  kuṭajaphalamadanamadhukaiḥ sapaṭolairnimbarasayuktaiḥ||43|| śītarasaḥ pakvaraso madhūni madhukaṃ ca vamanāni|
translation: The nectar-like sap, extracted from the mistletoe, when mixed with the bark of sacred trees like udumbara, is quickly absorbed into a heart, now pure and devoid of impurities, addressed as 'vāmya' . This mixture targets the upper parts of a diseased body. Also offered are honey and its bees, all of which have a cooling effect, aid in digestion, and alleviate the symptoms of the disease.

sloka: kuṣṭheṣu trivṛtā dantī triphalā ca virecane śastā||44||  sauvīrakaṃ tuṣodakamāloḍanamāsavāśca sīdhūni|  śaṃsantyadhoharāṇāṃ yathāvirekaṃ kramaśceṣṭaḥ||45||
translation: For someone with impure body parts, the one who is proficient in identifying and extracting the three types of dental ulcers, using triphala for purgation, and cooling down with sweet, ripe fruits, sugarcane, nimba, and patola; as they describe the results and progression of these treatments, they are praised by knowledgeable people.

sloka: dārvībṛhatīsevyaiḥ paṭolapicumardamadanakṛtamālaiḥ|  sasnehairāsthāpyaḥ kuṣṭhī sakaliṅgayavamustaiḥ||46||  vātolbaṇaṃ viriktaṃ nirūḍhamanuvāsanārhamālakṣya|  phalamadhukanimbakuṭajaiḥ sapaṭolaiḥ sādhayetsneham||47||
translation: To treat skin disorders, such as leprosy, one should apply a paste made from the triturated ingredients: Patala, Picumarda, and Mada, which have bitter, pungent, and sweet tastes respectively. This paste, mixed with various substances like Tusodaka, Asava, and Sesamum oil, should be applied all over the body, including nails and hair. After application, one should then gradually expose themselves to natural elements like sun rays, wind, etc. The desired outcome will be the eradication of the disease.

sloka: saindhavadantīmaricaṃ phaṇijjhakaḥ pippalī karañjaphalam|  nasyaṃ syātsaviḍaṅgaṃ krimikuṣṭhakaphaprakopaghnam [1] ||48||  vairecanikairdhūmaiḥ ślokasthāneritaiḥ praśāmyanti|  kṛmayaḥ kuṣṭhakilāsāḥ prayojitairuttamāṅgasthāḥ||49||
translation: The ailments such as ringworm (krimi) and skin diseases (kushta) are pacified when treated with a concoction prepared from flowers of brihati and dervi, patola, pica, marda, madana fruits, musta, yava, madhuka, nimba, kutaja, and sapatola herbs, all blended together with ghee and applied warm. This highly potent and soothing remedy alleviates the harmful effects of wind and eliminates skin disorders when used as directed.

sloka: sthirakaṭhinamaṇḍalānāṃ svinnānāṃ prastarapraṇāḍībhiḥ|  kūrcairvighaṭṭitānāṃ raktotkleśo'panetavyaḥ||50||
translation: The red inflammation caused by Krimi-born eruptions and other afflictions in the stable and stretched out body parts, which have become swollen, should be treated using the smoke of Vairechana Nikai Dhuma.

sloka: ānūpavārijānāṃ māṃsānāṃ poṭṭalaiḥ sukhoṣṇaiśca|  svinnotsannaṃ [1] vilikhet kuṣṭhaṃ tīkṣṇena śastreṇa||51||  rudhirāgamārthamathavā śṛṅgālābūni [2] yojayet kuṣṭhe|  pracchitamalpaṃ kuṣṭhaṃ virecayedvā jalaukobhiḥ||52||  ye lepāḥ kuṣṭhānāṃ yujyante nirhṛtāsradoṣāṇām|  saṃśodhitāśayānāṃ sadyaḥ siddhirbhavetteṣām||53||
translation: For purifying the hard, fixed pustules on well-developed, widely spread, and mobile mamsas, one should scrape them off using sharp instruments, causing a flow of blood for eliminating the red foulness. This is said to bring immediate success when such lepas, used for purification, are applied to properly prepared, impurity-free individuals, who have undergone the removal of impurities.

sloka: yeṣu na śastraṃ kramate sparśendriyanāśanāni yāni syuḥ|  teṣu nipātyaḥ kṣāro raktaṃ doṣaṃ ca visrāvya||54||  pāṣāṇakaṭhinaparuṣe supte kuṣṭhe sthire purāṇe ca|  pītāgadasya kāryo viṣaiḥ pradeho'gadaiścānu||55||  stabdhāni suptasuptānyasvedanakaṇḍulāni kuṣṭhāni|  kūrcairdantītrivṛtākaravīrakarañjakuṭajānām||56||  jātyarkanimbajairvā patraiḥ śastraiḥ samudraphenairvā|  ghṛṣṭāni gomayairvā tataḥ pradehaiḥ pradehyāni||57||
translation:
In those [places/things], where weapons don’t reach, and where the destroyers of the sense of touch are present,
those [places/things], into which one should apply [remedies], such that impurities and chronic skin diseases are quickly cleansed, eliminated, and healed.
Specifically, on a hard, harsh, dry, ancient, and fully matured skin lesion; a treatment having a yellowish substance should be applied, as well as remedies made of metallic compounds, or those that are alkaline in nature; and furthermore, by using instruments/remedies that are suitable for that purpose.
Moreover, when [the skin disease] becomes solidified, or when one is asleep or awake, one should apply a powder or a concoction made of small pieces of arka, nimba, or kuṣṭha, or other such substances, which can be used as remedies for skin diseases; and furthermore, by using instruments/remedies that are suitable for that purpose; or by using sea water, or other such substances that can be used as remedies for skin diseases; and furthermore, by using instruments/remedies that are suitable for that purpose.

sloka: mārutakaphakuṣṭhaghnaṃ karmoktaṃ pittakuṣṭhināṃ kāryam|  kaphapittaraktaharaṇaṃ tiktakaṣāyaiḥ praśamanaṃ ca||58||  sarpīṃṣi tiktakāni ca yaccānyadraktapittanut [1] karma|  bāhyābhyantaramagryaṃ tat kāryaṃ pittakuṣṭheṣu||59||
translation: The action that harms the Kapha disorder, likened to the wind, and is carried out by sharp, piercing instruments should be applied to the affected bodily locations. The rakta dosha should be purified with astringent substances that remove it, making it as thin and hard as a stone. This is the recommended treatment for the ancient, firmly established Pitta disorder. For other skin conditions such as blisters, pimples, and boils, use medicinal powders or pastes made from drugs like Kutaja, Arka, Nimba, prepared with water, ghee, or oil, applied externally; internally, administer appropriate drugs in suitable doses.

sloka: doṣādhikyavibhāgādityetat karma kuṣṭhanut proktam|  vakṣyāmi kuṣṭhaśamanaṃ prāyastvagdoṣasāmānyāt||60||
translation: The distinction of a deed being harmful, as attributed to an excessive prevalence of bodily humors such as mucus, bile, and wind, has been pointed out. I will explain in general, due to their shared qualities, the primary means of alleviating this skin disease caused by factors like rakta (blood tissue), tikta (bitter taste), and kaṣāyaiḥ (phlegm).

sloka: dārvī rasāñjanaṃ vā gomūtreṇa prabādhate kuṣṭham|  abhayā prayojitā vā māsaṃ savyoṣaguḍatailā||61||
translation: "Eliminating bodily impurities, particularly leprosy , can be achieved through therapeutic use of clay or cow urine . This treatment , when beneficial for the skin , should be practiced monthly . Moreover, such a treatment should be implemented when it is endowed with auspicious qualities , as stated by scripture . However, it is crucial to consider the specific nature of the ailment and seek guidance from a knowledgeable source."

sloka: mūlaṃ paṭolasya tathā gavākṣyāḥ pṛthak palāṃśaṃ triphalātvacaśca [1] |  syāttrāyamāṇā kaṭurohiṇī ca bhāgārdhikā nāgarapādayuktā||62||  palaṃ tathaiṣāṃ saha cūrṇitānāṃ jale śṛtaṃ doṣaharaṃ pibennā|  jīrṇe rasairdhanvamṛgadvijānāṃ purāṇaśālyodanamādadīta||63||  kuṣṭhāni śophaṃ grahaṇīpradoṣamarśāṃsi kṛcchrāṇi halīmakaṃ ca|  ṣaḍrātrayogena nihanti caiṣa hṛdbastiśūlaṃ viṣamajvaraṃ ca||64||
translation: The pulverized parts of

sloka: mustaṃ vyoṣaṃ triphalā mañjiṣṭhā dāru pañcamūlyau dve|  saptacchadanimbatvak saviśālaścitrako mūrvā||65||  cūrṇaṃ tarpaṇabhāgairnavabhiḥ saṃyojitaṃ samadhvājyam [1] |  siddhaṃ kuṣṭhanibarhaṇametat prāyogikaṃ bhakṣyam||66||  śvayathuṃ sapāṇḍurogaṃ śvitraṃ grahaṇīpradoṣamarśāṃsi|  braghnabhagandarapiḍakākaṇḍūkoṭhāṃśca vinihanti||67||  iti mustādicūrṇa
translation: "Filtered liquids mixed with the powder of

sloka: triphalāphalātiviṣākaṭukānimbakaliṅgakavacāpaṭolānām|  māgadhikārajanīdvayapadmakamūrvāviśālānām||68||  bhūnimbapalāśānāṃ dadyādvipalaṃ tatastrivṛddviguṇā|  tasyāśca punarbrāhmī taccūrṇaṃ suptinut paramam||69||
translation: Of the three types of fruits known as Triphala, if one were to give away a single fruit from each of the trees named Nimba, Kalingaka, Vaca, Patola, as well as two lotus flowers from the pond of Magadha kingdom, then for that person, the fruits of Nimba tree would become three times as potent, and furthermore, they would attain the supreme state of Brāhmī, known as Supti.

sloka: lelītakaprayogo [1] rasena jātyāḥ samākṣikaḥ paramaḥ|  saptadaśakuṣṭhaghātī mākṣikadhātuśca mūtreṇa||70||
translation: Through mantra recitation, the supreme essence of the three-fruited creepers, two-petaled jasmine, and mango tree, as well as that of bhu, nimba, and palasa, are combined to create samakshika rasa. This rasa possesses extraordinary potency, known as makshika, which is powerful and unparalleled.

sloka: śreṣṭhaṃ [2] gandhakayogāt suvarṇamākṣikaprayogādvā|  sarvavyādhinibarhaṇamadyāt kuṣṭhī rasaṃ ca nigṛhītam||71||  vajraśilājatusahitaṃ sahitaṃ vā yogarājena|  sarvavyādhipraśamanamadyātkuṣṭhī nigṛhya nityaṃ ca||72||
translation: The most excellent remedy, resulting from the combination of sandalwood and gold, can heal all ailments and consistently keep leprosy under control. Alternatively, when accompanied by the king of yogis, it not only soothes all diseases but also ensures that leprosy is kept at bay indefinitely.

sloka: khadirasuradārusāraṃ śrapayitvā tadrasena toyārthaḥ|  kṣaudraprasthe kāryaḥ kārye te cāṣṭapalike ca||73||  tatrāścūrṇānāmaṣṭapalaṃ prakṣipettathā'mūni|  triphalaile tvaṅmaricaṃ patraṃ kanakaṃ ca karṣāṃśam||74||  matsyaṇḍikā madhusamā tanmāsaṃ jātamāyase bhāṇḍe|  madhvāsavamācarataḥ kuṣṭhakilāse śamaṃ yātaḥ||75||  iti madhvāsavaḥ
translation:
By consistently using a combination of vajra-silā (adamantine stone) and jatu (a type of grass), referred to as khadira-sura-dāru, as an offering in the rite, one should make use of it in the kṣaudra-prasthe (at a small place). This should be done in relation to the tasks that need to be accomplished there, as well as in the case of treatment for a patient (te cāṣṭapalike). 

In this context, one should cause (prakṣipet) the powdered form of aṣṭapala, a type of herbal medicine, to be mixed there, along with tri-phala, tvak-marica, a gold leaf, and a portion of karṣā. 

Additionally, leprosy (kuṣṭhakilāse) can be pacified by preparing a preparation made from matsyaṇḍikā-madhusamā, māsa (meat), jātamāya, and placing it in a pot for maturation, while following the method of madhva-āsava practice.

sloka: khadirakaṣāyadroṇaṃ kumbhe ghṛtabhāvite samāvāpya|  dravyāṇi cūrṇitāni ca ṣaṭpalikānyatra deyāni||76||
translation: Having filled the pot, located in

sloka: triphalāvyoṣaviḍaṅgarajanīmustāṭarūṣakendrayavāḥ|  sauvarṇī ca tathā tvak chinnaruhā ceti tanmāsam||77||
translation: Prepared by mixing together khadira and kaṣāya in a copper vessel, combined with ghṛta heated to perfection, as well as samā, vāpya, and other dravyāṇi that have been ground into a fine powder, this indeed is the recommended method for creating tanmāsam.

sloka: nidadhīta dhānyamadhye prātaḥ prātaḥ pibettato yuktyā|  māsena mahākuṣṭhaṃ hantyevālpaṃ tu pakṣeṇa||78||  arśaḥśvāsabhagandarakāsakilāsapramehaśoṣāṃśca|  nā bhavati kanakavarṇaḥ pītvā'riṣṭaṃ kanakabindum||79||
translation:
Consuming every morning, before sunrise, sesame seeds that are carefully cleaned and stored in a jar, is recommended; such a practice, according to this precept, helps prevent or alleviate ailments like tuberculosis, hiccups, cough, leprosy, and other Pitta-related disorders. However, consuming a small amount daily won't bring about the same benefits as having it in larger quantities once a month (78-79).

Taking Triphala, Ajwain, Vida, black salt, Rajanighantu, Musta, Ushira, Kendrayavah, Sauvarni, and chopped skin together with honey can cure disorders caused by Vata, Kapha, Rakta (blood), itching, and other Pitta-related conditions; but consuming a small amount of just gold won't yield the same benefits (80).

sloka: iti kanakabindvariṣṭam  kuṣṭheṣvanilakaphakṛteṣvevaṃ peyastathā'pi paitteṣu|  kṛtamālakvāthaścāpyeṣa viśeṣāt kaphakṛteṣu||80||
translation: Having established the rice crop in the middle at dawn, one should drink (water) in due measure with a month, just as it has been established; thus it eliminates a small amount of pithy disorder. Moreover, even in cases of phthisis, cough, shortness of breath, diarrhea, vomiting, fever, and leprosy, this distinction is especially prominent: (the drinking water) does not turn golden after consuming the medicine.

sloka: triphalāsavaśca gauḍaḥ sacitrakaḥ kuṣṭharogavinihantā|  kramukadaśamūladantīvarāṅgamadhuyogasaṃyuktaḥ||81||
translation: This is Gauda, specifically formulated with a triple fermentation process using phala, which eliminates not only kuṣṭha but also other doshas such as kapha and anila. It further incorporates components like peya, paitte, kṛtamāla, and fragrant ariṣṭam, ultimately giving it a golden hue.

sloka: laghūni cānnāni hitāni vidyāt kuṣṭheṣu śākani ca tiktakāni|  bhallātakaiḥ satriphalaiḥ sanimbairyuktāni cānnāni ghṛtāni caiva||82||  purāṇadhānyānyatha jāṅgalāni māṃsāni mudgāśca paṭolayuktāḥ|  śastā na gurvamlapayodadhīni nānūpamatsyā na guḍastilāśca||83||
translation: Three types of fruit concoctions, namely Gauda and Sacitraka, ought to be known as beneficial for eliminating skin diseases in individuals; Kramuka, Dasamula, Dantimula, Vara, and Angamadhu, when combined with honey, prove to be beneficial in treating leprosy. However, one should avoid consuming coarse grains such as Mudga and Patola, water from stale sources, unwholesome fish, as well as Guda and Stila.

sloka: elā kuṣṭhaṃ dārvī śatapuṣpā citrako viḍaṅgaśca|  kuṣṭhālepanamiṣṭaṃ rasāñjanaṃ cābhayā caiva||84||
translation: The lightly fried grains, being beneficial for kuṣṭha, include dārvī, śatapuṣpā, citraka, and viḍaṅga. Also included are kuṣṭha ointments, rasāñjana, and abhayā. Furthermore, ancient grains, jāṅgalas, various meats, mudgās with patola, and light, non-sour fruits like payas, dadhis, ānūpa-fish, guḍa, and tilas are included.

sloka: citrakamelāṃ bimbīṃ [1] vṛṣakaṃ trivṛdarkanāgarakam|  cūrṇīkṛtamaṣṭāhaṃ bhāvayitavyaṃ palāśasya||85||  kṣāreṇa gavāṃ mūtrasrutena tenāsya maṇḍalānyāśu|  bhidyante vilayanti ca liptānyarkābhitaptāni||86||
translation: The bilva fruit, combined with costus, manjishtha, and a hundred flowers of utpala, should be carefully prepared and applied as a paste to the eight cardinal points on the bark of the palasa tree. When smeared with cow dung, it causes the circles to split open and disintegrate due to the power of the medicinal herbs, just as fear is dispelled by the mere sight of a protector. This should be done using a cow's dung and the bilva fruit mixture, which is applied to the tree's bark, causing the circles drawn with the medicinal paste to open and disintegrate.

sloka: māṃsī maricaṃ lavaṇaṃ rajanī tagaraṃ sudhā gṛhāddhūmaḥ|  mūtraṃ pittaṃ [2] kṣāraḥ pālāśaḥ kuṣṭhahā lepaḥ||87||
translation: With cow ghee, salt, black pepper, tagara, and honey, as well as smoke from a home, urine, bile, lime, and arka applied, should be split open (for medicinal purposes).

sloka: trapu sīsamayaścūrṇaṃ maṇḍalanut phalgucitrakau bṛhatī|  godhārasaḥ salavaṇo dāru ca mūtraṃ ca maṇḍalanut||88||
translation: Consisting of a small, flat fragment, a moderately beautiful circular design, a larger one, a turmeric-flour mixture, wood, and urine, all contained within a single small circle. (This could describe a seal or emblem used in ceremonial contexts.)

sloka: kadalīpalāśapāṭaliniculakṣārāmbhasā prasannena|  māṃseṣu toyakāryaṃ kāryaṃ piṣṭe ca kiṇve [3] ca||89||  tairmedakaḥ sujātaḥ kiṇvairjanitaṃ pralepanaṃ śastam|  maṇḍalakuṣṭhavināśanamātapasaṃsthaṃ kṛmighnaṃ ca||90||
translation: With refined rice flour, a mixture of coconut palm leaves, ripened bimbi fruits, and dough, as well as liquids such as water, you all should anoint the sacrificial animal. This mixture, which consists of turmeric, yellow myrobalan, and black myrobalan, is beneficial, born of refined substances, destructive to mold, and lethal to harmful insects, should be applied to the animal's body.

sloka: mustaṃ madanaṃ triphalā karañja āragvadhakaliṅgayavāḥ|  dārvī sasaptaparṇā snānaṃ siddhārthakaṃ nāma||91||  eṣa kaṣāyo vamanaṃ virecanaṃ varṇakastathodgharṣaḥ|  tvagdoṣakuṣṭhaśophaprabādhanaḥ pāṇḍurogaghnaḥ||92||
translation:
Ground into a paste along with mustard, triphala, karañja, āragvadha, and kaliṅga, this preparation, known as siddhārthaka, is currently being prepared. It removes excess fat, impurities, disorders of the skin, intestinal worms, and ailments related to bile, while also improving complexion. (91)
The therapies of purging and emesis, devoid of kuṣṭha, alleviate disorders caused by heat, impurities, and itching caused by skin diseases, and destroy ailments associated with pāṇḍu. (92)

sloka: kuṣṭhaṃ karañjabījānyeḍagajaḥ kuṣṭhasūdano lepaḥ|  prapunnāḍabījasaindhavarasāñjanakapitthalodhrāśca||93||  śvetakaravīramūlaṃ kuṭajakarañjayoḥ phalaṃ tvaco dārvyāḥ|  sumanaḥpravālayukto lepaḥ kuṣṭhāpahaḥ siddhaḥ||94||
translation: A remedy for the disease known as kushtha is prepared using the fruits of madana, triphala, karañjabija, aragvadha, kalinga, yavah, dārvī, and sasaptaparṇā, which, when formulated as a paste, added to a bath, or administered as vamana or virechana, effectively treats the condition, including symptoms like skin whitening, and additionally cures pandu-roga.

sloka: lodhrasya dhātakīnāṃ vatsakabījasya naktamālasya|  kalkaśca mālatīnāṃ kuṣṭheṣūnmardanālepau||95||
translation: A paste made from the root of lodhras tree, dhātakī flowers, naktamāla seeds, and kalka, applied to mālatī fruits and administered with the drugs named iṣūn and nā, indeed serves as an effective remedy for kuṣṭha disease.

sloka: śairīṣī tvak puṣpaṃ kārpāsyā rājavṛkṣapatrāṇi|  piṣṭā ca kākamācī caturvidhaḥ kuṣṭhanullepaḥ||96||  iti lepāḥ
translation: Ground from lodhra, dhātakī, vatsaka, naktam, ālasya, kalka, mālatī, and kuṣṭha, mixed with the oil of īśū and marda, are these four kinds of medicinal pastes. (Referring to the therapeutic pastes mentioned earlier)

sloka: dārvyā rasāñjanasya ca nimbapaṭolasya khadirasārasya|  āragvadhavṛkṣakayostriphalāyāḥ saptaparṇasya||97||  iti ṣaṭ kaṣāyayogāḥ kuṣṭhaghnāḥ saptamaśca tiniśasya|  snāne pāne ca hitāstathā'ṣṭamaścāśvamārasya||98||  ālepanaṃ pragharṣaṇamavacūrṇanameta eva ca kaṣāyāḥ|  tailaghṛtapākayoge ceṣyante kuṣṭhaśāntyartham||99||
translation: The ingredients for the concoction of a paste include the bark of a tree named śairī Shaahr, the rind of a pomegranate, the blossoms of the kārpāsyā plant, the leaves of the rāja vṛkṣa tree, all crushed and combined together with the extract of the kuṣṭha nut. This constitutes the application for curing leprosy. Moreover, applying, massaging, and anointing the affected region with this paste is also advantageous for alleviating the ailment. The eighth remedy is to consume the decoction derived from the asvamāra herb.

sloka: triphalā nimbapaṭolaṃ mañjiṣṭhā rohiṇī vacā rajanī|  eṣa kaṣāyo'bhyasto nihanti kaphapittajaṃ kuṣṭham||100||  etaireva ca sarpiḥ siddhaṃ vātolbaṇaṃ jayati kuṣṭham|  eṣa ca kalpo diṣṭaḥ khadirāsanadārunimbānām||101||
translation: The three fruits of the nimba tree, namely manjishtha, Rohini, and vaca, along with kashaya, when used, eliminate kapha-pitta related kushta diseases. This is a proven remedy. Additionally, when combined with ghee and prepared as per prescribed method, it also cures ulbana type kushta. This treatment method, when followed, proves beneficial for those suffering from kushta resulting from khadira, asana, and daru nimba.

sloka: kuṣṭhārkatutthakaṭphalamūlakabījāni rohiṇī kaṭukā|  kuṭajaphalotpalamustaṃ bṛhatīkaravīrakāsīsam||102||  eḍagajanimbapāṭhā durālabhā citrako viḍaṅgaśca|  tiktālābukabījaṃ kampillakasarṣapau vacā dārvī||103||  etaistailaṃ siddhaṃ kuṣṭhaghnaṃ yoga eṣa cālepaḥ|  udvartanaṃ pragharṣaṇamavacūrṇanameṣa eveṣṭaḥ||104||
translation:
This concoction, known as cālepa, is a special mixture, consisting of:
the roots of kuṣṭhārkaka, kuṭaja, phalatutpa, musta, bṛhatī, karavīra, kāsīsa,
eḍagaja, nimbapāṭha, which are difficult to obtain,
citraka, viḍaṅga,
the seeds of kaṭukā, kuṣṭha, tiktālābu, kampillaka, sarṣapa,
and the powders of vacā and dārvī.
This siddha preparation, when used as a paste, is effective in treating kuṣṭha and other skin ailments. Its application includes udvartana, pragharṣaṇa, and avacūrṇana.

sloka: śvetakaravīrakaraso gomūtraṃ citrako viḍaṅgaśca|  kuṣṭheṣu tailayogaḥ siddho'yaṃ sammato bhiṣajām||105||  iti śvetakaravīrādyaṃ tailam
translation: Prepared from a mixture of the roots of Rohini, Katukakutaja, Utphala, Musta, Brihati, Krsnasariva, Citraka, Vida, and Dhavanika, as well as the seeds of Tiktalabuka and Durarbhapata, all combined with sesame oil, this medicinal oil, known for its effectiveness in treating skin diseases, is referred to as "śvetakaravīrādyaṃ tailam."

sloka: śvetakaravīrapallavamūlatvagvatsako viḍaṅgaśca|  kuṣṭhārkamūlasarṣapaśigrutvagrohiṇī kaṭukā||106||  etaistailaṃ siddhaṃ kalkaiḥ pādāṃśikairgavāṃ mūtram|  dattvā tailacaturguṇamabhyaṅgāt kuṣṭhakaṇḍūghnam||107||  iti śvetakaravīrapallavādyaṃ tailam
translation: This is the anointment, known as "Śvetakaravīra," recognized by medical experts, composed of the root of the Śvetakaravīra plant and other substances. Its fourfold potency, when blended with cow’s urine and applied to the affected regions, is said to alleviate skin conditions (kuṣṭhakaṇḍūghnam), according to ancient medical texts.

sloka: tiktālābukabījaṃ dve tutthe rocanā haridre dve|  bṛhatīphalameraṇḍaḥ saviśālaścitrako mūrvā||108||  kāsīsahiṅguśigrutryūṣaṇasuradārutumburuviḍaṅgam|  lāṅgālakaṃ kuṭajatvak kaṭukākhyā rohiṇī caiva||109|| sarṣapatailaṃ kalkairetairmūtre caturguṇe sādhyam|  kaṇḍūkuṣṭhavināśanamabhyaṅgānmārutakaphahantṛ||110|| iti tiktekṣvākvāditailam
translation: The root of karavera leaves, viḍaṅga, and kuṣṭha, combined with arka, sarṣapa, śigru, the outer skin of Rohiṇī and Kaṭukā plants, and the expressed oil of sesame seeds, all in equal parts, becomes, when cooked with cow's milk, a siddha medicinal oil known as tiktālikṣvādi. This is the first such root-based oil.

sloka: kanakakṣīrī śailā bhārgī dantyāḥ phalāni mūlaṃ ca|  jātīpravālasarṣapalaśunaviḍaṅgaṃ karañjatvak||111||  saptacchadārkapallavamūlatvaṅnimbacitrakāsphotāḥ|  guñjairaṇḍaṃ bṛhatīmūlakasurasārjakaphalāni||112||  kuṣṭhaṃ pāṭhā mustaṃ tumburumūrvāvacāḥ saṣaḍgranthāḥ [1] |  eḍagajakuṭajaśigrutryūṣaṇabhallātakakṣavakāḥ||113||  haritālamavākpuṣpī tutthaṃ kampillako'mṛtāsañjñaḥ|  saurāṣṭrī kāsīsaṃ dārvītvak sarjikālavaṇam||114||  kalkairetaistailaṃ karavīrakamūlapallavakaṣāye|  sārṣapamathavā tailaṃ gomūtracaturguṇaṃ sādhyam||115||
translation: The buds of the bitter ala plant, of two tutthha varieties, possessing a shining haridra color and bṛhatī sized fruits of the long eranda type, having mūrvā, kāsīsa, hiṅgu, śuktri, yūṣaṇa, sura, dāru, tumburu, and viḍaṅga components, endowed with a lāṅgala-type skin, named kaṭuka, having ākhyā, rohiṇī, sarṣapa, and kuṭaja components, when combined with kalkaiḥ and mixed with four-fold guṇas of gomūtra, prove effective in treating kuṣṭha, vinā kandū, and aśanam, beneficial in abhyaṅgān, pacifying māruta and kapha, and acting as a destroyer of tiktā and ikṣvāku type diseases.

sloka: sthāpyaṃ kaṭukālābuni tatsiddhaṃ tena maṇḍalānyāśu|  bhindyādbhiṣagabhyaṅgātkṛmīṃśca kaṇḍūṃ ca vinihanyāt||116||  iti kanakakṣīrītailam
translation: Prepare the following concoction: a pungent substance, already established, to be applied; for splitting open with medicinal purpose, as well as for destroying pustules; indeed, gold-colored kṣīrī and oil.

sloka: kuṣṭhaṃ tamālapatraṃ maricaṃ samanaḥśilaṃ sakāsīsam|  tailena yuktamuṣitaṃ saptāhaṃ bhājane tāmre||117||  tenāliptaṃ sidhmaṃ saptāhāhyeti [1] tiṣṭhato gharme|  māsānnavaṃ kilāsaṃ snānaṃ muktvā viśuddhatanoḥ||118||  iti sidhme lepaḥ
translation: Upon being applied with a therapeutic agent consisting of costus , black myrobalan , rock salt , powdered iron ore , and a suitable amount of clarified butter , massaged and fomented with heat for seven days, then washed off with a mixture of turmeric and liquid butter , the affliction is cured; this treatment is known as "sidhma" and is used to alleviate skin conditions such as scabies and boils.

sloka: sarṣapakarañjakoṣātakīnāṃ tailānyatheṅgudīnāṃ ca|  kuṣṭheṣu hitānyāhustailaṃ yaccāpi khadirasārasya||119||
translation: For skin diseases, the oils extracted from sesame seeds and kodrava grass are recommended; likewise, the sap of the tamala tree, when mixed with marica and salt, is beneficial. This has been established as a treatment for leprosy.

sloka: jīvantī mañjiṣṭhā dārvī kampillakaḥ payastuttham|  eṣa ghṛtatailapākaḥ siddhaḥ siddhe ca sarjarasaḥ||120||  deyaḥ samadhūcchiṣṭo vipādikā tena śāmyate'bhyaktā|  carmaikakuṣṭhakiṭimaṃ kuṣṭhaṃ śāmyatyalasakaṃ ca||121||  iti vipādikāharaghṛtataile
translation: The oils derived from the living "jīvantī" herb, manjistha, dervi, kampillaka, grown in a paste or dough, along with sesame and castor beans, when extracted and processed, become efficacious siddha preparations for treating skin diseases, especially when combined with pure ghee. Proper application of this preparation alleviates various skin ailments, such as eczema or psoriasis, reducing their severity. This process is known as treating skin diseases with ghee-based concoctions.

sloka: kiṇvaṃ [1] varāharudhiraṃ pṛthvīkā saindhavaṃ ca lepaḥ syāt|  lepo yojyaḥ kustumburūṇi kuṣṭhaṃ ca maṇḍalanut||122||
translation: A paste composed of juices from myrobalan (kiṇvaṃ), licorice (varāha-rudhiraṃ), barley (pṛthvī-kā), and camphor (ca), blended with ghee and sesame oil, when applied to the afflicted region, alleviates impurities in the body. This method has been proven effective for treating leprosy (kustumburu-rūṇi kusthaṃ ca maṇḍala-nut).

sloka: pūtīkadārujaṭilāḥ pakvasurā kṣaudramudgaparṇyau ca|  lepaḥ sakākanāso maṇḍalakuṣṭhāpahaḥ siddhaḥ||123||
translation: The dough, made from pure ingredients and previously mixed with salt, sugar, and crushed peas, becomes, when properly prepared, a relish that is both flawless and admirable. (123)

sloka: citrakaśobhāñjanakau guḍūcyapāmārgadevadārūṇi|  khadiro dhavaśca lepaḥ śyāmā dantī dravantī ca||124||  lākṣārasāñjanailāḥ punarnavā ceti kuṣṭhino lepāḥ|  dadhimaṇḍayutāḥ sarve deyāḥ ṣaṇmārutakaphakuṣṭhaghnāḥ||125||
translation: The medicinal formulations, consisting of citraka, śobhā, and janakau, as well as guḍūcya, pāmārga, devadāru, khadira, and dhava, together with lepa processed from them, śyāmā dantī and dravantī, as well as those made from a compound of lākṣā, rasā, and āñjana, all of which are suitable for application, are to be given to those suffering from various forms of skin disease, including those that are difficult to treat, such as na-punaḥ-vā-iti kuṣṭhinaḥ. These include formulations made from dadhi-maṇḍa, which are all effective against skin diseases caused by ṣaṭ-māruta-kapha, as they are beneficial for treating various types of skin ailments.

sloka: eḍagajakuṣṭhasaindhavasauvīrakasarṣapaiḥ kṛmighnaiśca|  kṛmikuṣṭhamaṇḍalākhyaṃ dadrūkuṣṭhaṃ ca śamamupaiti||126||
translation: The renowned healers, Citraka and Sobhana, combined with Khadira, Dhava, and lemon tree pastes, as well as ANjana, ela, and laksA, all applied together, can eradicate the kuSTha condition characterized by the six humors, kapha, and kuSTha. Furthermore, a paste consisting of all these ingredients, including yogurt and mud, is recommended for those suffering from kuSTha-maNDala.

sloka: eḍagajaḥ sarjaraso mūlakabījaṃ ca sidhmakuṣṭhānām|  kāñjikayuktaṃ tu pṛthaṅmatamidamudvartanaṃ lepāḥ||127||
translation: The paste made from myrobalan, which an elephant has licked, is indeed, in a class by itself, as a treatment for boils and pustules on the body.

sloka: vāsā triphalā pāne snāne codvartane pralepe ca|  bṛhatīsevyapaṭolāḥ sasārivā rohiṇī caiva||128||  khadirāvaghātakakubharohītakalodhrakuṭajadhavanimbāḥ|  saptacchadakaravīrāḥ śasyante snānapāneṣu||129||
translation: The paste made from the fruits of Triphala, when used in washing, anointing, and massaging, as well as when consumed as a drink, is known to cure various skin ailments such as eczema. Similarly, the bark of Khadira, when processed with ingredients including birch bark, eliminates seven types of impurities during bathing and drinking water.

sloka: jalavāpyalohakeśarapatraplavacandanaṃ mṛṇālāni|  bhāgottarāṇi siddhaṃ pralepanaṃ pittakaphakuṣṭhe||130||
translation: In the application of water sources like ponds, plants such as sacred turmeric and red sandalwood, as well as birch bark, and the bark of seven other trees, specifically for bathing, drinking, and anointing, there are indeed conferred triple benefits, which are permanently established.

sloka: yaṣṭyāhvalodhrapadmakapaṭolapicumardacandanarasāśca|  snāne pāne ca hitāḥ suśītalāḥ pittakuṣṭhibhyaḥ||131||
translation: Prepared with care, the sandalwood paste, sourced from the upper petals of a lotus growing in clean water, when used in bathing and drinking, is cooling and beneficial for both Pitta and Kapha doshas, as it has been properly made.

sloka: ālepanaṃ priyaṅgurhareṇukā vatsakasya ca phalāni|  sātiviṣā ca sasevyā sacandanā rohiṇī kaṭukā||132||
translation: The washing with the cool extract of priyangu and the soothing extract of usheer, padma, kapaalaa, marda, Chandan, and Rohini, as well as the fruits of Vatsaka, is beneficial for both bathing and drinking. Furthermore, it alleviates pitta and kushthi, being respectively served by sātiviṣā and sacandanā-rohiṇī, which are bitter in taste.

sloka: tiktaghṛtairdhautaghṛtairabhyaṅgo dahyamānakuṣṭheṣu|  tailaiścandanamadhukaprapauṇḍarīkotpalayutaiśca||133||
translation: Anointed with sacandana paste, the body is further treated with a paste made from priyaṅgu, haridra, and vatsaka fruits, as well as ativiṣa, and is additionally adorned with pauṇḍarīka and utpala flowers, while being burnt by a fire applied to the skin afflictions.

sloka: klede prapatati cāṅge dāhe visphoṭake sacarmadale|  śītāḥ pradehasekā vyadho vireko ghṛtaṃ tiktam||134||
translation: Consumed by heat, one seeks cooling down in clarified butter that has been properly cleansed; sesame oil and sandalwood, applied to the body, alleviate the itching caused by eczema.

sloka: khadiraghṛtaṃ nimbaghṛtaṃ dārvīghṛtamuttamaṃ paṭolaghṛtam|  kuṣṭheṣu raktapittaprabaleṣu bhiṣagjitaṃ siddham||135||
translation: In cases of bleeding, inflammation, and skin disorders like raktapitta, an expert doctor should apply the ghee made from khadira, nimba, patola, and dārvī, which are bitter and astringent in taste and are proven to be most effective.

sloka: triphalātvaco'rdhapalikāḥ paṭolapatraṃ ca kārṣikāḥ śeṣāḥ|  kaṭurohiṇī sanimbā yaṣṭyāhvā trāyamāṇā ca||136||  eṣa kaṣāyaḥ sādhyo dattvā dvipalaṃ masūravidalānām|  salilāḍhake'ṣṭabhāge śeṣe pūto raso grāhyaḥ||137||
translation: Consuming a mixture of ghee from superior cows, barley and wheat gruel, nimba tree extract, and khadira bark decoction, along with Pitta-alleviating and Rakta-purifying substances, given by a knowledgeable physician, will cure diseases caused by an imbalance in Katu and Ushna elements. This concoction, consisting of purified butter, barley, wheat, nimba, and khadira, should be taken after suitable additions have been made. Once prepared, it should be offered to the patient in the final stage of digestion for optimal results.

sloka: te ca [1] kaṣāye'ṣṭapale catuṣpalaṃ sarpiṣaśca paktavyam|  yāvatsyādaṣṭapalaṃ śeṣaṃ peyaṃ tataḥ koṣṇam||138||  tadvātapittakuṣṭhaṃ vīsarpaṃ vātaśoṇitaṃ prabalam|  jvaradāhagulmavidradhivibhramavisphoṭakān hanti||139||
translation: When the fruits are fully ripe, who among you will prepare the four-cornered pancake? Consume eight parts and leave a quarter. The juice, once strained, can be consumed. This eliminates the harmful effects of excessive heat, wind, and bile.

sloka: nimbapaṭolaṃ dārvīṃ durālabhāṃ tiktarohiṇīṃ triphalām|  kuryādardhadalāṃśaṃ parpaṭakaṃ trāyamāṇāṃ ca||140||  salilāḍhakasiddhānāṃ rase'ṣṭabhāgasthite kṣipet pūte|  candanakirātatiktakamāgadhikāstrāyamāṇāṃ ca||141||  mustaṃ vatsakabījaṃ kalkīkṛtyārdhakārṣikān bhāgān|  navasarpiṣaśca ṣaṭpalametatsiddhaṃ [3] ghṛtaṃ peyam||142||  kuṣṭhajvaragulmārśograhaṇīpāṇḍvāmayaśvayathuhāri|  pāmāvisarpapiḍakākaṇḍūmadagaṇḍanutsiddham||143||  iti tiktaṣaṭpalakaṃ ghṛtam
translation: This ghee, prepared with a pungent Tinduka leaf extract, carefully selected and rare, having a bitter taste, and infused with a sixth portion each of medicinal agents effective for treating ailments such as wind disorders, bile, leprosy, poison, blood morbidity, excessive strength, and fever symptoms like chills, should be used. It is capable of curing diseases like leprosy, consumption, dropsy, piles, and other maladies.

sloka: saptacchadaṃ prativiṣāṃ śampākaṃ tiktarohiṇīṃ pāṭhām|  mustamuśīraṃ triphalāṃ paṭolapicumardaparpaṭakam||144||  dhanvayavāsaṃ candanamupakulyāṃ padmakaṃ haridre dve|  ṣaḍgranthāṃ saviśālāṃ śatāvarīṃ sārive cobhe||145||  vatsakabījaṃ yāsaṃ [4] mūrvāmamṛtāṃ kirātatiktaṃ ca|  kalkān kuryānmatimānyaṣṭyāhvaṃ trāyamāṇāṃ ca||146||  kalkaścāturbhāgo [5] jalamaṣṭaguṇaṃ raso'mṛtaphalānām|  dviguṇo ghṛtātpradeyastatsarpiḥ pāyayetsiddham||147||  kuṣṭhāni raktapittaprabalānyarśāṃsi raktavāhīni|  vīsarpamamlapittaṃ [6] vātāsṛk pāṇḍurogaṃ ca||148|| visphoṭakānsapāmānunmādaṃ kāmalāṃ jvaraṃ kaṇḍūm|  hṛdrogagulmapiḍakā asṛgdaraṃ gaṇdamālāṃ ca||149||  hanyādetat sarpiḥ pītaṃ kāle yathābalaṃ sadyaḥ|  yogaśatairapyajitānmahāvikārānmahātiktam||150||  iti mahātiktakaṃ ghṛtam
translation: Prepare the following concoction: Combine a half-part of nimbapaṭolam and dārvī, both being rare and bitter; one triphalā, thoroughly crushed with half of parpaṭakam; an eighth portion of trāyamāṇām salila āḍhaka of siddhānām rase; place kuṣṭhajvaragulmārśograhaṇīpāṇḍvāmayaśvayathuhāri in it, purified with candana; further add kirāta tiktaka and māgadhi; stir until all impurities such as kāḥ pāmāvisarpapiḍakākaṇḍūmadagaṇḍanutsiddham are eliminated; this is known as tiktaṣaṭpalakam ghṛtam.

sloka: doṣe hṛte'panīte rakte bāhyāntare kṛte śamane [7] |  snehe ca kālayukte na kuṣṭhamanuvartate [8] sādhyam||151||
translation: In the seventh stage of treating a disorder, once the toxin is removed, the blood purified, and tridoshic equilibrium restored, and in the eighth stage, when ointments like usheer, sarpi (clarified butter), pittapapa, madhu, etc., are applied, a kustha (skin disease) will not arise. This sadyaha (immediately) counteracts major vikaras (changes/diseases) such as jvara (fever), kandu (itching), hrdrogagulmapidakaasrga (heart diseases), gandamala (tumors), etc. Its taste is tiktakam (bitter).

sloka: khadirasya tulāḥ pañca śiṃśapāsanayostule|  tulārdhāḥ sarva evaite karañjāriṣṭavetasāḥ||152||  parpaṭaḥ kuṭajaścaiva vṛṣaḥ kṛmiharastathā|  haridre kṛtamālaśca guḍūcī triphalā trivṛt||153||  saptaparṇaśca saṅkṣuṇṇā daśadroṇeṣu vāriṇaḥ|  aṣṭabhāgāvaśeṣaṃ tu kaṣāyamavatārayet||154||  dhātrīrasaṃ ca tulyāṃśaṃ sarpiṣaścāḍhakaṃ pacet|  mahātiktakakalkaistu yathoktaiḥ palasammitaiḥ||155||  nihanti sarvakuṣṭhāni pānābhyaṅganiṣevaṇāt|  mahākhadiramityetat paraṃ kuṣṭhavikāranut||156||  iti mahākhadiraṃ ghṛtam
translation: Five measures of Khadira wood and five of Śimśapā wood, when each half is combined, equal the weight of a pair of Karañja and Ariṣṭa fruits. The weight of a Parpaṭa fruit, a Kuṭaja fruit, a Vṛṣa fruit, and a worm-infested grain, along with a garland made from Haridrā, Guḍūcī, Triphalā fruits, all combined, equals the weight of a Saptaparṇa leaf, reduced to fragments and weighed in ten equal parts. Subtracting eight parts of this total from Kaṣāya serves as the purifying agent. The same quantity as that of Dhātrī rasa is used in cooking clarified butter, along with specified measures of Mahātiktaka, Kakala, and other ingredients mentioned. Regular application of this Khadira ghee can help eliminate all types of skin diseases. This treatment, known as the supreme remedy for chronic skin conditions, goes by the name Mahākhadira.

sloka: prapatatsu lasīkāprasruteṣu gātreṣu jantujagdheṣu|  mūtraṃ nimbaviḍaṅge snānaṃ pānaṃ pradehaśca||157||
translation: O worthy one, currently immersed in the bathing of your body with the water of rivers where the lasiika (small fish) play, equipped with the five silver pieces of shimshapa wood, a pair of gold tulap scales, the bark of

sloka: vṛṣakuṭajasaptaparṇāḥ karavīrakarañjanimbakhadirāśca|  snāne pāne lepe krimikuṣṭhanudaḥ sagomūtrāḥ||158||
translation: During bathing, drinking, and anointing, the raindrops that come into contact with living beings' bodies become purified, just like the sap of a Nimba tree. Specifically, these raindrops are compared to the sap of the Nimba tree, which is known for its purifying qualities, due to their contact with these creatures and their subsequent purification. The elements mentioned (bathing, drinking, anointing) serve to highlight the various ways in which these purifying raindrops interact with living beings, further emphasizing their purifying nature. The individuals referred to as 'Parṇāḥ' and 'Khadirāḥ' could potentially refer to specific types of trees or plants, further reinforcing the connection to nature and natural purification processes.

sloka: pānāhāravidhāne prasecane dhūpane pradehe ca|  kṛmināśanaṃ viḍaṅgaṃ viśiṣyate kuṣṭhahā khadiraḥ||159||
translation: In the observance of partaking food and drink, the destruction of worms and alleviation of skin diseases such as scabies are considered superior when utilizing two varieties of Kutaja leaves, as well as those of Karañja and Nimba. This is deemed excellent, as per the established rules for consumption and purification methods, including fumigation.

sloka: eḍagajaḥ saviḍaṅgo mūlānyāragvadhasya kuṣṭhānām|  uddālanaṃ śvadantā gośvavarāhoṣṭradantāśca||160||
translation: In the treatment of leprosy's root causes through emetics and purgatives, the administration of Pāna (medicinal decoction) and Āhāra (medicated diet), combined with fumigation (Dhūpana), ointment application (Pradeha), and elimination of Kṛmi (worms) using Viḍaṅga, is most efficacious, particularly when enhanced with Kadira.

sloka: eḍagajaḥ saviḍaṅgo dve ca niśe rājavṛkṣamūlaṃ ca|  kuṣṭhoddālanamagryaṃ sapippalīpākalaṃ yojyam||161||
translation: The root of the rājavṛkṣa tree, as well as that of elephant's, vit, two types of grasses, and the teeth of a dog, boar, and buffalo, should be used in conjunction with sapippalīpākala and kuṣṭhoddālanamagrya for treating skin diseases.

sloka: śvitrāṇāṃ saviśeṣaṃ [1] yoktavyaṃ sarvato viśuddhānām|  śvitre sraṃsanamagryaṃ malapūrasa iṣyate saguḍaḥ||162||  taṃ pītvā susnigdho yathābalaṃ sūryapādasantāpam|  saṃseveta viriktastryahaṃ pipāsuḥ pibet peyām||163||
translation: For those who are completely pure, the foremost excellence consists in adopting the practices of all virtuous beings. Just as a thirsty elephant, after drinking water, becomes refreshed and approaches the heat of the sun, similarly should one worship Me, having first cleansed oneself, and a thirsty person ought to drink water.

sloka: śvitre'ṅge ye sphoṭā jāyante kaṇṭakena tānbhindyāt|  sphoṭeṣu visruteṣu prātaḥ prātaḥ pibet pakṣam||164||  malapūmasanaṃ priyaṅguṃ śatapuṣpāṃ cāmbhasā samutkvāthya|  pālāśaṃ vā kṣāraṃ yathābalaṃ phāṇitopetam||165||
translation: In the presence of a shining object, when bubbles emerge, one should, in the morning, sip the (soup) that has arisen, similar to the warmth of the sun's foot; alleviating the heat of exhaustion. Just as a tree sheds its leaves, a man should, as his strength allows, release and let go of his semen, refined and contained.

sloka: yaccānyat kuṣṭhaghnaṃ śvitrāṇāṃ sarvameva tacchastam|  khadirodakasaṃyuktaṃ khadirodakapānagryaṃ vā||166||
translation: One should drink in the morning water mixed with a Khadira decoction, which eliminates all leprosy symptoms in those affected by it. Alternatively, one may drink it as a preferred beverage, having extracted the essence of one hundred Priyangu flowers and added it to water. Just as one regains bodily strength by consuming nutritious food, similarly, one's vitality lost due to the ailment can be restored by consuming this decoction.

sloka: samanaḥśilaṃ viḍaṅgaṃ kāsīsaṃ rocanāṃ kanakapuṣpīm|  śvitrāṇāṃ praśamārthaṃ sasaindhavaṃ lepanaṃ dadyāt||167||
translation: Use as a topical application, for effectively pacifying all types of leprosy, a mixture that consists of powdered Khadira wood, water, and the finest quality of turmeric, which is cool, fragrant, and golden in color.

sloka: kadalīkṣārayutaṃ vā kharāsthi dagdhaṃ gavāṃ rudhirayuktam|  hastimadādhyuṣitaṃ vā mālatyāḥ korakakṣāram||168||  nīlotpalaṃ sakuṣṭhaṃ sasaindhavaṃ hastimūtrapiṣṭaṃ vā|  mūlakabījāvalgujalepaḥ piṣṭo gavāṃ mūtre||169||  kākodumbarikā vā sāvalgujacitrakā gavāṃ mūtre|  piṣṭā manaḥśilā vā saṃyuktā barhipittena||170||  lepaḥ kilāsahantā bījānyāvalgujāni lākṣā ca|  gopittamañjane dve pippalyaḥ kālaloharajaḥ||171||
translation: One should offer an equally cooling paste for the cows' temperament, which can be made from mud from the Kasi region, adorned with saffron, yellow turmeric, and white camphor, for pacification. Alternatively, one may give a salty lepa paste, which has been prepared and processed from a variety of ingredients, including a cooling paste made of cow dung, a charred piece of wood from a khadira tree, a processed piece of barley, or a combination of various grains, powders, and substances, including lākṣā, or a processed mixture of grains, powders, and substances, mixed with gopittamañjane, or two types of pippalya, or a preparation made from kālaloharaja, or a type of iron ore.

sloka: śuddhyā śoṇitamokṣairvirūkṣaṇairbhakṣaṇaiśca saktūnām|  śvitraṃ kasyacideva praṇaśyati kṣīṇapāpasya||172||
translation: The blemish of certain roots such as kutaja, utpala, nila, and mallika disappears when cooked with a mixture of barley powder, mudgaraka, manahshila, kustha, pippali, kasha, loha, rajah, and mustard seeds, blended with ghee, milk, curd, kshira, cow urine and excreta, and consumed along with kadali, phalgu, patala, draksha, dhavani, kapittha fruits, honey, and water, all of which are purified by the process of purification involving gunavat and kshinapapasya.

sloka: dāruṇaṃ cāruṇaṃ [1] śvitraṃ kilāsaṃ nāmabhistribhiḥ|  vijñeyaṃ trividhaṃ tacca [2] tridoṣaṃ prāyaśaśca tat||173||  doṣe raktāśrite raktaṃ tāmraṃ māṃsasamāśrite|  śvetaṃ medaḥśrite śvitraṃ guru taccottarottaram||174||
translation: Through purification in that location, one can recognize three types of blemishes: blood-letting treatments are effective in one instance, while avoidance of certain foods is recommended in another; furthermore, some blemishes quickly disappear when evil tendencies are diminished. The white sheen, as fat disappears, becomes increasingly prominent on the body, and it becomes even heavier as it further subsides.

sloka: yat parasparato'bhinnaṃ bahu yadraktalomavat|  yacca varṣagaṇotpannaṃ tacchvitraṃ naiva sidhyati||175||  araktaloma tanu yat pāṇḍu nāticirotthitam|  madhyāvakāśe cocchūnaṃ śvitraṃ tatsādhyamucyate||176||
translation: That which is distinguished by its unique flaws and has many red iron-like appearances, or that which originates from the passing of multiple seasons, such a distinctly marked entity does not become auspicious. And that body, which is neither discolored by the impurity's flaw nor inflamed, appearing only slightly yellowish in the middle region, is deemed auspicious.

sloka: vacāṃsyatathyāni kṛtaghnabhāvo nindā surāṇāṃ [1] gurudharṣaṇaṃ ca|  pāpakriyā pūrvakṛtaṃ ca karma hetuḥ kilāsasya virodhi cānnam||177||
translation: The cause of one's agitation is the sinful action, preceded by evil deeds, that becomes an obstacle to the pure, bright luster, akin to a cloud, arising in the central part of a fair-complexioned body, neither too slender nor too stout, and coexisting with other qualities.

sloka: tatra ślokāḥ  heturdravyaṃ liṅgaṃ vividhaṃ ye yeṣu cādhikā doṣāḥ|  kuṣṭheṣu doṣaliṅgaṃ samāsato doṣanirdeśaḥ||178||  sādhyamasādhyaṃ kṛcchraṃ kuṣṭhaṃ kuṣṭhāpahāśca ye yogāḥ|  siddhāḥ kilāsaheturliṅgaṃ gurulāghavaṃ tathā śāntiḥ||179||  iti saṅgrahaḥ praṇīto maharṣiṇā kuṣṭhanāśane'dhyāye|  smṛtibuddhivarghanārthaṃ śiṣyāya hutāśaveśāya||180||
translation: that can aid in the treatment and elimination of skin diseases, including those that are difficult to achieve , already present , and those that can help cure skin diseases . Such practices, which are conducive to success in treating skin diseases, are indicated by the sage in this section . This compilation serves as a learning aid for those seeking to understand the treatment of skin diseases .

sloka: athātaḥ śvayathucikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: Now we shall explain the means for curing scrofula (śvayathu), as previously stated by the sage Atreya. This is the initial statement, which covers the reasons, various elements, qualities, and symptoms of the disease, as well as the straightforward and challenging treatments, the elimination of its causes, and the achievement of tranquility. It is presented for teaching purposes in this chapter of the Hutasana Agni Purana. (As per the morphological tags, ātreyaḥ is a masculine nominative singular, implying that it refers to the one who is speaking or doing the action, i.e., sage Atreya.)

sloka: bhiṣagvariṣṭhaṃ surasiddhajuṣṭaṃ munīndramatryātmajamagniveśaḥ|  mahāgadasya śvayathoryathāvat prakoparūpapraśamānapṛcchat||3||
