translation: Then Atreya, the lord, addressed him, inquiring about the detailed treatment of Mahagada, who was previously favored by the divine siddhas and is superior, just as Śvayathu was.

sloka: tasmai jagādāgadavedasindhupravartanādripravaro'trijastān|  vātādibhedāttrividhasya samyaṅnijānijaikāṅgajasarvajasya||4||
translation: To that most excellent among physicians, endorsed by the foremost of gods and siddhas, being the son of Atri and identified with Agni, Mahagadasya, was spoken in inquiry regarding the true form of the threefold division of all-pervasive, self-born, and single-bodied remedy for anger.

sloka: śuddhyāmayābhaktakṛśābalānāṃ kṣārāmlatīkṣṇoṣṇagurūpasevā|  dadhyāmamṛcchākavirodhiduṣṭagaropasṛṣṭānnaniṣevaṇaṃ ca||5||  arśāṃsyaceṣṭā na ca dehaśuddhirmarmopaghāto viṣamā prasūtiḥ|  mithyopacāraḥ pratikarmaṇāṃ ca nijasya hetuḥ śvayathoḥ pradiṣṭaḥ||6||
translation: To the pure, supreme being, whom the Vedas, rivers, and meritorious mountains such as Meru have praised, I now speak of the manifestations of his inherent power. This power, though singular, is divided into all beings and their individual aspects. It neither causes impurity in the bodies nor interferes with their proper functioning; it does not lead to any adverse consequences; it is not a falsehood or mere pretense; and it is not contrary to the performance of one's prescribed duties. I further advise against engaging in dishonest actions, obstructing the functions of one's own body, or partaking in actions that are contrary to one's inherent nature.

sloka: bāhyāstvaco dūṣayitā'bhighātaḥ kāṣṭhāśmaśastrāgniviṣāyasādyaiḥ [1] |  āgantuhetuḥtrividho nijaśca sarvārdhagātrāvayavāśritatvāt||7||
translation: The threefold impurities, arising from external sources or one’s own actions, that can tarnish [the body] from within or externally are caused by the consumption of incompatible substances, misuse of the senses, and improper digestion of food, all of which find their origin in one’s own limbs and organs.

sloka: bāhyāḥ sirāḥ prāpya yadā kaphāsṛkpittāni sandūṣayatīha vāyuḥ|  tairbaddhamārgaḥ sa tadā visarpannutsedhaliṅgaṃ śvayathuṃ karoti||8||  uraḥsthitairūrdhvamadhastu [1] vāyoḥ sthānasthitairmadhyagataistu madhye|  sarvāṅgagaḥ sarvagataiḥ kvacitsthairdoṣaiḥ kvacit syācchvayathustadākhyaḥ||9||
translation: When air, gaining entry to exterior vessels, causes mucus, bile, and phlegm to congeal, then, with the path obstructed, it incites coughing in the body. This condition, known as shvayathu, arises from faults situated variably either internally or externally in the body. In the body, air resides in three locations: in the upper region of the thorax, in the middle of the limbs, and in the lower region of the abdomen; it can be affected by faults present throughout or in specific parts of the body.

sloka: ūṣmā tathā syāddavathuḥ sirāṇāmāyāma ityeva ca pūrvarūpam|
translation: Upon reaching the siras (blood vessels), when the vayu (wind) carries away the kapha-srikh Pittani (phlegm and bile) that had clogged the previously mentioned pathway, then that nut (tube or conduit), referred to as davathuḥ, becomes unblocked, straightened, and assumes its original form, just as it was before.

sloka: sarvastridoṣo'dhikadoṣaliṅgaistacchabdamabhyeti bhiṣagjitaṃ ca||10||
translation: Just as excessive sweating on the head indicates a more severe affliction, so too does the experienced physician recognize a disease in its initial stages through its signs.

sloka: sagauravaṃ syādanavasthitatvaṃ sotsedhamuṣmā'tha sirātanutvam|  salomaharṣā'ṅgavivarṇatā ca sāmānyaliṅgaṃ śvayathoḥ pradiṣṭam||11||
translation: The one possessing dignity, who is steadfast, and has overcome pride, along with being adorned with uniform physical characteristics, devoid of irregularities in bodily hair and complexion, is designated as suitable for self-realization according to Śvayatha.

sloka: calastanutvakparuṣo'ruṇo'sitaḥ prasuptiharṣārtiyuto'nimittataḥ|  praśāmyati pronnamati prapīḍito divābalī ca śvayathuḥ samīraṇāt||12||
translation: Endowed with heaviness/solemnity, the *sun* subsides, having lost its brilliant color and heat; its form reddens, and its rays become pale and commonplace . During the day, this *sun* becomes ordinary/weak, as preordained, just like the cooling wind at dusk.

sloka: mṛduḥ sagandho'sitapītarāgavān bhramajvarasvedatṛṣāmadānvitaḥ|  ya uṣyate sparśarugakṣirāgakṛt [1] sa pittaśotho bhṛśadāhapākavān||13||
translation: The one who is characterized by being easily irritable, thin, with rough skin, copper-hued, and bluish-black; who is often languid, whose cause is thirst caused by bile, who is pacified during daytime, potent, and who moves with the wind – such a person is said to be highly afflicted by bile disorder.

sloka: guruḥ sthiraḥ pāṇḍurarocakānvitaḥ prasekanidrāvamivahnimāndyakṛt|  sa kṛcchrajanmapraśamo nipīḍito na connamedrātribalī kaphātmakaḥ||14||
translation: The steadfast and fair-complexioned teacher, radiating light like an undisturbed lamp flame, remains unfazed. Despite being afflicted by the hardship of repeated births, he is not shaken by the three maladies of egoism, attachment, and ignorance, which are rooted in the bodily constitutions of phlegm, bile, and wind. (Note: The *present-optative class1 active third-person singular 'unnamet' might indicate a prophecy or a general truth that such a teacher remains undisturbed.)

sloka: kṛśasya rogairabalasya yo bhavedupadravairvā vamipūrvakairyutaḥ|  sa hanti marmānugato'tha rājimān parisraveddhīnabalasya sarvagaḥ||15||
translation: The one who is fair and firm, dispelling darkness, and associated with the alleviation of weakness, indeed harms the vital points and subdues an enemy who is powerless and afflicted by hardships, if he becomes one who eliminates ailments, is tranquil, unagitated, and of a phlegmatic nature, and remains unable to stay still during the night.

sloka: ahīnamāṃsasya ya ekadoṣajo navo balasthasya sukhaḥ sa sādhane|  nidānadoṣartuviparyayakramairupācarettaṃ baladoṣakālavit||16||
translation: The one who, as an enemy to life, becomes the sole cause of afflictions for a weak person, already tormented by a single defect/flaw, is indeed that ninefold strong person who, while being ill-behaved, prides himself and roams around as if omnipresent, during the time of that person's weakness.

sloka: athāmajaṃ laṅghanapācanakramairviśodhanairulbaṇadoṣamāditaḥ|  śirogataṃ śīrṣavirecanairadho [4] virecanairūrdhvaharaistathordhvajam||17||  upācaret snehabhavaṃ virūkṣaṇaiḥ prakalpayet snehavidhiṃ ca rūkṣaje|  vibaddhaviṭke'nilaje nirūhaṇaṃ ghṛtaṃ tu pittānilaje satiktakam||18||  payaśca mūrcchāratidāhatarṣite viśodhanīye tu samūtramiṣyate|  kaphotthitaṃ kṣārakaṭūṣṇasaṃyutaiḥ samūtratakrāsavayuktibhirjayet||19||
translation: Once free from impurities, one should first cleanse undigested food in the body with emetics and purgatives. Then, using medicinal oils or ghee, one should apply it starting from the head, first downwards, then upwards; similarly, an absorptive paste/powder of herbs should be prepared for the lower part of the body. For doshas accumulated in the fatty tissue, use clarified butter; for those in muscle tissue, rice porridge; for those in the blood, induce emesis and purgation. For elevated phlegm, use a decoction of pungent, bitter, and hot herbs, combined with chalk.

sloka: grāmyābjānūpaṃ piśitamabalaṃ śuṣkaśākaṃ navānnaṃ  gauḍaṃ piṣṭānnaṃ dadhi tilakṛtaṃ [5] vijjalaṃ [6] madyamamlam|  dhānā vallūraṃ samaśanamatho gurvasātmyaṃ vidāhi  svapnaṃ cārātrau śvayathugadavān varjayenmaithunaṃ ca||20||
translation: One should cultivate affection and establish the rules for extracting oil bound by wind from dry stalks . One should consume curd mixed with rice , clarified butter , and sesame seeds . One must avoid sexual intercourse , sleep during the daytime , feces , urine , fasting , and exhaustion . Additionally, one should abstain from food that leads to unconsciousness or increased thirst due to its astringent , pungent , or hot qualities, combined with the rising of phlegm and bile and the production of digestive juices .

sloka: vyoṣaṃ trivṛttiktakarohiṇī ca sāyorajaskā triphalārasena|  pītaṃ kaphotthaṃ śamayettu śophaṃ gavyena mūtreṇa harītakī ca||21||
translation: Utilizing a three-fold action approach, which includes expertise in administering treatments, combined with decoctions made from Triphala and Haritaki, as well as cow’s urine, one can alleviate disorders caused by an excess of phlegm.

sloka: harītakīnāgaradevadāru sukhāmbuyuktaṃ sapunarnavaṃ vā|  sarvaṃ pibettriṣvapi mūtrayuktaṃ snātaśca jīrṇe payasā'nnamadyāt||22||
translation: One should drink the decoction made from Haritaki, Rohini, and Tiktaka fruits, mixed with ghee, and optionally with salt water, even if one has bathed and is free from urine and excreta. It is recommended to consume this mixture when it becomes slightly warm, as it would help in better digestion; this concoction alleviates all three doshas - vata, pitta, and kapha.

sloka: punarnavānāgaramustakalkān prasthena dhīraḥ payasā'kṣamātrān|  mayūrakaṃ māgadhikāṃ samūlāṃ sanāgarāṃ vā prapibet savāte||23||
translation: Steadfast and composed, one should drink every day, in addition to the early morning urine and bathing water, the decoction made from haritaki and the essence infused in water from a newly grown city or forest tree, as well as from plants like mayura and magadhi, and from all other sources.

sloka: dantītrivṛttryūṣaṇacitrakairvā payaḥ śṛtaṃ doṣaharaṃ pibennā|  dviprasthamātraṃ tu palārdhikaistairardhāvaśiṣṭaṃ pavane sapitte||24||
translation: With feet not soiled by city dust, one should sip carefully the purifying milk, offered in a vessel made from a split coconut shell, only half-filled, that which destroys sins, adorned with the marks of a triple stripe.

sloka: saśuṇṭhipītadrurasaṃ prayojyaṃ śyāmorubūkoṣaṇasādhitaṃ vā|  tvagdāruvarṣābhumahauṣadhairvā guḍūcikānāgaradantibhirvā||25||
translation: With a mouth rinsed using a three-part dental mixture, one should consume milk, equal to two and a half prasthas (a measure), mixed with the leftover of pala (16 digits) and ardhika (eighth part of a digit) units of measures, filtered through a cloth, and processed using herbs like guduci (Tinospora cordifolia), so as to eliminate the dosha (impurity) from the chest.

sloka: saptāhamauṣṭraṃ tvathavā'pi māsaṃ payaḥ pibedbhojanavārivarjī|  gavyaṃ samūtraṃ mahiṣīpayo vā kṣīrāśano mūtramatho gavāṃ vā||26||
translation: In the seventh or eighth month of pregnancy, one should drink milk or partake in a meal devoid of liquids. Alternatively, one may consume ghee made from a black cow's milk, curd, or buttermilk. If nothing else is available, even cow urine or dung may be consumed.

sloka: takraṃ pibedvā gurubhinnavarcāḥ savyoṣasauvarcalamākṣikaṃ ca|  guḍābhayāṃ vā guḍanāgaraṃ vā sadoṣabhinnāmavibaddhavarcāḥ||27||
translation: By drinking curd, either produced from a churning process involving seven ingredients or sourced from a pure, well-nourished cow, or by consuming ghee and milk from such a cow, one’s complexion will become bright and unblemished.

sloka: viḍvātasaṅge payasā rasairvā prāgbhaktamadyādurubūkatailam [7] |  srotovibandhe'gnirucipraṇāśe madyānyariṣṭāṃśca pibet sujātān||28||
translation: With water mixed with the essence of curd, one should drink during the initial part of the day; or, with refined and fragrant alcohol, one should drink at the end of the day, consuming that which is superior.

sloka: gaṇḍīrabhallātakacitrakāṃśca vyoṣaṃ viḍaṅgaṃ bṛhatīdvayaṃ ca|  dviprasthikaṃ gomayapāvakena droṇe pacet kūrcikamastunastu [8] ||29||  tribhāgaśeṣaṃ ca supūtaśītaṃ droṇena tat prākṛtamastunā ca|  sitopalāyāśca śatena yuktaṃ lipte ghaṭe citrakapippalīnām||30||  vaihāyase sthāpitamādaśāhāt prayojayaṃstadvinihanti śophān|  bhagandarārśaḥkrimikuṣṭhamehān vaivarṇyakārśyānilahikkanaṃ ca||31||  iti gaṇḍīrādyariṣṭaḥ

kāśmaryadhātrīmaricābhayākṣadrākṣāphalānāṃ [9] ca sapippalīnām|  śataṃ śataṃ jīrṇaguḍāttulāṃ [10] ca saṅkṣudya kumbhe madhunā pralipte||32||  saptāhamuṣṇe dviguṇaṃ tu śīte sthitaṃ jaladroṇayutaṃ pibennā|  śophān vibandhān kaphavātajāṃśca nihantyariṣṭo'ṣṭaśato'gnikṛcca||33||  ityaṣṭaśato'riṣṭaḥ
translation: Having mixed a hundred measures of refined sugar with the remaining third portion of the curd in an earthen pot, one should consume it in seven portions at a time, doubling this quantity in cold weather. This mixture destroys phlegm, wind, bile, and other causes of diseases such as ringworm, itching, leprosy, tuberculosis, and dysentery.

sloka: punarnave dve ca bale sapāṭhe dantīṃ [11] guḍūcīmatha citrakaṃ ca|  nidigdhikāṃ ca tripalāni paktvā droṇāvaśeṣe salile tatastam||34||  pūtvā rasaṃ dve ca guḍāt purāṇāttule madhuprasthayutaṃ suśītam|  māsaṃ nidadhyādghṛtabhājanasthaṃ palle yavānāṃ paratastu māsāt||35||  cūrṇīkṛtairardhapalāṃśikaistaṃ patratvagelāmaricāmbulohaiḥ [12] |  gandhānvitaṃ kṣaudraghṛtapradigdhe jīrṇe pibed vyādhibalaṃ samīkṣya||36||
translation: Having cleansed, one should drink seven mouthfuls of water, twice, first heated and then cooled; in case of illness, one should consider drinking water, previously boiled and mixed with ghee and powdered herbs. This is the eightfold treatment, as prescribed in scriptures, for countering the eight faults caused by vata, pitta, and kapha imbalances.

sloka: hṛtpāṇḍurogaṃ śvayathuṃ pravṛddhaṃ plīhajvarārocakamehagulmān|  bhagandaraṃ ṣaḍjaṭharāṇi kāsaṃ śvāsaṃ grahaṇyāmayakuṣṭhakaṇḍūḥ||37||  śākhānilaṃ baddhapurīṣatāṃ ca hikkāṃ kilāsaṃ ca halīmakaṃ ca|  kṣipraṃ jayedvarṇabalāyurojastejonvito māṃsarasānnabhojī||38||  iti punarnavādyariṣṭaḥ
translation: Having pondered over the ancient recipe, one should quickly consume this nutritious and refreshing mixture: two parts sugar, one part ghee, and one part honey, combined with a bit of curd and salt; made from grains, pots, and barley, procured from elsewhere.

sloka: phalatrikaṃ dīpyakacitrakau ca sapippalīloharajo viḍaṅgam|  cūrṇīkṛtaṃ kauḍavikaṃ dviraṃśaṃ kṣaudraṃ purāṇasya tulāṃ guḍasya||39||  māsaṃ nidadhyādghṛtabhājanasthaṃ yaveṣu tāneva nihanti rogān|  ye cārśasāṃ pāṇḍuvikāriṇāṃ ca proktā hitāḥ śophiṣu te'pyariṣṭāḥ||40||  iti triphalādyariṣṭaḥ
translation: Each month, one should consume a mixture of three myrobalans along with other recommended ingredients to alleviate conditions such as pallor, bloating, indigestion, enlarged spleen, tumors, abscesses, consumption, lung diseases, heart ailments, skin issues, and joint problems. This will swiftly overcome weakness, loss of appetite, strength, vitality, and youth. Moreover, I do not claim this to be a universal remedy.

sloka: kṛṣṇā sapāṭhā gajapippalī ca nidigdhikā citrakanāgare ca|  sapippalīmūlarajanyajājīmustaṃ ca cūrṇaṃ sukhatoyapītam||41||  hanyāttridoṣaṃ cirajaṃ ca śophaṃ kalkaśca bhūnimbamahauṣadhasya|  ayorajastryūṣaṇayāvaśūkacūrṇaṃ ca pītaṃ triphalārasena||42||
translation: In the city of Citrakanaga, one should crush and mix together pippali and ila, their resins, the powder of viḍaṅgam, kauḍavikam in two parts, the kernel of a mature triphala fruit, an amount of guḍa equivalent to a tula, and a mass of honey equal to it. When consumed regularly with ghṛta from a steady vessel, this mixture eradicates long-standing dosas, as well as arśas and vikāriṇām diseases; moreover, it proves beneficial for śophiṣu; even the three major arisṭa types are eliminated by this method.

sloka: kṣāradvayaṃ syāllavaṇāni catvāryayorajo vyoṣaphalatrike ca|  sapippalīmūlaviḍaṅgasāraṃ mustājamodāmaradārubilvam||43||  kaliṅgakāścitrakamūlapāṭhe yaṣṭyāhvayaṃ sātiviṣaṃ palāṃśam|  sahiṅgukarṣaṃ tvaṇuśuṣkacūrṇaṃ droṇaṃ tathā mūlakaśuṇṭhakānām||44||  syādbhasmanastat salilena sādhyamāloḍya yāvadghanamapradagdham|  styānaṃ tataḥ kolasamāṃ tu mātrāṃ kṛtvā suśuṣkāṃ vidhinopayuñjyāt||45||
translation: Of dark complexion, he should consume in this world a mixture prepared from citraka and pippalī fruits, which has been ground with fluids such as water, milk, and ghee, and is free of impurities and coarse husk. He should then dry and thoroughly mix in cow dung, nimba bark, and mahā auṣadhi powder, as well as kalaṃka bark, which has been reduced to a fine powder in a mortar.

sloka: plīhodaraśvitrahalīmakārśaḥpāṇḍvāmayārocakaśoṣaśophān|  visūcikāgulmagarāśmarīśca saśvāsakāsāḥ praṇudet sakuṣṭhāḥ||46||  iti kṣāraguḍikā
translation: A mixture consisting of ingredients such as lavaṇa, āryaya, aja, vyoṣa, moda, amara dāru, bilva, kaliṅga, citraka, yaṣṭī, pāṭha, mūla, hiṅgu, karṣam, aṇu, śuṣka cūrṇa, droṇa, bhasmanaḥ, and mūlakashuṇṭhaka, when combined with salila, should be cooked until it becomes thin like kola. Once it reaches an appropriate consistency, it should be employed as prescribed. Notably, this concoction includes alkaline substances like plīhā, udara, śvitra, halīmaka, arśa, and pāṇḍu, combined with āmaya and arocaka, followed by śoṣa, śophān, visūcikā, gulma, garāśma, and mṛīś, which should all be finely powdered before use.

sloka: prayojayedārdrakanāgaraṃ vā tulyaṃ guḍenārdhapalābhivṛddhyā|  mātrā paraṃ pañcapalāni māsaṃ jīrṇe payo yūṣarasāśca bhaktam||47|| gulmodarārśaḥśvayathupramehāñ śvāsapratiśyālasakāvipākān|  sakāmalāśoṣamanovikārān kāsaṃ kaphaṃ caiva jayet prayogaḥ||48||
translation: To prepare and apply a remedy for conditions such as bloating, indigestion, constipation, vitiligo, anal fissures, anemia, and poor eyesight, one should utilize a combination of ingredients that includes kşara, gulika, modaka, and various herbs like triphala, haritaki, bhibhitaki, and amalaki. Furthermore, one should control breathing, regulate diet, and monitor bodily functions through practices such as sakusṭhāḥ praṇudet, plihodarashvayathupramehañ, and svasa-pratisyaya-laksakavipakan.

sloka: rasastathaivārdrakanāgarasya peyo'tha jīrṇe payasā'nnamadyāt|  jatvaśmajaṃ [13] ca triphalārasena hanyāttridoṣaṃ śvayathuṃ prasahya||49||  iti śilājatuprayogaḥ
translation: Thus, the preparation of shilajitu: When cow's milk has soured after a month, consume an equal mixture of twenty parts of ardraka and powdered nagaram, increased in quantity with jaggery. This application of shilajitu eliminates the three doshas, alleviates gulma in the stomach and udara, suppresses the causes of vata-rougaha, kapha, and eliminates the unwanted transformations of kapha.

sloka: dvipañcamūlasya pacet kaṣāye kaṃse'bhayānāṃ ca śataṃ guḍasya|  lehe susiddhe'tha vinīya cūrṇaṃ vyoṣaṃ trisaugandhyamuṣāsthite ca||50||  prasthārdhamātraṃ madhunaḥ suśīte kiñcicca cūrṇādapi yāvaśūkāt|  ekābhayāṃ prāśya tataśca lehācchuktiṃ nihanti śvayathuṃ pravṛddham||51||  śvāsajvarārocakamehagulmaplīhatridoṣodarapāṇḍurogān|  kārśyāmavātāvasṛgamlapittavaivarṇyamūtrānilaśukradoṣān||52||  iti kaṃsaharītakī
translation: Thus, in the current context, the rock candy should be prepared by cooking it in a mixture of five constituents, including the bark of a tree, in a hundredfold quantity, in a vessel set over a gentle fire. After being properly cooked, it should be strained through a cloth, cooled, and then formed into small pieces. Consuming a portion of this candy with honey, taken in prescribed quantities, eliminates various disorders such as dyspnea, fever, cough, worm infestation, and skin diseases.

sloka: paṭolamūlāmaradārudantītrāyantipippalyabhayāviśālāḥ|  yaṣṭyāhvayaṃ tiktakarohiṇī ca sacandanā syānniculāni dārvī||53||  karṣonmitaistaiḥ kvathitaḥ kaṣāyo ghṛtena peyaḥ kuḍavena yuktaḥ|  vīsarpadāhajvarasannipātatṛṣṇāviṣāṇi śvayathuṃ ca hanti||54||
translation: With five pestle-like roots, [the plant] boiling for a hundred instances in a pot made of castor oil and ghee, mixed with well-ground pieces of sacandana, and when the kaṣāya has been extracted, it becomes a drink fit for consumption, alleviating diseases such as vīsarpadā, hajvara, and excessive thirst.

sloka: sacitrakaṃ [14] dhānyayavānyajājīsauvarcalaṃ tryūṣaṇavetasāmlam|  bilvāt phalaṃ dāḍimayāvaśūkau sapippalīmūlamathāpi cavyam||55||  piṣṭvā'kṣamātrāṇi jalāḍhakena paktvā ghṛtaprasthamatha prayuñjyāt|  arśāṃsi gulmaṃ śvayathuṃ  kṛcchraṃ nihanti vahniṃ ca karoti dīptam||56||
translation: Having ground together patola root, amra, arjuna, triphala, pippali, bhayavisha, syamni, candana, dravanti, kasha, unmita, and kvathita kaṣaya, and mixed it with ghee, one can prepare an effective medicine against arsha, gulma, śvayathu, kṛcchrā, as well as to alleviate thirst, fever, snake bite, and other such ailments; moreover, it can be used to kindle fire.

sloka: pibedghṛtaṃ vā'ṣṭaguṇāmbusiddhaṃ sacitrakakṣāramudāravīryam|  kalyāṇakaṃ vā'pi sapañcagavyaṃ tiktaṃ mahadvā'pyatha tiktakaṃ vā||57||
translation: Should one opt to churn the grains and measure out a prastha of water, adding to the clarified butter (ghrita) eight qualities, or prepare a drink from five cow products that is either sweet or slightly bitter, it is necessary to kindle the fire for cooking in either case.

sloka: kṣīraṃ ghaṭe citrakakalkalipte dadhyāgataṃ sādhu vimathya tena|  tajjaṃ ghṛtaṃ citrakamūlagarbhaṃ takreṇa siddhaṃ śvayathughnamagryam||58||  arśo'tisārānilagulmamehāṃścaitannihantyagnibalapradaṃ [15] ca|  takreṇa cādyāt saghṛtena tena bhojyāni siddhāmathavā yavāgūm||59||  iti citrakaghṛtam
translation: Drink the siddha clarified butter, which has eight qualities, resulting from being mixed with water and the carefully curdled ingredient. It is sweet , sturdy , vigorous , and auspicious . Even if it is pungent and strong , it becomes suitable for consumption after being mixed with water. It eliminates ailments caused by vata, pitta, and kapha .

sloka: jīvantyajājīśaṭipuṣkarāhvaiḥ sakāravīcitrakabilvamadhyaiḥ|  sayāvaśūkairbadarapramāṇairvṛkṣāmlayuktā ghṛtatailabhṛṣṭā||60||  arśo'tisārānilagulmaśophahṛdrogamandāgnihitā yavāgūḥ|  yā pañcakolairvidhinaiva [16] tena siddhā bhavet sā ca samā tayaiva||61||
translation: Mixing ghee with water in a vessel, along with a paste made of citraka and bilva, applied to freshly churned curd, is considered appropriate. When blended with five specified ingredients in their respective measures, it becomes perfected and serves as an effective fat-reducer.

sloka: kulatthayūṣaśca sapippalīko maudgaśca satryūṣaṇayāvaśūkaḥ|  rasastathā viṣkirajāṅgalānāṃ sakūrmagodhāśikhiśallakānām||62||  suvarcalā gṛñjanakaṃ paṭolaṃ savāyasīmūlakavetranimbam|  śākārthināṃ śākamiti praśastaṃ bhojye purāṇaśca yavaḥ saśāliḥ||63||
translation: Consisting of jujube, peepal, mango, and madhuka trees, along with other trees bearing ripe, unripe, or falling fruits, and those yielding bilva and badara fruits, mixed with ghee and oil, serves as the prescribed offering for those living beings mentioned earlier (62). Barley and wheat, too, are recommended as part of this meal (63).

sloka: ābhyantaraṃ bheṣajamuktametadbarhirhitaṃ yacchṛṇu tadyathāvat|  snehān pradehān pariṣecanāni svedāṃśca vātaprabalasya kuryāt||64||
translation: Listen to the description of this internal medicine, derived from the Kulattha plant: it is to be used through anointing with oil and heat treatment, as primary applications, especially for alleviating symptoms of an excess of vata (wind).

sloka: śaileyakuṣṭhāgurudārukauntītvakpadmakailāmbupalāśamustaiḥ|  priyaṅguthauṇeyakahemamāṃsītālīśapatraplavapatradhānyaiḥ||65||  śrīveṣṭakadhyāmakapippalībhiḥ spṛkkānakhaiścaiva yathopalābham|  vātānvite'bhyaṅgamuśanti tailaṃ siddhaṃ supiṣṭairapi ca pradeham||66||
translation: Listen to this recipe for an effective medical treatment: Inside , apply a cure that is pure and liberated from impurities. This is beneficial when applied with barley . Increase sweat if the wind is strong. Additionally, use pure oil and medicinal herbs , such as śrīveṣṭaka, kapikacchu, and pippali, following this procedure for optimal results. Also, apply a paste made from priyaṅgu and uṇeyaka on the body.

sloka: jalaiśca vāsārkakarañjaśigrukāśmaryapatrārjakajaiśca  siddhaiḥ|  svinno mṛdūṣṇai  ravitaptatoyaiḥ snātaśca gandhairanulepanīyaḥ||67||
translation:
Washed in fragrant waters and anointed with divine unguents,
massaged with various ointments and smeared with paste made from
Bilva, Priyangu, Daru, Kushtha, Utpala, Musta, Padma, and Palasha,
all carefully selected based on merit, and bathed in waters heated by the sun.

sloka: savetasāḥ kṣīravatāṃ drumāṇāṃ tvacaḥ samañjiṣṭhalatāmṛṇālāḥ|  sacandanāḥ padmakavālakau ca paitte pradehastu satailapākaḥ||68||  āktasya tenāmbu raviprataptaṃ sacandanaṃ sābhayapadmakaṃ ca|  snāne hitaṃ kṣīravatāṃ kaṣāyaḥ kṣīrodakaṃ candanalepanaṃ ca||69||
translation: Washed with water and anointed with fragrances, when one becomes softened by the gentle, warm rays of the sun, they become capable of producing shoots similar to those of graceful kasha, arjaka, shigru, and other plants. The bathing in such water and application of sandalwood paste is beneficial for the growth of excellent quality rice and lotus, and for removing impurities from it. Specifically, rice that has been treated with this water becomes capable of growth (āktasya), and ten such rice grains, when cooked, can produce a stalk bearing a ear/cob (pradehaḥ) that is as valuable as a hundred normal stalks (satailapākaḥ).

sloka: kaphe tu kṛṣṇāsikatāpurāṇapiṇyākaśigrutvagumāpralepaḥ|  kulatthaśuṇṭhījalamūtrasekaścaṇḍāgurubhyāmanulepanaṃ ca||70||
translation: In the bark of the tree resembling a Kshira vine, shredded and soaked in water heated by the sun, as well as in the saffron-like Kashaayah, when applied to the skin that resembles the sheath of a drum and has the consistency of soft lotus petals, mixed with Chandanam, is beneficial for bathing.

sloka: bibhītakānāṃ phalamadhyalepaḥ sarveṣu dāhārtiharaḥ pradiṣṭaḥ|  yaṣṭyāhvamustaiḥ sakapitthapatraiḥ sacandanaistatpiḍakāsu lepaḥ||71||
translation: The paste, known as bibhītaka-madhya-lepa, has been recommended for all types of burns. It is made by mixing the powder of kulattha and dried shunthi with water and urine, as well as iron filings. This paste is then applied to affected areas using hands that have been anointed with ghee and dusted with candana powder.

sloka: rāsnāvṛṣārkatriphalāviḍaṅgaṃ śigrutvaco mūṣikaparṇikā ca|   nimbārjakau vyāghranakhaḥ sadūrvā suvarcalā tiktakarohiṇī ca||72||  sakākamācī bṛhatī sakuṣṭhā punarnavā citrakanāgare ca|  unmardanaṃ śophiṣu mūtrapiṣṭaṃ śastastathā mūlakatoyasekaḥ||73||
translation: For those tormented by insects, the following remedies are prescribed: applying fruit as a balm to the site of affliction, which alleviates all burning pain; using the tender shoot of the mustard tree, sacred fig leaves, and black myrobalan bark; consuming juice extracted from costus and punarnava roots; and drinking a decoction made from citrakanaga flowers.

sloka: śophāstu gātrāvayavāśritā ye te sthānadūṣyākṛtināmabhedāt|  anekasaṅkhyāḥ  katicicca teṣāṃ nidarśanārthaṃ gadato nibodha||74||
translation: Of those who stain various bodily parts, such as the head, arms, and legs, as well as those who resemble tree bark, a tiger, or its claws, and those who share habits with an elephant, dog, cat, or deer, learn for the sake of identification the characteristics of the excretions, spitting, and washing of those who are causes of corruption, whether they be numerous or few, as well as their distinct physical forms.

sloka: doṣāstrayaḥ svaiḥ kupitā nidānaiḥ kurvanti śophaṃ śirasaḥ sughoram| antargale ghurghurikānvitaṃ ca śālūkamucchvāsanirodhakāri||75||
translation: Comprehend the three causes, when driven by their own anger, they bring about a severe swelling on the body parts and, taking the form of a harsh, rattling sound, obstruct breathing within the throat.

sloka: galasya sandhau cibuke gale ca sadāharāgaḥ śvasanāsu  cograḥ|  śopho bhṛśārtistu biḍālikā  syāddhanyādgale cedvalayīkṛtā sā||76||
translation: A fault, specifically a harsh sound in the throat, arises when one suppresses a cough that originates from one's own sources of irritation. Alternatively, a whistling sound at the neck may occur if the airflow is constricted in some other manner.

sloka: syāttāluvidradhyapi dāharāgapākānvitastāluni sā tridoṣāt|  jihvopariṣṭādupajihvikā syāt kaphādadhastādadhijihvikā ca||77||
translation: At the junction of the throat, there is always the presence of āgāh, and in the exhaled breath, there is the intense distress of fierce śophaḥ. If a swelling in the form of a valayī occurs, it is called dhanyāt kṛtā; below that location, kapha is present.

sloka: yo dantamāṃseṣu tu raktapittāt pāko bhavet sopakuśaḥ pradiṣṭaḥ|  syāddantavidradhyapi dantamāṃse śophaḥ kaphācchoṇitasañcayotthaḥ||78||
translation: Even a skilled dentist, if he doesn't take proper precautions, can become infected by a patient with inflamed gums; an accumulation of kapha below the tongue and above the soft palate can also cause oral disorders.

sloka: galasya pārśve galagaṇḍa ekaḥ syādgaṇḍamālā bahubhistu gaṇḍaiḥ|  sādhyāḥ smṛtāḥ pīnasapārśvaśūlakāsajvaracchardiyutāstvasādhyāḥ||79||
translation: The one who is established in the teeth (phlegm) and bones, and is known as "opakusuma" in the flesh and marrow, and who arises from blood - such a Sadyaha is remembered to be associated with the neck and cheek, as indicated by the causal future passive participle "sādhyāḥ" referring to Sadyaha, and the instrumental plural "gaṇḍaiḥ" referring to the cheek and neck.

sloka: teṣāṃ sirākāyaśirovirekā dhūmaḥ purāṇasya ghṛtasya pānam|  syāllaṅghanaṃ vaktrabhaveṣu cāpi pragharṣaṇaṃ syāt kavalagrahaśca||80||
translation: At the necks of those, the smoke is that of ancient ghee having been consumed; at the cheeks, sweating, chills, and fever become manifest in the form of pimples, etc., when these symptoms are fully developed.

sloka: aṅgaikadeśeṣvanilādibhiḥ syāt svarūpadhārī sphuraṇaḥ sirābhiḥ|  granthirmahānmāṃsabhavastvanartirmedobhavaḥ snigdhatamaścalaśca||81||
translation: When, at times, the true form becomes manifest in the angular body parts due to smoke and other things like wind, as well as hair on the body, then there arises an increase in great flesh, a supreme unctuousness that is steady, and a pleasant sensation in the mouth and lips that become smooth.

sloka: saṃśodhite sveditamaśmakāṣṭhaiḥ sāṅguṣṭhadaṇḍairvilayedapakvam|  vipāṭya coddhṛtya bhiṣak sakośaṃ śastreṇa dagdhvā vraṇavaccikitset||82||
translation: Once, a physician, having cleaned it with gently flowing air and oil made from pure substances, uses his thumb as a probe to fully examine the abscess in the body, which has been previously cleaned. Then, with a surgical instrument, he lances the swollen boil to treat it.

sloka: adagdha īṣat pariśeṣitaśca prayāti bhūyo'pi śanairvivṛddhim|  tasmādaśeṣaḥ kuśalaiḥ samantācchedyo bhavedvīkṣya śarīradeśān||83||  śeṣe kṛte pākavaśena śīryāttataḥ kṣatotthaḥ prasaredvisarpaḥ|  upadravaṃ taṃ pravicārya tajjñastairbheṣajaiḥ  pūrvatarairyathoktaiḥ||84||  nivārayedādita  eva yatnādvidhānavit svasvavidhiṃ vidhāya|  tataḥ krameṇāsya yathāvidhānaṃ vraṇaṃ vraṇajñastvarayā cikitset||85||
translation: Having purified oneself slightly and having sweated out some of the impurities, one should carefully, in a matured state, break open the abscess using a pestle of stone or wood. Then, the healer, after opening his medical kit, should burn and clean out the abscess. After assessing the situation, experienced healers should apply previously described or other appropriate medicines to the wound. With great care, one must then proceed to treat the wound according to proper procedure, as guided by a wound specialist. (83-85)

sloka: vivarjayet kukṣyudarāśritaṃ ca tathā gale marmaṇi saṃśritaṃ ca|  sthūlaḥ kharaścāpi bhavedvivarjyo yaścāpi bālasthavirābalānām||86||
translation: One should carefully cause (others) to avoid a person who has taken shelter in the abdomen and also one who has taken shelter near vital organs. Both the coarse and the sharp should be deemed unsuitable, as well as any harmful elements that remain after surgical procedures. After examining the cause of the injury, one should apply previously described remedies, in their proper order, to treat the injury promptly.

sloka: granthyarbudānāṃ ca yato'viśeṣaḥ pradeśahetvākṛtidoṣadūṣyaiḥ|  tataścikitsedbhiṣagarbudāni vidhānavidgranthicikitsitena||87||
translation: From the digestive system, one should discard that which arises from the improper mixture of coarse and sharp substances; this should be done by a scholar specialized in treating the "diseases" of texts, i.e., a pundit or scholar.

sloka: tāmrā saśūlā  piḍakā bhavedyā sā cālajī nāma parisrutāgrā|  śopho'kṣataścarmanakhāntare  syānmāṃsāsradūṣī bhṛśaśīghrapākaḥ||88||
translation: The physician endowed with skill should examine the cause of the affliction in the remaining portions of the tumorous elephant, as it features rapid, impure growth, and is known as "Cala-jī."

sloka: jvarānvitā vaṅkṣaṇakakṣajā yā vartirnirartiḥ kaṭhināyatā ca|  vidārikā sā kaphamārutābhyāṃ teṣāṃ yathādoṣamupakramaḥ syāt||89||  visrāvaṇaṃ piṇḍikayopanāhaḥ pakveṣu caiva vraṇavaccikitsā|
translation: The discharge , named "Parasruta" , located in the blister , becomes rancid due to an inflammation . This symptom arises from an imbalance of phlegm and wind in them. Similarly, oozing , swelling , maturation , and suppuration in wounds indicate an imbalance of these humors.

sloka: visphoṭakāḥ sarvaśarīragāstu sphoṭāḥ [27] sarāgajvaratarṣayuktāḥ||90||
translation: The bursting of all bodily inflammations, marked by explosive sounds , is associated with fever, cough, and other ailments , when the inherent firmness of the body is disturbed by the aggravated doshas of kapha and vayu at the onset of the disease . Treatment should be initiated with the elimination of the accumulation in the form of pus that forms in the early stages of such a condition.

sloka: yajñopavītapratimāḥ prabhūtāḥ pittānilābhyāṃ janitāstu kakṣāḥ [28] | yāścāparāḥ syuḥ piḍakāḥ prakīrṇāḥ sthūlāṇumadhyā api pittajāstāḥ||91||
translation: The ribcages, wide and prominent, that originate from both parents are comparable to yajñopavītas (sacred threads). Even those that are coarse, thin, or of medium size are born from the father.

sloka: kṣudrapramāṇāḥ piḍakāḥ śarīre sarvāṅgagāḥ sajvaradāhatṛṣṇāḥ|  kaṇḍūyutāḥ sārucisaprasekā romāntikāḥ pittakaphāt pradiṣṭāḥ||92||
translation: Small, sized blisters, spread across the whole body, feverish, afflicted by thirst, characterized by itching and exuding pus, and specifically caused by an excess of bile and phlegm in the body.

sloka: yāḥ sarvagātreṣu masūramātrā masūrikāḥ pittakaphāt pradiṣṭāḥ|  vīsarpaśāntyai vihitā kriyā yā tāṃ teṣu  kuṣṭhe ca hitāṃ vidadhyāt||93||
translation: Restrain through appropriate action those minor bodily activities, such as sneezing and twitching, which are characterized by the manifestation of humor imbalances caused by the combinations of physical factors like bile and phlegm, and accompanied by sensations such as itching and tingling, as well as other symptoms of imbalance like heat in the entire body. These should be restrained in all places when they arise, as they are characterized by the minor physical factors in every bodily location.

sloka: bradhno'nilādyairvṛṣaṇe  svaliṅgairantraṃ nireti praviśenmuhuśca|  mūtreṇa pūrṇaṃ mṛdu medasā cet snigdhaṃ ca vidyāt kaṭhinaṃ ca śotham||94||  virecanābhyaṅganirūhalepāḥ pakveṣu caiva vraṇavaccikitsā|  syānmūtrasekaḥ  kaphajaṃ vipāṭya viśodhya sīvyedvraṇavacca pakvam||95||
translation: The therapeutic procedures, as prescribed, that involve the use of masura beans in the measurement of massaging various body parts should be applied to alleviate skin disorders, dryness, and edema caused by Kapha and Pitta doshas. Similarly, a massage with masura paste can help heal wounds and ulcers when followed by an application of the same paste.

sloka: krimyasthisūkṣmakṣaṇanavyavāyapravāhaṇānyutkaṭakāśvapṛṣṭhaiḥ  |  gudasya pārśve piḍakā bhṛśārtiḥ pakvaprabhinnā tu bhagandaraḥ syāt||96||  virecanaṃ caiṣaṇapāṭanaṃ ca viśuddhamārgasya ca tailadāhaḥ|  syāt kṣārasūtreṇa supācitena  chinnasya cāsya vraṇavaccikitsā||97||
translation: With gusts of air from nostrils and other natural openings, one can eliminate blockages in the passage of feces. A soft, unctuous substance like clarified butter can be used for enema administration to alleviate constipation. For a matured ulcer, treatment with sharp, strong purgatives, and external applications like fomentation and ointment can be performed. Purgatives, emetics, and medicated oils are used for thorough bodily cleansing. Through urine expulsion and emesis, accumulated phlegm and waste products can be eliminated, resulting in body purification.

sloka: jaṅghāsu piṇḍīprapadopariṣṭāt [35] syācchlīpadaṃ māṃsakaphāsradoṣāt|  sirākaphaghnaśca vidhiḥ samagrastatreṣyate sarṣapalepanaṃ ca||98||
translation: A tiny worm located in the bone , subtle and transient , a recent one found in the marrow's flow , as well as a tiny parasite on the back of the hip – this is the prescribed method for completely eradicating grain sprouts . Additionally, a wound on the mouth should be treated with pure oil , alkali , and a clean, sharp bandage , while medical treatment should be administered for any fissure in the air .

sloka: mandāstu pittaprabalāḥ praduṣṭā doṣāḥ sutīvraṃ tanuraktapākam|  kurvanti śothaṃ jvaratarṣayuktaṃ visarpaṇaṃ jālakagardabhākhyam||99||    vilaṅghanaṃ raktavimokṣaṇaṃ ca virūkṣaṇaṃ kāyaviśodhanaṃ ca|  dhātrīprayogāñ śiśirān pradehān kuryāt sadā jālakagardabhasya||100||
translation: When the digestive fire is weak, impurities are produced: they manifest slowly, derive from enhanced paternal strength, and are tainted by flaws, causing a harsh effect on the son's body and cooking up symptoms similar to an edematous donkey, such as wasting disease and emaciation. Additionally, there are symptoms like rashes, discoloration, foul odor, and bloodletting. Regularly, one should administer therapies, like Dhatri, to counteract these ailments of the edematous donkey condition.

sloka: evaṃvidhāṃścāpyaparān parīkṣya śothaprakārānanilādiliṅgaiḥ|  śāntiṃ nayeddoṣaharairyathāsvamālepanacchedanabhedadāhaiḥ||101||
translation: After examining those of a different kind, who, by their impure qualities such as causing swelling and named like a donkey, incite severe thirst, fever, and exhaustion, one should, through purgation, bloodletting, and emetics, cleanse such [qualities]. Regularly apply cooling substances, like dhātrī, which counteract the harmful effects of a donkey-like nature, to the body.

sloka: prāyo'bhighātādanilaḥ saraktaḥ śothaṃ sarāgaṃ prakaroti tatra|  vīsarpanunmārutaraktanucca kāryaṃ viṣaghnaṃ viṣaje ca karma||102||
translation: In most cases, one should carry out there the action of eliminating impurities such as foul smell and excess mucus, which have adhered to and are loved by the wind, by examining other ways that neutralize the causes of disease. Indeed, just as a physician removes foreign matter, applies ointments, lances boils, and administers medicinal smoke, so should one perform such a remedial course of action.

sloka: tatra ślokaḥ  trividhasya doṣabhedāt sarvārdhāvayavagātrabhedācca|  śvayathordvividhasya  tathā liṅgāni cikitsitaṃ coktam||103||
translation: "Here, it is advised that treatment, desired to be done and prescribed, should be carried out differently according to the distinction of three types of disorders (wind-borne, phlegm-bound, and bile-tainted) and various forms of the patients' bodies."

sloka: ityagniveśakṛte tantre'prāpte dṛḍhabalasampūrite cikitsāsthāne  śvayathucikitsitaṃ nāma dvādaśo'dhyāyaḥ||12||
translation: In the twelfth chapter, named "Specific Treatment," found in the Agnivesa-scripture, which is firm, strong, and causatively complete in its presentation, the text discusses three types of therapeutic approaches, based on the divisions of bodily parts and their respective doshas.

sloka: athāto jvaracikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha  bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: Hence, having been well-established in the ritual teaching from the Agnivesha Tantra, we will now explain the fever remedy. The Lord Ātreya declared, "Thus it was."

sloka: vijvaraṃ jvarasandehaṃ paryapṛcchat punarvasum|  vivikte śāntamāsīnamagniveśaḥ kṛtāñjaliḥ||3||
translation: Now, Atreya is once again asked about the fever treatment: "Describe, O healer, this jvara (a type of fever) along with its associated uncertainty." The inquirer, poised in tranquility, has sought this knowledge from the expert, who is himself established in isolation, having completed his own learning.

sloka: dehendriyamanastāpī sarvarogāgrajo balī|  jvaraḥ pradhāno rogāṇāmukto bhagavatā purā||4||  tasya prāṇisapatnasya dhruvasya pralayodaye|  prakṛtiṃ ca pravṛttiṃ ca prabhāvaṃ kāraṇāni ca||5||  pūrvarūpamadhiṣṭhānaṃ balakālātmalakṣaṇam|  vyāsato vidhibhedācca  pṛthagbhinnasya cākṛtim||6||  liṅgamāmasya jīrṇasya sauṣadhaṃ ca kriyākramam|  vimuñcataḥ praśāntasya cihnaṃ yacca pṛthak pṛthak||7||  jvarāvasṛṣṭo rakṣyaśca yāvatkālaṃ yato yataḥ|  praśāntaḥ kāraṇairyaiśca punarāvartate jvaraḥ||8||  yāścāpi punarāvṛttaṃ kriyāḥ praśamayanti tam|  jagaddhitārthaṃ tat sarvaṃ bhagavan! vaktumarhasi||9||  tadagniveśasya vaco niśamya gururabravīt|  jvarādhikāre yadvācyaṃ tat saumya! nikhilaṃ śṛṇu||10||
translation: In the presence of a patient overwhelmed by fever and delirium, the teacher, after careful deliberation and achieving a tranquil state of mind, should recite the following words spoken by the fire god regarding the treatment of severe fevers.

sloka: jvaro vikāro rogaśca vyādhirātaṅka eva ca|  eko'rtho  nāmaparyāyairvividhairabhidhīyate||11||
translation: "In this world, fever, illness, affliction, and ailment are designated as roga, vikara, jvara, and aтанка, respectively. However, the ultimate reality, the one true designation of the aggregate of the body, senses, and mind, is not referred to by these various names. Just as a prudent person protects a feverish patient until they recover, one must similarly safeguard the released true self with appropriate means, for as long as it hasn't yet achieved complete stillness. Such protection of the true self is beneficial for all, O Bhagavan, it is your duty to describe this."

sloka: tasya prakṛtiruddiṣṭā doṣāḥ śārīramānasāḥ|  dehinaṃ na hi nirdoṣaṃ jvaraḥ samupasevate||12||
translation: The inherent nature and bodily/mental imperfections of someone have been distinguished; indeed, a fever-like disease does not attach itself to a physically/mentally flawless person.

sloka: kṣayastamo jvaraḥ pāpmā mṛtyuścoktā  yamātmakāḥ|  pañcatvapratyayānnṝṇāṃ kliśyatāṃ svena karmaṇā||13||  ityasya prakṛtiḥ proktā ...|14|
translation: The nature of that fever, referred to by Yama and characterized by decay (kṣayaḥ), darkness (tamaḥ), affliction (jvaraḥ), and evil (pāpmā), as well as death (mṛtyuḥ), torments those who adhere to the belief in the five elements as their true self. This occurs through their own actions; indeed, those who are free from this "fever" are not troubled by the impurities of body or mind. (13-14)

sloka: ... pravṛttistu parigrahāt|  nidāne pūrvamuddiṣṭā rudrakopācca dāruṇāt||14||
translation: The five symptoms -- wasting disease, darkness, fever, wickedness, and death -- that afflict embodied beings arise from their own actions, as previously stated; this is the implied meaning of "pravrttistu parigrahāt" (arising from their own actions).

sloka: dvitīye hi yuge śarvamakrodhavratamāsthitam|  divyaṃ sahasraṃ varṣāṇāmasurā abhidudruvuḥ||15||  tapovighnāśanāḥ kartuṃ  tapovighnaṃ mahātmanaḥ|  paśyan samarthaścopekṣāṃ cakre dakṣaḥ prajāpatiḥ||16||
translation: In the second age, Sarva, steadfast in the vow of non-anger, was struck by a thousand-year drought, divinely ordained and caused by the celestials and demons. Seeing the great-souled one's capability to overcome this ascetic hindrance, Daksha, the lord of creatures, having witnessed it, acted with purpose to remove the ascetic obstacle.

sloka: punarmāheśvaraṃ bhāgaṃ dhruvaṃ dakṣaḥ prajāpatiḥ|  yajñe na kalpayāmāsa procyamānaḥ surairapi||17||  ṛcaḥ paśupateryāśca śaivya āhatayaśca yāḥ|  yajñasiddhipradāstābhirhīnaṃ caiva sa iṣṭavān||18||
translation:
In the second age, Daksha, the Prajapati, resolute in his firm, unwavering vow for a thousand years, participated in the ritual (yajna) as it was being conducted by the gods. Seeing the demons creating obstacles for the great soul's asceticism, he decided to eliminate those hindrances in the yajna. (17)
The hymns (rcah) dedicated to Pasupati and those intended for the Shaivya rituals, which grant success in the ritual, were neglected by him, leading to his incompleteness.

sloka: athottīrṇavrato devo buddhvā dakṣavyatikramam|  rudro raudraṃ puraskṛtya bhāvamātmavidātmanaḥ||19||
translation: After having turned away from the sacred fire, the god Rudra, becoming aware of Prajapati Daksha's unrighteous intent, performs the rudra state. Established in his own self-knowledge, he partakes in the sacrifices prescribed by the Vedas as Pushupate, rendered powerless by those sacrificial acts meant for his propitiation. Here, "devaḥ" referring to Rudra, has distanced himself from "uttīrṇa vrataḥ", the sacred fire, indicating his withdrawal from it. The awareness of "dakṣavyatikramam", Prajapati Daksha's transgression, prompts Rudra's "raudraṃ bhāvam" or fierce state. The phrase "ātmavidātmanaḥ" suggests Rudra's deep understanding of his own self, further emphasized by his participation in the Vedic rituals as "Pushupate," a form of Shiva.

sloka: sṛṣṭvā  lalāṭe cakṣurvai dagdhvā tānasurān prabhuḥ|  bālaṃ krodhāgnisantaptamasṛjat satranāśanam||20||  tato yajñaḥ sa vidhvasto vyathitāśca divaukasaḥ|  dāhavyathāparītāśca bhrāntā bhūtagaṇā diśaḥ||21||
translation:
Then, the deity Rudra, having abandoned his vow, became aware and skillfully overstepped his limits. He created and emitted a baleful eye from his forehead, destroying Tānasur, my very self.

The celestial beings and elements of nature were thrown into disarray due to the imminent danger and destruction caused by this act.

sloka: atheśvaraṃ devagaṇaḥ saha saptarṣibhirvibhum|  tamṛgbhirastuvan yāvacchaive bhāve śivaḥ sthitaḥ||22||
translation: Once the lord of gods was created by Shiva, together with the seven sages, they continued to extol him using hymns, as he took on the form of a bull. Even after reducing the suras to ashes with his anger, Shiva remained in that state. At this point, the celestial beings were distressed and agitated, as all created beings were confused by the darkness enveloping the directions, when the sacrificial fire for its destruction was produced.

sloka: śivaṃ śivāya bhūtānāṃ sthitaṃ jñātvā kṛtāñjaliḥ|  bhiyā bhasmapraharaṇastriśirā navalocanaḥ||23||  jvālāmālākulo raudro hrasvajaṅghodaraḥ kramāt|  krodhāgniruktavān devamahaṃ kiṃ karavāṇi te||24||
translation: Having learned that I, the deity revered as Shiva, dwell in all beings, one should bow down with reverence. As one realizes my presence in the form of auspiciousness, what can I do for you, O god, who is surrounded by a garland of flames, is fierce, has a short build, and is renowned for anger?

sloka: tamuvāceśvaraḥ krodhaṃ jvaro loke bhaviṣyasi|  janmādau nidhane ca tvamapacārāntareṣu ca||25||
translation: The lord of all beings, Shiva, recognized as serene, you still harbor anger. In this life, at your birth and death, and in the interim, you will be like a fever in the world. You pay respect with folded hands, but out of fear, you apply ashes to three of your heads, nine of your eyes burn with flames, and your agitated limbs resemble fire. Speaking to the god, you act like another Agni.

sloka: santāpaḥ sārucistṛṣṇā sāṅgamardo hṛdi vyathā|  jvaraprabhāvo janmādau nidhane ca mahattamaḥ||26||  prakṛtiśca  pravṛttiśca prabhāvaśca pradarśitaḥ|27|
translation: The Supreme Lord said: "Supreme beings exhibit their inherent power and disposition from birth to death, being afflicted by anger, the craving for sensual pleasures, and bodily distress in this world." (26-27)

sloka: nidāne kāraṇānyaṣṭau pūrvoktāni  vibhāgaśaḥ||27||
translation: In the context, the ten causes of suffering mentioned earlier are, namely: thirst, enjoyment, bodily ailments, mental distress, fever, sound, origin, great darkness, nature, and manifestation; these are described at the outset and end.

sloka: ālasyaṃ nayane sāsre jṛmbhaṇaṃ gauravaṃ kramaḥ|  jvalanātapavāyvambubhaktidveṣāvaniścitau||28||  avipākāsyavairasye hāniśca balavarṇayoḥ|  śīlavaikṛtamalpaṃ ca jvaralakṣaṇamagrajam||29||
translation: The symptoms of idleness in the eyes are described as eightfold: blinking, faintheartedness, deliberation, flaring up from heat, agitation from wind, aversion, dryness in the mouth, and depletion of strength.

sloka: kevalaṃ samanaskaṃ ca jvarādhiṣṭhānamucyate|  śarīraṃ balakālastu nidāne sampradarśitaḥ||30||
translation: Laziness and eye dullness, as well as yawning, are identified as the initial symptoms of this fever, whose physical seat is manifested in children as diminished appetite and thirst; it is called 'the sole ruler of fever.'

sloka: jvarapratyātmikaṃ liṅgaṃ santāpo dehamānasaḥ|  jvareṇāviśatā bhūtaṃ na hi kiñcinna tapyate||31||
translation: Fever's specific symptom, identified as the locus of the disease, dwells in the body and mind; indeed, nothing at all gets heated by it. (31)

sloka: dvividho vidhibhedena jvaraḥ śārīramānasaḥ|  punaśca dvividho dṛṣṭaḥ saumyaścāgneya eva vā||32||
translation: The fever, manifesting in both the body and mind, is of two kinds, as per the division in methods. It can also be observed to be either gently soothing or intensely fiery in nature.

sloka: antarvego bahirvego dvividhaḥ punarucyate|  prākṛto vaikṛtaścaiva sādhyaścāsādhya eva ca||33||
translation: The fever is classified as twofold: as internal and external, manifest and unmanifest, respectively; and as causally conditioned and unconditioned, in subtle forms.

sloka: punaḥ pañcavidho dṛṣṭo doṣakālabalābalāt|  santataḥ satato'nyedyustṛtīyakacaturthakau||34||  punarāśrayabhedena dhātūnāṃ saptadhā mataḥ|  bhinnaḥ kāraṇabhedena punaraṣṭavidho jvaraḥ||35||
translation: The fever, previously observed to have five forms based on the variation in the duration and intensity of its occurrence, is now classified as sevenfold, distinguished according to the separate manifestations in internal and external symptoms. Moreover, it is classified as eightfold, based on distinct causes.

sloka: śārīro jāyate pūrvaṃ dehe manasi mānasaḥ|  vaicittyamaratirglānirmanasastāpalakṣaṇam||36||  indriyāṇāṃ ca vaikṛtyaṃ jñeyaṃ  santāpalakṣaṇam|37|
translation: The body is first produced with five types of attributes: those related to time, strength, and weakness, persisting either continuously or occasionally, arising from various causes. Similarly, seven types of sensory inflammations are distinguished, each having its own specific cause.

sloka: vātapittātmakaḥ śītamuṣṇaṃ vātakaphātmakaḥ||37||  icchatyubhayametattu jvaro vyāmiśralakṣaṇaḥ|38|
translation: The one having constituents of wind and bile is born with a cold (fever) that is made hot; this fever is marked by both weakness in the senses and wasting of the body, as well as a dislike for both food and drink.

sloka: yogavāhaḥ paraṃ vāyuḥ saṃyogādubhayārthakṛt||38||  dāhakṛttejasā yuktaḥ śītakṛt somasaṃśrayāt|39|
translation: The foremost carrier of yoga practices is the wind , which, through union , contributes to both humors - one causing heat and the other causing coolness . It strives to maintain equilibrium between them, thereby alleviating fever caused by humoral imbalance. This equilibrium is attained when it absorbs heat from the fire humor and seeks refuge in the moon's coolness .

sloka: antardāho'dhikastṛṣṇā pralāpaḥ śvasanaṃ bhramaḥ||39||  sandhyasthiśūlamasvedo doṣavarcovinigrahaḥ|  antarvegasya liṅgāni jvarasyaitāni lakṣayet||40||  santāpo'bhyadhiko bāhyastṛṣṇādīnāṃ ca mārdavam|  bahirvegasya liṅgāni sukhasādhyatvameva ca||41||
translation: The inner agitation, exceeding in thirst, is called pralapa when united with heat, and swallowing and dizziness when joined with breath. These, too, are indicators of an internal fever. When combined with coolness, derived from the moon and seeking refuge in the self, it is known as antardaha. The indicators of an external fever are just the opposite of these.

sloka: prākṛtaḥ sukhasādhyastu vasantaśaradudbhavaḥ|  uṣṇamuṣṇena saṃvṛddhaṃ pittaṃ śaradi kupyati||42||  citaḥ śīte kaphaścaivaṃ vasante samudīryate|  varṣāsvamlavipākābhiradbhiroṣadhibhistathā||43||
translation: The fever arising from natural causes, excessive thirst, delirious speech, and heavy breathing indicate that pitta has been aggravated in spring, caused by the intensifying heat. Likewise, in winter, kapha increases in those with a predisposition, characterized by congestion, heaviness, and mucus; and further exacerbated by seasonal variations such as rains, cold, and unripe fruits.

sloka: sañcitaṃ pittamudriktaṃ  śaradyādityatejasā|  jvaraṃ sañjanayatyāśu tasya cānubalaḥ kaphaḥ||44||  prakṛtyaiva  visargasya tatra nānaśanādbhayam|  adbhiroṣadhibhiścaiva madhurābhiścitaḥ kaphaḥ||45||
translation: The phlegm, accumulated in the body and made visible, is aggravated by the heat of the summer solstice. This same phlegm is quickly pacified by the cool and tranquil nature of spring. Moreover, it is further alleviated by various means such as sweet tastes, rainfall, and various kinds of herbs.

sloka: hemante sūryasantaptaḥ sa vasante prakupyati|  vasante śleṣmaṇā tasmājjvaraḥ samupajāyate||46||  ādānamadhye tasyāpi vātapittaṃ bhavedanu| ādāvante ca madhye ca buddhvā doṣabalābalam||47||
translation: In autumn, when the sun's heat is intense, a fever arises in one. Similarly, in early spring, due to an imbalance of phlegm, it is further provoked. Even in this state, by comprehending the relative strength of the bodily humors, and by avoiding irregular eating, one can manage this fever. This can be achieved through the use of warm substances, such as medicinal herbs and honey, during both the onset and cessation of this condition.

sloka: śaradvasantayorvidvāñjvarasya pratikārayet| kālaprakṛtimuddiśya nirdiṣṭaḥ prākṛto jvaraḥ||48||
translation: In both the spring season and at the onset of autumn, when the heat of the sun wanes, an excess of phlegm gets aggravated; therefore, fever arises. At the beginning, middle, or end of this fever, having recognized whether the wind and bile are weak or strong, one should take appropriate measures in terms of indicating and counteracting the fever's essential nature.

sloka: prāyeṇānilajo duḥkhaḥ kāleṣvanyeṣu vaikṛtaḥ|  hetavo vividhāstasya nidāne sampradarśitāḥ||49||
translation: The fever, typically arising in autumn and spring, is usually caused by various factors. It is to be diagnosed and treated by a knowledgeable person, indicating those causes and remedies.

sloka: balavatsvalpadoṣeṣu jvaraḥ sādhyo'nupadravaḥ| hetubhirbahubhirjāto balibhirbahulakṣaṇaḥ||50||  jvaraḥ prāṇāntakṛdyaśca śīghramindriyanāśanaḥ| saptāhādvā daśāhādvā dvādaśāhāttathaiva ca||51||  sapralāpabhramaśvāsastīkṣṇo hanyājjvaro naram| jvaraḥ kṣīṇasya śūnasya gambhīro dairgharātrikaḥ||52||  asādhyo balavān yaśca keśasīmantakṛjjvaraḥ|53|
translation: "Most frequently caused by an imbalance in the wind element, a disease is manifested through multiple causes and symptoms, some of which are hard to treat and severely debilitating, while others are milder and easily cured. A severe fever, for instance, can rapidly diminish a person's vitality, consuming their life force within seven to twelve days, or it can become chronic, deeply affecting the body over an extended period. Likewise, a disease that is difficult to treat can manifest as severe symptoms affecting the scalp and hair."

sloka: srotobhirvisṛtā doṣā guravo rasavāhibhiḥ||53||  sarvadehānugāḥ stabdhā jvaraṃ kurvanti santatam|  daśāhaṃ dvādaśāhaṃ vā saptāhaṃ vā suduḥsahaḥ||54||
translation: Arising from many causes, a severe fever, constantly tormenting, is brought about in the body by flaws in the veins, released among them. Steady and all-pervasive, it manifests in a variety of forms, such as one that lasts for seven days, one that lasts for ten days, or one that lasts for twelve days. It is difficult to cure, causing hair loss and emaciation of features, and its intense form persists throughout the night.

sloka: sa śīghraṃ śīghrakāritvāt praśamaṃ yāti hanti vā|  kāladūṣyaprakṛtibhirdoṣastulyo hi santatam||55||
translation: The one who acts quickly , due to its own quickness , either swiftly brings about tranquility or causes harm . This is similar to the inherent nature of a kāla-dūṣya, which constantly causes diseases and is unforgiving , consisting of twelve and seven . These impurities , dispersed in rivers , being heavy , act in this equal manner like an inherent nature. I am that nature , unforgiving , consisting of twelve and seven .

sloka: niṣpratyanīkaḥ kurute tasmājjñeyaḥ suduḥsahaḥ|  yathā dhātūṃstathā  mūtraṃ purīṣaṃ cānilādayaḥ||56||  yugapaccānupadyante niyamāt  santate jvare|  sa śuddhyā vā'pyaśuddhyā vā rasādīnāmaśeṣataḥ||57||  saptāhādiṣu kāleṣu praśamaṃ yāti hanti vā|  yadā tu nātiśudhyanti na vā śudhyanti sarvaśaḥ||58||
translation: The agent acting without opposition promptly attains, according to its nature of quickness, either calm or destruction during the designated time spans, whether through purification or otherwise; all impurities being alike in the case of an entity that can be permanently affected by corruption, either in the course of seven days or other time spans.

sloka: dvādaśaite samuddiṣṭāḥ santatasyāśrayāstadā|  visargaṃ dvādaśe kṛtvā divase'vyaktalakṣaṇam||59||  durlabhopaśamaḥ kālaṃ dīrghamapyanuvartate|  iti buddhvā jvaraṃ vaidya upakrāmettu santatam  ||60||  kriyākramavidhau yuktaḥ prāyaḥ prāgapatarpaṇaiḥ|61|
translation: The inexorable one should be recognized as the one who carries out the successive actions in their proper order without resistance. Just as bodily fluids and waste products such as feces, urine, and wind arise together according to their inherent nature during the seven days of a fever, which can either lessen or grow until complete purification occurs, similarly, in implementing therapeutic measures, one should persistently adhere to the prescribed steps, even if it requires a considerable amount of time.

sloka: raktadhātvāśrayaḥ prāyo doṣaḥ satatakaṃ jvaram||61||  sapratyanīkaḥ kurute kālavṛddhikṣayātmakam|  ahorātre satatako dvau kālāvanuvartate||62||
translation: The primary defect, which consistently arises from resorting to a raktadhātva, is mostly this constant ailment. A skilled physician, understanding the hidden and exceptional quality of long duration, should consistently attend to the appropriate treatment, utilizing the regular procedure and means of calming, even if the disease persists for extended periods such as day and night.

sloka: kālaprakṛtidūṣyāṇāṃ prāpyaivānyatamādbalam|  anyedyuṣkaṃ jvaraṃ doṣo ruddhvā medovahāḥ sirāḥ||63||  sapratyanīko janayatyekakālamaharniśi|
translation: Upon reaching the debilitating condition brought about by an imbalance in bodily humors, it becomes the most severe; similarly, another type of affliction, such as dysentery, when warded off, disrupts the functioning of the nutrient-carrying veins; an enemy causes decay in an instant, either during day or night, persisting unabated.

sloka: doṣo'sthimajjagaḥ kuryāttṛtīyakacaturthakau||64||  gatirdvyekāntarā'nyedyurdoṣasyoktā'nyathā  paraiḥ|  anyedyuṣkaṃ jvaraṃ kuryādapi saṃśritya śoṇitam||65||
translation: Upon encountering an impurity, one should apply the third or fourth remedy; for instance, in the case of excessive heat or fever, one may resort to bloodletting. The rule regarding this applies equally during both the day and night, as well as in all other instances. Alternatively, this rule is stated as follows: the antidotes for impurities must be applied appropriately, such as bloodletting in the case of fever; this rule applies at all times, whether during the day or at night.

sloka: māṃsasrotāṃsyanugato janayettu tṛtīyakam|  saṃśrito medaso mārgaṃ doṣaścāpi caturthakam  ||66||  anyedyuṣkaḥ pratidinaṃ dinaṃ hitvā tṛtīyakaḥ|  dinadvayaṃ yo viśramya pratyeti sa caturthakaḥ||67||
translation: The third evacuation route should give rise to a clot following the blood vessels, and the fourth, arising in fatty tissue, should cause an impurity. The one who, instead of observing the daily third evacuation, takes a break for two days and then returns is considered the fourth. Furthermore, if one causes harm to the marrow, bones, nerves, or other impurities, they should seek purification through bloodletting.

sloka: adhiśete yathā bhūmiṃ bījaṃ kāle ca rohati|  adhiśete tathā dhātuṃ doṣaḥ kāle ca kupyati||68||  sa vṛddhiṃ balakālaṃ ca prāpya doṣastṛtīyakam|  caturthakaṃ ca kurute pratyanīkabalakṣayāt||69||  kṛtvā vegaṃ gatabalāḥ sve sve sthāne vyavasthitāḥ|  punarvivṛddhāḥ sve kāle jvarayanti naraṃ malāḥ||70||
translation: Just as a seed sprouts in due course upon being sown in the earth, so does a bodily humor (dosha) develop at its designated time. In the same way, an anomaly arises in that humor at its own time. Having reached maturity and strength, it manifests in the third phase and further escalates, becoming a full-fledged illness in the fourth stage. Once the body's energy is exhausted, and after resting for two and a half days, it resumes growth in the fourth phase.

sloka: kaphapittāttrikagrāhī pṛṣṭhādvātakaphātmakaḥ|  vātapittācchirogrāhī trividhaḥ syāttṛtīyakaḥ||71||  caturthako darśayati prabhāvaṃ dvividhaṃ jvaraḥ|  jaṅghābhyāṃ ślaiṣmikaḥ pūrvaṃ śirasto'nilasambhavaḥ||72||
translation: In their respective seasons, just as the seed of a plant grows in its own time and place, similarly, the three doshas (kapha, pitta, vata) grow in their own way and cause an increase in their strength. The fourth type of dosha, which is threefold in nature, manifests in two forms - one that arises from the shlesma located in the legs and another that originates in the head due to an excess of phlegm. Once these imbalances, which are causative in nature, develop, they move towards the location of their origin, gain strength, and ultimately result in fever in the individual.

sloka: viṣamajvara evānyaścaturthakaviparyayaḥ|  trividho dhāturekaiko dvidhātusthaḥ karoti yam||73||
translation: The fourth kind of fever, specifically marked by an imbalance in all three doshas (kapha, pitta, and vata), manifests in two ways: either as a vata-dominated fever, originating in the legs and progressing toward the head, or as a shlesma-dominated fever, initially presenting in the head.

sloka: prāyaśaḥ sannipātena dṛṣṭaḥ pañcavidho jvaraḥ|  sannipāte tu yo bhūyān sa doṣaḥ parikīrtitaḥ||74||
translation: Normally, the five types of fever are witnessed to emerge due to a convergence of symptoms. When this convergence is especially intense, it is known as a distinct disorder.

sloka: ṛtvahorātradoṣāṇāṃ  manasaśca balābalāt|  kālamarthavaśāccaiva jvarastaṃ taṃ prapadyate||75||
translation: In most cases, when there is a convergence of five types of fevers, due to an imbalance in the mind's strength and physical strength, one submits to that condition, which is considered the more severe form of fever.

sloka: gurutvaṃ dainyamudvegaḥ sadanaṃ chardyarocakau|  rasasthite bahistāpaḥ sāṅgamardo vijṛmbhaṇam||76||
translation: At the proper time, daily, during the elimination of mental flaws, strength appropriately overcomes weakness for the pursuit of prosperity; fever, however, seizes one who seeks to exert control over external bodily pleasures, established outside of oneself.

sloka: raktoṣṇāḥ piḍakāstṛṣṇā saraktaṃ ṣṭhīvanaṃ muhuḥ|  dāharāgabhramamadapralāpā raktasaṃsthite||77||
translation: With minds made heavy, exhibiting humility, and being mentally agitated, constantly affected by a burning sensation, as bile and phlegm surge up, along with the body trembling, and a discolored, swollen tongue – these are all indicators of anger made manifest.

sloka: antardāhaḥ satṛṇmohaḥ saglāniḥ sṛṣṭaviṭkatā|  daurgandhyaṃ gātravikṣepo jvare māṃsasthite bhavet||78||
translation: When established in the flesh, constant inflammation, characterized by increased heat, itching, discoloration, and throbbing, as well as confusion and delusion, accompanied by excessive talking and foul odor, arises.

sloka: svedastīvrā pipāsā ca pralāpo vamyabhīkṣṇaśaḥ|  svagandhasyāsahatvaṃ ca medaḥsthe glānyarocakau||79||
translation: In the body, an intense thirst, a sharp feeling of dryness, continuous sighing, and loss of natural fragrance may occur; additionally, the flesh becomes loose.

sloka: virekavamane cobhe sāsthibhedaṃ prakūjanam|  vikṣepaṇaṃ ca gātrāṇāṃ śvāsaścāsthigate jvare||80||
translation: Perspiration becomes distinct and plentiful, thirst and incoherent speech increase; frequent vomiting, retention of gases in the body, and loss of bodily strength are also present in a fever that has firmly taken hold.

sloka: hikkā śvāsastathā kāsastamasaścātidarśanam|  marmacchedo bahiḥ śaityaṃ dāho'ntaścaiva majjage||81||
translation: The expulsion of phlegm, inhalation, and excretion, as well as the two movements of contraction and expansion in the limbs; these are all visible symptoms of fever, accompanied by shaking and redness occurring on the body surface.

sloka: śukrasthānagataḥ śukramokṣaṃ kṛtvā vināśya ca|  prāṇaṃ vāyvagnisomaiśca sārdhaṃ gacchatyasau vibhuḥ||82||
translation: By expelling semen, the all-pervasive one, having caused dissolution (of the physical body) and destruction (of ignorance), goes away from the source of pleasure, together with air and fire (the vital breath and heat of the body), in a state of liberation. This is referred to in the eighty-second verse.

sloka: rasaraktāśritaḥ sādhyo medomāṃsagataśca yaḥ|  asthimajjagataḥ kṛcchraḥ śukrastho naiva siddhyati||83||
translation: One who is established in semen, impassioned by rasa (fluids), and originates from flesh and fat, such a powerful being, unless he eradicates the life-winds associated with Vayu, Agni, and Soma, cannot attain liberation, however hard he tries.

sloka: hetubhirlakṣaṇaiścoktaḥ pūrvamaṣṭavidho jvaraḥ|  samāsenopadiṣṭasya vyāsataḥ śṛṇu lakṣaṇam||84||
translation: The fever, previously identified by eight characteristics and described using those symptoms, is now being explained; listen to its definition: it resides in the blood, flesh, fat, marrow, and reproductive fluids; it does not arise without a host or if perfection has been attained.

sloka: śiroruk  parvaṇāṃ bhedo dāho romṇāṃ praharṣaṇam|  kaṇṭhāsyaśoṣo vamathustṛṣṇā mūrcchā bhramo'ruciḥ||85||  svapnanāśo'tivāgjṛmbhā vātapittajvarākṛtiḥ|
translation: The symptoms of the fever, as described previously, include: a severe headache in the head; a splitting pain in the joints; a burning sensation on the skin; goosebumps on the body hair; shivering at the back of the neck; intense thirst; fainting; dizziness; loss of consciousness; and physical manifestations such as excessive sweating, rapid pulse, and elevated body temperature.

sloka: śītako gauravaṃ tandrā staimityaṃ parvaṇāṃ ca ruk||86||  śirograhaḥ pratiśyāyaḥ kāsaḥ svedāpravartanam|  santāpo madhyavegaśca vātaśleṣmajvarākṛtiḥ||87||
translation: The condition characterized by chills, tremors in the limbs, onset of sweating, and goosebumps can be identified as a fever; at the onset of a cough, hiccups, facial paleness, fainting, loss of consciousness, and disturbances in vision, one can recognize the symptoms of vata-, pitta-, and kapha-related fevers.

sloka: muhurdāho muhuḥ śītaṃ svedastambho  muhurmuhuḥ|  mohaḥ kāso'rucistṛṣṇā śleṣmapittapravartanam||88||  liptatiktāsyatā tandrā śleṣmapittajvarākṛtiḥ|  ityete dvandvajāḥ proktāḥ ...|89|
translation: Consisting of pairs, these are declared: cold (passive past participle) and heaviness, drowsiness and steadfastness, occurring at specific moments; thirst, sweat, and its onset; delusion, cough, and increased phlegm; tandoor-like warmth, sticky excretions, and fatigue. (88) Tear-like dripping, lethargy, and the form of phlegm-related fever; these are the dual entities mentioned. (89)

sloka: ... sannipātaja ucyate||89||  sannipātajvarasyordhvaṃ trayodaśavidhasya hi|  prāksūtritasya vakṣyāmi lakṣaṇaṃ vai pṛthak pṛthak||90||
translation: The gathering of symptoms is referred to as 'sannipāta'. I will describe the distinct symptoms of the 'sannipātajvara' fever, which has eleven types. These include repeated bouts of burning, chill, sweating, stiffness, delusion, cough, lack of luster, thirst, phlegm, and bile, as well as its evacuation.

sloka: bhramaḥ pipāsā dāhaśca gauravaṃ śiraso'tiruk|  vātapittolbaṇe vidyālliṅgaṃ mandakaphe jvare||91||
translation: Of the thirteen types of fever, I will describe the distinct symptoms, beginning with those above the head: a dizzying sensation, intense thirst, a burning feeling, and an increased heaviness of the head, as well as a phlegmatic fever.

sloka: śaityaṃ kāso'rucistandrāpipāsādāharugvyathāḥ|  vātaśleṣmolbaṇe vyādhau liṅgaṃ pittāvare viduḥ||92||
translation: Skilled physicians recognize, in imbalances, the indicators of disorders such as excessive thirst, burning sensations, and heaviness in the head caused by wind, bile, and excessive phlegm; they also understand the symptoms of afflictions like mild fever and wasting disease.

sloka: chardiḥ śaityaṃ muhurdāhastṛṣṇā moho'sthivedanā|  mandavāte vyavasyanti liṅgaṃ pittakapholbaṇe||93||
translation: In the current context , a fever , caused by exhaustion , delusion , instability , lethargy , and weakness , as well as symptoms like thirst, recognized by knowledgeable people, arise due to an imbalance of wind , phlegm , and bile in the body.

sloka: sandhyasthiśirasaḥ śūlaṃ pralāpo gauravaṃ bhramaḥ|  vātolbaṇe syād dvyanuge tṛṣṇā kaṇṭhāsyaśuṣkatā||94||
translation: Practicing regularly to control vomiting, thirst, and delusion at sandhyan times, as well as stiffness in the neck and symptoms of imbalanced vata, pitta, and kapha in the throat, will ensure steadiness, dignity, and proper functioning in the future.

sloka: raktaviṇmūtratā dāhaḥ svedastṛḍ balasaṅkṣayaḥ|  mūrcchā ceti tridoṣe syālliṅgaṃ pitte garīyasi||95||
translation: In the presence of an excess of the three doshas, the following symptoms may arise: at the throat and chest, pitta prevails, leading to increased thirst, delirium, fainting, and emaciation; likewise, vata may cause tremors at that site.

sloka: ālasyārucihṛllāsadāhavamyaratibhramaiḥ|  kapholbaṇaṃ sannipātaṃ tandrākāsena cādiśet||96||
translation: Let a reddish tinge in phlegm, impaired digestion, loss of strength, sweating, and fainting indicate the onset of a kapha excess, combined with symptoms of increased pitta, as revealed by rakta-viṇmūtra-tā-dāhaḥ. (96)

sloka: pratiśyā chardirālasyaṃ tandrā'rucyagnimārdavam|  hīnavāte pittamadhye liṅgaṃ śleṣmādhike matam||97||
translation: The sign of slothfulness and indolence is considered to be a pallor in the complexion, an increase in phlegm in the locative, and weakened digestive fire, marked by tremors; such is the diagnosis in cases of feeble digestion.

sloka: hāridramūtranetratvaṃ dāhastṛṣṇā bhramo'ruciḥ|  hīnavāte madhyakaphe liṅgaṃ pittādhike matam||98||
translation: Flatulence, excessive thirst, and heat, as well as sloth and dullness of the senses, are considered signs of an imbalance in the body, specifically when accompanied by phlegm in the middle of wind and bile, according to medical science. This imbalance is characterized by lightness and a lowly nature.

sloka: śirorugvepathuḥ śvāsaḥ pralāpaśchardyarocakau|  hīnapitte madhyakaphe liṅgaṃ syānmārutādhike||99||
translation: The symptoms of increased wind in the body include: excessive thirst, giddiness, loss of taste, debilitation, and when in excess, it manifests as a burning sensation, as well as palpitations in the heart or throat; these symptoms occur either in the middle or at the end of digestion.

sloka: śītako gauravaṃ tandrā pralāpo'sthiśiro'tiruk|  hīnapitte vātamadhye liṅgaṃ śleṣmādhike viduḥ||100||
translation: The man characterized by an unsteady head and incoherent speech, who has vomited and fainted, is recognized as having an excess of phlegm in the abdominal region.

sloka: śvāsaḥ kāsaḥ pratiśyāyo mukhaśoṣo'tipārśvaruk|  kaphahīne pittamadhye liṅgaṃ vātādhike matam||101||
translation: Knowledgeable ones identify the following as symptoms of an increased vata dosha: an excess of gas, lightness, and mobility in the body, as well as a dry mouth, constipation, and rough skin.

sloka: varcobhedo'gnidaurbalyaṃ [3] tṛṣṇā dāho'rucirbhramaḥ|  kaphahīne vātamadhye liṅgaṃ pittādhike viduḥ||102||
translation: They recognize the following symptoms: when bile predominates, a continuous, strong fever accompanied by a bitter taste in the mouth serves as the symptom; when wind predominates, dryness of the mouth and skin, located to the sides and back, accompanied by tremors, serves as the symptom. This is what they identify as the symptoms of an imbalance in the bodily humors.

sloka: sannipātajvarasyordhvamato vakṣyāmi lakṣaṇam|  kṣaṇe dāhaḥ kṣaṇe śītamasthisandhiśirorujā||103||  sāsrāve kaluṣe rakte nirbhugne cāpi darśane [4] |  sasvanau sarujau karṇau kaṇṭhaḥ śūkairivāvṛtaḥ||104||
translation: I will describe the symptoms of an ascending, sharp fever: at one moment, there is burning; at another, shivering; the head becomes heated; and the senses are afflicted by cold. The eyes turn red, and there is discharge from the nose; the ears seem congested, and the neck appears dirt-covered.

sloka: tandrā mohaḥ pralāpaśca kāsaḥ śvāso'rucirbhramaḥ|  paridagdhā kharasparśā jihvā srastāṅgatā param||105||
translation: I will describe the symptoms of an imminent fever: it suddenly rises from the lower part of the body upward, characterized by drowsiness , delusion , incoherent speech , and heavy, unsteady breathing , a burning tongue , and a throbbing headache ; it has already begun to affect the limbs .

sloka: ṣṭhīvanaṃ raktapittasya kaphenonmiśritasya ca|  śiraso loṭhanaṃ tṛṣṇā nidrānāśo hṛdi vyathā||106||
translation: Drowsiness, delusion, incoherent speech, and cough are symptoms of blood impurity and swelling in the head, respectively; thirst, loss of sleep, anxiety in the heart, and unclear perception also serve as indicators of this condition.

sloka: svedamūtrapurīṣāṇāṃ cirāddarśanamalpaśaḥ|  kṛśatvaṃ nātigātrāṇāṃ pratataṃ kaṇṭhakūjanam||107||
translation: The sweating and urine of the disciplined ones, due to their longtime restraint, are seldom seen, as slenderness prevails extensively in their bodies, caused by the constant suppression of hunger, thirst, sleep, and anxiety in their heads, chests, and hearts.

sloka: koṭhānāṃ śyāvaraktānāṃ maṇḍalānāṃ ca darśanam|  mūkatvaṃ srotasāṃ pāko gurutvamudarasya ca||108||  cirāt pākaśca doṣāṇāṃ sannipātajvarākṛtiḥ|109|
translation: After a long time, observing the appearance of discolored spots on the bodies of many, along with symptoms such as sweating, urination, and defecation, as well as the development of moderate leanness, and intermittent throat murmurs.

sloka: doṣe vibaddhe naṣṭe'gnau sarvasampūrṇalakṣaṇaḥ||109||  sannipātajvaro'sādhyaḥ kṛcchrasādhyastvato'nyathā| nidāne trividhā proktā yā pṛthagjajvarākṛtiḥ||110||  saṃsargasannipātānāṃ tayā coktaṃ svalakṣaṇam|111|
translation: In the presence of impurities located in circles of black, red, and white hues in the body, the fever arising from their close gathering is fully marked by symptoms such as altered complexion, speech, urine flow, thirst, and stomach heaviness. This fever, classified into three categories according to distinct manifestations, is either easily curable or requires hard effort depending on the specific cause of this fever caused by impurity gathering.

sloka: āganturaṣṭamo yastu sa nirdiṣṭaścaturvidhaḥ||111||  abhighātābhiṣaṅgābhyāmabhicārābhiśāpataḥ|
translation: The eighth stage of the Vedic fire sacrifice, specifically designated as such, is of four kinds and can be afflicted by four types of faults: transgression, destruction, absence, or connection with a prohibited substance; as well as two types of fevers, contagious and non-contagious; and three kinds of causes, incurable, curable, and those arising from distress. Additionally, such a one may exhibit a fever distinct from the ones mentioned, caused by the convergence of various factors. This is the separate description for each type.

sloka: śastraloṣṭakaśākāṣṭhamuṣṭyaratnitaladvijaiḥ||112||  tadvidhaiśca hate gātre jvaraḥ syādabhighātajaḥ|  tatrābhighātaje vāyuḥ prāyo raktaṃ pradūṣayan||113||  savyathāśophavaivarṇyaṃ karoti sarujaṃ jvaram|114|
translation: The eighth form of external affliction , specifically designated as arising from one of the four types of physical impacts, brings about a fever when it affects the body . Moreover, such afflictions can cause symptoms such as redness, swelling, and pain . When this type of affliction affects individuals of noble character , it primarily involves the blood , being predominantly spread through the agency of wind .

sloka: kāmaśokabhayakrodhairabhiṣaktasya yo jvaraḥ||114||
translation: The fever that, for one protected by/from (abhisaktasya) desire, sorrow, fear, and anger, is caused by weapons, fists, sticks, or blows from the hands of twice-born ones using stones, pieces of wood, or bare hands, becomes irregular in color (bluish, reddish, etc.), accompanied by cough and expercation, and is difficult to cure.

sloka: so'bhiṣaṅgājvaro jñeyo yaśca bhūtābhiṣaṅgajaḥ|  kāmaśokabhayādvāyuḥ krodhāt pittaṃ trayo malāḥ||115||
translation: The fever, caused by the combined influence of desire, sorrow, fear, and anger, known as the "affliction-causing fever" (abhisaṅgājvaraḥ), should be understood (jñeyaḥ) as originating from the three impurities (trayaḥ), namely passion, darkness, and ignorance (malāḥ), which are also described as the wind (vāyuḥ) of desire and fear, and the bile (pittam) of anger (krodhāt), respectively.

sloka: bhūtābhiṣaṅgāt kupyanti bhūtasāmānyalakṣaṇāḥ|  bhūtādhikāre vyākhyātaṃ tadaṣṭavidhalakṣaṇam||116||
translation: The bodily humors, when agitated by external factors, become agitated themselves and manifest as the three dysfunctions of desire, anger, and fear, which are characterized as wind, bile, and phlegm, respectively. This has been explained in relation to their respective causes.

sloka: viṣavṛkṣānilasparśāttathā'nyairviṣasambhavaiḥ|  abhiṣaktasya cāpyāhurjvarameke'bhiṣaṅgajam||117||
translation: Agitated by symptoms of disease arising from contact with a poisonous tree or the bite of a venomous creature, as well as from other causes, they say that it manifests as one of eight kinds, referring to the general indications of afflictions.

sloka: cikitsayā viṣaghnyaiva sa śamaṃ labhate naraḥ|  abhicārābhiśāpābhyāṃ siddhānāṃ yaḥ pravartate||118||
translation: By treating a poisonous tree with various methods such as wind or touch, one does not bring about its destruction; rather, it is through the application of exorcism that the afflictions caused by the tree can be removed. Similarly, only a true sage, through the practice of exorcism , can achieve peace. This is the teaching of those who know about the removal of afflictions caused by poisonous people and those similar to them. .

sloka: sannipātajvaro ghoraḥ sa vijñeyaḥ suduḥsahaḥ|  sannipātajvarasyoktaṃ liṅgaṃ yattasya tat smṛtam||119||
translation: The severe illness , marked by the convergence of evil forces, is formidable and must be recognized as hard to combat . Its distinguishing feature is being caused by malignant spells and curses cast by those adept in such arts . This is remembered as the definition of an illness arising from a malevolent assembly.
