sloka: cittondriyaśarīrāṇāmartayo'nyāśca naikaśaḥ|  prayogaṃ tvabhicārasya dṛṣṭvā śāpasya caiva hi||120||
translation: Upon witnessing the combination of bodily ailments, as well as other unique ones, and discerning their indications, one should recollect what has been described about them, while also being vigilant against improper application and speaking ill of them.

sloka: svayaṃ śrutvā'numānena lakṣyate  praśamena vā|  vaividhyādabhicārasya śāpasya ca tadātmake||121||
translation: The mind, senses, and body, as well as offspring, are explicitly included when, through one's own experience or inference, determining the manifestation of recklessness and verbal abuse pertaining to oneself. This is true in the case of excessive behavior and abusive language, as well.

sloka: yathākarmaprayogeṇa lakṣaṇaṃ syāt pṛthagvidham|  dhyānaniḥśvāsabahulaṃ liṅgaṃ kāmajvare smṛtam||122||  śokaje bāṣpabahulaṃ trāsaprāyaṃ bhayajvare|  krodhaje bahusaṃrambhaṃ bhūtāveśe tvamānuṣam||123||
translation: Through observing the manifestation of actions, one can recognize different signs: meditation and heavy breathing indicate lust, while tears, trembling, and fear signify sorrow; similarly, agitation points towards anger; and in a state of possession by a supernatural being, unusual behavior can be observed.

sloka: mūrcchāmohamadaglānibhūyiṣṭhaṃ viṣasambhave|  keṣāñcideṣāṃ liṅgānāṃ santāpo jāyate puraḥ||124||  paścāttulyaṃ tu keṣāñcideṣu kāmajvarādiṣu|  kāmādijānāmuddiṣṭaṃ jvarāṇāṃ yadviśeṣaṇam||125||
translation:
By what specific action does one recognize the distinct symptoms of fainting, infatuation, unsteadiness, and poisoning? (124)
In whom do the distinguishing features of desire and fever first appear? And what is their characteristic in other entities? (125)
Grief, tears, fear, constant anxiety, horror, excessive attachment, extreme agitation, and irrational behavior are known to be its common symptoms. (125)

sloka: kāmādijānāṃ rogāṇāmanyeṣāmapi tat smṛtam|  manasyabhihate pūrvaṃ kāmādyairna tathā balam||126||  jvaraḥ prāpnoti vātādyairdeho yāvanna dūṣyati|  dehe cābhiha(dru)te pūrvaṃ vātādyairna tathā balam||127||  jvaraḥ prāpnoti kāmādyairmano yāvanna dūṣyati| te pūrvaṃ kevalāḥ paścānnijairvyāmiśralakṣaṇāḥ||128||  hetvauṣadhaviśiṣṭāśca bhavantyāgantavo jvarāḥ|129|
translation: The initial symptoms of diseases arising from desire, such as fainting, delusion, and intoxication, are remembered as the primary signs. At first, strength does not arise in the mind due to these desires, just as it doesn’t in the case of poisoning. Similarly, a physical illness caused by wind or other factors, which hasn’t yet affected the body, may not reduce one’s strength immediately. However, later on, these desire-related symptoms become dominant, while those caused by wind or bile are less so. The causes of fever can be treated with medicines and other remedies, as is widely known.

sloka: saṃsṛṣṭāḥ sannipatitāḥ pṛthagvā kupitā malāḥ||129||  rasākhyaṃ dhātumanvetya paktiṃ  sthānānnirasya ca|  svena tenoṣmaṇa caiva kṛtvā dehoṣmaṇo balam||130||  srotāṃsi ruddhvā samprāptāḥ kevalaṃ dehamulbaṇāḥ|  santāpamadhikaṃ dehe janayanti narastadā||131||  bhavatyatyuṣṇasarvāṅgo jvaritastena cocyate|132|
translation: The senses, having been obstructed, affect the body alone; they cause an extraordinary fever in the individual. When the body becomes excessively hot and feverish, it is called "jvarita" (feverish). Diseases, distinguished by their various causes and remedies, have yet to arrive as long as the mind is not affected by memories of past and present afflictions.

sloka: srotasāṃ sanniruddhatvāt svedaṃ nā nādhigacchati||132||  svasthānāt pracyute cāgnau prāyaśastaruṇejvare|133|
translation: When the flowing channels are obstructed, sweat does not reach the surface; similarly, when impurities accumulate and are forcibly expelled from their sources, the body's inherent heat intensifies, becoming excessively high, leading to a severe feverish state.

sloka: aruciścāvipākaśca gurutvamudarasya ca||133||  hṛdayasyāviśuddhiśca tandrā cālasyameva ca|  jvaro'visargī balavān doṣāṇāmapravartanam||134||  lālāpraseko hṛllāsaḥ kṣunnāśo virasaṃ  mukham|  stabdhasuptaguruvaṃ ca gātrāṇāṃ bahumūtratā||135||  na viḍ jīrṇā na ca glānirjvarasyāmasya lakṣaṇam|
translation: The symptoms of a fully developed fever include an absence of wasting in the body, lack of flow in the bodily fluids, failure of sweat to reach its proper location, just as on a smoldering fire; additionally, there is no dryness or weakness, and there is trembling, emaciation, and a gaping mouth. The characteristic of an active fever is marked by these symptoms.

sloka: jvaravego'dhikastṛṣṇā pralāpaḥ śvasanaṃ bhramaḥ||136||  malapravṛttirutkleśaḥ pacyamānasya lakṣaṇam|137|
translation: The symptoms of a feverish person undergoing digestion include excessive thirst, delirious speech, heavy breathing, dizziness, impure digestion, abdominal bloating, loss of appetite, weakness, accelerated pulse, body heat, increased salivation, sweating, wasting, fainting, lethargy, stiffness, sleepiness, loose teeth, emaciation, cracking joints, and eruptions. These are the indicators of fever and indigestion.

sloka: kṣut kṣāmatā laghutvaṃ ca gātrāṇāṃ jvaramārdavam||137||  doṣapravṛttiraṣṭāho nirāmajvaralakṣaṇam|138|
translation: Prominent among the symptoms of a person afflicted by disease are excessive thirst, prolonged fever, delirious speech, shallow breathing, dizziness, and the emission of impurities.

sloka: navajvare divāsvapnasnānābhyaṅgānnamaithunam||138||  krodhapravātavyāyāmān kaṣāyāṃśca vivarjayet|139|
translation: During the initial stages of a fever, one should avoid during the daytimes: wasting of tissues, symptoms of disease, as well as bodily heaviness; sleep, bathing, anointing, sexual activity, and anger should also be abandoned; such abstention is recommended.

sloka: jvare laṅghanamevādāvupadiṣṭamṛte jvarāt||139||  kṣayānilabhayakrodhakāmaśokaśramodbhavāt  |140|
translation: For fever, it has been recommended initially to rest during the day and stay awake at night, avoid bathing, anointing, eating, sexual activity, anger, and the buildup of impurities, as these arise from fear, desire, shock, exhaustion, and sadness. (This is stated in the context of treating fever.)

sloka: laṅghanena kṣayaṃ nīte doṣe sandhukṣite'nale||140||  vijvaratvaṃ laghutvaṃ ca kṣuccaivāsyopajāyate  |  prāṇāvirodhinā cainaṃ laṅghanenopapādayet||141||  balādhiṣṭhānamārogyaṃ yadartho'yaṃ kriyākramaḥ|142|
translation: Upon ending the fever through controlled suppression, lightness and the absence of lethargy arise; one should also eliminate, through the application of strength, the underlying causes such as wind, fear, anger, desire, sorrow, and exhaustion. This is the proper sequence for establishing health and well-being.

sloka: laṅghanaṃ svedanaṃ kālo yavāgvastiktako rasaḥ||142||  pācanānyavipakvānāṃ doṣāṇāṃ taruṇe jvare|143|
translation: Through reducing the errors by sweating , as indicated by the initial stage of fever , when the digestive fire has diminished , lightness and absence of hunger are produced. This sequence of actions , including reducing errors and promoting sweating, leads to strength and health , nourishing the bodily functions .

sloka: tṛṣyate salilaṃ coṣṇaṃ dadyādvātakaphajvare  ||143||  madyotthe paittike cātha śītalaṃ tiktakaiḥ śṛtam|  dīpanaṃ pācanaṃ caiva jvaraghnamubhayaṃ hi tat||144||  srotasāṃ śodhanaṃ balyaṃ rucisvedakaraṃ śivam|145|
translation: The thirst is quenched by drinking cool water, especially in the summer heat or during fever. Its taste is pleasant, and it aids in digestion, eliminating toxins from the body, and balancing the three doshas (vata, pitta, kapha) in both young and old. It also purifies the bodily channels, increases strength, improves complexion, and promotes overall well-being.

sloka: mustaparpaṭakośīracandanodīcyanāgaraiḥ||145||  śṛtaśītaṃ jalaṃ dadyāt pipāsājvaraśāntaye|146|
translation: For alleviating both thirst and fever, one should give cool water to those afflicted by summer heat, phlegm, alcohol, bile, and wind. Such drinking brings calmness, stimulates appetite, illuminates, soothes burns, is beneficial for all bodily channels, promotes strength, enhances taste, induces sweating, and is auspicious.

sloka: kaphapradhānānutkliṣṭān doṣānāmāśayasthitān||146||  buddhvā jvarakarān kāle vamyānāṃ vamanairharet|147|
translation: Upon recognizing, at the appropriate time, the predominant and aggravated faults (i.e., bodily humors) located in the stomach, one should cause the patients to take a purgative made from a mixture of mustard seeds, barley, licorice, sandalwood powder, and Dicyanota opposita leaf, all combined with water.

sloka: anupasthitadoṣāṇāṃ vamanaṃ taruṇejvare||147||  hṛdrogaṃ śvāsamānāhaṃ mohaṃ  ca janayedbhṛśam|  sarvadehānugāḥ sāmā dhātusthā asunirharāḥ  ||148||  doṣāḥ phalānāmāmānāṃ  svarasā iva sātyayāḥ|149|
translation: Upon recognizing the aggravated chief bodily humors, specifically the kapha located in the stomach, one should administer therapeutic emesis at the appropriate time using recommended emetics. This can effectively alleviate the cause of the fever, as well as prevent confusion and fear from arising.

sloka: vamitaṃ laṅghitaṃ kāle yavāgūbhirupācaret||149||  yathāsvauṣadhasiddhābhirmaṇḍapūrvābhirāditaḥ|  yāvajjvaramṛdūbhāvāt ṣaḍahaṃ vā vicakṣaṇaḥ||150||  tasyāgnirdīpyate tābhiḥ samidbhiriva pāvakaḥ|  tāśca bheṣajasaṃyogāllaghutvāccāgnidīpanāḥ||151||
translation: A discerning person should carefully administer emetics to a young patient with a newly arisen fever in the chest, causing vomiting, just as one would use medicinal plants prepared in advance. Indeed, just as kindling woods ignite a fire, these remedies, when combined, can ignite the elimination of the disease, for their lightness promotes the burning of the agni (digestive fire), as designated by dīpanāḥ, the masculine vocative plural of bheṣajam, meaning "medicine."

sloka: vātamūtrapurīṣāṇāṃ doṣāṇāṃ  cānulomanāḥ|  svedanāya dravoṣṇatvāddravatvāttṛṭpraśāntaye||152||  āhārabhāvāt prāṇāya saratvāllāghavāya ca|  jvaraghnyo jvarasātmyatvāttasmāt  peyābhirāditaḥ||153||
translation: For the afflictions of both the bodily and excretory systems, you should apply medicinal plants and preparations in a directed manner until fever is calmed. Therefore, just as a fire, when ignited with suitable fuel, blazes forth brilliantly, so too do medicines, due to their combined properties and lightness, eliminate fever.

sloka: jvarānupacareddhīmānṛte  madyasamutthitāt|  madātyaye madyanitye grīṣme pittakaphādhike||154||  ūrdhvage raktapitte ca yavāgūrna hitā jvare|155|
translation: The one who can properly care for the disorders of fevers, namely alleviating disturbances of wind, feces, and urine caused by upward movement, bringing about sweating and discharge due to warmth and thinness, and calming down when the cause is due to unwholesome food, drink, or seasonal illnesses such as those occurring in summer and characterized by an increase in bile and phlegm.

sloka: tatra tarpaṇamevāgre prayojyaṃ  lājasaktubhiḥ||155||  jvarāpahaiḥ phalarasairyuktaṃ samadhuśarkaram|156|
translation: For the feverish, the wise one should first resort to performing tarpana with a mixture of grains and medicinal plants. This is always advantageous in cases of excessive pitta during summer, especially when kapha is minimal, rising upward and impacting the blood.

sloka: tataḥ sātmyabalāpekṣī bhojayejjīrṇatarpaṇam||156||  tanunā mudgayūṣeṇa jāṅgalānāṃ rasena vā|  annakāleṣu cāpyasmai vidheyaṃ dantadhāvanam||157||
translation: In that context, one should cause the worthy one to enjoy fresh food, either grains or, when those are unavailable, the sap of wild plants; at appropriate times, one should assign this to him; moreover, brushing one's teeth is to be observed as a duty. Spoiled food offerings should be avoided.

sloka: yo'sya vaktrarasastasmādviparītaṃ priyaṃ ca yat|  tadasya mukhavaiśadyaṃ prakāṅkṣāṃ cānnapānayoḥ||158||  dhatte rasaviśeṣāṇāmabhijñatvaṃ karoti yat|  viśodhya drumaśākhāgrairāsyaṃ prakṣālya cāsakṛt||159||  mastvikṣurasamadyādyairyathāhāramavāpnuyāt|160|
translation: Upon attaining that mature state, one should offer suitable fare to the cherished companion who is capable and in need of nourishment; prepare and serve them food made from pulses like mudga and other nutritious elements at appropriate intervals; and consistently cleanse their teeth using a tree twig.

sloka: pācanaṃ śamanīyaṃ vā kaṣāyaṃ pāyayedbhiṣak||160||  jvaritaṃ ṣaḍahe'tīte laghvannapratibhojitam|161|
translation: The physician should give to that feverish patient, who has a bitter taste in his mouth, an agreeable concoction or a taste-moderating remedy, or even a purgative , six hours after the fever has set in . Moreover, such a remedy should be easily digestible and taken in small quantities . Additionally, one should regularly cleanse the mouth with tree twigs, thereby acquiring sweet substances like sugar and other palatable flavors.

sloka: stabhyante na  vipacyante kurvanti viṣamajvaram||161||  doṣā baddhāḥ kaṣāyeṇa stambhitvāttaruṇe jvare|  na tu kalpanamuddiśya kaṣāyaḥ pratiṣidhyate||162||  yaḥ kaṣāyakaṣāyaḥ  syāt sa varjyastaruṇajvare|163|
translation: The imbalanced bodily humors should be neutralized by a purgative that is applied skillfully, agreeable, and effective; they do not get obstructed when thickened by bile in fever due to an intentionally applied purgative, but rather by the impurity inherent within it. One should reject such a purgative when caused by impurities during fever.

sloka: yūṣairamlairanamlairvā jāṅgalairvā rasairhitaiḥ||163||  daśāhaṃ yāvadaśnīyāllaghvannaṃ jvaraśāntaye|164|
translation: Using potent drugs and remedies that either alleviate, aggravate, or cause uneven effects, as well as those that induce stupor, should be neutralized by a saffron treatment for fever, as long as it's indicated. Such saffron treatment with light food should be avoided if one is young.

sloka: ata ūrdhvaṃ kaphe mande vātapittottare jvare||164||  paripakveṣu doṣeṣu sarpiṣpānaṃ yathā'mṛtam| nirdaśāhamapi jñātvā kaphottaramalaṅghitam||165||  na sarpiḥ pāyayedvaidyaḥ kaṣāyaistamupācaret  |  yāvallaghutvādaśanaṃ dadyānmāṃsarasena ca||166||  balaṃ hyalaṃ nigrahāya doṣāṇāṃ balakṛcca tat  |167|
translation: Once wind or phlegm causes an advanced stage of fever, it should be treated with appropriate medicinal remedies based on the imbalance. Just as ghee is used to balance the properties of food when phlegm is predominant, one shouldn't administer ghee if phlegm has surpassed its appropriate level, even if one knows it. Instead, use purgative or astringent treatments until the imbalance is reduced through light and nourishing food. This approach enhances the body's strength for controlling the disorder.

sloka: dāhatṛṣṇāparītasya vātapittottaraṃ jvaram||167||  baddhapracyutadoṣaṃ vā nirāmaṃ payasā jayet|168|
translation: For an inflammation caused by excessive thirst, induced by wind or bile at its height, one should consume butter that has been boiled in water, making sure it is easily digestible. As an alternative, a physician may choose to administer a purgative treatment using a decoction until the patient's strength is restored to control the imbalances.

sloka: kriyābhirābhiḥ praśamaṃ na prayāti yadā jvaraḥ||168||  akṣīṇabalamāṃsāgneḥ  śamayettaṃ virecanaiḥ|169|
translation: The fever, caused by an imbalance of bile, wind, thirst, or burning, does not retreat if counteracted by emesis, when it has not yet reached the irreversible stage; it is pacified by the power of these very counteractions.

sloka: jvarakṣīṇasya na hitaṃ vamanaṃ na virecanam||169||  kāmaṃ tu payasā tasya nirūhairvā harenmalān|  nirūho balamagniṃ ca vijvaratvaṃ mudaṃ rucim||170||  paripakveṣu doṣeṣu prayuktaḥ śīghramāvahet| pittaṃ vā kaphapittaṃ vā pittāśayagataṃ haret||171||  sraṃsanaṃ trīnmalān bastirharet pakvāśayasthitān|172|
translation: When fever persists due to a decline in vitality, one shouldn't resort to purgation or emesis, instead, one should administer a cooling concoction to the patient. This approach will strengthen the body, enhance digestive fire, promote complexion, and increase comfort. Once the doshas (humors) have fully matured, they should be quickly eliminated using appropriate measures, such as medicinal emesis, to remove excess bile, or an enema for fully matured impurities.

sloka: jvare purāṇe saṅkṣīṇe kaphapitte dṛḍhāgnaye||172||  rūkṣabaddhapurīṣāya pradadyādanuvāsanam|173|
translation: In an advanced stage of an old fever, when it has become firmly established and diminished, with an increase in phlegm and bile, one should give, as required, therapeutic emesis and purgation to the patient. Use clarified butter to stimulate digestion and quickly eliminate the aggravated doshas from their abnormal location in the body. This will promote strength, lightness, happiness, and contentment when the body's tissues are properly nourished. It will also help evacuate the excess bile and phlegm that have left their normal location in the body. The three bastis should be administered after digestion, when the doshas are mature.

sloka: gaurave śirasaḥ śūle vibaddheṣvindriyeṣu ca||173||  jīrṇajvare rucikaraṃ kuryānmūrdhavirecanam|174|
translation: In the context of a severe, advanced fever, one should perform head ablutions using astringent, heating, and binding substances for phlegm and bile, and administer an enema using a binding agent.

sloka: abhyaṅgāṃśca pradehāṃśca pariṣekāvagāhane||174||  vibhajya śītoṣṇakṛtaṃ  kuryājjīrṇe jvare bhiṣak|  tairāśu praśamaṃ yāti bahirmārgagato jvaraḥ||175||  labhante sukhamaṅgāni balaṃ varṇaśca vardhate|176|  dhūpanāñjanayogaiśca yānti jīrṇajvarāḥ śamam||176||  tvaṅmātraśeṣā yeṣāṃ ca bhavatyāganturanvayaḥ|177|
translation: With due reverence, one should perform abhyanga and pariseka on the limbs, dividing them appropriately in cases of jwara when the body temperature is either decreased or increased. One should apply medicinal treatments to those afflicted with fever. By following this method, the external fever is pacified. They attain comfort, strength, and improved complexion. With the use of dhupana and anjana , even chronic fever patients can find relief. Those who abandon all other treatments, focusing solely on therapies that involve the tongue , will experience a departure from fever and its associated symptoms.

sloka: iti kriyākramaḥ siddho jvaraghnaḥ samprakāśitaḥ||177||  yeṣāṃ tveṣa kramastāni dravyāṇyūrdhvamataḥ śṛṇu|  raktaśālyādayaḥ śastāḥ purāṇāḥ ṣaṣṭikaiḥ saha||178||  yavāgvodanalājārthe jvaritānāṃ jvarāpahāḥ|179|
translation: The fever-curing sequence has been revealed, consisting of abhyanga (oil massage), followed by applying decoctions, and then cold or warm treatments, according to the fever's stage. By using ṣaṣṭika grain recipes, raktaśālya, and ancient treatments, fevers caused by various ailments can be cured. Quick relief can be achieved through fumigation, applying medicinal powders, and consuming appropriate internal medicines. Once fevers have run their course, strength returns, complexion improves, and fever subsides in those who follow this method, experiencing comfort in their bodies. Furthermore, external remedies like āñjana can help reduce fevers caused by external factors.

sloka: lājapeyāṃ sukhajarāṃ pippalīnāgaraiḥ śṛtām||179||  pibejjvarī jvaraharāṃ kṣudvānalpāgnirāditaḥ|  amlābhilāṣī tāmeva dāḍimāmlāṃ sanāgarām||180||
translation: In the sequence of rituals, here are described the means for those seeking to alleviate fever in the future. I will explain the superior efficacy of red grains, barley, and wheat, as prescribed in ancient texts for fever relief. You should administer this sour tamarind concoction to the patient.

sloka: sṛṣṭaviṭ paittiko vā'tha śītāṃ madhuyutāṃ pibet|  peyāṃ vā raktaśālīnāṃ pārśvabastiśiroruji||181||  śvadaṃṣṭrākaṇṭakāribhyāṃ siddhāṃ jvaraharāṃ pibet|  jvarātisārī peyāṃ vā pibet sāmlāṃ śṛtāṃ naraḥ||182||  pṛśniparṇībalābilvanāgarotpaladhānyakaiḥ|  śṛtāṃ vidārīgandhādyairdīpanīṃ svedanīṃ naraḥ||183||  kāsī śvāsī ca hikkī ca yavāgūṃ jvaritaḥ pibet|  vibaddhavarcāḥ sayavāṃ pippalyāmalakaiḥ śṛtām||184||
translation: Let a feverish person first sip a drink that brings happiness and counters aging, specifically prepared with Pippali and Nagara herbs; then, one desiring a sour taste should drink a concoction prepared with Dadima and Amla fruits; next, drink something cool to alleviate the fever; and finally, enjoy a soothing beverage made from Kasha grains, sweetened with sugar, Yavagu cereal, and warm water.

sloka: sarpiṣmatīṃ pibet peyāṃ jvarī doṣānulomanīm|  koṣṭhe vibaddhe saruji pibet peyāṃ śṛtāṃ jvarī||185||  mṛdvīkāpippalīmūlacavyāmalakanāgaraiḥ|  pibet sabilvāṃ peyāṃ vā jvare saparikartike||186||
translation: One should drink the cool, honey-like liquid, free from bile and phlegm impurities. Also, drink the sweat-inducing liquid, made from rice, barley, pippali, vidārī, gandha, ādya, dīpanī, and kāsa juices, mixed with water, as it wards off fever. Moreover, consume the liquid extracted from utpala, dhānyaka, bilva, nāgara roots, and pippali, āmalakī leaves, which is beneficial for those weakened by disease and has lost their luster. (185-186)

sloka: balāvṛkṣāmlakolāmlakalaśīdhāvanīśṛtām|  asvedanidrastṛṣṇārtaḥ pibet peyāṃ saśarkarām||187||  nāgarāmalakaiḥ siddhāṃ ghṛtabhṛṣṭāṃ jvarāpahām|188|
translation:
Let one afflicted by thirst drink, for his relief, the purified mixture, now ready, consisting of ghee blended with juices of pippali, pippalīmūla, cavya, āmalaka, nāgaraiḥ, and śabilvām, all of which have been bound in a cloth and placed in a pot. (187)
This very mixture, when consumed, can alleviate fevers arising from an imbalance in the bodily constituents. (188)

sloka: mudgānmasūrāṃścaṇakān kulatthān samakuṣṭakān||188||  yūṣārthe yūṣasātmyānāṃ  jvaritānāṃ pradāpayet|189|
translation: For those afflicted by fever and resembling a withered tree, one should administer, as a drink, a mixture of sugar, ghee, and ripe āmalaka fruits to invigorate the self consisting of body and senses.

sloka: paṭolapatraṃ saphalaṃ kulakaṃ pāpacelikam||189||  karkoṭakaṃ kaṭhillaṃ ca vidyācchākaṃ jvare hitam|190|
translation: For someone afflicted by fever, a preparation made from patola (trailanga beans), ulupa (masura grains), chanaka ( vegetables), kulattha (kulattha beans), samaka (samak grains), and yusha, when administered, will prove beneficial; such a concoction, being successful and pure, can counteract evil tendencies.

sloka: lāvān kapiñjalāneṇāṃścakorānupacakrakān||190||  kuraṅgān kālapucchāṃśca hariṇān pṛṣatāñchaśān|  pradadyānmāṃsasātmyāya jvaritāya jvarāpahān||191||  īṣadamlānanamlān vā rasān kāle vicakṣaṇaḥ|  kukkuṭāṃśca mayūrāṃśca tittirikrauñcavartakān||192||  gurūṣṇatvānna śaṃsanti jvare keciccikitsakāḥ|  laṅghanenānilabalaṃ jvare yadyadhikaṃ bhavet||193||  bhiṣaṅmātrāvikalpajño  dadyāttānapi kālavit|194|
translation: With a mat spread out, one should carefully offer termites, creepers, rice, fragments of pots, pebbles, shells, lumps of salt to a fever-stricken patient. This is said to be beneficial for the patient. A discerning person, knowledgeable about the proper time, should offer fresh leaves and water. Additionally, chickens, peacocks, partridges, hawks can be given, as some experts consider them helpful in treating fever. However, one should not forcibly administer these remedies if the patient's strength is diminished. A knowledgeable healer should carefully administer these treatments at appropriate times, considering their effects.

sloka: gharmāmbu cānupānārthaṃ tṛṣitāya pradāpayet||194||  madyaṃ vā madyasātmyāya yathādoṣaṃ yathābalam|195|
translation: For alleviating thirst in this world, one should give cool water or an appropriate amount of alcohol, considering the individual's tolerance and potential ill effects. Likewise, a skilled physician may administer a moderate amount of sour food or a therapeutic treatment that increases body heat, if suitable for a feverish patient.

sloka: gurūṣṇasnigdhamadhurān kaṣāyāṃśca navajvare||195||  āhārān doṣapaktyarthaṃ prāyaśaḥ parivarjayet|  annapānakramaḥ siddho jvaraghnaḥ samprakāśitaḥ||196||
translation: One should offer fresh, sweet water and food, not tainted by faults, to the revered guru and those who possess noble qualities and are new to the job. This practice, conducive for nurturing friendliness, is also well-known to counteract fever.

sloka: ata ūrdhvaṃ pravakṣyante kaṣāyā jvaranāśanāḥ|  pākyaṃ śītakaṣāyaṃ vā mustaparpaṭakaṃ pibet||197||  sanāgaraṃ parpaṭakaṃ pibedvā sadurālabham|  kirātatiktakaṃ mustaṃ guḍūcīṃ viśvabheṣajam||198||  pāṭhāmuśīraṃ sodīcyaṃ pibedvā jvaraśāntaye|  jvaraghnā dīpanāścaite kaṣāyā doṣapācanāḥ||199||  tṛṣṇārucipraśamanā mukhavairasyanāśanāḥ|200|
translation: The revered teacher shall hereafter disclose the following fever-alleviating remedies: a coolant, namely, water mixed with musta or parpataka, or a drink prepared with shade-dried sugar; a potion of sanaka, gara, parpataka, or a drink mixed with kiratatiktaka, musta, and guducī; a decoction of pathsamushira, sudīcya, or a drink that pacifies impurities; these, being fever-subduing, light-giving, and eliminators of oral bitterness, shall be spoken of as powerful medicinal concoctions.

sloka: kaliṅgakāḥ paṭolasya patraṃ kaṭukarohiṇī||200||  paṭolaḥ sārivā mustaṃ pāṭhā kaṭukarohiṇī|  nimbaḥ paṭolastriphalā mṛdvīkā mustavatsakau|| 201||   kirātatiktamamṛtā candanaṃ viśvabheṣajam|  guḍūcyāmalakaṃ mustamardhaślokasamāpanāḥ||c02||  kaṣāyāḥ śamayantyāśu pañca pañcavidhāñjvarān|  santataṃ satatānyedyustṛtīyakacaturthakān||203||
translation: Ahead, it will be described what provides relief for fevers caused by five types of bile: one should consume hot or cold water, as well as musta, guduchi, vataka, kirata tiktaka, and usheera. These remedies help reduce the intensity of the bile, eliminate it, and alleviate symptoms such as thirst, loss of appetite, aversion to speech, and other disorders.

sloka: vatsakāragvadhau pāṭhāṃ ṣaḍgranthāṃ kaṭurohiṇīm|  mūrvāṃ sātiviṣāṃ nimbaṃ paṭolaṃ dhanvayāsakam||204||  vacāṃ mustamuśīraṃ ca madhukaṃ triphalāṃ balām|  pākyaṃ śītakaṣāyaṃ vā pibejjvaraharaṃ naraḥ||205||  madhūkamustamṛdvīkākāśmaryāṇi parūṣakam|  trāyamāṇāmuśīraṃ ca triphalāṃ kaṭurohiṇīm||206||  pītvā niśisthitaṃ janturjvarācchīghraṃ vimucyate|207|
translation: A person suffering from chronic fever, whether they are of Kalinga or Kirata descent, can find relief by consuming either the fresh or dried leaves of the Patala tree, combined with a preparation of musta, triphala, nimba, and vatsaka. Alternatively, they can consume a mixture of honey, madhuka, pippali, and vatsakau, or a remedy made from guducti, amalaki, candana, and visva bhesaja. These remedies, when taken, quickly alleviate the five types of fever that persist continuously or occur at regular intervals.

sloka: jātyāmalakamustāni tadvaddhanvayavāsakam||207||  vibaddhadoṣo jvaritaḥ kaṣāyaṃ saguḍaṃ pibet|  triphalāṃ trāyamāṇāṃ ca mṛdvīkāṃ kaṭurohiṇīm||208||  pittaśleṣmaharastveṣa kaṣāyo hyānulomikaḥ|  trivṛtāśarkarāyuktaḥ pittaśleṣmajvarāpahaḥ||209||
translation: In the present time, an afflicted person suffering from a fever caused by a flaw (poison) should drink a mixture prepared from āmalaka and musta fruits, as well as a decoction made from dhanvaya, which has been treated to remove any impurities, along with triphalā, which is being treated, and a bitter variety of kaṭurohṇī, which promotes digestion. This mixture, which includes trivṛta, śarkarā, and is instrumental in alleviating fever and eliminating impurities from pitta and śleṣma, should be consumed.

sloka: bṛhatyau vatsakaṃ mustaṃ devadāru mahauṣadham|  kolavallī ca yogo'yaṃ sannipātajvarāpahaḥ||210||
translation: This medicinal concoction, consisting of a pair of large deodar creeper branches, mustard seeds, āmalaka fruit, and kolavallī plant, as well as being bound by a minor fault, is declared to be a remedy for fevers, phlegm, bile, and impurities when consumed with honey, molasses, rock candy, and triple-fruit; indeed, it is known as such in the texts.

sloka: śaṭī puṣkaramūlaṃ ca vyāghrī śṛṅgī durālabhā|  guḍūcī nāgaraṃ pāṭhā kirātaṃ kaṭurohiṇī||211||  eṣa śaṭyādiko vargaḥ sannipātajvarāpahaḥ|  kāsahṛdgrahapārśvārtiśvāsatandrāsu śasyate||212||
translation: This set, including the mustard-seed-sized puṣkaramūla and the hard-to-find guḍūcī, as well as nāgaram, pāṭhā, kirātam, kaṭurohiṇī, and others, is known to counteract conditions such as aggregated disorders, fever, and various ailments that arise in the vicinity of bodily parts.

sloka: bṛhatyau pauṣkaraṃ bhārgī śaṭī śṛṅgī durālabhā|  vatsakasya ca bījāni paṭolaṃ kaṭurohiṇī||213||  bṛhatyādirgaṇaḥ proktaḥ sannipātajvarāpahaḥ|  kāsādiṣu ca sarveṣu dadyāt sopadraveṣu ca||214||
translation: The powerful Paushkara root, named Bhargi, combined with Shatii, and the hardy, singular Shringi - all these, when combined with the seeds of Vatsaka, make the bitter Rohini, known as Brihati, and also as Adi in various mixtures; it is prescribed for all kinds of Kasa and other ailments, as well as in emergencies.

sloka: kaṣāyāśca yavāgvaśca pipāsājvaranāśanāḥ|  nirdiṣṭā bheṣajādhyāye bhiṣaktānapi yojayet||215||
translation: The two powerful medicinal plants, Bhargi and Shatii, along with the seeds of Paulom, Kaatu, and Rohiṇi, classified as a group known as Sannipāta, should indeed be employed by physicians; they are precisely designated as remedies in treatises for eliminating fevers, cough, and other diseases.

sloka: jvarāḥ kaṣāyairvamanairlaṅghanairlaghubhojanaiḥ|  rūkṣasya ye na śāmyanti sarpisteṣāṃ bhiṣagjitam||216||  rūkṣaṃ tejo jvarakaraṃ tejasā rūkṣitasya ca|  yaḥ syādanubalo dhātuḥ snehavadhyaḥ  sa cānilaḥ||217||
translation: Even by employing light eating, astringent food, and purgatives, those fevers that do not abate are, in the medical treatises, called sarpishtha. The one who, being weaker than the dry bodily constituent (rūkṣa), enhances it, resembling the wind's quality, is known as the fever-aggravating factor.

sloka: kaṣāyāḥ sarva evaite sarpiṣā saha yojitāḥ|  prayojyā jvaraśāntyarthamagnisandhukṣaṇāḥ śivāḥ||218||
translation: The impurities themselves, all of them, are indeed joined with ghee in these instances. For the purpose of pacifying fevers, they are to be deliberately employed as mild, balancing, and penetrating agents, namely ghee. The doshas (bodily humors) that have become vitiated are counteracted by the power of ghee, which in turn pacifies fevers caused by impurities and aggravation of bodily tissues. Furthermore, the wind element present in ghee aids in eliminating toxins from the body.

sloka: pippalyaścandanaṃ mustamuśīraṃ kaṭurohiṇī|  kaliṅgakāstāmalakī sārivā'tiviṣā sthirā||219||  drākṣāmalakabilvāni trāyamāṇā nidigdhikā|  siddhamitairghṛtaṃ sadyo jīrṇajvaramapohati||220||  kṣayaṃ kāsaṃ śiraḥśūlaṃ pārśvaśūlaṃ halīmakam|  aṃsābhitāpamāgniṃ ca viṣamaṃ sanniyacchati||221||
translation: The resins of pippalī, candana, musta, uśīra, as well as the Rohiṇī kāṣṭa of Kaliṅga and āmalakī, combined with ghee, alleviate fever and other ailments caused by an imbalance in bodily humors, when used in a treatment, right away. Similarly, the bilva fruits, processed and made free from impurities with ghee, can alleviate conditions like consumption, fever, headache, paralysis, and burning sensations, when skillfully applied.

sloka: vāsāṃ guḍūcīṃ triphalāṃ trāyamāṇāṃ yavāsakam|  paktvā tena kaṣāyeṇa payasā dviguṇena ca||222||  pippalīmustamṛdvīkācandanotpalanāgaraiḥ|  kalkīkṛtaiśca vipaceddhṛtaṃ jīrṇajvarāpaham||223||
translation: Prepared using the juices of pippalī, candana, musta, urali, this concoction, including those of bilva, draksha, kashta, amalaki, guḍūcī, triphalā, currently being processed, is mixed with sesame, ghruta, and siddhamita, as well as with fresh juices. It quickly cures chronic fever, eliminating it from the body, subduing bile, wind, and phlegm, pacifying burning sensations, poison, and other ailments, having been treated by Kalkī with treated ingredients.

sloka: balāṃ śvadaṃṣṭrāṃ bṛhatīṃ kalasīṃ dhāvanīṃ sthirām|  nimbaṃ parpaṭakaṃ mustaṃ trāyamāṇāṃ durālabhām||224||  kṛtvā kaṣāyaṃ peṣyārthe dadyāttāmalakīṃ śaṭīm|  drākṣāṃ puṣkaramūlaṃ ca medāmāmalakāni ca||225||  ghṛtaṃ payaśca tat siddhaṃ sarpirjvaraharaṃ param|  kṣayakāsaśiraḥśūlapārśvaśūlāṃsatāpanut  ||226||
translation: Prepare a concoction by boiling the three fruits of Guḍūcī, triphalā, and Yavāsaka, mixed with twice the quantity of milk and water. To this, add crushed Musta, Mṛdvīka, Candana, Utpalā, Nāgarai, and Kalkī, all reduced to powder. This potion, regularly consumed, alleviates consumptive fevers and other chronic ailments.

sloka: jvaribhyo bahudoṣebhya ūrdhvaṃ cādhaśca buddhimān|  dadyāt saṃśodhanaṃ kāle kalpe yadupadekṣyate||227||
translation: A clear-minded individual should offer purification at the appointed time, separating and removing from pitta fever various impurities: the strength of a wolf's teeth, greatness of a mortar and pestle, firmness of a nimba fruit, instability of a creeping vine, hard-to-find quality of a durva grass, bitterness of an amalaki fruit, sourness of a shati fruit, sweetness of a grape, and coolness of a lotus root, as described. This eliminates fever's harmful effects, reducing fever's severity, destroying it at its root, and curing cough, wasting of the body, and headache that accompany it.

sloka: madanaṃ pippalībhirvā kaliṅgairmadhukena vā|  yuktamuṣṇāmbunā peyaṃ vamanaṃ jvaraśāntaye||228||  kṣaudrāmbunā rasenekṣorathavā lavaṇāmbunā|  jvare pracchardanaṃ śastaṃ madyairvā tarpaṇena vā||229||
translation: For alleviating fever, which arises from an accumulation of impurities both internally and externally, an intelligent person should administer, at the proper time, a purgative made with pepper decoctions and kaliṅga, or simply with warm water, or by inducing sweating through alcohol, or even by appeasing it with madira.

sloka: mṛdvīkāmalakānāṃ vā rasaṃ praskandanaṃ pibet|  rasamāmalakānāṃ vā ghṛtabhṛṣṭaṃ jvarāpaham||230||
translation: One should drink the sap of mridvika (bitter gourd or Indian coral tree) that has been boiled with honey or hot/regular water, or consume the juice of Indian radish or rock salt, as such actions, respectively, alleviate thirst, fever, and fever with burning sensation. Alternatively, consuming alcohol is recommended for certain types of fever.

sloka: lihyādvā traivṛtaṃ cūrṇaṃ saṃyuktaṃ madhusarpiṣā|  pibedvā kṣaudramāvāpya saghṛtaṃ triphalārasam||231||  āragvadhaṃ vā payasā mṛdvīkānāṃ rasena vā|  trivṛtāṃ trāyamāṇāṃ vā payasā jvaritaḥ pibet||232||  jvarādvimucyate pītvā mṛdvīkābhiḥ sahābhayām|  payo'nupānamuṣṇaṃ vā pītvā drākṣārasaṃ naraḥ||233||
translation: One may optionally drink a liquid produced by crushing and grinding three myrobalans, which has been mixed with honey or ghee, or juice of āmalaka fruits; after drinking it, either mixed with water from mṛdvīka or on its own, one is freed from fever. This is achieved by causing [the liquid] to be drunk, or by drinking a heated version of it.

sloka: kāsācchvāsācchiraḥśūlātpārśvaśūlāccirajvarāt|  mucyate jvaritaḥ pītvā pañcamūlīśṛtaṃ payaḥ||234||
translation: The fever-stricken person is liberated from the fever by drinking a concoction prepared from the roots of a medicinal plant, which is sweet and buttery, and consists of the sap of five types, as well as a decoction made from the three fruits of the tree, warm milk, and drumstick leaves, all taken together.

sloka: eraṇḍamūlotkvathitaṃ jvarāt saparikartikāt| payo vimucyate pītvā tadvadbilvaśalāṭubhiḥ||235||
translation: One is liberated from severe fever by drinking water drawn from a palm tree's root, extracted using a swing and rope, such as it is with this method using bilva-śala and other similar instruments.

sloka: trikaṇṭakabalāvyāghrīguḍanāgarasādhitam|  varcomūtravibandhaghnaṃ śophajvaraharaṃ payaḥ||236||
translation: Preparing a decoction with Eranda stem and Bilva leaves endows one with strength, and consuming this water destroys fever, just as fully ripening and consuming the fruit itself.

sloka: sanāgaraṃ samṛdvīkaṃ saghṛtakṣaudraśarkaram|  śṛtaṃ payaḥ sakharjūraṃ pipāsājvaranāśanam||237||
translation: As a well-constructed harbor overcomes the challenges of sand, stones, and salt-ridden shells, it is called such; it neutralizes thirst and fever, and yields sweet and clear water.

sloka: caturguṇenāmbhasā vā śṛtaṃ jvaraharaṃ payaḥ|  dhāroṣṇaṃ vā payaḥ sadyo vātapittajvaraṃ jayet||238||
translation: Made swiftly with salty-bitter ingredients, milk or buttermilk can cure fevers caused by an imbalance of the wind and bile elements, or alternatively, they can be victorious over such fevers.

sloka: jīrṇajvarāṇāṃ sarveṣāṃ payaḥ praśamanaṃ param| peyaṃ taduṣṇaṃ śītaṃ vā yathāsvaṃ bheṣajaiḥ śṛtam||239||
translation: Of all remedies for chronic fever, drinking large quantities of water, either cold or at room temperature, as medicine prescribes, is the supreme soother.

sloka: prayojayejjvaraharānnirūhān sānuvāsanān|  pakvāśayagate doṣe vakṣyante ye ca siddhiṣu||240||
translation: The fever-reducing remedy should be prepared using milk, which can be consumed either hot or cold as per one's liking, as explained in the texts dealing with the accomplishment of various successes (such as alchemical siddhis).

sloka: paṭolāriṣṭapatrāṇi sośīraścaturaṅgulaḥ|  hrīberaṃ rohiṇī tiktā śvadaṃṣṭrā madanāni ca||241||  sthirā balā ca tat sarvaṃ payasyardhodake śṛtam|  kṣīrāvaśeṣaṃ niryūhaṃ saṃyuktaṃ madhusarpiṣā||242||  kalkairmadanamustānāṃ pippalyā madhukasya ca|  vatsakasya ca saṃyuktaṃ bastiṃ dadyājjvarāpaham||243||
translation: In this context, the means of achieving success involves defeating the causes of disease, eliminating residual impurities, and expelling matured wastes from the body. Specifically, one who aims to cure a fever should combine pippali with madhuka, prepare a decoction of patola, usira, and four angulas of rhizomes, add rohini, which is slightly pungent, and madana, along with matured kshira and leftover buttermilk, all mixed together with honey and sarpi. This concoction, prepared as instructed, serves as a fever-curing remedy.

sloka: śuddhe mārge hṛte doṣe viprasanneṣu dhātuṣu|  gatāṅgaśūlo laghvaṅgaḥ sadyo bhavati vijvaraḥ||244||
translation: Upon the pure path, having discarded impurities and having achieved stable states in the elements, one can promptly become fever-free, as [the result of] a concoction made from usheera, patala, and arista being consumed.

sloka: āragvadhamuśīraṃ ca madanasya phalaṃ tathā|  catasraḥ parṇinīścaiva [1] niryūhamupakalpayet||245||  priyaṅgurmadanaṃ mustaṃ śatāhvā madhuyaṣṭikā|  kalkaḥ sarpirguḍaḥ kṣaudraṃ jvaraghno bastiruttamaḥ||246||
translation: By pursuing the unblemished path, establishing virtuous qualities in one's bodily elements, and having pure traits in senses, one gains agility in limbs, swiftly recuperating from sickness; as well as consuming juicy priyangu fruits, musta, madhu, yashtika, kalka, sarpi, guda, and the excellent basti, which are all illness-dispelling.

sloka: guḍūcīṃ trāyamāṇāṃ ca candanaṃ madhukaṃ vṛṣam|  sthirāṃ balāṃ pṛśniparṇīṃ madanaṃ ceti sādhayet||247||  rasaṃ jāṅgalamāṃsasya rasena sahitaṃ bhiṣak|  pippalīphalamustānāṃ kalkena madhukasya ca||248||  īṣatsalavaṇaṃ yuktyā nirūhaṃ madhusarpiṣā|  jvarapraśamanaṃ dadyādbalasvedarucipradam||249||
translation: One should prepare a medicinal concoction using

sloka: jīvantīṃ madhukaṃ medāṃ pippalīṃ madanaṃ vacām|  ṛddhiṃ rāsnāṃ balāṃ viśvaṃ [2] śatapuṣpāṃ śatāvarīm||250||  piṣṭvā kṣīraṃ jalaṃ sarpistailaṃ ca vipacedbhiṣak|  ānuvāsanikaṃ snehametaṃ vidyājjvarāpaham||251||
translation: By pulverizing kṣīra (cream of milk), jala (water), sarpiḥ (clarified butter), and taila (sesame oil), mixed with a concoction of pippalī (long pepper), treated guḍūcī and madhuka juices, and powdered madhukasya fruit, along with a sprinkle of salt and mustard seeds, as directed by an expert physician, one can prepare a potion that alleviates jvara (fever), enhances strength, promotes sweating, and improves digestion.

sloka: paṭolapicumardābhyāṃ guḍūcyā madhukena ca|  madanaiśca śṛtaḥ sneho jvaraghnamanuvāsanam||252||
translation: After churning together curd, water, ghee, and sesame oil, the doctor should administer this coolant as a remedy, which has been instilled with passion and serves to quell fever. (252)

sloka: candanāgurukāśmaryapaṭolamadhukotpalaiḥ|  siddhaḥ sneho jvaraharaḥ snehabastiḥ praśasyate||253||
translation: Prepared from Chandana, Patola, honey, and Madhuka, the fever-curing ointment, referred to as Sneha, is praised as an effective remedy.

sloka: yaduktaṃ bheṣajādhyāye vimāne rogabheṣaje|  śirovirecanaṃ kuryādyuktijñastajjvarāpaham||254||  yacca nāvanikaṃ tailaṃ yāśca tailaṃ yāśca prāgdhūmavartayaḥ|  mātrāśitīye nirdiṣṭāḥ prayojyāstā jvareṣvapi||255||
translation: In the context of treating fever, one should apply a medicated enema, as has been stated, which is prepared in the following way: Take a decoction made from the bark of sandalwood, kasha, kapikachhu, patala, and madhuka trees, combined with sesame oil, and an amount of ghee and honey as appropriate, in accordance with the instructions of the medical textbook. This treatment should be applied, even in other types of fevers, as it has been indicated and advocated for use in such situations.

sloka: abhyaṅgāṃśca pradehāṃśca pariṣekāṃśca kārayet|  yathābhilāṣaṃ śītoṣṇaṃ vibhajya dvividhaṃ jvaram||256|| sahasradhautaṃ sarpirvā tailaṃ vā candanādikam|  dāhajvarapraśamanaṃ dadyādabhyañjanaṃ bhiṣak||257||
translation: As prescribed in the treatment chapter, the doctor should causatively make (i.e., cause) the application of ointments and the anointing of various parts of the body, as well as the sprinkling of liquids, dividing the fever into two types according to desire and whether it is hot or cold. He should administer a remedy for fevers that are a thousand times worse, such as oil or sandalwood paste, whose smoke has been specified.

sloka: bhavanti cātra  pauṣkareṣu suśīteṣu padmotpaladaleṣu ca|  kadalīnāṃ ca patreṣu kṣaumeṣu vimaleṣu ca||260||
translation: In the cool season, during dew-fresh mornings, [they] become manifest on lotus petals, golden banana leaves, and on the calyxes of water lilies, that indeed are thoroughly purified; one should perform oil anointment and sprinkling as desired, following the two methods of treatment for sandalwood and other cooling substances mixed with ghee or oil, which alleviate burning fever.

sloka: candanodakaśīteṣu śīte  dhārāgṛhe'pi vā|  himāmbusikte sadane dāhārtaḥ  saṃviśet sukham||261||
translation: He/she will delightfully settle in the well-cooled areas made by pauṣkara trees, adorned with lotuses and blue water lilies in their ponds, as well as in a clean, clear location near banana plant's patras.

sloka: hemaśaṅkhapravālānāṃ maṇīnāṃ mauktikasya ca|  candanodakaśītānāṃ saṃsparśānurasān  spṛśet||262||  sragbhirnīlotpalaiḥ padmairvyajanairvividhairapi|  śītavātāvahairvyajjyeccandanodakavarṣibhiḥ  ||263||
translation: In the dwellings of pearls, shells, and golden filaments, one should touch/sprinkle (themselves) with the cool, sandalwood-infused water and drizzles available there, to alleviate heat. Likewise, they should make use of various fans made from cool breezes, fragrant blue lotus flowers, and other such leaves and petals.

sloka: nadyastaḍāgāḥ padminyo hradāśca vimalodakāḥ|  avagāhe hitā dāhatṛṣṇāglānijvarāpahāḥ||264||
translation: Approaching the clear waters of rivers, ponds, and elephant goads, as well as sandalwood, adorned with various blue lotuses , and cooled by water lilies, white lilies, and soothing breezes, all of which are cooling , indeed brings benefit; these, namely, the conch, pearl, etc., destroy thirst, fever, and other ailments .

sloka: priyāḥ pradakṣiṇācārāḥ pramadāścandanokṣitāḥ|  sāntvayeyuḥ paraiḥ kāmairmaṇimauktikabhūṣaṇāḥ||265||
translation: The pleasingly flowing waters, adorned with pure sandalpaste, that alleviate people's afflictions and are desired by others should be respectfully approached using alluring charms by those who are pure in conduct.

sloka: śītāni cānnapānāni śītānyupavanāni ca|  vāyavaścandrapādāśca śītā dāhajvarāpahāḥ||266||
translation: "Cool drinks and shady groves, as well as cooling breezes and the moon's calming light, indeed alleviate burning heat. Similarly, pleasing conduct, self-restraint, and serenity, along with sandalwood paste and pearl ornaments, can also soothe and delight the mind."

sloka: bhavanti cātra  trayodaśavidhaḥ svedaḥ svedādhyāye nidarśitaḥ| mātrākālavidā yuktaḥ sa ca śītajvarāpahaḥ||268||
translation: Here, thirteen types of sweats are described in the relevant chapter. When combined with the proper measure of time, a coolant can effectively counteract fever, as demonstrated by cool foods, parkland breezes, and the moon's cooling footsteps.

sloka: sā kuṭī tacca śayanaṃ taccāvacchādanaṃ jvaram|  śītaṃ praśamayantyāśu dhūpāścāgurujā ghanāḥ||269||
translation: Here, the sweat of thirteen types, as described in the text, arising from physical and mental exertion, is capable of alleviating cold and fever when used appropriately with time and quantity. Specifically, it can be cooled down, caused to subside quickly by incense made from aguru and other substances, which are heavy, fragrant, and plentiful.

sloka: cārūpacitagātryaśca taruṇyo yauvanoṣmaṇā|  āśleṣācchamayantyāśu pramadāḥ śiśirajvaram||270||
translation: With her elegant form, having been adorned, she, along with the young women, disperses the summer heat by embracing the coolness of the evening, while being engaged in spreading soothing sandalwood smoke, just like the cool breeze of the winter season; she is rejuvenation itself.

sloka: svedanānyannapānāni vātaśleṣmaharāṇi ca|  śītajvaraṃ jayantyāśu saṃsargabalayojanāt||271||
translation: Beautifully adorned and youthful bodies are made weak by the close embrace of lust and thoughtlessness, leading to wasting away and susceptibility to fevers caused by an imbalance in the body's constitution, due to the influence of cold and other external factors.

sloka: vātaje śramaje caiva purāṇe kṣataje jvare|  laṅghanaṃ na hitaṃ vidyācchamanaistānupācaret||272||
translation: In cases of old wounds, exhaustion, and fever, one should not consume sweating and other excretions; such restraint is understood to be beneficial and conducive to quick recovery.

sloka: vikṣipyāmāśayoṣmāṇaṃ yasmādgatvā rasaṃ nṛṇām|  jvaraṃ kurvanti doṣāstu hīyate'gnibalaṃ tataḥ||273||
translation: The disruption of mental calm and depletion of vitality in humans occurs from where , due to neglecting the proper treatment of wounds and not maintaining traditional practices . This results in fever being caused by harmful factors . Additionally, Agni's strength within them diminishes , leading to a loss of essential vitality .

sloka: yathā prajvalito vahniḥ sthālyāmindhanavānapi|  na pacatyodanaṃ samyaganilaprerito bahiḥ||274||
translation: Even when a fire is well kindled on dry fuel, it does not consume it entirely if it isn't fanned from outside; similarly, a person's vitality gets depleted by the internal heat generated from digesting food.

sloka: paktisthānāttathā doṣairūṣmā kṣipto bahirnṛṇām|  na pacatyabhyavahṛtaṃ kṛcchrāt pacati vā laghu||275||
translation: Just like a blazing fire, when driven away from its fuel source, becomes agitated by flaws such as inappropriate fuel or insufficient wind, it does not cook food nor is it cooked.

sloka: ato'gnibalarakṣārthaṃ laṅghanādikramo hitaḥ|  saptāhena hi pacyante saptadhātugatā malāḥ||276||
translation: Therefore, moving around (fire) for the purpose of protecting it is beneficial; indeed, malas inherent in the body's seven constituents are purified and eliminated through this seven-day process.

sloka: nirāmaścāpyataḥ prokto jvaraḥ prāyo'ṣṭame'hani|  udīrṇadoṣastvalpāgniraśnan guru viśeṣataḥ||277||
translation: "Rooted in the seventh form of fire, agni, this dosha, which is generally referred to as jvara, can be eliminated through special measures when it has become prominent and there is a lack of strength . This weakness or loss of strength is caused by this dosha, which has spread in the tenth part of the body. This is what is indicated by the passive past participle 'proktaḥ' and the present participle 'aśnan'."

sloka: mucyate sahasā prāṇaiściraṃ kliśyati vā naraḥ|  etasmātkāraṇādvidvān vātike'pyādito jvare||278||
translation: A person is instantly liberated from or tormented for a prolonged period by the fever that typically arises on the eighth day, either due to improper digestion resulting from overeating or a weakened digestive capacity, all because of this reason, as previously stated by the knowledgeable one, even when struck by it in the open air.

sloka: nāti gurvati vā snigdhaṃ bhojayet sahasā naram|  jvare mārutaje tvādāvanapekṣyāpi hi kramam||279||
translation: A knowing person should not suddenly cause someone to partake of greasy food, whether it be a respected teacher or not; especially in the context of a fever caused by imbalanced wind, one should not neglect to gradually introduce food, for such neglect could hasten the patient's death and cause prolonged suffering.

sloka: kuryānniranubandhānāmabhyaṅgādīnupakramān|  pāyayitvā kaṣāyaṃ ca bhojayedrasabhojanam||280||  jīrṇajvaraharaṃ kuryāt sarvaśaścāpyupakramam|  śleṣmalānāmavātānāṃ jvaro'nuṣṇaḥ  kaphādhikaḥ||281||
translation: One should not abruptly provide a sick person, afflicted by fever and given to unctuous or heavy food, with a meal or cold drafts. Instead, one should initially consider the sequence and, if suitable, begin by administering warm barley gruel. Only then should other foods be gradually introduced, according to their capacity and the stage of the illness. This approach alleviates fever caused by an excess of phlegm and wind, as stated earlier.

sloka: paripākaṃ na saptāhenāpi yāti mṛdūṣmaṇām|  taṃ krameṇa yathoktena laṅghanālpāśanādinā||282||  ādaśāhamupakramya kaṣāyādyairupācaret|283|
translation: For those who are not restricted, one should initially engage in the careful maturation process, which should not be hurried even over the course of seven days, using a gentle approach for those with excess heat . Through gradual application of methods such as purgation and emesis , as well as other techniques, remove phlegm, fevers, excess heat, and wind. Additionally, eliminate kapha-related ailments and encourage them to consume nourishing food and beverages that are tasty, conducive to digestion, and help alleviate any fevers or weaknesses.

sloka: sāmā ye ye ca kaphajāḥ kaphapittajvarāśca ye||283||  laṅghanaṃ laṅghanīyoktaṃ teṣu kāryaṃ prati prati|284| vamanaiśca virekaiśca bastibhiśca yathākramam||284||
translation: As for the seven types of both kapha-predominant and pitta-predominant disorders, as well as those accompanied by fever, one should apply, in every instance, the lightening therapeutic measure in accordance with their respective order, through emesis, purgation, and medicated enema; one should begin, in a step-by-step manner, with a light diet and progressively eliminate impurities.

sloka: jvarānupacareddhīmān kaphapittānilodbhavān| saṃsṛṣṭān sannipatitān buddhvā taratamaiḥ samaiḥ||285||
translation: He who is intelligent should treat fevers arising from the imbalance of phlegm, bile, and wind, having understood their manifestation. At appropriate times, he should eliminate them through emesis, purgation, etc., in accordance with their respective natures.

sloka: jvarān doṣakramāpekṣī yathoktairauṣadhairjayet|  vardhanenaikadoṣasya kṣapaṇenocchritasya vā||286||  kaphasthānānupūrvyā vā sannipātajvaraṃ jayet|287|
translation: The wise person should cure fevers by examining the sequence of doshas, as previously outlined in the appropriate medicines: initially by addressing the fever caused by the convergence of these humors, or even after their onset. They should treat fevers by enhancing or reducing the specific dosha, such as kapha's location, in the proper order.

sloka: sannipātajvarasyānte karṇamūle sudārūṇaḥ||287||  śothaḥ sañjāyate tena kaścideva pramucyate|  raktāvasecanaiḥ śīghraṃ sarpiṣpānaiśca taṃ jayet||288||  pradehaiḥ kaphapittaghnairnāvanaiḥ kavalagrahaiḥ|289|
translation: Upon the termination of a fever marked by confluence (of symptoms), an unpleasant discharge arises at the ear opening. One can be liberated from this ailment by employing certain medicines, strengthened with a treatment administered either during day or night, as well as by timely eliminating phlegm and other Kapha-related accumulations using appropriate substances.

sloka: śītoṣṇasnigdharūkṣādyairjvaro yasya na śāmyati||289||  śākhānusārī raktasya  so'vasekāt praśāmyati|290|
translation: When the fever, characterized by cold, heat, and dryness, and manifesting at the earroot, reaches a severe stage, and is alleviated by sudorific and purgative treatments, one should promptly administer medicinal decoctions that reduce kapha and pitta, as this is what calms such a fever in a person.

sloka: visarpeṇābhighātena yaśca visphoṭakairjvaraḥ||290||  tatrādau sarpiṣaḥ pānaṃ kaphapittottaro na cet|291|
translation: The fever that is triggered by chills and sweating, if one is caused to violently erupt using therapeutics, does not subside at the outset if one's diet consists of items like ghee. Likewise, it doesn't abate either if there is an increase in the flow of raktas (blood) according to the veins (sąkhā).

sloka: daurbalyāddehadhātūnāṃ jvaro jīrṇo'nuvartate||291||
translation: Fever, characterized by excessive heat, arises through affliction of the body's constituent elements; initially, it affects the sap and nutrients, subsequently progressing to phlegm and bile, ultimately reaching the uppermost parts.

sloka: balyeḥ sambṛṃhaṇaistasmādāhāraistamupācaret|292| karma sādhāraṇaṃ jahyāttṛtīyakacaturthakau  ||292||
translation: For a weak body, caused by the depletion of its constituents and fever, one should maintain oneself with nourishing foods and activities; one should give up common and tertiary/fourth-level actions.

sloka: āganturanubandho hi prāyaśo viṣamajvare|  vātapradhānaṃ sarpirbhirbastibhiḥ sānuvāsanaiḥ||293||
translation: For in predominant cases of uneven fever, incoming attachments such as a heavy diet should be generally avoided, just as a wind-predominant snake becomes irritated by regular bites of insects during the initial and post-digestion stages.

sloka: snigdhoṣṇairannapānaiśca śamayedviṣamajvaram|  virecanena payasā sarpiṣā saṃskṛtena ca||294||  viṣamaṃ tiktaśītaiśca jvaraṃ pittottaraṃ jayet|
translation: Generally, a feverish condition can be soothed using warm substances such as ghee and by causing purgation, as well as by employing bitter and cooling substances. Additionally, this condition can be conquered by endogenous factors like āgantu associated with vāta, situated in the middle of basti, and vāsanaiḥ cleansing procedures.

sloka: vamanaṃ pācanaṃ rūkṣamannapānaṃ vilaṅghanam||295||  kaṣāyoṣṇaṃ ca viṣame jvare śastaṃ kaphottare|296|
translation: A mild diet, warm liquids, evacuation, payasana, ghee, and processed food can respectively calm, alleviate an irregular fever in its Kaphottara stage, while bitter and cold preparations can overcome Pittottara.

sloka: yogāḥ parāḥ  pravakṣyante viṣamajvaranāśanāḥ||296||  prayoktavyā matimatā doṣādīn pravibhajya te|  surā samaṇḍā pānārthe bhakṣyārthe caraṇāyudhaḥ||297||  tittiriśca mayūraśca prayojyā viṣamajvare|  pibedvā ṣaṭpalaṃ sarpirabhayāṃ vā prayojayet||298||  triphalāyāḥ kaṣāyaṃ vā guḍūcyā rasameva vā|  nīlinīmajagandhāṃ ca trivṛtāṃ kaṭurohiṇīm||299||
translation: In the context of curing diverse forms of poisonous fever, the following methods should be employed in accordance with intelligence: therapeutic emesis, purgation, consumption of rough food, intake of liquids, and elimination of waste products. For severe fevers, one may utilize concoctions derived from kaṣaya, uṣṇa, or viśamajvare herbs. Specific treatments, such as administering kapha-uttara to a serpent, can also be applied. Furthermore, remedies such as consuming triphala decoctions, guḍūcya broth, or nīlinīmajagandhā, as well as using trivṛtā and kaṭurohiṇī, are recommended. The causative present-optative third-person singular form of 'prayuj' (to employ) is used in this context, indicating a recommendation for someone else to carry out these actions.

sloka: pibejjvarāgame yuktyā snehasvedopapāditaḥ|  sarpiṣo mahatīṃ mātrāṃ pītvā vā chardayet punaḥ||300||  upayujyānnapānaṃ vā prabhūtaṃ punarullikhet|  sānnaṃ madyaṃ prabhūtaṃ vā pītvā svapyājjvarāgame||301||  āsthāpanaṃ yāpanaṃ vā kārayedviṣamajvare|  payasā vṛṣadaṃśasya śakṛdvā  tadahaḥ pibet||302||  vṛṣasya dadhimaṇḍena surayā vā  sasaindhavam|  pippalyāstriphalāyāśca dadhnastakrasya sarpiṣaḥ||303||  pañcagavyasya payasaḥ prayogo viṣamajvare|  rasonasya satailasya prāgbhaktamupasevanam||304||  medyānāmuṣṇavīryāṇāmāmiṣāṇāṃ ca bhakṣaṇam|  hiṅgutulyā tu vaiyāghrī vasā nasyaṃ sasaindhavā||305||  purāṇasarpiḥ siṃhasya vasā tadvat sasaindhavā|  saindhavaṃ pippalīnāṃ ca taṇḍulāḥ samanaḥśilāḥ||306||  netrāñjanaṃ tailapiṣṭaṃ śasyate viṣamajvare|  palaṅkaṣā nimbapatraṃ vacā kuṣṭhaṃ harītakī||307||  sarṣapāḥ sayavāḥ sarpirdhūpanaṃ jvaranāśanam|  ye dhūmā dhūpanaṃ yacca nāvanaṃ cāñjanaṃ ca yat||308||
translation:
For different types of fever, carefully administer a large quantity of ghee as the first remedy, then cause it to be expelled, or consume an excessive amount of ghee before sleeping during fever. In severe fever cases, consume a mixture of cow's milk, butter, and sugar. Additionally, eating meat, honey, and black sesame seeds is recommended. 

Applying the ashes of burnt peacock or partridge feathers on the body may provide relief. Moreover, eye ointment made from antimony, copper, or gold can be beneficial during fever. 

Using horse gram, barley, mustard seeds, and dhoopa (incense) is recommended during fever. Various types of incenses, collyriums, and other remedies like antimony, copper, or gold application can also be beneficial.

sloka: manovikāre nirdiṣṭaṃ kāryaṃ tadviṣamajvare|  maṇīnāmoṣadhīnāṃ ca maṅgalyānāṃ viṣasya ca||309||  dhāraṇādagadānāṃ ca sevanānna bhavejjvaraḥ|310|
translation: In the mental state (of a feverish person), the assigned task is to eliminate the fever through sweating, which can be induced by applying an appropriate amount of oil either after consuming a nourishing meal or drinking warm milk mixed with sugar and ghee, or consuming rice cooked in milk, yogurt sweetened with sugar, buttermilk, or a soup made from aged ghee, similar to a tiger's foam or small pinewood pieces. Various substances such as long pepper, black pepper, dried ginger, pippali, triphala, takra, gavya, rasonasa, taila, honey, licorice, vaiyaghri vasA, hingu, nasyam, sasaindhavA purANa sarpiH, pippalI, taṇḍulaH, netrā āñjanam, taila, piṣṭam, śasyate, palaṅkaṣA nimbapatram, vacA, kuṣTham, harITakI, sarṣapAH, sayavAH, sarpir dhūpanam, nAsanam can be used for this purpose. One should avoid smoke and fumes.

sloka: somaṃ sānucaraṃ devaṃ samātṛgaṇamīśvaram||310||  pūjayan prayataḥ śīghraṃ mucyate viṣamajvarāt|  viṣṇuṃ sahasramūrdhānaṃ carācarapatiṃ vibhum||311||  stuvannāmasahasreṇa jvarān sarvānapohati|  brahmāṇamaśvināvindraṃ hutabhakṣaṃ himācalam||312||  gaṅgāṃ marudgaṇāṃśceṣṭyā  pūjayañjayati jvarān|  bhaktyā mātuḥ pituścaiva gurūṇāṃ pūjanena ca||313||  brahmacaryeṇa tapasā satyena niyamena ca|  japahomapradānena vedānāṃ śravaṇena ca||314||  jvarādvimucyate śīghraṃ sādhūnāṃ darśanena ca|
translation: The mind, in its various states, should deem it essential to employ medicinal herbs and auspicious substances for alleviating a harmful fever. One may quickly achieve liberation from such a fever by venerating Lord Soma, who companions the gods, leads the foremost Marut band, and governs all beings. Likewise, reciting Lord Vishnu's names, who possesses a thousand heads, commands both mobile and immobile entities, and wields boundless power, can cure all fevers. By worshiping Indra, Ashvinikumaras, Brahma, and the divine Himalayas, one can eradicate fevers through their blessings. Honoring parents, teachers, and sages, practicing celibacy, austerity, truthfulness, self-control, generosity, performing sacred duties, and listening to the Vedas can swiftly eliminate fevers. Additionally, gazing upon virtuous souls can bring about prompt fever relief.

sloka: jvare rasasthe vamanamupavāsaṃ ca kārayet||315||  sekapradehau raktasthe tathā saṃśamanāni ca|  virecanaṃ sopavāsaṃ māṃsamedaḥsthite hitam||316||  asthimajjagate deyā nirūhāḥ sānuvāsanāḥ|317|
translation: For one suffering from fever, one should offer a drink of soma, worship Gaṇeśa, and perform: emesis (vamanam), fasting (upavāsaṃ), controlling urine/feces (sekapradehau), purging (raktasthe tathā saṃśamanāni), purging (virecanam), more fasting, and consuming only meat (māṃsamedaḥsthite hitam). For severe fever, give milk, rice, and ghee; worship the imperishable Viṣṇu; offer oblations to Vaiśvadeva, Indra, the Aśvin twins, and the Maruts; honor earth, water, fire, air, ether, and the moon with appropriate rituals; show reverence to one's mother, father, teachers by bowing down; practice self-discipline through austerity (tapasā), truthfulness (satyena), restraint (niyamena), mantra recitation (japa), fire offerings (homa), giving (pradānena), Veda study (vedānām śravaṇena); and seek the company of the wise (sānuvāsanāḥ).

sloka: śāpābhicārādbhūtānāmabhiṣaṅgācca yo jvaraḥ||317||  daivavyapāśrayaṃ tatra sarvamauṣadhamiṣyate|
translation: The fever afflicting those who have been subjected to curses or malicious influences is to be treated entirely with medicaments that have divine sanction. Indeed, this is the course of action to be followed: induce emesis and prescribe fasting; apply sudation and fomentation; administer beef, marrow broths, and fatty/bony decoctions; perform bloodletting and purgation; eliminate waste products; and address deep-seated desires, all following divine instruction.

sloka: abhighātajvaro naśyet  pānābhyaṅgena sarpiṣaḥ||318||  raktāvasekairmadyaiśca  sātmyairmāṃsarasaudanaiḥ|  sānāho madyasātmyānāṃ madirārasabhojanaiḥ||319||  kṣatānāṃ vraṇitānāṃ ca kṣatavraṇacikitsayā|
translation: The fever arising from supernatural causes or malicious acts should be treated using medicinal concoctions and other suitable remedies administered through touch or ingested, as well as through treatments for injuries using appropriate medicines for wound healing.

sloka: āśvāseneṣṭalābhena vāyoḥ praśamanena ca||320||  harṣaṇaiśca śamaṃ yānti kāmaśokabhayajvarāḥ|  kāmyairarthairmanojñaiśca pittaghnaiścāpyupakramaiḥ||321||  sadvākyaiśca śamaṃ yāti jvaraḥ krodhasamutthitaḥ|  kāmāt krodhajvaro nāśaṃ krodhāt kāmasamudbhavaḥ||322||  yāti tābhyāmubhābhyāṃ ca bhayaśokasamutthitaḥ| jvarasya vegaṃ kālaṃ ca cintayañjvaryate tu yaḥ||323||  tasyeṣṭaistu vicitraiśca viṣayairnāśayet smṛtim|324|
translation: By seeking to alleviate fever through tranquilizing drinks, ointments, and rice porridge made from sesame and ghee, as well as through self-discipline in consuming alcoholic beverages and food, along with appropriate treatments for injuries and wounds, one can weaken fever's grasp and lessen its intensity. Indeed, the one who reflects upon these measures, employing them skillfully, can achieve their destruction.

sloka: jvarapramokṣe puruṣaḥ kūjan vamati ceṣṭate|  śvasanvivarṇaḥ svinnāṅgo vepate līyate muhuḥ||324||  pralapatyuṣṇasarvāṅgaḥ śītāṅgaśca bhavatyapi|  visañjño jvaravegārtaḥ sakrodha iva vīkṣyate  ||325||  sadoṣaśabdaṃ ca śakṛddravaṃ sravati vegavat|  liṅgānyetāni jānīyājjvaramokṣe vicakṣaṇaḥ||326||  bahudoṣasya balavān  prāyeṇābhinavo jvaraḥ|  satkriyādoṣapaktyā  cedvimuñcati sudāruṇam||327||  kṛtvā doṣavaśādvegaṃ kramāduparamanti ye|  teṣāmadāruṇo mokṣo jvarāṇāṃ cirakāriṇām||328||
translation:
In the process of fever treatment, a person rapidly breathes in fresh air, becomes exhilarated, and grows still. Their complexion fluctuates, they perspire heavily, tremble, turn pale or ruddy, and their limbs twitch. They might become delirious, losing control over their speech, or become unusually quiet. A knowledgeable healer should recognize these various symptoms, understanding that a severe fever may ensue if appropriate treatment is delayed.

In cases where an individual has a history of recurring fevers, the emergence of a new fever should be promptly addressed. If the fever stems from an aggravation of imbalanced bodily humors and isn't treated properly, it may intensify, becoming difficult to cure. Those who diligently adhere to proper treatment methods can prevent such harsh fever consequences.

sloka: vigataklamasantāpamavyathaṃ vimalendriyam|  yuktaṃ prakṛtisattvena vidyāt puruṣamajvaram||329||
translation: Perceive that purusha (individual soul), who, free from feverish existence and mental agitation, possesses unclouded senses and is established in his true nature. I perceive such a purusha, who shows signs of life such as pulsation, quivering, fading, waxing, speaking, sweating, being warm, having a form that changes according to the disposition of the body, becoming pale or reddish, and experiencing various other physical transformations. A discerning person can release this feverish soul from its many afflictions by performing skillful actions and abandoning harmful ones. This liberation from long-standing fevers is typically gentle in its progression.

sloka: sajvaro jvaramuktaśca vidāhīni gurūṇi ca|  asātmyānyannapānāni viruddhāni ca varjayet||330||  vyavāyamaticeṣṭāśca snānamatyaśanāni ca|  tathā jvaraḥ śamaṃ yāti praśānto jāyate na ca||331||  vyāyāmaṃ ca vyavāyaṃ ca snānaṃ caṅkramaṇāni ca|  jvaramukto na seveta yāvanna balavān bhavet||332||
translation: Relinquishing current fatigue and being freed from exhaustion, one should avoid incompatible and conflicting foods, as well as excessive exertion, sexual activity, and movement, while endowed with knowledge of the self and calm mind. Once free from disease, one should not engage in activities that reduce strength until one has attained sufficient strength. This includes physical exercise, sexual activity, bathing, and moving about.

sloka: asañjātabalo yastu jvaramukto niṣevate|  varjyametannarastasya punarāvartate jvaraḥ||333||
translation: The man, who has been born free from a feverish condition and who conducts himself thus, having been released from the fever, should avoid reprehensible activities such as exertion, sexual indulgence, unhealthy diet, and agitating actions. Instead, he should adopt wholesome practices like moderate exercise, proper nourishment, tranquility, etc. In this way, he will not return to the feverish state.

sloka: durhṛteṣu ca doṣeṣu yasya vā vinivartate|  svalpenapyapacāreṇa tasya vyāvartate punaḥ||334||  cirakālaparikliṣṭaṃ durbalaṃ hīnatejasam [1] |  acireṇaiva kālena sa hanti punarāgataḥ||335||
translation: The one who, in unrighteousness, remains unwavering amidst afflictions or mistakes, even a slight transgression can make them waver. The one who is weak and energy-depleted over a long period, however, can swiftly regain their strength through timely care and treatment.

sloka: athavā'pi  parīpākaṃ dhātuṣveva kramānmalāḥ|  yānti jvaramakurvantaste tathā'pyapakurvate||336||
translation: Even if one has only a few and minor flaws in their actions, they can still cause illness if not corrected promptly. Similarly, if one addresses such flaws, health can be regained.

sloka: dīnatāṃ śvayathuṃ glāniṃ pāṇḍutāṃ nānnakāmatām|  kaṇḍūrutkoṭhapiḍakāḥ kurvantyagniṃ ca te mṛdum||337||  evamanye'pi ca gadā vyāvartante punargatāḥ|  anirghātena doṣāṇāmalpairapyahitairnṛṇām||338||
translation: Even in the act of cooking, impurities such as boils, blisters, and itches emerge in the substances through their own qualities; they cause corruption. Similarly, with an unmindful attitude, people too accumulate faults and contaminations, not only in small measures but to a great extent.

sloka: nirvṛtte'pi jvare tasmādyathāvasthaṃ yathābalam|  yathāprāṇaṃ hareddoṣaṃ prayogairvā śamaṃ nayet||339||  mṛdubhiḥ śodhanaiḥ śuddhiryāpanā bastayo hitāḥ|  hitāśca laghavo yūṣā jāṅgalāmiṣajā rasāḥ||340||
translation: Even when fever persists, one should regulate the body's conditions such as weakness, paleness, and itching, as well as impurities, as appropriate to one's strength. One should lead harmful effects caused by such ailments toward calmness through gentle treatments and purification measures. Additionally, one should apply nourishing and light remedies, as well as wholesome and suitable treatments for all humans.

sloka: abhyaṅgodvartanasnānadhūpanānyañjanāni ca|  hitāni punarāvṛtte jvare tiktaghṛtāni ca||341||  gurvyabhiṣyandyasātmyānāṃ bhojanāt punarāgate|  laṅghanoṣṇopacārādiḥ kramaḥ kāryaśca pūrvavat||342||  kirātatiktakaṃ tiktā mustaṃ parpaṭako'mṛtā|  ghnanti pītāni cābhyāsāt punarāvartakaṃ jvaram||343||
translation: In a feverish state, one should return to consuming food as tolerated, according to their strength and endurance, following a sequence of mild digestive measures, starting from liquids and gradually moving towards solid and bitter substances such as Kirataka, Tiktaka, Musta, Parpataka, and Amla, which have fever-alleviating properties, having been processed before. This should be done in a manner similar to the previous routine, including actions such as anointing, massaging, bathing, fumigation, and application of medicinal pastes, which are beneficial for the recovery process.

sloka: tasyāṃ tasyāmavasthāyāṃ jvaritānāṃ vicakṣaṇaḥ|  jvarākriyākramāpekṣī kuryāttattaccikitsitam||344||
translation: While that patient is in a feverish state, a discerning expert should administer treatment considering the following: massages, sudorific therapies, baths, fumigation, other remedies, and nourishing food, reapplied post-recovery; purgatives and warm foods should be given in a regulated sequence; bitter, astringent, sour, and heavy meals must be avoided.

sloka: rogarāṭ sarvabhūtānāmantakṛddāruṇo jvaraḥ|  tasmādviśeṣatastasya yateta praśame bhiṣak||345||
translation: In all beings, when it comes to fevers that are extremely destructive and harsh, the specialist should strive particularly in their alleviation to treat such a fever.

sloka: tatra ślokaḥ  yathākramaṃ yathāpraśnamuktaṃ jvaracikitsitam|  ātreyeṇāgniveśāya bhūtānāṃ hitakāmyayā||346||
translation: In the Atharvaveda, a specific treatment for the severe fever, known as jvaracikitsitam, should be considered and applied in the proper order as asked in the verse, for the purpose of benefiting all beings . This treatment is designed for agnivesa, as presented in the atharvanic text .

sloka: apasmāracikitsitopakramaḥ athāto'pasmāracikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: Here, we describe the course of treatment for apasmara. Previously, it was stated by the revered Atreya.

sloka: smṛterapagamaṃ prāhurapasmāraṃ bhiṣagvidaḥ|  tamaḥpraveśaṃ bībhatsaceṣṭaṃ dhīsattvasamplavāt||3||
translation: The healers declare that forgetfulness (or amnesia) is incurable, as it is like entering into darkness; this frightful manifestation arises from the disturbance of consciousness and intellect.

sloka: vibhrāntabahudoṣāṇāmahitāśucibhojanāt [1] |  rajastamobhyāṃ vihate sattve doṣāvṛte hṛdi||4|| cintākāmabhayakrodhaśokodvegādibhistathā|  manasyabhihate nṝṇāmapasmāraḥ pravartate||5||
translation: Forgetfulness, characterized as the departure from proper recollection, arises from the intellect being overshadowed by rajas and tamas gunas, leading to the entrance of darkness (tamaḥ). It is caused by unwholesome food, improper conduct, and the onset of physical and mental ailments (bhishak). Additionally, it is associated with disturbing emotions such as worry, desire, fear, anger, sorrow, and others. This state of forgetfulness is triggered when such emotions become predominant in one's mind (manasi).

sloka: dhamanībhiḥ śritā doṣā hṛdayaṃ pīḍayanti hi|  sampīḍyamāno vyathate mūḍho bhrāntena cetasā||6||  paśyatyasanti rūpāṇi patati prasphuratyapi|  jihvākṣibhrūḥ sravallālo hastau pādau ca vikṣipan||7||
translation: The deficiencies, such as worry, desire, fear, anger, grief, and anxiety, when they afflict the heart, distress the one who is confused and has a distracted consciousness . Such a person may perceive forms , but not comprehend them; stumbles , wavers, and trembles while the tongue , eyes , nose , and ears , as well as the hands and feet , falter.

sloka: doṣavege ca vigate suptavat pratibuddhyate|
translation: Even when freed from afflictions, one who is distracted in the face of faults becomes startled, like one awakening from sleep; such a deluded fool sees non-existent forms, stammering and twitching.

sloka: pṛthagdoṣaiḥ samastaiśca vakṣyate sa caturvidhaḥ||8||
translation: Explained comprehensively and in a fourfold manner, it is described as being devoid of all flaws and becoming manifest, as if from a state of ignorance or slumber.

sloka: kampate pradaśeddantān phenodvāmī śvasityapi|  paruṣāruṇakṛṣṇāni paśyedrūpāṇi cānilāt||9||
translation: In the present moment, one who shakes off all impurities and perspires perceives the fourfold forms that are harsh , reddish , and dark in complexion, as they manifest .

sloka: pītaphenāṅgavaktrākṣaḥ pītāsṛgrūpadarśanaḥ|  satṛṣṇoṣṇānalavyāptalokadarśī  ca paittikaḥ||10||
translation: The golden-hued one, revealing the father's ornaments, body, and facial features, and perceiving through divine senses the world's properties such as heat, cold, and others, you are the illuminating nature.

sloka: śuklaphenāṅgavaktrākṣaḥ śīto hṛṣṭāṅgajo guruḥ|  paśyañchuklāni rūpāṇi ślaiṣmiko mucyate cirāt||11||
translation: Wearing white-garlands and with a radiant face, being cooled down and rejoiced, the one who sees forms as transient, will soon be liberated for a long time, as the heavyset elephant-like person (here implied as a symbol of strength, stability, and wisdom).

sloka: sarvairetaiḥ samastaistu liṅgairjñeyastridoṣajaḥ| apasmāraḥ sa cāsādhyo yaḥ kṣīṇasyānavaśca yaḥ||12||
translation: The disorder, known as "Apasmara," is imperceptible, difficult to diagnose and cure by all examination methods. It is characterized by qualities such as whiteness, foam, body, face, eyes, coolness, and joy, as well as those of an elephant or a heavy mass, and has white, smooth, and icy forms. This disorder is incurable by any means and gets eliminated only after a long time.

sloka: pakṣādvā dvādaśāhādvā māsādvā kupitā malāḥ|  apasmārāya kurvanti vegaṃ kiñcidathāntaram||13||
translation: The three inherent defects--desire, aversion, and ignorance, when they become exacerbated in a being, hasten the onset of an epileptic fit to some extent.

sloka: tairāvṛtānāṃ hṛtsrotomanasāṃ samprabodhanam|  tīkṣṇairādau bhiṣak kuryāt karmabhirvamanādibhiḥ||14||
translation: The healer should administer at the outset, using purgative methods characterized by sharpness, the awakening (of the senses) of those who are surrounded by (the condition of) being enveloped by (the serious disease of) corruption, which is caused by the buildup of toxins and delusion, among those afflicted by it in this world. (This is to be done) during the twelve-day treatment.

sloka: vātikaṃ bastibhūyiṣṭhaiḥ paittaṃ prāyo virecanaiḥ|  ślaiṣmikaṃ vamanaprāyairapasmāramupācaret||15||
translation: For those suffering from ailments, physicians should primarily use purgatives made from pungent substances and alkalies, as well as therapeutic emesis, which are indicated by ślaiṣmika and vamanaprāya, to care for and alleviate the obstructions in the body and mental channels.

sloka: sarvataḥ suviśuddhasya samyagāśvāsitasya ca|  apasmāravimokṣārthaṃ yogān saṃśamanāñchṛṇu||16||
translation: To achieve liberation from mental confusion, listen to and practice the yoga that involves restraining [the senses] and the pursuit of purification, including the regular performance of cleansing practices such as purging and enema, using pure substances like water and clay. (16)

sloka: gośakṛdrasadadhyamlakṣīramūtraiḥ samairghṛtam|  siddhaṃ pibedapasmārakāmalājvaranāśanam||17||  iti pañcagavyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: "This is called 'Panchagavya Ghrita,' the clarified butter, prepared from a mixture of cow milk, curd, ghee, urine, and dung. One should consume it in a pure and serene state to achieve the effect of completely eliminating afflictions such as epilepsy, fever, and desires."

sloka: dve pañcamūlyau triphalā rajanyau kuṭajatvacam|  saptaparṇamapāmārgaṃ nīlinīṃ kaṭurohiṇīm||18||  śampākaṃ phalgumūlaṃ ca pauṣkaraṃ sadurālabham|  dvipalāni jaladroṇe paktvā pādāvaśeṣite||19||  bhārgīṃ pāṭhāṃ trikaṭukaṃ trivṛtāṃ niculāni ca|  śreyasīmāḍhakīṃ mūrvāṃ dantīṃ bhūnimbacitrakau||20||  dve sārive rohiṣaṃ ca bhūtīkaṃ madayantikām|  kṣipetpiṣṭvā'kṣamātrāṇi tena  prasthaṃ ghṛtāt pacet||21|| gośakṛdrasadadhyamlakṣīramūtraiśca tatsamaiḥ|  pañcagavyamiti khyātaṃ mahattadamṛtopamam||22||  apasmāre tathonmāde  śvayathāvudareṣu ca|  gulmārśaḥpāṇḍurogeṣu kāmalāyāṃ halīmake||23||  śasyate ghṛtametattu prayoktavyaṃ dine dine|  alakṣmīgraharogaghnaṃ cāturthakavināśanam||24||  iti mahāpañcagavyaṃ ghṛtam
translation: "This excellent and unparalleled Mahapancagavya, characterized by its sweet taste, sourness, and coolness, is prepared by mixing ghee, curd, butter, and milk derived from cows. It should be consumed daily, as it is beneficial in treating various ailments such as indigestion, diarrhea, and fever, as well as in eliminating misfortunes of a fourth-dimensional nature."

sloka: brāhmīrasavacākuṣṭhaśaṅkhapuṣpībhireva ca|  purāṇaṃ ghṛtamunmādālakṣmyapasmārapāpanut||25||
translation: With the two valuable fruits of royal and kuṭaja trees, as well as saptaparṇa, nīlinī, kaṭu, rohiṇī, śam, pākam, phalgu, mūlam, pauṣkara, ura, āla, bhārgī, kaṭukam, trivṛtā, niculāni, śreyasī, āḍhakī, mūrvā, dantī, nimba, citraka, sārive, rohiṣa, bhūti, kama, made, antikā, mixed in proper measures, and cooked in ghee, milk, curd, and water, an elixir known as mahat amṛta is created. This great gavya, when consumed daily, can destroy all impurities and ailments such as gulma, arśa, pāṇḍu, roga, kāmalāyā, halīmaka, and other afflictions in the body, as well as remove bad luck and evil spirits from one's dwelling, ensuring good health and longevity.

sloka: ghṛtaṃ saindhavahiṅgubhyāṃ vārṣe bāste caturguṇe|  mūtre siddhamapasmārahṛdgrahāmayanāśanam||26||
translation: "The ghee, obtained from the ocean of milk through the use of Kushtha and Shankpushpi in a year, when employed in a twofold manner as a potent chant and a remedy, becomes effective in destroying the root of incurable mental disorders such as epilepsy."

sloka: vacāśampākakaiṭaryavayaḥsthāhiṅgucorakaiḥ|  siddhaṃ palaṅkaṣāyuktairvātaśleṣmātmake ghṛtam||27||
translation: With ocean salt, prepared through settled practice using sesame oil, barley, and beans as the four ingredients, infused ghee, now made effective, can destroy diseases such as epilepsy, heart ailments, and possession.

sloka: tailaprasthaṃ ghṛtaprasthaṃ jīvanīyaiḥ palonmitaiḥ|  kṣīradroṇe pacet siddhamapasmāravināśanam||28||
translation: With specified ingredients and fire, one should prepare the perfectly purified ghee as a potion for longevity; when cooked together with rice, it will destroy the embodied impurities.

sloka: kaṃse kṣīrekṣurasayoḥ kāśmarye'ṣṭaguṇe rase|  kārṣikairjīvanīyaiśca ghṛtaprasthaṃ vipācayet||29||
