translation: With rice cooked in a mixture of sesame oil and ghee, prepared together with herbs that sustain life, one should efficaciously prepare rice gruel in the case of epilepsy; this is certainly the established remedy.

sloka: vātapittodbhavaṃ kṣipramapasmāraṃ niyacchati|  tadvat kāśavidārīkṣukuśakvāthaśṛtaṃ ghṛtam||30||
translation: Quickly cure the fever arising from wind and bile, similarly, ghee that is prepared with cow's milk, sugarcane juice, and Kasha grains, which possess eight excellent qualities, you should churn it rapidly.

sloka: madhukadvipale kalke droṇe cāmalakīrasāt|  tadvat siddho ghṛtaprasthaḥ pittāpasmārabheṣajam||31||
translation: Just as disorders caused by wind (vāta) and bile (pitta) are quickly pacified by the Kāśividārikṣukuśakvaṭa, similarly, a condition known as apasmāra is swiftly calmed by ghṛtaprasthaṃ, a medicine made from clarified butter, which has been previously prepared (siddhaḥ).

sloka: abhyaṅgaḥ sārṣapaṃ tailaṃ bastamūtre caturguṇe|  siddhaṃ syādgośakṛnmūtraiḥ snānotsādanameva ca||32||
translation: The practice of massaging the body with sesame oil, followed by evacuation, and bathing in a decoction composed of Madhuka, Dvi-pala, Kalka, Drōṇa, Āmalakī, as well as ghṛta and pitta, all added in four measures, is a tried and true remedy for addressing digestive ailments such as apasmāra.

sloka: kaṭabhīnimbakaṭvaṅgamadhuśigrutvacāṃ rase|  siddhaṃ mūtrasamaṃ tailamabhyaṅgārthe praśasyate||33|| palaṅkaṣāvacāpathyāvṛścikālyarkasarṣapaiḥ|  jaṭilāpūtanākeśīnākulīhiṅgucorakaiḥ||34||
translation: For applying oil in massage, it is considered settled that pure sesame oil, which is suitable for all body types, is free from urine, feces, and other impurities, and has been cleansed, is to be praised. This is also recommended for use after bathing and washing the body with water, along with clothes that are clean, free from dirt, and not torn.

sloka: laśunātirasācitrākuṣṭhairviḍbhiśca pakṣiṇām|  māṃsāśināṃ yathālābhaṃ bastamūtre caturguṇe||35||  siddhamabhyañjanaṃ tailamapasmāravināśanam|  etaiścaivauṣadhaiḥ kāryaṃ dhūpanaṃ sapralepanam||36||
translation: With a paste made from licorice, nimba, pungent herbs, honey, an appropriate amount of śigru and tvacām, mixed with sesame oil for abhyanga, a medicinal concoction can be prepared; it eliminates phlegm, scorpions, aliea, arka, mustard seeds, as well as lice, keśī, kulī, hiṅgu, cora, and other small insects. This preparation serves as incense and medicinal paste.

sloka: pippalīṃ lavaṇaṃ citrāṃ  hiṅgu hiṅguśivāṭikām|  kākolīṃ sarṣapān kākanāsāṃ kaiṭaryacandane||37||  śunaḥskandhāsthinakharān parśukāṃ ceti peṣayet|  bastamūtreṇa puṣyarkṣe pradehaḥ syāt sadhūpanaḥ||38||
translation: With a mixture of pungent ingredients such as garlic (hingu), colored spices (citrā), and viḍa seeds (hiṅguśivāṭikā), along with the meat of birds (kākolīṃ, kākanāsāṃ) and animals (śunaḥ-skandha-asthi-nakharān), one should apply to the body, using basti method, oil, four kinds of medicinal plants (parśukām), and other treatments (iti), in order to achieve the desired result for ailments like apasmara, and to alleviate hunger (sadhūpanaḥ).

sloka: apetarākṣasīkuṣṭhapūtanākeśicorakaiḥ|  utsādanaṃ mūtrapiṣṭairmūtrairevāvasecanam||39||
translation: After applying a paste made from pippali, salt, triphala, honey, and sugar to eyes, ears, head, nails, and skin afflicted by impurities, one should then cleanse (the area) with urine; this practice is known as sadhupana.

sloka: jalaukaḥśakṛtā tadvaddagdhairvā bastaromabhiḥ|  kharāsthibhirhastinakhaistathā gopucchalomabhiḥ||40||
translation: Slaying the Rakshasi Putana with jujube fruits smeared with a brazen poison, as well as Keshí with his hoof, and a cattle thief with cattle prods; and further, sprinkling go-mixture and urine all over, this is what Jalauka did.

sloka: kapilānāṃ gavāṃ mūtraṃ [1] nāvanaṃ paramaṃ hitam|  śvaśṛgālabiḍālānāṃ siṃhādīnāṃ ca śasyate||41||
translation: The urine of a cow with a Kapila hue is proclaimed to be extremely beneficial for creatures like Jalauka, Khar, Hasti, and others destroyed by sharp weapons such as teeth, horns, and nails.

sloka: bhārgī vacā nāgadantī śvetā śvetā  viṣāṇikā|  jyotiṣmatī nāgadantī pādoktā mūtrapeṣitāḥ||42||  yogāstrayo'taḥ ṣaḍ bindūn pañca vā nāvayedbhiṣak|
translation: With a serpentine power of speech, referred to as "nāgadantī," being white and marked with lines, and known as "svetā" and "viṣāṇikā," one should not, as a healer, causatively reduce through yoga practices the three constituents, six bindus, or five elements, designated as "pādoukta" and "mūtrapeṣitā" in the dual number.

sloka: triphalāvyoṣapītadruyavakṣāraphaṇijjhakaiḥ||43||  śyāmāpāmārgakārañjaphalairmūtre'tha bastaje|  sādhitaṃ nāvanaṃ tailamapasmāravināśanam||44||
translation:
Prepared with a triphala decoction, consumed by purgatives and expectorants,
and smeared with a substance like the excretion of a black snake,
I have formulated this medicine: it eliminates the impurity from five or six drops of fluid.

sloka: pippalī vṛścikālī ca kuṣṭhaṃ ca lavaṇāni ca|  bhārgī ca cūrṇitaṃ nastaḥ kāryaṃ pradhamanaṃ param||45||
translation: "Eradicate specifically formulated ingredients, including triphala, vyosha, pitadruya, kasha, raphana, jihva-kshaudra, shadeva, bhargi, and impurities, as well as phlegm. The primary measure for treatment involves carefully consuming salt, oil, and a purgative."

sloka: kāyasthāṃ śāradānmudgānmustośīrayavāṃstathā|  savyoṣān bastamūtreṇa piṣṭvā vartīḥ prakalpayet||46||  apasmāre tathonmāde sarpadaṣṭe garārdite|  viṣapīte jalamṛte caitāḥ syuramṛtopamāḥ||47||
translation: For treating conditions such as pimples, lice, scabies, and leprosy, as well as salt crusts, one should prepare a paste using pippalī, vṛścika, and ālī mixed with kuṣṭham, lavaṇāni, and bhārgī. Once reduced to a powdery state and freed from impurities, this mixture serves as the prime remedy for afflictions like intoxication, poisoning, epilepsy, and diseases caused by tainted water.

sloka: mustaṃ vayaḥsthāṃ triphalāṃ kāyasthāṃ hiṅgu śādvalam|  vyoṣaṃ māṣān yavānmūtrairbāstamaiṣārṣabhaistribhiḥ||48||  piṣṭvā kṛtvā ca tāṃ vartimapasmāre prayojayet|  kilāse ca tathonmāde jvareṣu viṣameṣu ca||49||
translation: Having ground the musta plant, triphala, kayasthaa, andhingu, all mixed together in a pestle and mortar, one should cause this preparation to be consumed and applied in cases of fainting, madness, fever, and other critical conditions.

sloka: puṣyoddhṛtaṃ śunaḥ pittamapasmāraghnamañjanam|  tadeva sarpiṣā yuktaṃ dhūpanaṃ paramaṃ matam||50||
translation: Ground and processed with musta, triphala, kayastha, hingu, sadvala, masa, and yava, mixed with ghee, this floral material (pusya), having been extracted, is considered the supreme incense. It should be used as an offering for the deities during rituals, and also to alleviate fainting, intoxication, and fever.

sloka: nakulolūkamārjāragṛdhrakīṭāhikākajaiḥ|  tuṇḍaiḥ [1] pakṣaiḥ purīṣaiśca dhūpanaṃ kārayedbhiṣak||51||
translation: The supreme remedy for curing diseases like jaundice and epilepsy is considered to be the fumigation using ghee mixed with ingredients such as nutgrass, costus, turmeric, long pepper, black cumin, and camphor.

sloka: ābhiḥ kriyābhiḥ siddhābhirhṛdayaṃ samprabudhyate|  srotāṃsi cāpi śudhyanti tataḥ [2] sañjñāṃ sa vindati||52||
translation: By performing accomplished actions with enthusiasm, one awakens the heart; then the senses get purified, and only then does one attain consciousness/understanding. (From Shiva Gita, verse 52)

sloka: yasyānubandhastvāganturdoṣaliṅgādhikākṛtiḥ|  dṛśyeta tasya kāryaṃ syādāgantūnmādabheṣajam||53||
translation: If one's association is marked by symptoms beyond the usual, indicative of an affliction, then that person's treatment should aim at addressing their excitement.

sloka: anantaramuvācedamagniveśaḥ kṛtāñjaliḥ|  bhagavan! prāk samuddiṣṭaḥ ślokasthāne mahāgadaḥ||54||  atattvābhiniveśo yastaddhetvākṛtibheṣajam|  tatra noktamataḥ śrotumicchāmi tadihocyatām||55||  śuśrūṣave vacaḥ śrutvā śiṣyāyāha punarvasuḥ|  mahāgadaṃ saumya! śṛṇu sahetvākṛtibheṣajam||56||
translation: The fire god, after saluting with folded hands, then spoke: "O Lord! Earlier, you had mentioned the remedy for the affliction caused by delusory attachment and its distinguishing features. I wish to hear about it now." Having listened to the disciple's words, Vasu then said, "Listen, Sootheswara, to this remedy for the affliction."

sloka: malināhāraśīlasya vegān prāptānnigṛhṇataḥ|  śītoṣṇasnigdharūkṣādyairhetubhiścātisevitaiḥ||57||  hṛdayaṃ samupāśritya manobuddhivahāḥ sirāḥ|  doṣāḥ sandūṣya tiṣṭhanti rajomohāvṛtātmanaḥ||58||  rajastamobhyāṃ vṛddhābhyāṃ buddhau [1] manasi cāvṛte|  hṛdaye vyākule doṣairatha mūḍho'lpacetanaḥ [2] ||59||  viṣamāṃ kurute buddhiṃ nityānitye hitāhite|  atattvābhiniveśaṃ tamāhurāptā mahāgadam||60||
translation: After some time, the blessed lord spoke: "The one who has adopted the lifestyle of a malnourished person, having quickly approached and taken up self-disciplinary vows such as hot and cold, rough and smooth, etc., fixes their mind, intellect, and senses in the heart. Then, afflictions arise in the heart of that deluded and weak-minded person, immersed in Rajas and Tamas, due to their absence of proper understanding of their own true nature and reality." The blessed lord further said: "O gentle one, I wish to hear about the means to remove this affliction, please speak." Vasu then repeated the earlier mentioned verse about the remedy for this great calamity.

sloka: snehasvedopapannaṃ taṃ saṃśodhya vamanādibhiḥ|  kṛtasaṃsarjanaṃ medhyairannapānairupācaret||61||  brāhmīsvarasayuktaṃ yat pañcagavyamudāhṛtam|  tat sevyaṃ śaṅkhapuṣpī ca yacca medhyaṃ rasāyanam||62||  suhṛdaścānukūlāstaṃ svāptā dharmārthavādinaḥ|  saṃyojayeyurvijñānadhairyasmṛtisamādhibhiḥ [3] ||63|| prayuñjyāttailalaśunaṃ payasā vā śatāvarīm|  brāhmīrasaṃ kuṣṭharasaṃ vacāṃ vā madhusaṃyutām||64||
translation: Having regulated malicious food and pacifying tendencies, one should cleanse themselves through emetic and other methods. One should maintain oneself with pure substances like panchagavya, along with shankha pushpi and other consecrated materials, which have been esteemed by those who comprehend the self's nature. Those who are virtuous, benevolent, and oriented towards dharma and artha should associate with such a person through the faculties of heart, mind, and intellect, while also engaging in practices that purify body, senses, and soul. With unwavering commitment to truth and detachment from worldly desires, one should consume pure substances like milk, ghee, honey, seeking always to purify the mind and avoid delusion.

sloka: duścikitsyo hyapasmāraścirakārī kṛtāspadaḥ [1] |  tasmādrasāyanairenaṃ prāyaśaḥ samupācaret||65||
translation: The one who is difficult to cure, having recovered from a prolonged illness and regained strength, should primarily be treated with a regimen including emesis, purgatives, and medicinal decoctions. Moreover, such a person should be administered clarified butter, garlic, milk, or licorice; as well as therapeutic concoctions made from the five products of a cow, such as ghee, urine, and dung, all of which are mentioned in sacred texts. Additionally, ointments made from sesame oil should be applied, and medicinal formulations made from plant ingredients like turmeric, cardamom, and honey should be administered, all of which have been combined appropriately.

sloka: jalāgnidrumaśailebhyo viṣamebhyaśca taṃ sadā|  rakṣedunmādinaṃ caiva sadyaḥ prāṇaharā hi te||66||
translation: Preserve him at all times from fire, water, and trees, as well as from the unsteady one and the sudden; indeed, your very lives depend on it. (66)

sloka: tatra ślokau  hetuṃ kurvantyapasmāraṃ doṣāḥ prakupitā yathā|  sāmānyataḥ pṛthaktvācca liṅgaṃ teṣāṃ ca bheṣajam||67|| mahāgadasamutthānaṃ liṅgaṃ covāca sauṣadham|  munirvyāsasamāsābhyāmapasmāracikitsite [1] ||68||
translation: Just as, when provoked, faults seek a cause for fainting in the form of distinctness from water, fire, trees, and mountains, so too is the distinguishing mark of the origin of a great epidemic. A sage named Vyasa has stated that this marks the cure for fainting spells.

sloka: athāto hikkāśvāsacikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ ||2||
translation: Now, we will explain the means of alleviating hiccups and heavy breathing. So declared the Lord Atreya: "Herein, a distinctive cause of epilepsy is treated by a common remedy."

sloka: vedalokārthatattvajñamātreyamṛṣimuttamam |  apṛcchat saṃśayaṃ dhīmānagniveśaḥ kṛtāñjaliḥ ||3||  ya ime dvividhāḥ proktāstridoṣāstriprakopaṇāḥ |  rogā nānātmakāsteṣāṃ kasko bhavati durjayaḥ ||4||
translation: Now, the revered Ātreyah, having completed explaining the treatments, inquired of the sage, who was well-versed in the nature of the matters related to the world, "Which among these three kinds of faults and causes of anger is the most difficult to overcome?"

sloka: agniveśasya tadvākyaṃ śrutvā matimatāṃ varaḥ |  uvāca paramaprītaḥ paramārthaviniścayam ||5||  kāmaṃ prāṇaharā rogā bahavo na tu te tathā |  yathā śvāsaśca hikkā ca prāṇānāśu nikṛntataḥ ||6||  anyairapyupasṛṣṭasya rogairjantoḥ pṛthagvidhaiḥ |  ante sañjāyate hikkā śvāso vā tīvravedanaḥ ||7||
translation: Having heard the words of Agniveśa, the most wise among them, inquired about the ultimate meaning, extremely delighted. He spoke with certainty: "Desires and afflictions do not affect your prāṇas like common afflictions do. However, at the end, a severe shortness of breath or a sharp pain may arise from various distinct disorders."

sloka: kaphavātātmakāvetau pittasthānasamudbhavau |  hṛdayasya rasādīnāṃ dhātūnāṃ copaśoṣaṇau ||8|| tasmāt sādhāraṇāvetau matau paramadurjayau |  mithyopacaritau kruddhau hata āśīviṣāviva ||9||
translation: Having heard the words of Agni Veshpat's messenger, the best among the wise, pleased in the highest sense, spoke with determination: "Diseases that rob life, such as coughs and others, are not few but numerous, arising in a creature from time to time. Among them, two are considered supreme: those caused by an imbalance of phlegm (kapha) and wind (vata), which have taken form (prev. part of compound words), and bile (pitta) that rises from its place (prev. part of compound words). These are extremely difficult to defeat when they become angry and are accompanied by other ailments." (lines 8-9)

sloka: pṛthak pañcavidhāvetau nirdiṣṭau rogasaṅgrahe |  tayoḥ śṛṇu samutthānaṃ liṅgaṃ ca sabhiṣagjitam ||10||  rajasā dhūmavātābhyāṃ śītasthānāmbusevanāt |  vyāyāmādgrāmyadharmādhvarūkṣānnaviṣamāśanāt ||11||  āmapradoṣādānāhādraukṣyādatyapatarpaṇāt |  daurbalyānmarmaṇo ghātāddvandvācchuddhyatiyogataḥ ||12||  atīsārajvaracchardipratiśyāyakṣatakṣayāt |  raktapittādudāvartādvisūcyalasakādapi ||13||  pāṇḍurogādviṣāccaiva pravartete gadāvimau |  niṣpāvamāṣapiṇyākatilatailaniṣevaṇāt ||14||  piṣṭaśālūkaviṣṭambhividāhigurubhojanāt |  jalajānūpapiśitadadhyāmakṣīrasevanāt ||15||  abhiṣyandyupacārācca śleṣmalānāṃ ca sevanāt |  kaṇṭhorasaḥ pratīghātādvibandhaiśca pṛthagvidhaiḥ ||16||
translation: In this world, the two doshas, Kapha composed of the water element and Vata of the air element, and Pitta originating from the heart site, responsible for digesting rasa (nutrient fluid) in bodily tissues, are distinguished as the fundamental causes of all diseases (10). They are commonly regarded as challenging to overcome when severe, assuming a destructive form, similar to serpent venom (11). Excessive dryness caused by Vata, misplaced Pitta, or tissue depletion due to imbalanced Kapha can lead to diseases (12). Engaging in activities contrary to one's nature, consuming foods difficult to digest, or eating at improper times or combinations can also cause diseases (13). Cold, wind, or excessive heat exposure, as well as overconsuming sour-salty foods, can increase Pitta, leading to skin issues (14). Vata aggravation, causing joint pain, results from excessive exercise or spicy-dry food consumption (15). Imbalanced Kapha can cause mucus, congestion, and respiratory problems, while overconsuming sweet, sour, or salty foods can increase Kapha, leading to various diseases (16). To maintain balance, a balanced lifestyle and diet, avoiding dosha-aggravating activities and substances, are essential, with regular detoxification, rejuvenation, and seasonal routines recommended for optimal health.

sloka: mārutaḥ prāṇavāhīni srotāṃsyāviśya kupyati |  uraḥsthaḥ kaphamuddhūya hikkāśvāsān karoti saḥ ||17||  ghorān prāṇoparodhāya prāṇināṃ pañca pañca ca |18|
translation: The wind that carries the life force becomes agitated when it enters the senses and becomes fivefold , causing various afflictions in living beings . Specifically, it gives rise to symptoms such as coughing and wheezing , due to phlegm and bile, as well as symptoms caused by impure blood, abscesses, tumors, burns, cuts, wounds, fractures, and other ailments . All of these are manifestations of the derangement of the life force . This can be traced back to various causes, including immoderate intake of food, drink, and behavior; wind and smoke; cold locations; physical exertion; inappropriate diet; irregular eating; excessive hunger or thirst; improper digestion; overeating; impure foods; and the eating of fish, meat, and garlic . Furthermore, an accumulation of phlegm in the throat and chest can cause swelling and other disorders . This includes conditions such as anemia, poisoning, emaciation, fainting, bleeding, inflammation, fever, diarrhea, delirium, jaundice, leprosy, and various other diseases .

sloka: ubhayoḥ pūrvarūpāṇi śṛṇu vakṣyāmyataḥ param ||18||  kaṇṭhorasorgurutvaṃ ca vadanasya kaṣāyatā |  hikkānāṃ pūrvarūpāṇi kukṣerāṭopa eva ca ||19||  ānāhaḥ pārśvaśūlaṃ ca pīḍanaṃ hṛdayasya ca |  prāṇasya ca vilomatvaṃ śvāsānāṃ pūrvalakṣaṇam ||20||
translation: Listen, I will describe for you the initial symptoms of the disturbances in the life-breaths (prana), as they enter the pathways of the hearers: when anger arises in the throat, chest, and other parts of the body, causing irritation; and phlegm rises upwards, producing hiccups and heavy breathing, as well as causing a severe obstruction to the life-breaths.

sloka: prāṇodakānnavāhīni srotāṃsi sakapho'nilaḥ |  hikkā karoti saṃrudhya tāsāṃ liṅgaṃ pṛthak śṛṇu ||21||  kṣīṇamāṃsabalaprāṇatejasaḥ sakapho'nilaḥ |  gṛhītvā sahasā kaṇṭhamuccairghoṣavatīṃ bhṛśam ||22||  karoti satataṃ hikkāmekadvitriguṇaṃ tathā |  prāṇaḥ srotāṃsi marmāṇi saṃrudhyoṣmāṇameva ca ||23||  sañjñāṃ muṣṇāti gātrāṇāṃ stambhaṃ sañjanayatyapi |  mārgaṃ caivānnapānānāṃ ruṇaddhyupahatasmṛteḥ ||24||  sāśruviplutanetrasya stabdhaśaṅkhacyutabhruvaḥ |  saktajalpapralāpasya nirvṛtiṃ nādhigacchataḥ ||25||  mahāmūlā mahāvegā mahāśabdā mahābalā |  mahāhikketi sā nṝṇāṃ sadyaḥ prāṇaharā matā ||26||  iti mahāhikkā |
translation: "Listen carefully to the distinctive features of this hiccup, described in two aspects. I will explain what lies beyond them. At the throat, chest, and sides, resembling a rod in the heart and windpipe, recognize the indications of the 150 breaths. Like a great thunderbolt, it is renowned for swiftly taking away life forces. Indeed, such is called the great hiccup."

sloka: hikkate yaḥ pravṛddhastu kṛśo dīnamanā naraḥ |  jarjareṇorasā kṛcchraṃ gambhīramanunādayan ||27||  sañjṛmbhan saṅkṣipaṃścaiva tathā'ṅgāni prasārayan |  pārśve cobhe samāyamya kūjan stambharugarditaḥ ||28||  nābheḥ pakvāśayādvā'pi hikkā cāsyopajāyate |  kṣobhayantī bhṛśaṃ dehaṃ nāmayantīva tāmyataḥ ||29||  ruṇaddhyucchvāsamārgaṃ tu pranaṣṭabalacetasaḥ |  gambhīrā nāma sā tasya hikkā prāṇāntikī matā ||30||  iti gambhīrā hikkā |
translation:
The one, in this world, whose body is weakened yet strives to control a severe cough, enduring great hardship,
while catching his breath and stabilizing his limbs, holding himself together as he coughs deeply and persistently on both sides of his chest.
Even if one, with diminished strength and vitality, has just a small amount of phlegm or mucus in their throat,
such intense, persistent coughs can greatly disturb the body, causing it to shake violently.
For those deeply absorbed in meditation, this kind of severe cough is considered life-threatening,
indicating that their vital energy and consciousness are significantly weakened.
Such a profound cough, affecting one's very existence and essence, is named "gambhira hikka."
Once it takes hold, even great forces cannot easily be restrained.

sloka: vyapetā jāyate hikkā yā'nnapāne caturvidhe |  āhārapariṇāmānte bhūyaśca labhate balam ||31||  pralāpavamyatīsāratṛṣṇārtasya vicetasaḥ |  jṛmbhiṇo viplutākṣasya śuṣkāsyasya vināminaḥ ||32||  paryādhmātasya hikkā yā jatrumūlādasantatā |  sā vyapeteti vijñeyā hikkā prāṇoparodhinī ||33||  iti vyapetā hikkā |
translation: The hiccup that arises in one who is weak, emaciated, and wretched due to old age, causing the chest to heave and subside forcefully, making the body tremble, and disrupting the normal breathing pattern; when it completely subsides, located at the root of the throat, it indicates a significant decrease in vitality, being considered a sign of serious illness for that individual.

sloka: kṣudravāto yadā koṣṭhādvyāyāmaparighaṭṭitaḥ |  kaṇṭhe prapadyate hikkāṃ tadā kṣudrāṃ karoti saḥ ||34||  atiduḥkhā na sā coraḥśiromarmaprabādhinī |  na cocchvāsānnapānānāṃ mārgamāvṛtya tiṣṭhati ||35||  vṛddhimāyasyato yāti bhuktamātre ca mārdavam |  yataḥ pravartate pūrvaṃ tata eva nivartate ||36||  hṛdayaṃ kloma kaṇṭhaṃ ca tālukaṃ ca samāśritā |  mṛdvī sā kṣudrahikketi nṛṇāṃ sādhyā prakīrtitā ||37||  iti kṣudrahikkā |
translation: When an insignificant wind arises from the stomach, causing a hiccup, it is regarded as a sign of weakness in an individual. One who, upon the completion of the four types of transformations of food intake, acquires increased strength and talks excessively is considered to be free from this ailment. Similarly, one devoid of symptoms such as vomiting, diarrhea, excessive thirst, restlessness, anxiety, protruding eyes, swollen face, and dry mouth is also considered free from it. These symptoms are known as those that occur when the life forces leave the body. Hence, when one is devoid of these symptoms, they are no longer designated as 'insignificant hiccups.'

sloka: sahasā'tyabhyavahṛtaiḥ pānānnaiḥ pīḍito'nilaḥ |  ūrdhvaṃ prapadyate koṣṭhānmadyairvā'timadapradaiḥ ||38||  tathā'tiroṣabhāṣyādhvahāsyabhārātivartanaiḥ |  vāyuḥ koṣṭhagato dhāvan pānabhojyaprapīḍitaḥ ||39||  uraḥsrotaḥ samāviśya kuryāddhikkāṃ tato'nnajām |  tathā śanairasambandhaṃ kṣuvaṃścāpi sa hikkate ||40||  na marmabādhājananī nendriyāṇāṃ prabādhinī |  hikkā pīte tathā bhukte śamaṃ yāti ca sā'nnajā ||41||  ityannajā hikkā |
translation: When a sudden gust of wind, arising from a cramped location in the body such as the stomach, rises up to the throat, it is called "hikka" (a type of hiccup). At that time, if one widens the air passage through which food and drink pass, the intensity of the hiccup decreases. And when it subsides, it disappears completely. This kind of hiccup, caused due to a cramped space in the body, is well-known among people as "sadyah". Its onset is marked by a sharp pain in the chest, throat, and navel areas. It originates from the heart and spreads to other parts of the body through the veins, causing discomfort and restlessness. However, when treated with gentle methods such as massaging the affected areas or taking medicines that relieve cramps, the hiccup subsides and eventually disappears. This is the description of a sudden hiccup in this Sanskrit verse.

sloka: atisañcitadoṣasya bhaktacchedakṛśasya ca |  vyādhibhiḥ kṣīṇadehasya vṛddhasyātivyavāyinaḥ ||42||  āsāṃ yā sā samutpannā hikkā hantyāśu jīvitam |  yamikā ca pralāpārtitṛṣṇāmohasamanvitā ||43||  akṣīṇaścāpyadīnaśca sthiradhātvindriyaśca yaḥ |  tasya sādhayituṃ śakyā yamikā hantyato'nyathā ||44||
translation: When one is greatly afflicted by an accumulation of faults due to excessive indulgence in alcohol and rich food, and the air element within the body becomes agitated and rises upwards, then for the one whose senses are disrupted, eating light food and drinking in moderation should be gradually adopted. This brings an end to hiccups, which arise from a disruption in the normal functioning of the senses, and alleviates any distress to the vital organs. (42-44)

sloka: yadā srotāṃsi saṃrudhya mārutaḥ kaphapūrvakaḥ |  viṣvagvrajati saṃruddhastadā śvāsānkaroti saḥ ||45||
translation: When the breath force , having accumulated all the built-up impurities , violently manifests in various symptoms such as quickened death , prattles , distress , thirst , and delusion in a person afflicted with consumption or other diseases and whose stable dhatus and indriyas are weakened ; then, one who can cure such a patient is a skilled physician . Otherwise, it is impossible .

sloka: uddhūyamānavāto yaḥ śabdavaddukhito naraḥ |  uccaiḥ śvasiti saṃruddho mattarṣabha ivāniśam ||46|| pranaṣṭajñānavijñānastathā vibhrāntalocanaḥ |  vikṛtākṣyānano baddhamūtravarcā viśīrṇavāk ||47||  dīnaḥ praśvasitaṃ cāsya dūrādvijñāyate bhṛśam |  mahāśvāsopasṛṣṭaḥ sa kṣiprameva vipadyate ||48||  iti mahāśvāsaḥ |
translation: When the airways are congested by a phlegm-driven wind, the man affected breathes heavily, forcefully, and noisily, resembling a bull in its distress. At that time, his knowledge and understanding are lost, his eyes roll about, his face becomes distorted, and his speech unclear. Perceiving him to be in such a state of great agitation, one can detect his distress from a distance, and he soon collapses. This, indeed, is the 'great consolation' – the swift resolution of his suffering.

sloka: dīrghaṃ śvasiti yastūrdhvaṃ na ca pratyāharatyadhaḥ |  śleṣmāvṛtamukhasrotāḥ kruddhagandhavahārditaḥ ||49||  ūrdhvadṛṣṭirvipaśyaṃśca vibhrāntākṣa itastataḥ |  pramuhyan vedanārtaśca śuṣkāsyo'ratipīḍitaḥ ||50||  ūrdhvaśvāse prakupite  hyadhaḥśvāso nirudhyate |  muhyatastāmyataścordhvaṃ śvāsastasyaiva hantyasūn ||51||  ityūrdhvaśvāsaḥ |
translation: The man, afflicted by the rising wind's sound, constantly pants and gasps for breath, with distended nostrils, eyes red and bulging, grim-faced, having lost knowledge and judgment, emaciated, with dry mouth and feeble voice. Such a man is swiftly overwhelmed by a violent, forceful bout of upward breaths.

sloka: yastu śvasiti vicchinnaṃ sarvaprāṇena pīḍitaḥ |  na vā śvasiti duḥkhārto marmacchedarugarditaḥ ||52||  ānāhasvedamūrcchārto dahyamānena bastinā |  viplutākṣaḥ parikṣīṇaḥ śvasan raktaikalocanaḥ ||53||  vicetāḥ pariśuṣkāsyo vivarṇaḥ pralapannaraḥ |  chinnaśvāsena vicchinnaḥ sa śīghraṃ prajahātyasūn ||54||  iti chinnaśvāsaḥ |
translation: The one who, having restrained the long breath, draws it upwards, and no longer pants, his senses restrained, tears streaming down his face, his gaze fixed and bewildered, his body dehydrated, mouth parched, and heart troubled – once he stops breathing, he quickly destroys his enemies. Such a person is known as "one who has ceased breathing."

sloka: pratilomaṃ yadā vāyuḥ srotāṃsi pratipadyate |  grīvāṃ śiraśca saṅgṛhya śleṣmāṇaṃ samudīrya ca ||55||  karoti pīnasaṃ tena ruddho ghurghurukaṃ tathā |  atīva tīvravegaṃ ca śvāsaṃ prāṇaprapīḍakam ||56||  pratāmyatyativegācca kāsate sannirudhyate |  pramohaṃ kāsamānaśca sa gacchati muhurmuhuḥ ||57||  śleṣmaṇyamucyamāne tu bhṛśaṃ bhavati duḥkhitaḥ |  tasyaiva ca vimokṣānte muhūrtaṃ labhate sukham ||58||  athāsyoddhvaṃsate kaṇṭhaḥ kṛcchrācchaknoti bhāṣitum |  na cāpi nidrāṃ labhate śayānaḥ śvāsapīḍitaḥ ||59||  pārśve tasyāvagṛhṇāti śayānasya samīraṇaḥ |  āsīno labhate saukhyamuṣṇaṃ caivābhinandati ||60||  ucchritākṣo lalāṭena svidyatā bhṛśamartimān |  viśuṣkāsyo muhuḥ śvāso muhuścaivāvadhamyate ||61||  meghāmbuśītaprāgvātaiḥ śleṣmalaiścābhivardhate |  sa yāpyastamakaśvāsaḥ sādhyo vā syānnavotthitaḥ ||62||  iti tamakaśvāsaḥ |
translation: When the wind assumes a disjointed flow , it engages with the air passages . At that time, grasping the neck and head, and drawing up the phlegm , it performs such actions as causing a wheeze , making the breath rough, and impeding the life force. It becomes intensely severe , brings about difficulty in breathing , causes coughing fits , makes one delirious , and causes great distress at the time of phlegm's release . Upon the cessation of this affliction, one experiences happiness for a short while . When the throat becomes affected, it becomes difficult for one to speak , and they do not find sleep , even when lying down , tormented by labored breathing . Those nearby perceive it as distressing, while those seated near such a person find comfort . With sunken eyes , a dry mouth , irregular breathing , one experiences this ailment . It may intensify due to factors such as cold , wind , or phlegm . If one can endure this condition without giving in , they can overcome (*sādh

sloka: jvaramūrcchāparītasya vidyāt pratamakaṃ tu tam |  udāvartarajo'jīrṇaklinnakāyanirodhajaḥ ||63||  tamasā vardhate'tyarthaṃ śītaiścāśu praśāmyati |  majjatastamasīvā'sya vidyāt santamakaṃ tu tam ||64||  iti pratamakasantamakaśvāsau |
translation: When the air enters through the ears, adhering to the neck and head, restraining the breath, causing a gritty sound and violent breathing that hinders the mind, leading to delusion and causing great distress when the phlegm is expelled; upon its release, there is a moment of happiness before the throat constricts, making it difficult to speak or sleep, as the breath becomes labored and hot, drying out the mouth, and the eyes become intensely bright; with each inhalation and exhalation, the phlegm increases due to the cold wind and rain; upon mastery of this breath, characterized by alternating phases of restraint and release, one may achieve liberation and relief. This is known as tamaka breath.

sloka: rūkṣāyāsodbhavaḥ koṣṭhe kṣudro vāta udīrayan |  kṣudraśvāso na so'tyarthaṃ duḥkhenāṅgaprabādhakaḥ ||65|| hinasti na sa gātrāṇi na ca duḥkho yathetare |  na ca bhojanapānānāṃ niruṇaddhyucitāṃ gatim ||66||  nendriyāṇāṃ vyathāṃ nāpi kāñcidāpādayedrujam |  sa sādhya ukto balinaḥ sarve cāvyaktalakṣaṇāḥ ||67||  iti śvāsāḥ samuddiṣṭā hikkāścaiva svalakṣaṇaiḥ |68|
translation: The breath that originates in a feeble state within a tough locus , stirred by the wind , is the one that immediately stills, whether it is feverish or caused by fainting, and grows due to darkness . This type of breath greatly increases in cold and quickly calms down when in contact with something cool. This, being the first type, does not harm the physical limbs , nor does it cause discomfort similar to other types. It does not disrupt the proper course of eating and drinking, nor does it disturb the functions of the senses. It is powerful, has unmanifest qualities, and has been described as the primary type of breath, characterized by its distinct features. Additionally, it neither brings about any suffering to the sense organs , nor does it cause any specific harm at any time . This, indeed, is the powerful and unmanifest type of breath that has been indicated as such, including its subtle characteristics . As for hikkāḥ, they will be explained separately.

sloka: eṣāṃ prāṇaharā varjyā ghorāste hyāśukāriṇaḥ ||68||  bheṣajaiḥ sādhyayāpyāṃstu kṣipraṃ bhiṣagupācaret |  upekṣitā daheyurhi śuṣkaṃ kakṣamivānalaḥ ||69||
translation: These intense life-takers, born from a small wind in the body cavity and shallow breath, and painful, limb-harming, cause destruction like a hot fire drying up grass. Therefore, one should quickly seek treatment from a physician for such harsh efforts and hiccups, which can be cured with proper medicines. Neglecting it results in further damage. The nature, cause, and symptoms of these hiccups are subtly described, and their characteristics differ from other causes of discomfort, such as those caused by irregular eating and drinking habits or the senses. The strong hiccups are unseen, but their symptoms are evident.

sloka: kāraṇasthānamūlaikyādekameva cikitsitam |  dvayorapi yathādṛṣṭamṛṣibhistannibodhata ||70||  hikkāśvāsārditaṃ snigdhairādau svedairupācaret |  āktaṃ lavaṇatailena nāḍīprastarasaṅkaraiḥ ||71||  tairasya grathitaḥ śleṣmā srotaḥsvabhivilīyate |  khāni mārdavamāyānti tato vātānulomatā ||72||  yathā'drikuñjeṣvarkāṃśutaptaṃ viṣyandate himam |  śleṣmā taptaḥ sthiro dehe svedairviṣyandate tathā ||73||  svinnaṃ jñātvā tatastūrṇaṃ bhojayet snigdhamodanam |  matsyānāṃ śūkarāṇāṃ vā rasairdadhyuttareṇa vā ||74|| tataḥ śleṣmaṇi saṃvṛddhe vamanaṃ pāyayettu tam |  pippalīsaindhavakṣaudrairyuktaṃ vātāvirodhi yat ||75||  nirhṛte sukhamāpnoti sa kaphe duṣṭavigrahe |  srotaḥsu ca viśuddheṣu caratyavihato'nilaḥ ||76||
translation: The root causes, when manifested, should be treated by a skilled physician using suitable medicines, as seen in the treatises. Just as when excess phlegm and bile are aggravated, they should be cleansed through therapeutic emesis when phlegm becomes prominent, using drugs that counter wind disorders. Once the phlegm has been eliminated, comfort is attained, and one moves about unhindered in purified channels. Similarly, when there is an increase in the faulty bodily humor, therapeutic emesis should be administered using drugs like Pippali, Sauvarcala, and rock salt, which counteract wind disorders, after phlegm has been eliminated. Once the unfavorable bodily humor is removed, comfort is attained, and one moves about unhindered in purified channels.

sloka: līnaśceddoṣaśeṣaḥ syāddhūmaistaṃ nirharedbudhaḥ |  haridrāṃ patrameraṇḍamūlaṃ lākṣāṃ manaḥśilām ||77||  sadevadārvalaṃ māṃsīṃ piṣṭvā vartiṃ prakalpayet |  tāṃ ghṛtāktāṃ pibeddhūmaṃ yavairvā ghṛtasaṃyutaiḥ ||78||  madhūcchiṣṭaṃ sarjarasaṃ ghṛtaṃ mallakasampuṭe |  kṛtvā dhūmaṃ pibecchṛṅgaṃ bālaṃ vā snāyu vā gavām ||79||  syonākavardhamānānāṃ nāḍīṃ śuṣkāṃ kuśasya vā |  padmakaṃ gugguluṃ lohaṃ śallakīṃ vā ghṛtāplutam ||80||
translation: The impurity, having caused all the faults, should be eradicated by a learned one through a united approach, just as in the treatment of similar ailments. At first, one should induce gentle sweating through heat and oil application, causing the blocked channels to open up and soften. Then, heat should be applied through sunlight or fire, making obstructed bodily substances liquified, solidified, and mobile again, thus establishing stability in the body. Knowing this, one should promptly consume a nourishing rice dish, seasoned with appropriate salt and oil, along with fish or pork, or any other oily substance, and clarified butter. In case of phlegm increase, use drugs like pippalī, rock salt, and horse gram, contradictory to vata, providing relief as foul humors get eliminated and channels get purified, resulting in unobstructed wind movement in a healthy body.

sloka: svarakṣīṇātisārāsṛkpittadāhānubandhajān |  madhurasnigdhaśītādyairhikkāśvāsānupācaret ||81||
translation: Having eliminated all faults, the wise one should carefully attend to oneself with sweet and mild substances such as turmeric, *Eranda* stem, lac, crystal clear mineral stones, and wood, and also consume honey-mixed clarified butter and leftover sweet rice in ghee kept in a bark box. Dry *Kusha* grass or lotus fibers should be used to fill a tube made from the hide of daily fattening cows, which should then be inserted into one's own dry, withered channels.

sloka: na svedyāḥ pittadāhārtā raktasvedātivartinaḥ |  kṣīṇadhātubalā rūkṣā garbhiṇyaścāpi pittalāḥ ||82||  koṣṇaiḥ kāmamuraḥkaṇṭhaṃ snehasekaiḥ saśarkaraiḥ |  utkārikopanāhaiśca svedayen mṛdubhiḥ kṣaṇam ||83||  tilomāmāṣagodhūmacūrṇairvātaharaiḥ saha |  snehaiścotkārikā sāmlaiḥ sakṣīrairvā kṛtā hitā ||84||  navajvarāmadoṣeṣu rūkṣasvedaṃ vilaṅghanam |  samīkṣyollekhanaṃ vā'pi kārayellavaṇāmbunā ||85||  atiyogoddhataṃ vātaṃ dṛṣṭvā vātaharairbhiṣak |  rasādyairnātiśītoṣṇairabhyaṅgaiśca śamaṃ nayet ||86||  udāvarte tathā''dhmāne mātuluṅgāmlavetasaiḥ |  hiṅgupīlubiḍaiścānnaṃ yuktaṃ syādanulomanam ||87||
translation: The one who protects himself should, in the present time, causatively make (his body) endure for a moment the sweating, caused by warm substances, expelling thus the phlegm, bile, and wind that have become excessive, as well as the products of digestion, and also the rough ones, with the help of smooth substances, unctuous substances, and those that cause sneezing, and also apply (to his body) in a suitable way, ointments prepared with salts, and other such remedies, in cases of new onset of fever, bile, poison, and other such afflictions, or even just by observing their initial signs, as well as in case of excessive upward movement of wind, or even by just observing it, or in case of a sudden increase of vata, or when it moves in an abnormal way, or when it becomes too high, or when it moves upward, or when it becomes too sharp, or when it moves in an irregular way, or when it becomes too uneven, or when it moves in a zigzag way, or when it becomes too unstable, or when it moves in an unstable way, or when it moves in an irregular way, or when it moves in an upward direction, or when it moves in an erratic way, or when it moves in a zigzag way, or when it moves in a reverse way, or when it moves in an irregular way, or when it moves in a wayward direction, or when it moves in an unnatural way, or when it moves in a deviant way, or when it moves in an abnormal way, or when it moves in a twisted way, or when it moves in an improper way, or when it moves in a disorderly way, or when it moves in a wrong way, or when it moves in a perverse way, or when it moves in a wrong direction, or when it moves in a distorted way, or when it moves in a crooked way, or when it moves in a convoluted way, or when it moves in a contorted way, or when it moves in a way that it shouldn't, or when it moves in an incorrect way, or when it moves in a way that is not normal, or when it moves in a way that is not appropriate, or when it moves in a wrongful way,

sloka: hikkāśvāsāmayī hyeko balavān durbalo'paraḥ |  kaphādhikastathaivaiko rūkṣo bahvanilo'paraḥ ||88||  kaphādhike balasthe ca vamanaṃ savirecanam |  kuryāt pathyāśine dhūmalehādiśamanaṃ tataḥ ||89|| vātikān durbalān bālān vṛddhāṃścānilasūdanaiḥ |  tarpayedeva śamanaiḥ snehayūṣarasādibhiḥ ||90||
translation: The one afflicted by an excess of bile and profuse sweating, rendered weak by dryness of tissues, and tormented by wind, should be treated using coolant substances and oleation. For such an individual, symptoms like burning sensation, thirst, and redness of the body indicate vitiation of the bile dosha. To alleviate this condition, moderate sweating-inducing measures, such as using sesame oil, cumin seed powder, black gram, and rice, along with oleation therapies, should be implemented. If there is an increase in the wind dosha, which manifests in symptoms like dryness, roughness, and emaciation, then treatments involving unctuous substances and sweet, sour, and salty tastes should be administered. The physician should evaluate the disease progression and decide whether to use cooling or heating therapies, such as applying cold or warm compresses made of bitter or astringent herbs. The diet should consist of easily digestible and nourishing food items, including grains like wheat and barley, along with ghee, to balance the wind dosha.

sloka: anutkliṣṭakaphāsvinnadurbalānāṃ viśodhanāt |  vāyurlabdhāspado marma saṃśoṣyāśu haredasūn ||91||  dṛḍhān bahukaphāṃstasmādrasairānūpavārijaiḥ |  tṛptānviśodhayetsvinnān bṛṃhayeditarān bhiṣak ||92||  barhitittiridakṣāśca jāṅgalāśca mṛgadvijāḥ |  daśamūlīrase siddhāḥ kaulatthe vā rase hitāḥ ||93||
translation: For one who is strong and has a superior wind humor, let him induce emesis and purgation due to its elimination. For those who are weak, with excessive phlegm and bile, equally harsh and drying measures should be adopted. For those who are weak, young, or old, they should be pacified with gentle, wind-reducing treatments and nourished with divine, calming preparations, given with love and care.

sloka: nidigdhikāṃ bilvamadhyaṃ karkaṭākhyāṃ durālabhām |  trikaṇṭakaṃ guḍūcīṃ ca kulatthāṃśca sacitrakān ||94|| jale paktvā rasaḥ pūtaḥ pippalīghṛtabharjitaḥ |  sanāgaraḥ salavaṇaḥ syādyūṣo bhojane hitaḥ ||95||  rāsnāṃ balāṃ pañcamūlaṃ hrasvaṃ mudgān sacitrakān |  paktvā'mbhasi rase tasmin yūṣaḥ sādhyaśca pūrvavat ||96||  pallavānmātuluṅgasya nimbasya kulakasya ca |  paktvā mudgāṃśca savyoṣān kṣārayūṣaṃ vipācayet ||97||  dattvā salavaṇaṃ kṣāraṃ śigrūṇi maricāni ca |  yuktyā saṃsādhito yūṣo hikkāśvāsavikāranut ||98||  kāsamardakapatrāṇāṃ yūṣaḥ śobhāñjanasya ca |  śuṣkamūlakayūṣaśca hikkāśvāsanivāraṇaḥ ||99||  sadadhivyoṣasarpiṣko yūṣo vārtākajo hitaḥ |  śāliṣaṣṭikagodhūmayavānnānyanavāni ca ||100||  hiṅgusauvarcalājājībiḍapauṣkaracitrakaiḥ |  siddhā karkaṭaśṛṅgyā ca yavāgūḥ śvāsahikkinām ||101||  daśamūlīśaṭīrāsnāpippalīmūlapauṣkaraiḥ |  śṛṅgītāmalakībhārgīguḍūcīnāgarāmbubhiḥ ||102||  yavāgūṃ vidhinā siddhāṃ kaṣāyaṃ vā pibennaraḥ |  kāsahṛdgrahapārśvārtihikkāśvāsapraśāntaye ||103||  puṣkarāhvaśaṭīvyoṣamātuluṅgāmlavetasaiḥ |  yojayedannapānāni sasarpirbiḍahiṅgubhiḥ ||104||
translation:
For those with unimpaired senses, air obtained from the labored breathing of weakened and congested patients should be purified by suitable means, such as refinement through heat, and then given to them. This will alleviate their phlegmatic conditions and strengthen them. Additionally, such purified air, mixed with the juices of various water-dwelling plants, when consumed in proper measure, will also invigorate other physicians who are exhausted, weakened, and afflicted by an excess of phlegm and bile. This treatment, involving the use of purified air and a concoction made from the juices of ten specific water-dwelling plants, can bring about a cure for such patients.

Ingesting these juices, mixed with suitable plant materials such as kaṣāya, vārijas, tittiri, mṛga, dvijā, daśamūlī, kaulatthe, rase, and hitāḥ, can also help to alleviate hiccups, other breathing difficulties, and provide nourishment for healthy individuals. This therapy is recommended for those skilled in the healing arts, as well as for forest-dwelling ascetics and birds. The ten water-dwelling plants mentioned, when properly prepared and used in conjunction with purified air, can help to promote health and well-being.

sloka: daśamūlasya vā kvāthamathavā devadāruṇaḥ |  tṛṣito madirāṃ vā'pi hikkāśvāsī pibennaraḥ ||105||
translation: For alleviating hiccups caused by a thirst for wine, should one use a medicine prepared from the deciphered decoction of either a tree of the name Devadāruṇa or the roots of a Dasamūla, or should the thirsty man drink from it?

sloka: pāṭhāṃ madhurasāṃ rāsnāṃ saralaṃ devadāru ca |  prakṣālya jarjarīkṛtya surāmaṇḍe nidhāpayet ||106||
translation: After rinsing out the mouth and smoothing away any roughness, one should cause to place in the sura-mandala either a drink sweetened with sugarcane juice or cool, refreshing water from a deodar tree.

sloka: taṃ mandalavaṇaṃ kṛtvā bhiṣak prasṛtasammitam |  pāyayettu tato hikkā śvāsaścaivopaśāmyati ||107||  hiṅgu sauvarcalaṃ kolaṃ samaṅgāṃ pippalīṃ balām |  mātuluṅgarase piṣṭamāranālena vā pibet ||108||  sauvarcalaṃ nāgaraṃ ca bhārgīṃ dviśarkarāyutam |  uṣṇāmbunā pibedetaddhikkāśvāsavikāranut ||109||  bhārgīnāgarayoḥ kalkaṃ maricakṣārayostathā |  pītadrucitrakāsphotāmūrvāṇāṃ cāmbunā pibet ||110||  madhūlikā tugākṣīrī nāgaraṃ pippalī tathā |  utkārikā ghṛte siddhā śvāse pittānubandhaje ||111||  śvāvidhaṃ śaśamāṃsaṃ ca śallakasya ca śoṇitam |  pippalīghṛtasiddhāni śvāse vātānubandhaje ||112||  suvarcalāraso dugdhaṃ ghṛtaṃ trikaṭukānvitam |  śālyodanasyānupānaṃ vātapittānuge hitam ||113||  śirīṣapuṣpasvarasaḥ saptaparṇasya vā punaḥ |  pippalīmadhusaṃyuktaḥ kaphapittānuge mataḥ ||114||  madhukaṃ pippalīmūlaṃ guḍo gośvaśakṛdrasaḥ [1] |  ghṛtaṃ kṣaudraṃ kāsaśvāsahikkābhiṣyandināṃ śubham ||115||  kharāśvoṣṭravarāhāṇāṃ meṣasya ca gajasya ca |  śakṛdrasaṃ bahukaphe caikaikaṃ madhunā pibet ||116||  kṣāraṃ cāpyaśvagandhāyā lihyānnā kṣaudrasarpiṣā |  mayūrapādanālaṃ vā śakalaṃ śallakasya vā ||117||  śvāvijjāṇḍakacāṣāṇāṃ [2] romāṇi kurarasya vā |  śṛṅgyekadviśaphānāṃ [3] vā carmāsthīni khurāṃstathā ||118||  sarvāṇyekaikaśo vā'pi dagdhvā kṣaudraghṛtānvitam |  cūrṇaṃ līḍhvā jayet kāsaṃ hikkāṃ śvāsaṃ ca dāruṇam ||119||  ete hi kaphasaṃruddhagatiprāṇaprakopajāḥ [4] |  tasmāttanmārgaśuddhyarthaṃ deyā lehā na niṣkaphe ||120||
translation: To alleviate cough and difficult breathing, the physician should prepare a mixture of honey, liquor, refined sugar, finely ground rock candy, and bel fruit juice. This remedy, when taken in small sips, will help mitigate conditions caused by an excess of kapha in the respiratory system.

sloka: kāsine cchardanaṃ dadyāt svarabhaṅge ca buddhimān |  vātaśleṣmaharairyuktaṃ tamake tu virecanam ||121||  udīryate bhṛśataraṃ mārgarodhādvahajjalam |  yathā tathā'nilastasya mārgaṃ nityaṃ viśodhayet ||122||
translation: The wise physician should give an emetic, featuring a mildly salty taste, to that person; having first administered a preparation combining colocynth and vadarika after the cessation of hiccups and forced breathing. The excretory passages of that individual should be regularly cleansed, eliminating blockages as one washes dirt from a road. Utilizing pippali, madhulika, tugaksirotpippali, utkarike ghrita, and siddha svasa, one should alleviate the various transformations of vata, pitta, and kapha in the body, including symptoms like discolored nails, urine, feces, and tongue. A decoction, comprised of hare, mongoose, porcupine, and rhinoceros meat, ghee, and honey, should be administered to counteract vata-induced morbidity. Beneficial vata foods, such as shirisha flowers, rice gruel, madhu, parnasamyukta kapha, and sarpiṣā, should be given in moderation. Impure substances, like an inferior mayura pada nalam, should be avoided; instead, administer pure ones that enhance strength and complexion.

sloka: śaṭīcorakajīvantītvaṅmustaṃ puṣkarāhvayam |  surasaṃ tāmalakyelā pippalyaguru nāgaram ||123||  vālakaṃ ca samaṃ cūrṇaṃ kṛtvā'ṣṭaguṇaśarkaram |  sarvathā tamake śvāse hikkāyāṃ ca prayojayet ||124||
translation: A wise person should make a concerted effort to clear obstructed channels, using "svah" expelling breaths at designated locations. They should also force out phlegm and air from the blocked passages of the nose and throat, and cleanse the breath path with water as necessary. In all ways, they should cause the eightfold virtue of purity to be accomplished in this manner, constantly keeping the breath path pure.

sloka: muktāpravālavaidūryaśaṅkhasphaṭikamañjanam |  sasāragandhakācārkasūkṣmailālavaṇadvayam [1] ||125||  tāmrāyorajasī rūpyaṃ sasaugandhikasīsakam [2] |  jātīphalaṃ śaṇādbījamapāmārgasya taṇḍulāḥ ||126||  eṣāṃ pāṇitalaṃ cūrṇaṃ tulyānāṃ kṣaudrasarpiṣā |  hikkāṃ śvāsaṃ ca kāsaṃ ca līḍhamāśu niyacchati ||127||  añjanāttimiraṃ kācaṃ nīlikāṃ puṣpakaṃ tamaḥ |  malyaṃ [3] kaṇḍūmabhiṣyandamarma caiva praṇāśayet ||128||  iti muktādyaṃ cūrṇam |
translation: Prepare a paste from finely powdered pearl, coral, lapis lazuli, conch, quartz, gem, lotus pollen, costus, nutgrass, Indian ironwood, cardamom, long pepper, agalloch, and belleric myrobalan, all mixed together in equal parts. Once prepared, combine it with eight parts of sugar. This mixture can be utilized in various ways: as snuff for the nose, to alleviate hiccups and breathing troubles. It can also eliminate catarrh, blue-black discoloration, redness, and dark circles around the eyes, as well as greasy hair, itching, boils or pimples, and inflamed areas of the body.

sloka: śaṭīpuṣkaramūlānāṃ cūrṇamāmalakasya ca |  madhunā saṃyutaṃ lehyaṃ cūrṇaṃ vā kālalohajam ||129||
translation: Of the powdered roots of Shatipushpa and impurity-free Kasha, mix it with honey or consume it in a burnt form. Such consumption will quickly help overcome fatigue, thirst, and hunger.

sloka: saśarkarāṃ tāmalakīṃ drākṣāṃ gośvaśakṛdrasam |  tulyaṃ guḍaṃ nāgaraṃ ca prāśayennāvayettathā ||130||  laśunasya palāṇḍorvā mūlaṃ gṛñjanakasya vā |  nāvayeccandanaṃ vā'pi nārīkṣīreṇa saṃyutam ||131||  sukhoṣṇaṃ ghṛtamaṇḍaṃ vā saindhavenāvacūrṇitam |  nāvayenmākṣikīṃ viṣṭhāmalaktakarasena vā ||132||  nārīkṣīreṇa siddhaṃ vā sarpirmadhurakairapi |  pītaṃ nasto niṣiktaṃ vā sadyo hikkāṃ niyacchati ||133||  sakṛduṣṇaṃ sakṛcchītaṃ vyatyāsāddhikkināṃ payaḥ |  pāne nastaḥkriyāyāṃ vā śarkarāmadhusaṃyutam ||134||
translation: Of the powdered roots of śaṭīpuṣkara and āmalaka mixed with madhu, or even of kāla, loha, and jam, one is recommended to take (prāśayet) it as a medication; or apply (āvayet) it, for instance, smeared with nārīkṣīra or saffron, or in the form of a paste made with śarkarā and madhu. Such medications, when promptly administered, can quickly alleviate hikkā, thirst, or even heat, or counteract poisoning, intoxication, or digestive disorders.

sloka: adhobhāgairghṛtaṃ siddhaṃ sadyo hikkāṃ niyacchati |  pippalīmadhuyuktau vā rasau dhātrīkapitthayoḥ ||135||  lājālākṣāmadhudrākṣāpippalyaśvaśakṛdrasān |  lihyāt kolamadhudrākṣāpippalīnāgarāṇi vā ||136||  śītāmbusekaḥ sahasā trāso vismāpanaṃ bhayam |  krodhaharṣapriyodvegā hikkāpracyāvanā matāḥ ||137||  hikkāśvāsavikārāṇāṃ nidānaṃ yat prakīrtitam |  varjyamārogyakāmaistaddhikkāśvāsavikāribhiḥ ||138||
translation: "A mixture consisting of ghee, sugar, tamarisk, grapes, cow milk, dog milk, sharkara, licorice rasam, and equal parts of jaggery, gud, naga sugandhi, and candan, when consumed with a woman who has mixed curd, butter, and saindhava, can immediately alleviate hiccups. Furthermore, consuming ripe pippali in the form of churna or drinking payasam prepared with sugar and madhu is said to cure chronic hiccups."

sloka: hikkāśvāsānubandhā [1] ye śuṣkoraḥkaṇṭhatālukāḥ |  prakṛtyā rūkṣadehāśca sarpirbhistānupācaret ||139||  daśamūlarase sarpirdadhimaṇḍe ca sādhayet |  kṛṣṇāsauvarcalakṣāravayaḥsthāhiṅgucorakaiḥ ||140||  kāyasthayā ca tat pānāddhikkāśvāsau praṇāśayet |141|
translation: The serpent, characterized by dryness and a rough body, and bound by the elements of hiccups and sighs, should dwell in its lair in the nether regions. It should prepare a concoction using the juices of pippalī, madhu, dhātrī, kapitthayoḥ, lāja, āla, akṣā, and drākṣā, combined with the ashes of kola, nāgarāṇi, and śīta ambu sekaḥ. This should be swiftly consumed through the mouth to alleviate hiccups and other respiratory disturbances, which are detrimental to health and desires, and can cause fear, astonishment, anger, and joy. These disturbances are rooted in hiccoughs and sighs, which must be eliminated.

sloka: tejovatyabhayā kuṣṭhaṃ pippalī kaṭurohiṇī ||141||  bhūtīkaṃ pauṣkaraṃ mūlaṃ palāśaścitrakaḥ śaṭī |  sauvarcalaṃ tāmalakī saindhavaṃ bilvapeśikā ||142||  tālīsapatraṃ jīvantī vacā tairakṣasammitaiḥ |  hiṅgupādairghṛtaprasthaṃ pacettoye caturguṇe ||143||  etadyathābalaṃ pītvā hikkāśvāsau jayennaraḥ |  śothānilārśograhaṇīhṛtpārśvaruja [1] eva ca ||144||  iti tejovatyādighṛtam |
translation: One should properly prepare a decoction using the roots of ten plants, namely tejovati, kustha, pippalii, kaṭu-rohini, bhūtī, pauṣkara, mūla of palāśa and citraka, tala-sapatra, jīvantī, vacā, combined with akṣa sammitaiḥ, honey, cow's milk, sugar, clarified butter, and yogurt. Drinking this mixture can alleviate cough, hiccups, fainting spells, and help retain bodily strength.

sloka: manaḥśilāsarjarasalākṣārajanipadmakaiḥ |  mañjiṣṭhailaiśca karṣāṃśaiḥ prasthaḥ siddho ghṛtāddhitaḥ ||145|| jīvanīyopasiddhaṃ vā sakṣaudraṃ lehayeddhṛtam |  tryūṣaṇaṃ dādhikaṃ vā'pi pibedvāsāghṛtaṃ tathā ||146|| iti manaḥśilādighṛtam |
translation: By preparing ghee with a mixture of medicinal plants and trees, including tejovatī, abhayā, kuṣṭham, pippalī, kaṭu, rohiṇī, bhūtī, kam, pauṣkaram, mūlam, palāśaḥ, citrakaḥ, śaṭī, sauvarcalam, tāmalakī, saindhavam, bilva, pā, īśikā, tālī, sapa, tram, jīvantī, and vacā, combined with akṣa, sammitaiḥ, and hiṅgupādairghṛtaprastham, one achieves a siddha ghṛtam. Drinking this or even a quarter of it, mixed with water, on a daily basis will ensure good health and vitality, known as manaḥśilādighṛtam.

sloka: yatkiñcit kaphavātaghnamuṣṇaṃ vātānulomanam |  bheṣajaṃ pānamatraṃ vā taddhitaṃ śvāsahikkine ||147||
translation: Use, whenever it is necessary, a mind free from impurities, extract of licorice, bitter and astringent substances, and clarified butter prepared with rice grains and Manjista plant, as medicine or just water; this is the treatment recommended for those suffering from respiratory ailments.

sloka: vātakṛdvā kaphaharaṃ kaphakṛdvā'nilāpaham |  kāryaṃ naikāntikaṃ tābhyāṃ prāyaḥ śreyo'nilāpaham ||148||  sarveṣāṃ bṛṃhaṇe hyalpaḥ śakyaśca prāyaśo bhavet |  nātyarthaṃ  śamane'pāyo bhṛśo'śakyaśca karśane ||149||
translation: That which reduces phlegm and, conversely, generates wind, and whose quality is warmth, which generally moves in a gentle, upward direction, serving as a remedy for residual phlegm—that is the very act of breathing. On the other hand, consistently trying to enlarge [the body] is usually unsuccessful, while reducing it is often challenging; maintaining equilibrium is mostly unfeasible, and fully restraining the senses is nearly impossible.

sloka: tasmācchuddhānaśuddhāṃśca śamanairbṛṃhaṇairapi |  hikkāśvāsārditāñjantūn prāyaśaḥ samupācaret ||150||
translation: Therefore, one should generally see to managing, through regulation and augmentation, both pure and impure entities as well as the bodily exhalations caused by hiccups and sighs. This, in most cases, promotes overall well-being and is not easily accomplished through drastic or forceful measures.

sloka: tatra ślokaḥ durjayatve samutpattau kriyaikatve ca kāraṇam |  liṅgaṃ pathyaṃ ca hikkānāṃ śvāsānāṃ ceha darśitam ||151||  ityagniveśakṛte tantre carakapratisaṃskṛte'prāpte dṛḍhabalasampūrite cikitsāsthāne hikkāśvāsacikitsitaṃ nāma saptadaśo'dhyāyaḥ ||17||
translation: Therefore, in the context of discussing the treatment of hiccups and difficult breathing, the text "agniveshakrta tantra" explains that the reason for their arising and becoming difficult to overcome lies in the unity of cause, and the means for their treatment is described as soothing and tonic. This has been presented in the seventeenth chapter of the text under the name "hikkashwasacikitsita."

sloka: athāto raktapittacikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ ||1|| iti ha smāha  bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: Now we shall describe the treatment for the condition of rakta pitta, a difficult ailment to conquer. This has been declared in the chapter "Agni Vesha" of the authoritative text "Caraka." The therapy for hiccups and shortness of breath, as mentioned here, becomes firmly established when all necessary conditions align. This concludes the first verse. So spoke Bhagavan Atreya.

sloka: viharantaṃ jitātmānaṃ pañcagaṅge punarvasum| praṇamyovāca nirmohamagniveśo'gnivarcasam||3|| bhagavan raktapittasya heturuktaḥ salakṣaṇaḥ| vaktavyaṃ yat paraṃ tasya vaktumarhasi tadguro||4||
translation: Now, as he wandered, having subdued his mind, near the fifth branch of the sacred river, after paying obeisance, the Lord of Fire, Agni, addressed him, "O Lord, you should describe the primary cause, excellently characterized, of the condition known as rakta pitta."

sloka: gururuvāca mahāgadaṃ mahāvegamagnivacchīghrakāri ca|  hetulakṣaṇavicchīghraṃ raktapittamupācaret||5|| tasyoṣṇaṃ tīkṣṇamamlaṃ ca kaṭūni lavaṇāni ca|  gharmaścānnavidāhaśca hetuḥ pūrvaṃ nidarśitaḥ||6||
translation: The revered teacher said to the exalted one, who had humbly bowed down by the Ganges, "Noble sir, I have previously explained the evident cause of your condition. Now, you should manage the sharp, piercing, bitter, astringent, and salty heat, as well as the excessive bodily heat, which has been indicated before."

sloka: tairhetubhiḥ samutkliṣṭaṃ pittaṃ raktaṃ prapadyate| tadyonitvāt prapannaṃ ca vardhatetat pradūṣayat||7|| tasyoṣmaṇā dravo dhāturdhātordhātoḥ prasicyate| svidyatastena saṃvṛddhiṃ bhūyastadadhigacchati||8||
translation: The guru, wielding a mace and possessing a swiftness like fire and wind, declared: "The Pitta dosha, which has been activated and made red by certain factors , seeks out those factors that intensify its heat and sharpness . Its essence, which includes heat, sharpness, lightness, minimality, oiliness, and saltiness, is found in food and during daytime hours . This has been previously identified as the cause of disease."

sloka: saṃyogāddūṣaṇāttattu sāmānyādgandhavarṇayoḥ| raktasya pittamākhyātaṃ raktapittaṃ manīṣibhiḥ||9||
translation: Through the association of unwholesome factors, the element of phlegm adopts the qualities of color and smell of bile; similarly, when bile is influenced by those same factors, it becomes known as raktapitta (a disease) among the wise. It seeks its origin and, upon finding it, grows and further contaminates the body.

sloka: plīhānaṃ ca yakṛccaiva tadadhiṣṭhāya vartate| srotāṃsi raktavāhīni tanmūlāni hi dehinām||10||
translation: Impurities and old age are sustained by my indwelling in the qualities of raktavaha (carrier of reddish humor) and pitta (bile), which, according to the learned, are respectively the cause of color and redness in bodily tissues.

sloka: sāndraṃ sapāṇḍu sasnehaṃ picchilaṃ ca kaphānvitam| śyāvāruṇaṃ saphenaṃ ca tanu rūkṣaṃ ca vātikam||11|| raktapittaṃ kaṣāyābhaṃ kṛṣṇaṃ gomūtrasannibham| mecakāgāradhūmābhamañjanābhaṃ ca paittikam||12|| saṃsṛṣṭaliṅgaṃ saṃsargāttriliṅgaṃ sānnipātikam|13|
translation: The fluid in the spleen, as well as that in the stomach, is sustained as pale and anointed, endowed with phlegm. The red and white fluids, flowing from the roots of the vessels, reside in living beings, resembling cow dung, soot, and collyrium. They become manifest through association, appearing in three forms due to various causes.

sloka: ekadoṣānugaṃ  sādhyaṃ dvidoṣaṃ yāpyamucyate||13|| yattridoṣamasādhyaṃ tanmandāgnerativegavat|vyādhibhiḥ  kṣīṇadehasya vṛddhasyānaśnataśca yat||14||
translation: A single faultful thing should be made a goal for correction, while two faults call for abandoning; that which is incurable, afflicted by three faults, is like a body, weakened by diseases, wasting away, not eating, and also touched by various ailments, or like pus, smoke, ash, dirt, or a mix of various excremental matters.

sloka: gatirūrdhvamadhaścaiva  raktapittasya darśitā| ūrdhvā saptavidhadvārā dvidvārā tvadharā gatiḥ||15||
translation: Upon examining a raktapitta patient's symptoms, one should recognize that their gati, or movement, is upward and downward. In a healthy state, however, gati is described as having seven openings represented by the compound word sapta-vidha-dvārā, with feminine singular number and instrumental singular case, referring to the ten bodily openings: two eyes, two ears, nostrils, mouth, urethra, and anus. The causal present participle darśitā, derived from the passive past participle rakta, implies that this observation should be made in a clear and evident manner. Moreover, the condition of an elderly or undernourished body with excessive heat like fire or milder symptoms can be difficult to treat in three ways, referred to as tri-asādhyam.

sloka: sapta cchidrāṇi śirasi dve cādhaḥsādhyamūrdhvagam| yāpyaṃ tvadhogaṃ mārgau tu sādhyaṃ prapadyate||16||
translation: The path consisting of seven openings in front and two behind indeed leads to accomplishment when followed upwards and downwards. This is the destination that one reaches.

sloka: yadā tu sarvacchidrebhyo romakūpebhya eva  tāmasaṅkhyeyāṃ gatiṃ tasyāhurāntikīm||17||
translation: When one turns downward, it is said that there exists an approach to the countless tamasic paths at the very culmination of the seven openings on the head (i.e., hair follicles), as stated in the sādhya text.

sloka: yaccobhayābhyāṃ mārgābhyāmatimātraṃ pravartate| tulyaṃ kuṇapagandhena raktaṃ kṛṣṇamatīva ca||18|| saṃsṛṣṭaṃ kaphavātābhyāṃ kaṇṭhe sajjati  cāpi yat| yaccāpyupadravaiḥ sarvairyathoktaiḥ samabhidrutam||19|| hāridranīlaharitatāmrairvarṇairupadrutam| kṣīṇasya  kāsamānasya yacca na  sidhyati||20||
translation: When both openings of vision and other senses become completely engrossed inward, they say that this is the closest approach to one's true nature, resembling a thing equally tainted by the smell of equal parts of excrement, it turns black like krsna mati (black earth), produced by the conjunction of phlegm and wind in the throat; similarly, when affected by all adversities mentioned earlier, it becomes discolored by various hues of green, blue, and red, and for one whose kasa (disease, disorder) is completely wasted away, it does not become successful.

sloka: yadvidoṣānugaṃ yadvā śāntaṃ śāntaṃ prakupyati| mārgānmārgaṃ caredyadvā  yāpyaṃ  pittamasṛk catat||21||
translation: Whichever one, whether affected by defects or tranquil, gets angry or remains calm, should pursue this path or that, cause this course or that to be taken; just as an equal mixture of phlegm and bile, having the hues of green, blue, and reddish-brown, when generated in the throat, is ineffective for someone who is debilitated or afflicted by various ailments.

sloka: ekamārgaṃ balavato nātivegaṃ navotthitam|  raktapittaṃ  kāle sādhyaṃ syānnirupadravam||22||
translation: For a strong person, a single path is sufficiently adequate, not to be hastily adopted nor delayed. It should be accomplished during the proper time when afflicted by the "rakta pitta" condition, and when practiced, it will cause no harm.

sloka: snigdhoṣṇamuṣṇarūkṣaṃ ca raktapittasya kāraṇam| adhogasyottaraṃ  prāyaḥ pūrvaṃ syādūrdhvagasya tu||23|| ūrdhvagaṃ kaphasaṃsṛṣṭamadhogaṃ mārutānugam| dvimārgaṃ kaphavātābhyāmubhābhyāmanubadhyate||24||
translation: The single cause of an increased red bile (rakta Pitta) in a short time is an abnormally swift movement of the vata dosha through a single pathway; it typically emerges in the lower part of the body and can generally be alleviated without complications if treated at an early stage. Here, "snigdha-uṣṇam" refers to increased body temperature, while "rūkṣam" indicates dryness, both of which contribute to an aggravation of the red bile. The vata dosha, represented as "kapha-saṃsṛṣṭam māruta-anugam," is swiftly moving through one pathway, as shown by "ūrdhva-gam" and "dvi-mārgaṃ." This situation usually affects the lower part of the body, as suggested by "adhogasya" and "pūrvaṃ syāt ūrdhva-gasya tu" implies that, in some cases, it might ascend, causing different symptoms. The passage concludes by stating that treating this condition at an early stage, using "ubhābhyām anubadhyate," can prevent further complications.

sloka: akṣīṇabalamāṃsasya raktapittaṃ yadaśnataḥ| taddoṣaduṣṭamutkliṣṭaṃ nādau   stambhanamarhati||25|| galagrahaṃ pūtinasyaṃ mūrcchāyamaruciṃ jvaram| gulmaṃ plīhānamānāhaṃ kilāsaṃkṛcchramūtratām||26|| kuṣṭhānyarśāṃsi vīsarpaṃ varṇanāśaṃ bhagandaram|  buddhīndriyoparodhaṃ ca kuryāt stambhitamāditaḥ||27|| tasmādupekṣyaṃ balino baladoṣavicāriṇā |  raktapittaṃ prathamatapravṛddhaṃsiddhimicchatā||28||
translation: The one who eats excessive amounts of rich, warm, and dry foods tends to develop increased heat in their body, primarily caused by rakta and pitta doshas. This can lead to various symptoms, such as giddiness , fainting , fever , eructation , skin diseases , swelling , abscess , discoloration of the body , and swelling in the groin . These symptoms may also arise from disorders related to dosha imbalances, like vata obstruction or kapha excess. To prevent further aggravation of rakta and pitta, it is advised to avoid consuming rich, warm, and dry foods, instead opting for light and dry food items. If an individual, already weak due to rakta and pitta excess, neglects their condition, they should seek medical advice to address the root cause and take appropriate actions.

sloka: prāyeṇa hi  samutkliṣṭamāmadoṣāccharīriṇām| vṛddhiṃ  prayātipittāsṛktasmāttallaṅghyamāditaḥ||29|| mārgau doṣānubandhaṃ ca nidānaṃ prasamīkṣya ca| laṅghanaṃ raktapittādau tarpaṇaṃ vā prayojayet||30||
translation: For the most part, those who consume food tainted by impurities such as rakta (red blood cells) and pitta (bile) will typically develop defects such as weakness in the eyes, limbs, and muscles, hardening, stagnation, tremors, dizziness, vomiting, hiccups, bloating, belching, fainting, thirst, cough, leprosy, tuberculosis, wasting, etc. However, by examining the causes and symptoms of these defects, one can attempt to alleviate them through appropriate measures such as emesis or purgation, considering the strength of the person, the nature of the defect, and the time of administration, if one wishes to achieve progress and success.

sloka: hrīberacandanośīramustaparpaṭakaiḥ śṛtam| kevalaṃ  śṛtaśītaṃ  vā dadyāttoyaṃ pipāsave||31||
translation: For bodily beings, generally characterized by qualities such as Kliṣṭa doṣa, growth caused by an increase of such faults is typically discarded. One should consider the cause and effect of this disorder and deviate from the usual course. In the initial stages, one may offer a palliative treatment for an excess of rakta and pitta.

sloka: ūrdhvage tarpaṇaṃ pūrvaṃ peyāṃ pūrvamadhogate| kālasātmyānubandhajño dadyāt prakṛtikalpavit||32||  jalaṃ kharjūramṛdvīkāmadhūkaiḥ saparūṣakaiḥ| śṛtaśītaṃ prayoktavyaṃ tarpaṇārthe saśarkaram||33||
translation: With devotion and humility, one should offer, as the first tarpaṇa, cool water (using a conch, grass, flower, etc.) in the upward direction. This should be done at the very beginning of the rite. For subsequent tarpaṇas, one who understands the significance of time and natural disposition should cause (the water) to be poured without any specific ritual implement.

sloka: tarpaṇaṃ saghṛtakṣaudraṃ lājacūrṇaiḥ pradāpayet| ūrdhvagaṃ raktapittaṃ tat pītaṃ kāle vyapohati||34|| mandāgneramlasātmyāya tat sāmlamapi kalpayet| dāḍimāmalakairvidvānamlārthaṃcānudāpayet||35||
translation: The initial Tarpana offering should be made by pouring water from above, mixed with mustard seeds and rice grains. This should be offered to the reddish-hued Pitta. When offered at the appropriate time, it purifies one's nature. For the steadfast, learned seeker of the true meaning, a subsequent Tarpana offering should be caused to be made with fresh pomegranate and bilva fruit juices, as per the scriptural injunctions.

sloka: śāliṣaṣṭikanīvārakoradūṣapraśāntikāḥ| śyāmākaśca priyaṅguśca bhojanaṃ raktapittinām||36||
translation: For those with a reddish complexion, one should administer at the appropriate time an upward-directed emetic made from boiled rice, barley, and other pure powders to eliminate excess bile. Also, one should give them bitter substances such as pomegranates and Indian gooseberries to further aid digestion.

sloka: mudgā masūrāścaṇakāḥ samakuṣṭhāḍhakīphalāḥ| praśastāḥ sūpayūṣārthe kalpitā raktapittinām||37||
translation: For those afflicted by conditions associated with red and white complexions, a meal consisting of mudgā, masūra, caṇaka, shali, shastika, and kanari grains, as well as mung beans, urad dal, and dried gourd, has been specifically designed, being praised for its calming effects.

sloka: paṭolanimbavetrāgraplakṣavetasapallavāḥ| kirātatiktakaṃ śākaṃ gaṇḍīraḥ sakaṭhillakaḥ||38||
translation: The leaves of Patola, Nimba, and Plaksha, together with gram, masur, and phalaka, form the ingredients for Kiratatiktaka and Gandira; the īra of gaṇḍī, as well as sakaṭhillaka, are included in this list.

sloka: kovidārasya puṣpāṇi kāśmaryasyātha śālmaleḥ| annapānavidhau śākaṃyaccānyadraktapittanut||39||
translation: The leaves of Paatala, Nimba, Vetasa, Plaksha, and Kapittha, as well as the bitter vegetable of the Kirata, the Shaaka plant, and Gandi; these are what the knowledgeable Ashvayuja consumes after purification, which includes lakes and ponds, as specified.

sloka: śākārthaṃ śākasātmyānāṃ tacchastaṃ raktapittinām| svinnaṃ vā sarpiṣā bhṛṣṭaṃ yūṣavadvā vipācitam||40|| pārāvatān kapotāṃśca lāvān raktākṣavartakān| śaśān kapiñjalāneṇān hariṇānkālapucchakān||41|| raktapitte hitān vidyādrasāṃsteṣāṃ prayojayet| īṣadamlānanamlān vā ghṛtabhṛṣṭān saśarkarān||42||
translation:
For a learned person, when dealing with those sharing the appearance of flowers, if they suffer from jaundice, then apply:
- A rice and yogurt mixture, or
- A barley and meat concoction, or
- A blend of bitter, astringent, and pungent tastes.

Further, for those resembling parrots among the Parāvata inhabitants, those with red eyes, those appearing like monkeys, or those similar to kapiñjala birds, use:
- Śālmali tree bark and water decoction as a remedy for jaundice.

For those skilled in medical science, utilize sugar-containing, digestive fire-enhancing medicines for jaundice patients.

sloka: kaphānuge yūṣaśākaṃ dadyādvātānuge rasam| raktapitte yavāgūnāmataḥ kalpaḥ pravakṣyate||43||
translation: For those characterized by a kapha constitution, a tonic prepared from spinach and mustard seeds is to be offered; for those characterized by a pitta constitution, a cooling concoction of barley and coral sapphire should be prepared; these remedies will be slightly sour, salty, and pungent in taste.

sloka: padmotpalānāṃ kiñjalkaḥ pṛśniparṇī yaṅgukāḥ| jale sādhyā rase tasmin peyā syādraktapittinām||44||
translation: Upon digesting the juice of lotus leaves and water plants' stems, a remedy that moves downward should be administered in that very juice to those afflicted by an imbalance of phlegm and bile, causing redness. This is the recommended practice, as this remedy is the downward-moving quality among the lotus leaves' and water plants' stems.

sloka: candanośīralodhrāṇāṃ rase tadvat nāgare| kirātatiktakośīramustānāṃ tadvadeva ca||45|| dhātakīdhanvayāsāmbubilvānāṃ vā rase śṛtā| masūrapṛśniparṇyorvā sthirāmudgarase'tha vā||46|| rase hareṇukānāṃ vā saghṛte sabalārase| siddhāḥ  pārāvatādīnāṃ rase vā syuḥ pṛthakpṛthak||47|| ityuktā raktapittaghnyaḥ śītāḥ samadhuśarkarāḥ| yavāgvaḥ kalpanā caiṣā kāryā māṃsaraseṣvapi||48||
translation: The soft fibers of lotus and blue water lilies, the juices of pomegranate, banyan leaves, licorice, and jasmine; the juices of rice, barley, wheat, and pulse plants; the juices of sugarcane, coconut, and harita fruit; or even the distinct juices of siddha plants—all of these can be employed as a cooling and astringent medicine for bleeding disorders, as has been advised by the one who is proficient in suppressing blood-related ailments.

sloka: śaśaḥ savāstukaḥ śasto vibandhe  raktapittinām| vātolbaṇe tittiriḥ syādudumbararase śṛtaḥ||49|| mayūraḥ plakṣaniryūhe nyagrodhasya ca  kukkuṭaḥ| rase bilvotpalādīnāṃvartakakrakarau hitau||50|| tṛṣyate tiktakaiḥ siddhaṃ tṛṣṇāghnaṃ vā phalodakam|  siddhaṃ vidārigandhādyairathavāśṛtaśītalam||51||
jñātvā doṣāvanubalau balamāhārameva ca| jalaṃ pipāsave  dadyādvisargādalpaśo'pi vā||52||
translation: Even a person of meager strength, having understood the balanced strength of counteracting the harmful and beneficial , should offer water for drinking; or, if thirsty, they may partake of fruits, roots, etc., that are cooling, fragrant, and thirst-quenching . This is beneficial for those suffering from hot and intense wind or raktapitta diseases, which cause thirst.

sloka: nidānaṃ raktapittasya yatkiñcit samprakāśitam| jīvitārogyakāmaistanna sevyaṃ raktapittibhiḥ||53|| ityannapānaṃ nirdiṣṭaṃ kramaśo raktapittanut|54|
translation: Knowing the revealed causes of anemia, one should consume an appropriate amount of iron-rich food and, at times, even small amounts of water should be given. This has been declared as the regimen for combating anemia.

sloka: vakṣyate bahudoṣāṇāṃ kāryaṃ balavatāṃ ca yat||54|| akṣīṇabalamāṃsasya yasya santarpaṇotthitam| bahudoṣaṃ balavato  raktapittaṃ śarīriṇaḥ||55|| kāle saṃśodhanārhasya taddharennirupadravam| virecanenordhvabhāgamadhogaṃ vamanena ca||56||
translation: The manifestation of minor symptoms of anemia and jaundice in someone not deficient in strength or vitality is caused by numerous faults. For such an afflicted person, it is proper at the appropriate time to apply a treatment that involves upward-directed purgation and downward-directed emesis to alleviate the excessive pitta (bile).

sloka: trivṛtāmabhayāṃ prājñaḥphalānyāragvadhasya vā| trāyamāṇāṃ gavākṣyā vā mūlamāmalakāni vā||57|| virecanaṃ prayuñjīta prabhūtamadhuśarkaram| rasaḥ śasyate teṣāṃ raktapitte viśeṣataḥ||58||
translation: The sagacious man should employ a powerful purgative when an increase of multiple flaws occurs in the body, such as that stemming from an imbalance of bodily humors and affecting the eyesight . He should purge the root causes of these flaws using a purgative abounding in virtues . The sap of these becomes manifest, particularly in the red and yellow biles . This should be administered at an appropriate time, in a harmless manner, through upward-moving purgation of the upper portion and downward-moving purgation of the lower portion.

sloka: vamanaṃ madanonmiśro manthaḥ sakṣaudraśarkaraḥ|  saśarkaraṃ vā salilamikṣūṇāṃ rasa eva vā||59|| vatsakasya phalaṃ mustaṃ madanaṃ madhukaṃ madhu| adhovahe raktapitte vamanaṃ paramucyate||60||
translation: The enlightened one should prepare a decoction for emesis, known as Arugvadha, using a mixture that includes three key ingredients and either unsalted curd or water. Specifically, a larger quantity of honey and ghee should be used, resulting in a salty-sweet taste. This variety is considered optimal for addressing kapha dominance.

sloka: ūrdhvage śuddhakoṣṭhasya tarpaṇādiḥ kramo hitaḥ| adhogate yavāgvādirna cetsyānmārutobalī||61||
translation: The series, beginning with tarpaṇa on the purified costal region of one known as Urdhvage, is deemed beneficial: initially offering mantha mixed with a bit of Madana, then Saksu and Udra, followed by sugarcane juice. If not performed this way, it's considered as something that heightens rakta and pitta flow, referring to Madana as a red liquid or blood and Udra as wind or bile.

sloka: balamāṃsaparikṣīṇaṃ śokabhārādhvakarśitam| jvalanādityasantaptamanyairvā kṣīṇamāmayaiḥ||62|| garbhiṇīṃ sthaviraṃ bālaṃ rūkṣālpapramitāśinam| avamyamavirecyaṃ vā yaṃ paśyedraktapittinam||63|| śoṣeṇa sānubandhaṃ vā tasya saṃśamanī yā| śasyate raktapittasya paraṃ sā'tha pravakṣyate||64||
translation: If one performs tarpanam to a purified container, beginning at the top and moving downwards, then for that individual, an herbal mixture made from barley can serve as a regulating wind for the imbalance of phlegm and bile in a person affected by rakta Pitta. This is known as samshani, an effective remedy for raktapitta. Moreover, it will be proclaimed as the ultimate cure for such a condition.

sloka: aṭarūṣakamṛdvīkāpathyākvāthaḥ saśarkaraḥ| madhumiśraḥ śvāsakāsaraktapittanibarhaṇaḥ||65|| aṭarūṣakaniryūhe priyaṅguṃ mṛttikāñjane|  vinīyalodhraṃ kṣaudraṃ ca raktapittaharaṃ pibet||66||
translation: The afflicted woman, oppressed by an undue burden of grief, should seek relief in the invigorating energy of the radiant sun, amplified by fires. As a therapeutic measure for her blood and bile disorders, she should consume a concoction made from bala, priyaṅgu, mṛttikā-añjana, lodhra, and kṣaudra, all of which help alleviate such disorders, being especially beneficial for the elderly and children, and easy to digest, devoid of impurities. Now I will describe the ultimate remedy for rakta pitta.

sloka: padmakaṃ padmakiñjalkaṃ dūrvāṃ vāstūkamutpalam|  nāgapuṣpaṃ ca lodhraṃ ca tenaiva vidhinā pibet||67||
translation: One should drink, as prescribed, a concoction made of padmaka, padmakijnjala, durva, utpala, nagapushpa, and lodhrA, prepared with atarushaka, mud, anjana, vinIya, and haram, and mixed with madhu, sarkara, and svAsa. This is beneficial for treating kAsa, rakta pitta, and nibarhana.

sloka: prapauṇḍarīkaṃ madhukaṃ madhu cāśvaśakṛdrase| yavāsabhṛṅgarajasormūlaṃ vā gośakṛdrase||68|| vinīya raktapittaghnaṃ peyaṃ syāttaṇḍulāmbunā| yuktaṃ vā maghusarpirbhyāṃ lihyādgośvaśakṛdrasam||69||
translation: One should consume a mixture of padma-kam, padmakiñjalkam, dūrvā, vāstū, kam, utpalam, nāga, and puṣpam, prepared in the following way: first, make raktapittaghnaṃ, a drink that counteracts blood disorders, by adding peyaṃ, a drink, to taṇḍula, a measure of rice; then, mix it with maghusarpiḥ, a type of cereal, using both, so that it tastes like cow's milk.

sloka: khadirasya priyaṅgūṇāṃ kovidārasya śālmaleḥ| puṣpacūrṇāni madhunā lihyānnā raktapittikaḥ||70||
translation: The one skilled in recognizing the prized qualities of both khadira and salmali trees should mix honey with freshly harvested flowers, along with extracted sap water, for it to become a sustaining food and drink that eliminates redness and bile.

sloka: śṛṅgāṭakānāṃ lājānāṃ mustakharjūrayorapi|  lihyāccūrṇāni madhunā padmānāṃ keśarasya ca||71|| dhanvajānāmasṛglihyānmadhunā mṛgapakṣiṇām| sakṣaudraṃ grathite rakte lihyāt pārāvataṃ śakṛt||72||
translation: The expert in the use of Khadira and Priyangu woods from the group of śṛṅgāṭaka, as well as Salmali's flower garland powder, when mixed with honey, is fit for anointing the sacrificial offerings of both elephants and birds, having been made red with lac dye.

sloka: uśīrakālīyakalodhrapadmakapriyaṅgukākaṭphalaśaṅkhagairikāḥ| pṛthak pṛthak candanatulyabhāgikāḥśarkarāstaṇḍuladhāvanāplutāḥ||73||
translation: The juices of usira and kalika plants, mustard seeds, the sap of kharjura and lajavrika, keśara of padma, all separately combined with red sandalwood powder and madhu, as well as those prepared from flowers and feathers of animals and birds, are all individually made with madhu.

sloka: raktaṃ sapittaṃ tamakaṃ pipāsāṃ dāhaṃ ca pītāḥ śamayanti sadyaḥ| kirātatiktaṃ kramukaṃ samustaṃ kamalotpale ca||74||  hrīberamūlāni paṭolapatraṃ durālabhā parpaṭako mṛṇālam|  dhanañjayodumbaravetasatvaṅnyagrodhaśāleyayavāsakatvak||75|| tugālatāvetasataṇḍulīyaṃsasārivaṃmocarasaḥ samaṅgā|    pṛthak pṛthak candanayojitāni tenaiva kalpena hitāni tatra||76|| niśisthitā vā svarasīkṛtā vā kalkīkṛtāvā mṛditāḥ śṛtā vā| ete samastā gaṇaśaḥ pṛthagvā raktaṃ sapittaṃ śamayanti yogāḥ||77||
translation: Made of sandalwood, liquorice, mango, patala, priyangu, kapittha, karira, punnaga, kesara, and sugar, either mixed together in equal parts or applied separately, these yogic practices, whether performed individually or collectively, immediately soothe the burning sensations caused by thirst and Pitta dosha. (74-75)

sloka: mudgāḥ  salājāḥsayavāḥ kṛṣṇāḥ sośīramustāḥsaha candanena|  balājale paryuṣitāḥ kaṣāyā raktaṃ sapittaṃ śamayantyudīrṇam||78||
translation: The dark Salijas and Krishnas, powerful in their own right, adorned with red flags, and smeared with candana, serve as means to alleviate thirst and heat associated with pitta. These remedies, including those derived from safflower, blue lotus from Hriberamula, as well as Dhanya, Udumbara, Vetasa, Nyagrodha, Shala, Vasaka, Tugalata, Avetasatanduliyamsasarivamocarasa, all skillfully compounded together, effectively counteract pitta. Use these concoctions, either at night or as prescribed, such as Yogas like Kalki, Krta, Mrta, Itaah, Sritaava, Ete, Samastaganashah, specifically designed for this purpose.

sloka: vaidūryamuktāmaṇigairikāṇāṃ mṛcchaṅkhahemāmalakodakānām| madhūdakasyekṣurasasya caiva pānācchamaṃ gacchati raktapittam||79|| uśīrapadmotpalacandanānāṃ pakvasya loṣṭasya ca yaḥ prasādaḥ saśarkaraḥ  kṣaudrayutaḥ suśīto raktātiyogapraśamāya deyaḥ||80|| priyaṅgukācandanalodhrasārivāmadhūkamustābhayadhātakījalam|  samṛtprasādaṃ saha yaṣṭikāmbunā saśarkaraṃ raktanibarhaṇaṃ param||81||
translation: The sap, freshly extracted and cool, of the
