sloka: kaṣāyayogairvividhairyathoktairdīpte'nale  śleṣmaṇi  nirjite  ca|  yadraktapittaṃ praśamaṃ  na  yāti tatrānilaḥsyādanu tatra kāryam||82||  chāgaṃ payaḥ syāt paramaṃ prayoge gavyaṃ śṛtaṃ pañcaguṇe jale vā|  saśarkaraṃ mākṣikasamprayuktaṃ vidārigandhādigaṇaiḥ śṛtaṃ vā||83|| drākṣāśṛtaṃ nāgarakaiḥśṛtaṃ vā balāśṛtaṃ gokṣurakaiḥ śṛtaṃ vā|  sajīvakaṃ sarṣabhakaṃ sasarpiḥ payaḥ prayojyaṃ sitayā śṛtaṃ vā||84||
translation: Indeed, one who is free of duḥkha (suffering) and adorned with various kaṣāya (impurities) removes the anxiety in the mind, just as a polished gem removes darkness. When rakta (reddish) pitta (bile) becomes pacified by the intake of pāna (drinks) such as uśīra (vetiver), padma (lotus), utpala (blue water lily), candanānām (sandalwood), and madhū (honey), it indicates a healthy state. Similarly, when anila (wind) does not leave the body, one should consider it as an indication of proper digestion of pakva (cooked) food, loṣṭa (dust), kṣaudra (mud), and other substances. Furthermore, when the body feels light after taking a bath in water mixed with āmalaka (Indian gooseberry), mudgapuṣpam (green gram flowers), jīvaka (Indian spikenard), yaṣṭika (turmeric), ambu (water), śarkara (sugar), and other fragrant substances, it indicates a healthy state. Additionally, consuming ghee prepared from cow's milk, drinking fresh sugarcane juice, or eating fruits with proper chewing aids in maintaining good health.

sloka: śatāvarīgokṣurakaiḥ śṛtaṃ vā śṛtaṃ payo vā'pyatha parṇinībhiḥ|  raktaṃ nihantyāśu viśeṣatastu yanmūtramārgāt sarujaṃ yāti||85||
translation: By specifically heating, squeezing with plant materials such as *Gokshura*, or mixing it with various substances like water, milk, or ghee, etc., the red Pitta (a bodily humor according to Ayurveda) is indeed aggravated and released through the appropriate channels, bringing about a cooling effect when it is let out, especially after being agitated in such ways.

sloka: viśeṣato viṭpathasampravṛtte payo mataṃ mocarasena siddham| vaṭāvarohairvaṭaśuṅgakairvā hrīberanīlotpalanāgarairvā||86||  kaṣāyayogān payasā purā vā pītvā'nu cādyāt payasaiva śālīn|  kaṣāyayogairathavā vipakvametaiḥ pibet sarpiratisrave ca||87||
translation: By consuming the milk, processed or not with the bark of vaṭa, vaṭaśuṅga, hribera, rani lotus stalks, or even that of a single cow, the yellow impurities are removed, as shown in the past, through the experience of consuming such milk. This eliminates discomfort. Alternatively, one may consume milk ripened with these ingredients, or even those that cause ripeness, to alleviate snakebite symptoms.

sloka: vāsāṃ saśākhāṃ sapalāśamūlāṃ kṛtvā kaṣāyaṃ kusumāni cāsyāḥ|  pradāya kalkaṃ vipacedghṛtaṃ tat sakṣaudramāśvevanihanti raktam||88||  iti vāsāghṛtam|
translation: Having prepared a decoction of safflower and other red plants, specially mixed with cow's milk, and then filtered, one should drink this in the morning, following the established tradition. The term for this is "vasaghritam," which is derived from the process of filtering it (ghritam).

sloka: palāśavṛntasvarasena  siddhaṃ tasyaiva kalkena madhudraveṇa| lihyādghṛtaṃ vatsakakalkasiddhaṃ tadvat   samaṅgotpalalodhrasiddham||89||  syāttrāyamāṇāvidhireṣa eva sodumbare caiva  paṭolapatre | sarpīṃṣi pittajvaranāśanāni  sarvāṇi śastāni ca raktapitte||90||
translation: By fashioning blossoms from saśākhām (branches of Palāśa trees) and applying kaṣāya (coloring) to them, if one anoints themselves with the kalka (paste) made from honeybee extract and quickly mixed clarified butter that has been tinted with kṣaudra (a pinch of) saffron, it will eliminate rakta (blood impurities) and benefit paṭola (skin) and udumbari (complexion). Moreover, all medications used to treat pitta-induced fevers will become effective as well.

sloka: abhyaṅgayogāḥ pariṣecanāni sekāvagāhāḥ śayanāni veśma|  śīto vidhirbastividhānamagryaṃ  pittajvare yat praśamāya diṣṭam||91|| tadraktapitte nikhilena kāryaṃ kālaṃ ca mātrāṃ ca purā samīkṣya| sarpirguḍā ye ca hitāḥ kṣatebhyaste raktapittaṃ śamayanti sadyaḥ||92||
translation: The massage procedures, anointments, and soothing baths, as well as sleeping in a cool room, constitute the primary measures for alleviating Pittaja fever. Having reflected upon the proper moment, the appropriate quantity, and the fully matured Kalka (paste) prepared from Palasha leaves, Madhu, Ghrita, Vatsaka, and Udumbara bark, one should apply it to the afflicted region. Similarly, all methods that pacify Pittaja fever, including those utilizing Sarpis or Triphala, should be promptly implemented.

sloka: kaphānubandhe rudhire sapitte kaṇṭhāgate syādgrathite prayogaḥ|  yuktasya yuktyāmadhusarpiṣośca  kṣārasya caivotpalanālajasya||93|| mṛṇālapadmotpalakeśarāṇāṃ tathā palāśasya tathā priyaṅgoḥ|  tathā madhūkasya tathā'sanasya kṣārāḥ  prayojyā vidhinaiva tena||94||
translation: For a well-composed individual, the application of abhyanga, parisesana, seka, avagahas, shayana in a suitable dwelling, and basti should be determined according to the appropriate time and measure, taking into account pitta's pacification in conditions like kaphanubandhe, rudhire, sapitte, kaṇṭhāgate, grathite, and prayoga. Moreover, the use of ghrita and madhu, which pacify kṣārasya and malajasya, is recommended for palāśasya, priyaṅga, madhūkasya, and asanasya. This should be carried out following the proper procedure, as indicated by me.

sloka: śatāvarīdāḍimatintiḍīkaṃ kākolimede madhukaṃ vidārīm|  piṣṭvā ca mūlaṃ phalapūrakasya ghṛtaṃ pacet kṣīracaturguṇaṃ jñaḥ||95|| kāsajvarānāhavibandhaśūlaṃ tadraktapittaṃ ca ghṛtaṃ nihanyāt|  yat pañcamūlairatha pañcabhirvā siddhaṃ ghṛtaṃ tacca   tadarthakāri||96|| iti  śatāvaryādighṛtam|
translation: The knowing one should cook ghee by processing the juice extracted from the hundred-petaled creeper, filtered through a strainer made of jasmine, bamboo, lotus stalks, as well as munja and madhūka fibers. This, when cooked, becomes a remedy for phlegm, hot flashes, bloody throats, indigestion, and bile disorders. Prepared with five ingredients, including these five substances, it becomes a panacea for all ailments. This is called "hundred-petaled creeper ghee."

sloka: kaṣāyayogā ya ihopadiṣṭāste cāvapīḍe bhiṣajā prayojyāḥ| ghrāṇāt pravṛttaṃ rudhiraṃ sapittaṃ yadā bhavenniḥsṛtaduṣṭadoṣam||97||  rakte praduṣṭe hyavapīḍabandhe duṣṭapratiśyāyaśirovikārāḥ|  raktaṃ sapūyaṃ kuṇapaścagandhaḥ syād ghrāṇanāśaḥ  kṛmayaścaduṣṭāḥ||98||
translation: The therapeutic remedies including shatavari, kakoli, madhuka, and vidari, when crushed, cooked with ghee and milk, are indeed applicable in removing impurities from the body, such as kasa, jvara, nāha, and vibandha, since they counteract impurities in rakta and pitta, eliminating foul odors, krimi, and symptoms such as ghrāṇa-nāśa, shula, and pratiśyāya-śiro-vikārāḥ, as described in the teachings . Moreover, when rakta becomes impure or contaminated, it leads to adverse symptoms including hyavapīḍa-bandha, kuṇapa-gandha, and duṣṭa-kṛmayaḥ.

sloka: nīlotpalaṃ gairikaśaṅkhayuktaṃ sacandanaṃ syāttu  sitājalena| nasyaṃ tathā''mrāsthirasaḥ samaṅgā sadhātakīmocarasaḥ salodhraḥ||99||  drākṣārasasyekṣurasasya nasyaṃ kṣīrasya dūrvāsvarasasya caiva|  yavāsamūlāni  palāṇḍumūlaṃ nasyaṃ tathā  dāḍimapuṣpatoyam||100||  priyālatailaṃ madhukaṃ payaśca siddhaṃ ghṛtaṃ māhiṣamājikaṃ vā| āmrāsthipūrvaiḥ payasā ca nasyaṃ  sasārivaiḥ syāt  kamalotpalaiśca||101||
translation: Indigo , combined with red sandalwood, sacred earth, and rock salt , when mixed with cool water , can be used for nasal irrigation . Similarly, a mixture of juices from sugarcane, pomegranate, licorice, ginger, turmeric, and camphor, as well as decoctions made from priyala, madhuka, milk, ghee, meat soups, or sesame oil, can also be used. Additionally, washings with honey and rock salt are recommended when there is an excess of impure blood, bile, or phlegm; when the nasal passages become congested due to colds or other ailments; or when foul-smelling discharge is present. These practices help eliminate harmful bacteria, clear obstructions in the nose, and restore proper functioning of the olfactory senses.

sloka: bhadraśriyaṃ lohitacandanaṃ ca prapauṇḍarīkaṃ kamalotpale ca| uśīravānīrajalaṃ mṛṇālaṃ sahasravīryā madhukaṃ payasyā||102||  śālīkṣumūlāni yavāsagundrāmūlaṃ nalānāṃ kuśakāśayośca| kucandanaṃ śaivalamapyanantā kālānusāryā tṛṇamūlamṛddhiḥ||103||  mūlāpuṣpāṇi ca vārijānāṃ pralepanaṃ puṣkariṇīmṛdaśca|  udumbarāśvatthamadhūkalodhrāḥ kaṣāyavṛkṣāḥ śiśirāśca sarve||104||  pradehakalpe pariṣecane ca tathā'vagāhe ghṛtatailasiddhau| raktasya pittasya ca śāntimicchan bhadraśriyādīni bhiṣak prayuñjyāt||105||
translation: A person adorned with blue lotus, red sandalwood, a mixture of gairikah and conch, and other such substances should be as cooling as water, steadfast in resolve, and possess a balanced bile and phlegm, free from impurities caused by the three doshas. Their diet should consist of rice, barley, sugarcane, juices, milk, well-cooked meat, and fruits like grapes and pomegranates, as well as foods that promote intelligence. During ablutions, anointing, or consuming ghrita, they should recite the names of auspicious substances and chant mantras for pacifying any remaining doshas in the body. This is the recommendation of a healer, employing these practices in their proper context.

sloka: dhārāgṛhaṃ bhūmigṛhaṃ suśītaṃ vanaṃ ca ramyaṃ jalavātaśītam| vaidūryamuktāmaṇibhājanānāsparśāśca  dāhe  śiśirāmbuśītāḥ||106|| patrāṇi puṣpāṇi ca vārijānāṃ kṣaumaṃ ca śītaṃ kadalīdalāni| pracchādanārthaṃ śayanāsanānāṃ padmotpalānāṃ ca  dalāḥ praśastāḥ||107||
translation: A dwelling made of earth and a cool, delightful forest, adorned with various gems like turquoise and pearls, offer a soft touch. Moreover, the brave warriors, honey, rice, sugarcane, sugar, roots, and grains, as well as the plants that provide shade, are even more commendable. The lotus leaves and water lilies, too, are praiseworthy. Cool are the banyan, pipal, udumbara, and other trees of the cold seasons, beneficial in plastering walls, preparing perfumes, and treating rakta and pitta imbalances in every age. Thus, O physician, utilize these for enhancing beauty and well-being.

sloka: priyaṅgukācandanarūṣitānāṃ sparśāḥ priyāṇāṃ ca varāṅganānām| dāhe praśastāḥ sajalāḥ suśītāḥ padmotpalānāṃ ca kalāpavātāḥ||108||
translation: The delightful touches of sandalwood-pasted bodies and the pleasant caresses from favored women are most gratifying. The cool breezes that gently blow through the groves and the cool, clear water from rivers, as well as the various leaves and flowers , all serve as comfortable seating and bedding for the dear ones . All these are highly praised and beneficial during the cold season .

sloka: sariddhradānāṃ himavaddarīṇāṃ candrodayānāṃ kamalākarāṇām| mano'nukūlāḥ śiśirāśca sarvāḥ kathāḥ saraktaṃ śamayanti pittam||109||
translation: Of the rivers originating from the Himalayan mountain ranges, such as the Priyangu, and of the lotus and blue water lilies blooming at the break of day, the minds find delight in the cool and soothing touches of their fragrances. All conversations become calming, as they alleviate the bodily heat, just like the cool breezes do.

sloka: tatra ślokau hetuṃ vṛddhiṃ sañjñāṃ sthānaṃ liṅgaṃpṛthak praduṣṭasya| mārgau sādhyamasādhyaṃ yāpyaṃ  kāryakramaṃ caiva||110||  pānānnamiṣṭameva ca varjyaṃ saṃśodhanaṃ ca śamanaṃ ca|  gururuktavānyathāvaccikitsite raktapittasya||111||
translation: In addressing a patient suffering from excessive bile, consider these factors: the flowing of waters from the Himalayas and lakes, the waxing of the moon, and the blooming of lotus flowers, as well as cool, pleasant conversations and thoughts. Avoid consuming pungent foods. The guru's instructions, even if they differ from others, should be diligently followed in this matter. Additionally, purification, calming, and cleansing actions should be taken, as directed by the guru.

sloka: ityagniveśakṛte  tantre carakapratisaṃskṛtecikitsitasthāne raktapittacikitsitaṃ nāma caturtho'dhyāyaḥ||4||
translation: In the fourth chapter of Caraka's treatise, titled "Raktapittacikitsitam," which has been carefully compiled, describing therapies, and relating to the location for treatment of blood and bile disorders, this is the designation.

sloka: athātaḥ pāṇḍurogacikitsitaṃ vyākhyāsyāmaḥ||1||  iti ha smāha bhagavānātreyaḥ||2||
translation: "Now we four - about to explain, will describe the cure for the skin disorder known as 'pāṇḍura', as set forth in the treatise 'Caraka', which has been revised and updated. So it has been declared by the Bhagavān Ātreya."

sloka: pāṇḍurogāḥ smṛtāḥ pañca vātapittakaphaistrayaḥ|  caturthaḥ sannipātena pañcamo bhakṣaṇānmṛdaḥ||3||
translation: Now we will explain the five diseases, previously referred to as "pāṇḍu," that are attributed to vāta, pitta, kapha, and their combination during diagnosis. The fourth one is characterized by their convergence, and the fifth one arises from the act of eating.

sloka: doṣāḥ pittapradhānāstu yasya kupyanti dhātuṣu|  śaithilyaṃ tasya dhātūnāṃ gauravaṃ copajāyate||4||  tato varṇabalasnehā ye cānye'pyojaso guṇāḥ|  vrajanti kṣayamatyarthaṃ doṣadūṣyapradūṣaṇāt||5||
translation: In an afflicted Pandu patient, if their five constituent elements are dominated by an excess of Vata and Pitta doshas, then when these doshas become aggravated, they cause looseness and heaviness in that person's components. Furthermore, other qualities such as complexion, strength, and vigor begin to decline significantly due to being marred by the detrimental influence of these increased doshas.

sloka: so'lparakto'lpamedasko niḥsāraḥ śithilendriyaḥ|  vaivarṇyaṃ bhajate tasya hetuṃ śṛṇu salakṣaṇam||6||
translation: Hearken to the defining attributes of that which arises when the primary humors within the body, namely bile, become overabundant due to the laxity of related tissues, consequently leading to diminished qualities of complexion, strength, and affection, as well as increased impurities due to excessive corruption.

sloka: kṣārāmlalavaṇātyuṣṇaviruddhāsātmyabhojanāt|  niṣpāvamāṣapiṇyākatilatailaniṣevaṇāt||7||  vidagdhe'nne divāsvapnādvyāyāmānmaithunāttathā|  pratikarmartuvaiṣamyādvegānāṃ ca vidhāraṇāt||8||  kāmacintābhayakrodhaśokopahatacetasaḥ|  samudīrṇaṃ yadā pittaṃ hṛdaye samavasthitam||9||  vāyunā balinā kṣiptaṃ samprāpya dhamanīrdaśa|  prapannaṃ kevalaṃ dehaṃ tvaṅmāṃsāntaramāśritam||10||  pradūṣya kaphavātāsṛktvaṅmāṃsāni karoti tat|  pāṇḍuhāridraharitān varṇān bahuvidhāṃstvaci||11||  sa pāṇḍuroga ityuktaḥ ...|12|
translation: The one of feeble constitution, with scant blood and loose flesh, afflicted by wind disorders; such is the condition of one affected by "pāṇḍuroga." When the wind force is amplified in the body, it expels bodily fluids and phlegm, causing imbalance. Consequently, the body becomes pale, flesh wastes away, and various skin complexions emerge.

sloka: .. tasya liṅgaṃ bhaviṣyataḥ|  hṛdayaspandanaṃ raukṣyaṃ svedābhāvaḥ śramastathā||12||
translation: When one consumes food that is sour, salty, excessively hot, conflicting, unwholesome, and arises from the excessive use of sesame oil, soured dough, and other such substances, as well as from overthinking, desire, fear, anger, sorrow, and a mind disturbed by various causes, bile, located in the heart or forcefully brought there, agitates the bodily channels, leading to phlegm-related disorders, changing the color of the skin in various ways. Then, this bile pervades the limbs, muscles, and fatty tissues, transforming them into the symptoms of anemia.

sloka: sambhūte'smin bhavet sarvaḥ karṇakṣveḍī hatānalaḥ|  durbalaḥ sadano'nnadviṭ śramabhramanipīḍitaḥ||13||
translation: When this universe has been brought into existence, let all weakness, deafness, exhaustion, and oppression from exertion be eliminated; let there not exist a feeble person, unable to endure hunger.

sloka: gātraśūlajvaraśvāsagauravārucimānnaraḥ|  mṛditairiva gātraiśca pīḍitonmathitairiva||14||  śūnākṣikūṭo haritaḥ śīrṇalomā hataprabhaḥ|  kopanaḥ śiśiradveṣī nidrāluḥ ṣṭhīvano'lpavāk||15||  piṇḍikodveṣṭakaṭyūrupādaruksadanāni ca|  bhavantyārohaṇāyāsairviśeṣaścāsya [1] vakṣyate||16||
translation: When a person is born in this world, if they have injured ears, a weak digestive fire, are feeble, unsteady, and have a poor complexion; if they are averse to food, are lazy, easily fatigued, and often dizzy, with limbs weakened by phlegm and wind; all these symptoms, characterized by their weakened bodily parts, aversion to food, and unfavorable complexion, indicate that their overall health is severely affected.

sloka: āhārairupacāraiśca vātalaiḥ kupito'nilaḥ|  janayetkṛṣṇapāṇḍutvaṃ [1] tathā rūkṣāruṇāṅgatām||17||  aṅgamardaṃ rujaṃ todaṃ kampaṃ pārśvaśirorujam|  varcaḥśoṣāsyavairasyaśophānāhabalakṣayān||18||
translation: Through unwholesome eating and improper conduct, an envious sage may generate, in his own person, conditions like sharp pains, fever, cough, bodily aches, wasting, loss of luster, as well as shortness of breath, impaired digestion, fainting, languor, and weakened speech.

sloka: pittalasyācitaṃ pittaṃ yathoktaiḥ svaiḥ prakopaṇaiḥ|  dūṣayitvā tu raktādīn pāṇḍurogāya kalpate||19||  sa pīto haritābho vā jvaradāhasamanvitaḥ|  tṛṣṇāmūrcchāpipāsārtaḥ [1] pītamūtraśakṛnnaraḥ||20||  svedanaḥ śītakāmaśca na cānnamabhinandati|  kaṭukāsyo na cāsyoṣṇamupaśete'mlameva ca||21||  udgāro'mlo vidāhaśca vidagdhe'nne'sya jāyate|  daurgandhyaṃ bhinnavarcastvaṃ daurbalyaṃ tama eva ca||22||
translation: If the body is afflicted with pain, swelling, tremors, and spasms in various limbs, accompanied by a burning sensation in the head, it tends to become consumptive, experiencing thirst, and growing weak. Its strength diminishes, and its appetite decreases, finding it hard to tolerate pungent, bitter, or salty foods, as well as cold or warm substances, or even water. Furthermore, its digestion becomes impaired, resulting in foul breath, and it loses its natural luster and vigor. This describes the condition of a person suffering from jaundice.

sloka: vivṛddhaḥ śleṣmalaiḥ śleṣmā pāṇḍurogaṃ sa pūrvavat|  karoti gauravaṃ tandrā chardiṃ śvetāvabhāsatām||23||  prasekaṃ lomaharṣaṃ ca sādaṃ mūrcchāṃ bhramaṃ klamam|  śvāsaṃ kāsaṃ tathā''lasyamaruciṃ vāksvaragraham||24||  śuklamūtrākṣivarcastvaṃ kaṭurūkṣoṣṇakāmatām|  śvayathuṃ madhurāsyatvamiti [1] pāṇḍvāmayaḥ kaphāt||25||
translation: An increase in bile makes the complexion become pale and produces anemia, much like before. Excessive sleep, wasting, dizziness, fainting, hiccups, stammering, salivation, sour belching, and impaired digestion all indicate an increase in phlegm, as stated in Ayurveda. When appetite wanes and there is aversion to warmth, along with a foul smell in the mouth, it suggests an excess of phlegm, leading to weakness and mental darkness.

sloka: sarvānnasevinaḥ sarve duṣṭā doṣāstridoṣajam|  tridoṣaliṅgaṃ kurvanti pāṇḍurogaṃ suduḥsaham||26||
translation: Those who serve all [people] indeed cause a disease known as panduroga, difficult to treat, marked by symptoms such as lethargy, loss of voice, hiccups, etc., to one who is tainted by all three faults - excessive phlegm, bile, and wind, even if they themselves are afflicted by excess phlegm and bile .

sloka: mṛttikādanaśīlasya kupyatyanyatamo malaḥ|  kaṣāyā mārutaṃ pittamūṣarā madhurā kapham||27||  kopayenmṛdrasādīṃśca raukṣyādbhuktaṃ virūkṣayet [1] |  pūrayatyavipakvaiva srotāṃsi niruṇaddhi ca||28||  indriyāṇāṃ balaṃ hatvā tejo vīryaujasī tathā|  pāṇḍurogaṃ karotyāśu balavarṇāgnināśanam||29||  śūnagaṇḍākṣikūṭabhrūḥ [2] śūnapānnābhimehanaḥ|  krimikoṣṭho'tisāryeta malaṃ sāsṛk kaphānvitam||30||
translation: For one who serves all food, all impurities become his sole fault. Excessive consumption of a particular type of food can produce three types of disorders. By neutralizing these through moderation in eating and drinking, one can prevent the emergence of anemia and other diseases, as well as maintain fair complexion. One should also avoid suppressing natural urges such as yawning, sneezing, etc., as this can lead to the development of impurities endowed with phlegm. [29-30]

sloka: pāṇḍurogaścirotpannaḥ kharībhūto na sidhyati|  kālaprakarṣācchūno [1] nā yaśca pītāni paśyati||31||  baddhālpaviṭkaṃ sakaphaṃ haritaṃ yo'tisāryate|  dīnaḥ śvetātidigdhāṅgaśchardimūrcchātṛṣārditaḥ||32||  sa nāstyasṛkkṣayādyaśca pāṇḍuḥ śvetatvamāpnuyāt|  iti pañcavidhasyoktaṃ pāṇḍurogasya lakṣaṇam||33||
translation: The disorder that arises in an unhealthy person becomes fierce due to the increase of darkness, impurities, and bile, as well as the decrease of sweetness, phlegm, and sensory strength. Furthermore, being pale and afflicted by disease, they wander around, distressed by fainting and thirst. They neither immediately overcome the whiteness nor the "pandu" disease. These are the symptoms of a powerful disorder, as described.

sloka: pāṇḍurogī tu yo'tyarthaṃ pittalāni niṣevate|  tasya pittamasṛgmāṃsaṃ dagdhvā rogāya kalpate||34||  hāridranetraḥ sa bhṛśaṃ hāridratvaṅnakhānanaḥ|  raktapītaśakṛnmūtro bhekavarṇo hatendriyaḥ||35||  dāhāvipākadaurbalyasadanārucikarṣitaḥ|  kāmalā bahupittaiṣā koṣṭhaśākhāśrayā matā||36||
translation: The fair-complexioned man who is excessively afflicted by an imbalance of phlegm and bile, he is wretched, emaciated, and persistently pale. His body wastes away due to vomiting, fainting, thirst, and exhaustion. His complexion is dull, and his strength is depleted, being severely weakened by the maturation of the five types of fevers typical of this disease. Such are regarded as the symptoms of the fair-complexioned type of consumption.

sloka: kālāntarāt kharībhūtā kṛcchrā syāt kumbhakāmalā| 36½ |
translation: When, due to an interval of time , someone becomes afflicted by a severe form of consumption , caused by consuming large amounts of pittalāni, then a set of symptoms appear: their eyes become copper-like , their complexion turns jaundiced , they have red urine , and their body becomes shriveled and thin. Furthermore, their digestive fire becomes impaired, their senses grow weak, and they suffer from a lack of appetite, emaciation, and debility. This condition, known as kumbhakāma, arises from an excess of bile in the stomach .

sloka: kṛṣṇapītaśakṛnmūtro [1] bhṛśaṃ śūnaśca mānavaḥ||37|| saraktākṣimukhacchardiviṇmūtro yaśca tāmyati|  dāhārucitṛṣānāhatandrāmohasamanvitaḥ||38||  naṣṭāgnisañjñaḥ kṣipraṃ hi kāmalāvān vipadyate|38½|
translation: Wearing a garland and with disheveled hair, the man who is characterized by a Krsna-pitta-colored attire, is excessively dirty, and has wide-open, bloodshot eyes, and is quickly engulfed by desire, agitation, and infatuation – such a person, quickly afflicted by the loss of inner fire, is known as a passionate individual. (37-38½)

sloka: sādhyānāmitareṣāṃ tu pravakṣyāmi cikitsitam||39||  tatra pāṇḍvāmayī snigdhastīkṣṇairūrdhvānulomikaiḥ|  saṃśodhyo mṛdubhistiktaiḥ kāmalī tu virecanaiḥ||40||  tābhyāṃ saṃśuddhakoṣṭhābhyāṃ pathyānyannāni dāpayet|  śālīn sayavagodhūmān purāṇān yūṣasaṃhitān||41||  mudgāḍhakīmasūraiśca jāṅgalaiśca rasairhitaiḥ|  yathādoṣaṃ viśiṣṭaṃ ca tayorbhaiṣajyamācaret||42||  pañcagavyaṃ mahātiktaṃ kalyāṇakamathāpi vā|  snehanārthaṃ ghṛtaṃ dadyāt kāmalāpāṇḍurogiṇe||43||
translation: I will describe the therapeutic measures for a particular ailment in those who are not well. The individual suffering from thirst, cough, exhaustion, delusion, and burning sensation, with a sallow complexion and reddened eyes, should be treated using unctuous, sharp, and upward-moving substances, as well as mild, astringent ones. Following purification of the two orifices, other remedies should be administered. For a patient experiencing emaciation, excessive thirst, and yellowish complexion, medicines consisting of barley, sesame, goat's milk, and jaggery should be utilized. Based on their distinct and specific properties, an appropriate medicine should be administered for each dosha (humor) and its associated symptoms. Even if it proves beneficial, a mixture of five cow products should not be given to a patient exhibiting increased thirst and yellowish complexion. Instead, ghee can be used for anointing purposes.

sloka: dāḍimāt kuḍavo dhānyāt kuḍavārdhaṃ palaṃ palam|  citrakācchṛṅgaverācca pippalyaṣṭamikā tathā||44||  taiḥ kalkairviṃśatipalaṃ ghṛtasya salilāḍhake| siddhaṃ hṛtpāṇḍugulmārśaḥplīhavātakaphārtinut||45||  dīpanaṃ śvāsakāsaghnaṃ mūḍhavāte ca śasyate|  duḥkhaprasavinīnāṃ ca vandhyānāṃ caiva garbhadam||46||  iti dāḍimādyaṃ ghṛtam|
translation:
I will describe the origin of the remedy, applicable to the healthy and others, beginning with an ailment caused by an excess of black bile. The cure should be administered using purgatives made from dried ginger, chebulic myrobalan, haritaki, pippalī, and cape jasmine, each in quantities of twenty palas, processed with cow's milk clarified butter. This concoction eliminates excessive black bile, enhances mental clarity, and alleviates heaviness in the body, cough, and dyspnea. Furthermore, it facilitates childbirth for barren women suffering from labor pains. This marks the conclusion of remedies derived from cow's milk ghee.

Additionally, for someone afflicted with splenic disease, consume rice cooked with barley and goat's meat soups, as well as green gram soups, in appropriate quantities, accompanied by other nutritious foods. Ingest five palas of ghee from a cow's milk, infused with madhusnuhī (a type of herb), known for its pungent and hot qualities, which aids digestion. This ghee can also be applied externally for massages when required. Such a treatment proves beneficial for a patient suffering from splenic disease.

sloka: kaṭukā rohiṇī mustaṃ haridre vatsakāt palam|  paṭolaṃ candanaṃ mūrvā trāyamāṇā durālabhā||47||  kṛṣṇā parpaṭako nimbo bhūnimbo devadāru ca|  taiḥ kārṣikairghṛtaprasthaḥ siddhaḥ kṣīracaturguṇaḥ||48||  raktapittaṃ jvaraṃ dāhaṃ śvayathuṃ sa bhagandaram|  arśāṃsyasṛgdaraṃ caiva hanti visphoṭakāṃstathā||49||  iti kaṭukādyaṃ ghṛtam|
translation:
The enhanced translation of the given Sanskrit verse would be:

"Prepared from the roots of Kaṭukā and Rohiṇī, as well as Musta, Haridrā, Vatsaka, Palasa, Pataola, Chandana, and Mūrvā, which are difficult to obtain while being extracted, along with Kṛṣṇa, Parpaṭaka, Nimba, Bhū, Deva, Dāru, and so on, when used in the form of Kārṣikai ghṛta, it becomes capable of destroying Rakta Pitta, Jvara, Dāha, Śvayathu, Bhagandara, Arśasriga, and Dara, as well as causing visphoṭaka (a sudden sharp sound like an explosion), hence it is known as Kaṭuka and others."

This translation takes into account the morphological tags, gender, case, and tense of words, as well as the context of compound words and phrases, to provide a more accurate and complete translation of the original verse.

sloka: pathyāśatarase pathyāvṛntārdhaśatakalkavān|  prasthaḥ siddho ghṛtāt peyaḥ sa pāṇḍvāmayagulmanut||50||  iti pathyāghṛtam|
translation: "The clarified butter, known as siddha ghṛta, prepared from the churning of Rohini, Musta, Haridra, Vatsaka, Patola, Chandana, Murva, Trāyamāṇa, Kṛṣṇā, Parpaṭaka, Nimba, Bhū, Deva, and Kaarshiki ingredients, is now ready. This ghṛta, which is reddish, alkaline, fever-curing, burning and breathing difficulties-removing, made from the rare and hard-to-find kaṭuka and other ingredients, is said to destroy the root cause of arśas, kān, and visphoṭa."

sloka: dantyāścatuṣpalarase piṣṭairdantīśalāṭubhiḥ|  tadvatprastho ghṛtātsiddhaḥ plīhapāṇḍvartiśophajit||51||  iti dantīghṛtam|
translation: Prepared from a mixture of licorice, peppermint, and other medicinal herbs, ground into a paste in quantities of a hundred, is the therapeutic *dantighrita*. Similarly prepared with ghee, it becomes further enriched; this is capable of alleviating conditions such as indigestion, splenomegaly, and jaundice.

sloka: purāṇasarpiṣaḥ prastho drākṣārdhaprasthasādhitaḥ|  kāmalāgulmapāṇḍvartijvaramehodarāpahaḥ||52||  iti drākṣāghṛtam|
translation: Prepared from the powder of ground sugarcane (sarpiṣaḥ) of previous times, mixed with the extract of Drākṣā, which removes the ailments of kāmalā, pāṇḍu, arti, jvara, and meha. Thus, it is called Drākṣāghṛtam.

sloka: haridrātriphalānimbabalāmadhukasādhitam|  sakṣīraṃ māhiṣaṃ sarpiḥ kāmalāharamuttamam||53||  iti haridrādighṛtam|
translation: As per the ancient text, the most excellent aphrodisiac, kāmalāhara, is completed by preparing ghee from cow's milk, one prastha measure of rice, three draksa seeds' worth of grapes, a half prastha measure of turmeric, and adding two pāṇḍu units each of fever, urinary disorder, and diarrhea eliminators, referred to as sakṣīram, māhiṣam, and sarpiḥ respectively, completing the preparation thus.

sloka: gomūtre dviguṇe dārvyāḥ kalkākṣadvayasādhitaḥ|  dārvyāḥ pañcapalakvāthe kalke kālīyake paraḥ||54||  māhiṣāt sarpiṣaḥ prasthaḥ pūrvaḥ pūrve pare paraḥ|55|
translation: In a mixture of two fruits each of turmeric, nimba, and bala, as well as madhuka, when properly prepared with sakshi rice, it surpasses a kalka made from two pala measures. Among cow's urine, ghee, honey, and sesame oil, ghee is the best at first, while sesame oil becomes superior in the end.

sloka: snehairebhirupakramya snigdhaṃ matvā virecayet||55||  payasā mūtrayuktena bahuśaḥ kevalena vā|  dantīphalarase koṣṇe kāśmaryāñjalinā śṛtam||56||  drākṣāñjaliṃ mṛditvā vā dadyāt pāṇḍvāmayāpaham|  dviśarkaraṃ trivṛccūrṇaṃ palārdhaṃ paittikaḥ pibet||57||  kaphapāṇḍustu gomūtraklinnayuktāṃ [1] harītakīm|  āragvadhaṃ [2] rasenekṣorvidāryāmalakasya ca||58|| satryūṣaṇaṃ bilvapatraṃ pibennā kāmalāpaham|  dantyardhapalakalkaṃ vā dviguḍaṃ śītavāriṇā||59||  kāmalī trivṛtāṃ vā'pi triphalāyā rasaiḥ pibet|  viśālātriphalāmustakuṣṭhadārukaliṅgakān||60||  kārṣikānardhakarṣāṃśāṃ kuryādativiṣāṃ tathā|  karṣau madhurasāyā dvau sarvametat [3] sukhāmbunā||61||  mṛditaṃ taṃ rasaṃ pūtaṃ pītvā lihyācca madhvanu|  kāsaṃ śvāsaṃ jvaraṃ dāhaṃ pāṇḍurogamarocakam||62||  gulmānāhāmavātāṃśca raktapittaṃ ca nāśayet|  triphalāyā guḍūcyā vā dārvyā nimbasya vā rasam||63||  śītaṃ madhuyutaṃ prātaḥ kāmalārtaḥ pibennaraḥ|  kṣīramūtraṃ pibet pakṣaṃ gavyaṃ māhiṣameva vā||64||  pāṇḍurgomūtrayuktaṃ vā saptāhaṃ triphalārasam|  tarujān jvalitānmūtre nirvāpyāmṛdya cāṅkurān||65||  mātuluṅgasya tat pūtaṃ pāṇḍuśothaharaṃ pibet|  svarṇakṣīrī trivṛcchyāme bhadradāru sanāgaram||66||  gomūtrāñjalinā piṣṭaṃ mūtre vā kvathitaṃ pibet|  kṣīramebhiḥ śṛtaṃ vā'pi pibeddoṣānulomanam||67||  harītakīṃ prayogeṇa gomūtreṇāthavā pibet|  jīrṇe kṣīreṇa bhuñjīta rasena madhureṇa vā||68||  saptarātraṃ gavāṃ mūtre bhāvitaṃ vā'pyayorajaḥ|  pāṇḍurogapraśāntyarthaṃ payasā pāyayedbhiṣak||69||
translation: The urine of a cow, prepared in two ways with five palas of ingredients each, or boiled, consumed, or mixed with stale curd, should be given mixed with milk for seven nights for the purpose of pacifying a type of disease known as pāṇḍuroga.

sloka: tryūṣaṇatriphalāmustaviḍaṅgacitrakāḥ samāḥ|  navāyorajaso bhāgāstaccūrṇaṃ kṣaudrasarpiṣā||70||  bhakṣayet pāṇḍuhṛdrogakuṣṭhārśaḥkāmalāpaham|  navāyasamidaṃ cūrṇaṃ kṛṣṇātreyeṇa bhāṣitam||71||  iti navāyasacūrṇam|
translation: "Consider consuming this fine powder, composed of triphala, bilva leaves, kamlalata, dry ginger, and haritaki, mixed with ghee and honey. When regularly taken in the morning, either with milk or water, it can alleviate ailments such as kamsahara, kamalaphala, arsha, vatarakta, pittadosha, and gulma. It can also pacify vatadosha, detoxify the body, and aid digestion. Moreover, this powder, golden in color and made from pure ingredients, can eliminate impurities, enhance strength, and bring mental tranquility. It is recommended to consume it at night as well, mixed with ghee and honey prepared from cow's milk."

sloka: guḍanāgaramaṇḍūratilāṃśānmānataḥ samān|  pippalīdviguṇāṃ kuryādguṭikāṃ pāṇḍurogiṇe||72||  tryūṣaṇaṃ triphalā mustaṃ viḍaṅgaṃ cavyacitrakau|  dārvītvaṅmākṣiko dhāturgranthikaṃ devadāru ca||73||  etān dvipalikānbhāgāṃścūrṇaṃ kuryāt pṛthak pṛthak|  maṇḍūraṃ dviguṇaṃ cūrṇācchuddhamañjanasannibham||74||  gomūtre'ṣṭaguṇe paktvā tasmiṃstat prakṣipettataḥ|  udumbarasamānkṛtvā vaṭakāṃstān yathāgni nā||75||  upayuñjīta takreṇa sātmyaṃ jīrṇe ca bhojanam|  maṇḍūravaṭakā hyete prāṇadāḥ pāṇḍurogiṇām||76||  kuṣṭhānyajīrṇakaṃ śothamūrustambhaṃ kaphāmayān|  arśāṃsi kāmalāṃ mehaṃ plīhānaṃ śamayanti ca||77||  iti maṇḍūravaṭakāḥ|
translation: The three constituents of triushana, two parts each of triphala, musta, and vidaya, together with citraka, making a total of nine parts, should be separately reduced to fine powder and mixed with sarpiṣa. This mixture should be consumed by a fair-skinned person suffering from ailments like kuṣṭha, arśa, kāmala, apahat, and vāyasam, as instructed by Atreya.

sloka: tāpyādrijaturūpyāyomalāḥ pañcapalāḥ pṛthak|  citrakatriphalāvyoṣaviḍaṅgaiḥ palikaiḥ saha||78||  śarkarāṣṭapalonmiśrāścūrṇitā madhunā''plutāḥ|  abhyasyāstvakṣamātrā hi jīrṇe hitamitāśinā||79||  kulatthakākamācyādikapotaparihāriṇā|80|
translation: Prepare a mixture of tāpyā, adri, jatu, rūpya, aya, malāḥ, pañca, and palāḥ, each one-fifth of the total, together with citraka, triphala, āvyā, ūṣa, viḍaṅgaiḥ, and palikaiḥ. Also mix in śarkarā, āṣṭapalona, miśrā, cūrṇitā_madhunā''plutāḥ. Apply this mixture to tvak in a measure of mātrāḥ when jīrṇe and tamita-āśinā. Prepare a mixture of kulattha, kākam, ācya, ādika, pā, and pari-hāriṇā, making it pṛthak and samāna. Add this mixture in aṣṭa guṇe after cooking it until śuddha like añjana. Perform umabharaṇa with vaṭakān, yathā agni, and then, without attachment, offer food to prāṇa dāḥ rogiṇām for healing kuṣṭha, āmayaān, arśāṃsi, kāmalām meham, plīhā, ānam śamayanti.

sloka: triphalāyāstrayo bhāgāstrayastrikaṭukasya ca||80||  bhāgaścitrakamūlasya viḍaṅgānāṃ tathaiva ca|  pañcāśmajatuno bhāgāstathā rūpyamalasya ca||81||  mākṣikasya ca śuddhasya lauhasya rajasastathā|  aṣṭau bhāgāḥ sitāyāśca tatsarvaṃ sūkṣmacūrṇitam||82||  mākṣikeṇāplutaṃ sthāpyamāyase bhājane śubhe|  udumbarasamāṃ mātrāṃ tataḥ khādedyathāgni nā||83||  dine dine prayuñjīta jīrṇe bhojyaṃ yathepsitam|  varjayitvā kulatthāni kākamācīṃ kapotakam||84|| yogarāja iti khyāto yogo'yamamṛtopamaḥ|  rasāyanamidaṃ śreṣṭhaṃ sarvarogaharaṃ śivam||85||  pāṇḍurogaṃ viṣaṃ kāsaṃ yakṣmāṇaṃ viṣamajvaram|  kuṣṭhānyajīrṇakaṃ mehaṃ śoṣaṃ śvāsamarocakam||86||  viśeṣāddhantyapasmāraṃ kāmalāṃ gudajāni ca|  iti yogarājaḥ|
translation: Of the three portions to be apportioned from triphala, these should be combined with an equal measure of citrakamula's parts, along with five kinds of ashes, pure copper, eight parts of sita, and a special substance effective against visamajwaram. This should be made into a fine powder, after eliminating impurities. This Yogaraja, likened to amrita, is the foremost rejuvenator, beneficial in curing various diseases such as pandu-roga, poison, kasa, yakshman, visamajwaram, kushta, jirnaka meha, sosha, shwasa-marocakam, and others. It must be applied daily in a quantity similar to that of a small lily on the clean skin, avoiding contact with kulatha, kaka, locusts, and other impurities.

sloka: kauṭajatriphalānimbapaṭolaghananāgaraiḥ||87||  bhāvitāni daśāhāni rasairdvitriguṇāni vā|  śilājatupalānyaṣṭau tāvatī sitaśarkarā||88|| tvakkṣīrī pippalī dhātrī karkaṭākhyā palonmitā|  nidigdhyāḥ phalamūlābhyāṃ palaṃ yuktyā trigandhakam|  cūrṇitaṃ madhunaḥ kuryāt tripalenākṣikān guḍān|  dāḍimāmbupayaḥpakṣirasatoyasurāsavān||90||  tān bhakṣayitvā'nupibenniranno bhukta eva vā|  pāṇḍukuṣṭhajvaraplīhatamakārśobhagandarān||91||  pūtihṛcchukramūtrāgnidoṣaśoṣagarodarān [1] |  kāsāsṛgdarapittāsṛkśothagulmagalāmayān||92||  te ca sarvavraṇān hanyuḥ sarvarogaharāḥ śivāḥ|  iti śilājatuvaṭakāḥ|
translation: "The three parts of bitter gourd, citraka, and other medicinal plants, when made into a concoction with a mixture of various tastes and threefold qualities by experts, become, when consumed or even taken in smaller amounts, effective in eliminating all types of impurities, diseases, and evil bodily humors, thus ensuring purity and health."

sloka: punarnavā trivṛdvyoṣaviḍaṅgaṃ dāru citrakam||93||  kuṣṭhaṃ haridre triphalā dantī cavyaṃ kaliṅgakāḥ|  pippalī [2] pippalīmūlaṃ mustaṃ ceti palonmitam||94||  maṇḍūraṃ dviguṇaṃ cūrṇādgomūtre dvyāḍhake pacet|  kolavadguṭikāḥ kṛtvā takreṇāloḍya nā pibet||95||  tāḥ pāṇḍurogān plīhānamarśāṃsi viṣamajvaram|  śvayathuṃ grahaṇīdoṣaṃ hanyuḥ kuṣṭhaṃ krimīṃstathā||96||  iti punarnavāmaṇḍūram|
translation: The herbal mixture called "punarnava" is to be prepared using the following components in prescribed quantities: three measures of "trivṛt," one measure of a plant known as "vyosa" to be processed, one measure each of "citraka" wood and "dāru" wood, two measures of "kuṣṭha" from the "haridrā" region, three measures of "triphalā," one measure of "dantī," one measure of "cavya" from "kaliṅgakā," two measures each of "pippalī" and its roots, one measure of "musta," all combined together. Then, after preparing "maṇḍūra" with double the quantity of "cūrṇa" and adding "gomūtra" in two parts, cook it at the specified location. Having made "kolavadguṭikā," do not drink this concoction without filtering it through a strainer. This preparation will help alleviate "pāṇḍu" diseases, "plīhā" ailments, "viṣama" fevers, "śvayathuṃ," "grahaṇīdoṣa," as well as "kuṣṭha" and "krimī" infections. Thus, this is the recipe for "punarnavāmaṇḍūra."

sloka: dārvītvak triphalā vyoṣaṃ viḍaṅgamayaso rajaḥ|  madhusarpiryutaṃ lihyāt kāmalāpāṇḍurogavān||97||  tulyā ayorajaḥpathyāharidrāḥ kṣaudrasarpiṣā|  cūrṇitāḥ kāmalī lihyādguḍakṣaudreṇa vā'bhayāḥ||98||  triphalā dve haridre ca kaṭurohiṇyayorajaḥ|  cūrṇitaṃ kṣaudrasarpirbhyāṃ sa lehaḥ kāmalāpahaḥ||99||
translation: Let it not be that one should consume, mixed together with a small amount of water, the powder of three types of vegetables, including triphala, black gram, and wood, and triphala combined with two varieties of haridra and four types of spices. If one consumes this mixture, it will destroy diseases such as leprosy, worms, and other physical ailments. Moreover, this mixture, when consumed in appropriate quantities, acts as a remedy for eliminating desires for those afflicted by impurities of the mind and body. However, one should not drink large amounts of water after ingesting it.

sloka: dvipalāṃśāṃ tugākṣīrīṃ nāgaraṃ madhuyaṣṭikām|  prāsthikīṃ pippalīṃ drākṣāṃ śarkarārdhatulāṃ śubhām||100||  dhātrīphalarasadroṇe cūrṇitaṃ lehavat pacet|  śītaṃ madhuprasthayutaṃ lihyāt pāṇitalaṃ tataḥ||101||  hantyeṣa kāmalāṃ pittaṃ pāṇḍuṃ kāsaṃ halīmakam|  iti dhātryavalehaḥ|
translation: Prepared from the bark of the dipala tree, triplephala, vidanga, iron, salt, honey, and ghee, mixed with equal parts of clarified butter and powdered haridra, and further combined with kashmarya, kasha, and halimaka, this medicinal paste is beneficial for treating skin diseases, Pitta, and Kapha. It also alleviates symptoms caused by poison. This is called Dhatryavaleha.

sloka: tryūṣaṇaṃ triphalā cavyaṃ citrako devadāru ca||102||  viḍaṅgānyatha mustaṃ ca vatsakaṃ ceti cūrṇayet|  maṇḍūratulyaṃ taccūrṇaṃ gomūtre'ṣṭaguṇe pacet||103||  śanaiḥ siddhāstathā śītāḥ kāryāḥ karṣasamā guḍāḥ|  yathāgni bhakṣaṇīyāste plīhapāṇḍvāmayāpahāḥ||104|| grahaṇyarśonudaścaiva takravāṭyāśinaḥ smṛtāḥ|  iti maṇḍūravaṭakāḥ|
translation: Prepare a mixture, in equal parts, of tryūṣaṇa (three myrobalans), triphalā, cavya, citraka, and devadāru; then grind musta, vatsaka, and these ingredients together; add

sloka: mañjiṣṭhā rajanī drākṣā balāmūlānyayorajaḥ||105||  lodhraṃ caiteṣu gauḍaḥ syādariṣṭaḥ pāṇḍurogiṇām|  iti gauḍo'riṣṭaḥ|
translation: "For the new moon night known as Mañjiṣṭhā, take equal parts of the ripe fruits from Cavya, Citraka, and Devadaru trees, along with crushed mustard seeds and Vatsaka plant. Add grinded Lodhrā, red sandalwood, and karkatasringi powder in equal amounts. Mix this with cow's urine and milk, gradually adding eight portions of water, and prepare a paste. Once settled and cooled, it can be consumed, which helps in eliminating poison, bile disorders, diseases caused by planetary influences and seasonal changes. It also cures piles and obesity. Those who consume it regularly will experience benefits similar to consuming agni, in terms of digestion and metabolism."

sloka: bījakātṣoḍaśapalaṃ triphalāyāśca viṃśatiḥ||106||  drākṣāyāḥ pañca lākṣāyāḥ sapta droṇe jalasya tat|  sādhyaṃ pādāvaśeṣe tu pūtaśeṣe samāvapet||107||  śarkarāyāstulāṃ prasthaṃ mākṣikasya ca kārṣikam|  vyoṣaṃ vyāghranakhośīraṃ kramukaṃ sailavālukam||108||  madhukaṃ kuṣṭhamityetaccūrṇitaṃ ghṛtabhājane|  yaveṣu daśarātraṃ tadgrīṣme dviḥ śiśire sthitam||109||  pibettadgrahaṇīpāṇḍurogārśaḥśothagulmanut|  mūtrakṛcchrāśmarīmehakāmalāsannipātajit||110||  bījakāriṣṭa ityeṣa ātreyeṇa prakīrtitaḥ|  iti bījakāriṣṭaḥ|
translation: In the "Ātreyabrahmavaiptara-brāhmaṇa" of the Atharvaveda, this concoction known as "bījakāriṣṭa" is described: it is prepared from manjishtha (Rubia cordifolia) and draksha (Vitis vinifera), and used for treating a patient named Pāṇḍu's various ailments such as consumption, wasting, jaundice, and skin diseases, among others.

sloka: dhātrīphalasahasre dve pīḍayitvā rasaṃ tu tam||111||  kṣaudrāṣṭāṃśena saṃyuktaṃ kṛṣṇārdhakuḍavena ca|  śarkarārdhatulonmiśraṃ pakṣaṃ snigdhaghaṭe sthitam||112||  prapibenmātrayā prātarjīrṇe hitamitāśanaḥ|  kāmalāpāṇḍuhṛdrogavātāsṛgviṣamajvarān||113|| kāsahikkāruciśvāsāṃścaiṣo'riṣṭaḥ praṇāśayet|  iti dhātryariṣṭaḥ
translation: To prepare the *dhātryariṣṭa*, crush in a mortar sixteen *dhātrī* fruits and two each of *triphalā*, *drākṣā*, *lākṣā*, and seven *droṇas* of jala's sādhyapada remainder. After purifying, mix this with an equal amount of sugar, a quarter of a *tulā* of rock salt, usīra, vyāghranakha, kramukam, elavālu, kam, madhukam, and kuṣṭham, kept in a ghṛta-bhājana for ten nights during grīṣma and as a concoction during śiśira. In the morning, consume it after straining, along with a drink made from the urine of a cow that has overcome the bījaka-ariṣṭa. This is called the ātreyena-prakīrtita *dhātryariṣṭa*, which destroys *kāmalā-sannipāta*, jit, and other afflictions such as aśmarī, meha, kṛcchra, and mūtra.

sloka: sthirādibhiḥ śṛtaṃ toyaṃ pānāhāre praśasyate||114||  pāṇḍūnāṃ kāmalārtānāṃ mṛdvīkāmalakīrasaḥ|115|
translation: In the morning, the mixture of equal parts sugarcane juice and jaggery, processed through a cloth, and combined with an extract from two thousand Dhatri tree fruits, consumed in moderation, is praised as a remedy for thirst, dysuria, cough, loss of appetite, irregular fever, hiccups, and other ailments in those affected by Pandu disorders, being strained and prepared with firmness, stability, and other virtues.

sloka: pāṇḍurogapraśāntyarthamiti proktaṃ maharṣiṇā||115||  vikalpyametadbhiṣajā pṛthagdoṣabalaṃ prati|  vātike snehabhūyiṣṭhaṃ paittike tiktaśītalam||116||  ślaiṣmike kaṭutiktoṣṇaṃ [1]  vimiśraṃ sānnipātike|117|
translation: For the benefit of fair-skinned people, who are troubled by various ailments, the Maharishi has stated that herbs such as śṛtam and toyam, when used in food, will bring peace to those suffering from kāmala and other diseases due to their soothing, cool, and agreeable tastes, similar to āmalakī. Such herbs, each having distinct properties, should be mixed together for maximum benefit in specific situations.

sloka: nipātayeccharīrāttu mṛttikāṃ bhakṣitāṃ bhiṣak||117||  yuktijñaḥ śodhanaistīkṣṇaiḥ prasamīkṣya balābalam|  śuddhakāyasya sarpīṃṣi balādhānāni yojayet||118||  vyoṣaṃ bilvaṃ haridre dve triphalā dve punarnave|  mustānyayorajaḥ pāṭhā viḍaṅgaṃ devadāru ca||119||  vṛścikālī ca bhārgī ca sakṣīraistaiḥ [1] samairghṛtam|  sādhayitvā pibedyuktyā naro mṛddoṣapīḍitaḥ||120||  tadvat keśarayaṣṭyāhvapippalīkṣāraśādvalaiḥ|  mṛdbhakṣaṇādāturasya laulyādavinivartinaḥ||121||  dveṣyārthaṃ bhāvitāṃ kāmaṃ dadyāttaddoṣanāśanaiḥ|  viṅgailātiviṣayā nimbapatreṇa pāṭhayā||122||  vārtākaiḥ kaṭurohiṇyā kauṭajairmūrvayā'pi vā|123|
translation: In order to calm disorders affecting the body and presenting in a white color, the great sage has stated that this constitutes the specific duty of the physician to be considered separately. The physician, having discerned the strength and weakness of each dosha (Vata, Pitta, Kapha) through sharpened insight gained through skillful means, should administer purifying treatments to the person with a pure body. This should be done using barley, bilva, haritaki, two types of triphala, purnarnava, musta, kasha, vinegar, patha, vidinga, devadaru, vrischikaali, bhargi, and sakshiri, mixed together with ghee, after preparing it according to the prescribed method. Similarly, one should treat the patient's ailments by gradually increasing the quantity of easily digestible foods, such as kesharaja, arista, hvapippali, ksheera, sharkara, vala, and madhurika. To eliminate hatred and fulfill beneficial desires, one should use nimba leaves prepared in a specific way or through kaṭu-ohinya, kautaja, mūrvya, etc.

sloka: yathādoṣaṃ prakurvīta bhaiṣajyaṃ pāṇḍurogiṇām||123||  kriyāviśeṣa eṣo'sya mato hetuviśeṣataḥ|124|
translation: The wise physician should apply the remedy to alleviate the specific defects in the patient, considering the special causes; he should administer using fresh, pure leaves.

sloka: tilapiṣṭanibhaṃ yastu varcaḥ sṛjati kāmalī||124|| śleṣmaṇā ruddhamārgaṃ tat pittaṃ kaphaharairjayet|  rūkṣaśītagurusvāduvyāyāmairveganigrahaiḥ||125||  kaphasammūrcchito vāyuḥ sthānāt pittaṃ kṣipedbalī|  hāridranetramūtratvak śvetavarcāstadā naraḥ||126||  bhavet sāṭopaviṣṭambho guruṇā hṛdayena ca|  daurbalyālpāgnipārśvārtihikkāśvāsārucijvaraiḥ||127||  krameṇālpe'nusajyeta [1] pitte śākhāsamāśrite|128|
translation:
Just as a remedy is applied to counteract a particular ailment in a patient suffering from white leprosy, so too should treatment be specifically adapted to counteract the dosha as follows:

For kapha dosha (one of the three bodily humors, characterized by heaviness), apply:
- Astringent taste
- Lightness in diet
- Exercise
- Restraint in eating

If vayu dosha is aggravated and located in its normal site, counteract it with:
- Strengthening treatment
- Heavy diet
- A calm environment

Progressively and gradually apply these treatments to restore balance to the doshas.

sloka: barhitittiridakṣāṇāṃ rūkṣāmlaiḥ kaṭukai rasaiḥ||128||  śuṣkamūlakakaulatthairyūṣaiścānnāni bhojayet|  mātuluṅgarasaṃ kṣaudrapippalīmaricānvitam||129||  sanāgaraṃ pibet pittaṃ tathā'syaiti svamāśayam|130|
translation: One who partakes of sesame seeds, finely ground and mixed with pungent, astringent flavors, can clear blocked channels caused by mucus, and alleviate phlegm, bile, and wind. They become a person of strength. Drinking salty water can help pacify bile, settling any heart disturbance, and restoring weakened appetite due to thinness, cough, fever, breathlessness, fatigue, or hiccups.

sloka: kaṭutīkṣṇoṣṇalavaṇairbhṛśāmlaiścāpyupakramaḥ||130||  āpittarāgācchakṛto [1] vāyoścāpraśamādbhavet|  svasthānamāgate pitte purīṣe pittarañjite||131||  nivṛttopadravasya syāt pūrvaḥ kāmaliko vidhiḥ|132|
translation: For an individual afflicted by ailments arising from pungent, bitter, hot, and salty foods, such as the hardened bile of peacocks' relatives, when offered a mixture of barley powder, long pepper, black pepper, dried ginger, pippali, and maricha with warm water, once digested, it will tranquilize his own bodily humors, thereby putting an end to prior desire-driven activities.

sloka: yadā tu pāṇḍorvarṇaḥ syāddharitaśyāvapītakaḥ||132||  balotsāhakṣayastandrā mandrāgnitvaṃ mṛdujvaraḥ|  strīṣvaharṣo'ṅgamardaśca śvāsastṛṣṇā'rucirbhramaḥ||133||  halīmakaṃ tadā tasya vidyādanilapittataḥ|134|
translation: When Pāṇḍu's complexion becomes free from harshness, piercing quality, heat, saltiness, excessive sourness, pallor, and early signs of illness, and there is a sign of natural recovery from the ailment, then that halīmaka condition, caused by the digestion process in the stomach, emerges.

sloka: guḍūcīsvarasakṣīrasādhitaṃ māhiṣaṃ ghṛtam||134||  sa pibettrivṛtāṃ snigdho rasenāmalakasya tu|  virikto madhuraprāyaṃ bhajet pittānilāpaham||135||  drākṣālehaṃ ca pūrvoktaṃ sarpīṃṣi madhurāṇi ca|  yāpanān kṣīrabastīṃśca śīlayetsānuvāsanān||136||  mārdvīkāriṣṭayogāṃśca pibedyuktyā'gnivṛddhaye|  kāsikaṃ cābhayālehaṃ pippalīṃ madhukaṃ balām||137||  payasā ca prayuñjīta yathādoṣaṃ yathābalam|138|
translation: When the complexion of Pandu's son turns pale, becomes yellowish, and loses strength, his enthusiasm wanes and digestive fire decreases, mild fever develops, appetite diminishes, and unguided touch is perceived in his body, then one should understand that his learning is impaired due to an increase in phlegm and bile. In such a situation, ghee prepared with guducí, svara, sakṣīra, sādhita, māhiṣa should be administered, as it alleviates increased phlegm and bile, eliminating symptoms of impaired learning. Similarly, when there is an increase in air and bile, one should offer kāsi, ābhayā, leha, pippalī, madhuka, and balā, and use payas to counteract the specific dosa based on one's strength.

sloka: tatra ślokau  pāṇḍoḥ pañcavidhasyoktaṃ hetulakṣaṇabheṣajam||138||  kāmalā dvividhā teṣāṃ sādhyāsādhyatvameva ca|  teṣāṃ vikalpo yaścānyo mahāvyādhirhalīmakaḥ|  tasya coktaṃ samāsena vyañjanaṃ sacikitsitam||139||
translation: In the description of Pāṇḍu's fivefold characteristics, a remedy for the symptoms is mentioned. There are two kinds of desires among them: achievable and unachievable, along with their respective fulfillment. Also mentioned is another great or minor ailment, accompanied by a concise explanation and proper treatment. Earlier, it was advised to use ghṛita (ghee) prepared from maHIṣa (buffalo), sarpis (clarified butter), and madhura (sweet) substances such as drākṣā (grapes), amalaka (Indian gooseberry), kasa, pippali, madhu (honey), milk, and payasam. Apply these wisely to enhance agni (digestive fire), strength, and to pacify vata, pitta, and kapha doshas. Additionally, one should eliminate the causes of impurities in srotas (body channels) through virecana (purgation), svedana (sudation), basti (enema), and udvartana (massage with herbal powders). Also, eliminate impurities from the physical body and mind by adopting a proper regimen, including wholesome diet, lifestyle, and habits.

sloka: ityagniveśakṛte tantre'prāpte dṛḍhabalasampūrite cikitsāsthāne  pāṇḍurogacikitsitaṃ nāma ṣoḍaśo'dhyāyaḥ||140||
translation: In the section of the scripture dealing with fire sacrifice, upon the acquisition of a powerful and stable treatment, the "pāṇḍurogacikitsitam" (fifteen methods for treating pandu disease), referred to as the "ṣoḍaśo'dhyāyaḥ" (sixteen chapters; a specific text), is described. This treatise, consisting of two categories, details their causes, symptoms, and medicines, and specifically excludes other severe diseases such as halīmaka.
